17-Hydroxyprogesterone.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, and monitor treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH); sometimes to help rule out other conditions with similar symptoms
17-Hydroxyprogesterone.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine newborn screen when an infant's sex is not obvious (ambiguous genitalia); when a female has increased growth of facial and body hair (hirsutism) or other symptoms that could be related to elevated male sex hormones; when a male child has premature sexual development; periodically to monitor CAH treatment
17-Hydroxyprogesterone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or blood from a heelstick for an infant
17-Hydroxyprogesterone.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but an early morning collection may be requested; it may also be requested that the blood sample be collected at a specific time during a woman's menstrual cycle. The test should not be ordered if the patient is taking steroids.

17-OH Progesterone.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, and monitor treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH); sometimes to help rule out other conditions with similar symptoms
17-OH Progesterone.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine newborn screen when an infant's sex is not obvious (ambiguous genitalia); when a female has increased growth of facial and body hair (hirsutism) or other symptoms that could be related to elevated male sex hormones; when a male child has premature sexual development; periodically to monitor CAH treatment
17-OH Progesterone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or blood from a heelstick for an infant
17-OH Progesterone.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but an early morning collection may be requested; it may also be requested that the blood sample be collected at a specific time during a woman's menstrual cycle. The test should not be ordered if the patient is taking steroids.

17-OHP.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, and monitor treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH); sometimes to help rule out other conditions with similar symptoms
17-OHP.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine newborn screen when an infant's sex is not obvious (ambiguous genitalia); when a female has increased growth of facial and body hair (hirsutism) or other symptoms that could be related to elevated male sex hormones; when a male child has premature sexual development; periodically to monitor CAH treatment
17-OHP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or blood from a heelstick for an infant
17-OHP.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but an early morning collection may be requested; it may also be requested that the blood sample be collected at a specific time during a woman's menstrual cycle. The test should not be ordered if the patient is taking steroids.

24-Hour Urine Protein.Why Get Tested?: To screen for excess protein in the urine, to help evaluate and monitor kidney function, and to detect kidney damage
24-Hour Urine Protein.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine physical, as a follow-up to a previous positive urine protein test, or when you have a disorder or disease that affects the kidney
24-Hour Urine Protein.Sample Required?: A single urine sample collected at any time (random) or 24-hour urine sample; occasionally, a split 24-hour sample, with the night collection (11pm to 7am) separated from the day collection (7am to 11pm). Often, a blood sample may also be taken to measure your creatinine and serum protein levels, especially when a 24-hour urine has been ordered.

25-hydroxyvitamin D; 1,25 dihydroxyvitam.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have a vitamin D deficiency; if you are receiving vitamin D supplementation, to determine if it is adequate
25-hydroxyvitamin D; 1,25 dihydroxyvitam.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal calcium, phosphorus, and/or parathyroid hormone level; when you have evidence of bone disease or bone weakness; when you are at high risk of deficiency or a healthcare practitioner suspects that you might have a vitamin D deficiency; prior to starting drug treatment for osteoporosis; periodically to monitor treatment of vitamin D deficiency
25-hydroxyvitamin D; 1,25 dihydroxyvitam.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

3-day Measles.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sufficient rubella antibodies to protect you from the rubella virus; to verify a past infection or detect a recent infection
3-day Measles.When To Get Tested?: Prior to or at the beginning of a pregnancy to verify immunity; when a pregnant woman has symptoms of rubella, such as fever and rash; when a newborn shows signs of abnormal development or birth defects that may be caused by an in utero infection; whenever there is need to verify a recent rubella infection or to verify immunity
3-day Measles.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm of an adult or blood drawn from a heelprick or from the umbilical cord of a newborn

3-ANCA.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
3-ANCA.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
3-ANCA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

4-marker Screen.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
4-marker Screen.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
4-marker Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

4q12 (CHIC2) deletion.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of hypereosinophilia (HE), a condition with persistent increase in the number of eosinophils, a specific type of white blood cell, or hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES), which is HE with associated tissue or organ damage; to help determine if someone with HE or HES can be treated with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) such as imatinib
4q12 (CHIC2) deletion.When To Get Tested?: After complete blood counts (CBC) indicate that you have persistently elevated eosinophils and your health practitioner has ruled out other causes such as allergies, parasitic infection, or medication; at regular intervals when you are being treated for HE or HES with imatinib
4q12 (CHIC2) deletion.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

5-HIAA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor treatment for a carcinoid tumor that produces serotonin
5-HIAA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggestive of a carcinoid tumor, such as flushing, diarrhea, and/or wheezing; at intervals following treatment
5-HIAA.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; rarely, a random urine sample
5-HIAA.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to avoid certain foods and medications prior to this test.

5-hydroxyindoleacetic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor treatment for a carcinoid tumor that produces serotonin
5-hydroxyindoleacetic Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggestive of a carcinoid tumor, such as flushing, diarrhea, and/or wheezing; at intervals following treatment
5-hydroxyindoleacetic Acid.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; rarely, a random urine sample
5-hydroxyindoleacetic Acid.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to avoid certain foods and medications prior to this test.

5-Hydroxytryptamine.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a carcinoid tumor that produces serotonin
5-Hydroxytryptamine.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggestive of a carcinoid tumor, such as flushing, diarrhea, and/or wheezing
5-Hydroxytryptamine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

5-HT.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a carcinoid tumor that produces serotonin
5-HT.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggestive of a carcinoid tumor, such as flushing, diarrhea, and/or wheezing
5-HT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

72 Hour Fecal Fat.Why Get Tested?: To detect and measure excess fat in the stool; to help diagnose conditions causing malabsorption
72 Hour Fecal Fat.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
72 Hour Fecal Fat.Sample Required?: A random stool collection; sometimes a 72-hour stool collection
72 Hour Fecal Fat.Test Preparation Needed?: For a 72-hour stool collection, follow your healthcare practitioner's instructions; this may include consuming 50-150 grams of fat a day in your diet for 2-3 days prior to and during the stool collection period.

A/G Ratio.Why Get Tested?: As part of a general health checkup, to determine your nutritional status or to screen for and help diagnose certain liver and kidney disorders as well as other diseases
A/G Ratio.When To Get Tested?: When you have a routine physical exam or when you experience unexpected weight loss or fatigue, or when a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver or kidney disorder
A/G Ratio.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick (adults and children) or heelstick (newborns)

A1AT.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of early onset emphysema and/or liver dysfunction; to establish the risk of emphysema and/or liver disease due to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency and determine the likelihood that children might inherit the risk
A1AT.When To Get Tested?: When your infant or young child show signs of liver disease; when you develop emphysema before age 40; when you have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or unexplained liver disease at any age; when you have a close relative with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
A1AT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

A1c.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you are at an increased risk of developing diabetes; to help diagnose diabetes and prediabetes; to monitor diabetes and to aid in treatment decisions
A1c.When To Get Tested?: As part of a health checkup or when you have risk factors for or symptoms of diabetes; after first diagnosis with diabetes, every 3-4 months or about 120 days to ensure that your glycemic goals are met and/or maintained or when your therapy plan has changed
A1c.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein or a drop of blood is taken from a finger by pricking it with a small, pointed lancet.

AAT.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of early onset emphysema and/or liver dysfunction; to establish the risk of emphysema and/or liver disease due to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency and determine the likelihood that children might inherit the risk
AAT.When To Get Tested?: When your infant or young child show signs of liver disease; when you develop emphysema before age 40; when you have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or unexplained liver disease at any age; when you have a close relative with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
AAT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ABGs.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate lung function by measuring blood pH, oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2); to monitor treatment for lung diseases; to detect an acid-base imbalance in your blood, which may indicate a respiratory, metabolic, or kidney disorder; to evaluate the effectiveness of oxygen therapy
ABGs.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a respiratory problem such as difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, or rapid breathing; when you are being treated for a lung disease; when an acid-base imbalance is suspected; periodically when you have a condition that causes an acute or chronic oxygen shortage and you are on oxygen therapy; during certain surgeries to monitor your blood's O2 and CO2 levels
ABGs.Sample Required?: Most often a blood sample collected from an artery, usually the radial artery in your wrist; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; capillary blood from a heelstick may be used for babies.
ABGs.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, none; however, if you are on oxygen therapy, the O2 may either be turned off for 20 to 30 minutes before the collection for a "Room Air" test. If this cannot be tolerated, or if your healthcare practitioner wants to check your oxygen levels with the O2 on, the amount of oxygen being delivered will be recorded.

ABO Group and Rh Type.Why Get Tested?: To determine your ABO blood group and Rh type
ABO Group and Rh Type.When To Get Tested?: When you need a transfusion of blood or blood components; when you donate blood at a collection facility or donate an organ, tissue, or bone marrow for transplantation; before or during a woman's pregnancy to determine the risk of Rh incompatibility with the fetus
ABO Group and Rh Type.Sample Required?: A sample of blood is drawn from a vein or from the tip of the finger (fingerstick). In newborns, blood from the umbilical cord or a small amount of blood from a heelstick may be used for testing.

ACA.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of anticentromere antibodies; to help diagnose limited cutaneous scleroderma
ACA.When To Get Tested?: When you have one or more symptoms that suggest CREST syndrome
ACA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Acetaminophen.Why Get Tested?: To determine if an overdose has occurred; to determine risk of liver damage and to help determine if treatment with an antidote is required
Acetaminophen.When To Get Tested?: When it is suspected that a person has ingested an overdose of acetaminophen or has signs and symptoms of toxicity, such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain; when following a patient, every 4 to 6 hours after an overdose of the drug is ingested
Acetaminophen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm

Acetoacetate.Why Get Tested?: To determine the amount of ketones (ketone bodies, acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood to help diagnose a life-threatening problem called diabetic ketoacidosis
Acetoacetate.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with ketoacidosis, such as increased urination, excessive thirst, dehydration, rapid breathing, and shortness of breath
Acetoacetate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

Acetoacetic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To determine the amount of ketones (ketone bodies, acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood to help diagnose a life-threatening problem called diabetic ketoacidosis
Acetoacetic Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with ketoacidosis, such as increased urination, excessive thirst, dehydration, rapid breathing, and shortness of breath
Acetoacetic Acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

Acetone.Why Get Tested?: To determine the amount of ketones (ketone bodies, acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood to help diagnose a life-threatening problem called diabetic ketoacidosis
Acetone.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with ketoacidosis, such as increased urination, excessive thirst, dehydration, rapid breathing, and shortness of breath
Acetone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

Acetylcholine Receptor (AChR) Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG) and to distinguish between MG and other conditions with similar symptoms
Acetylcholine Receptor (AChR) Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest MG, such as a drooping eyelid, double vision, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and/or weakness in specific muscles
Acetylcholine Receptor (AChR) Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Acetylcholine Receptor Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG) and to distinguish between MG and other conditions with similar symptoms
Acetylcholine Receptor Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest MG, such as a drooping eyelid, double vision, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and/or weakness in specific muscles
Acetylcholine Receptor Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Acetylcholine Receptor Binding Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG) and to distinguish between MG and other conditions with similar symptoms
Acetylcholine Receptor Binding Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest MG, such as a drooping eyelid, double vision, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and/or weakness in specific muscles
Acetylcholine Receptor Binding Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Acetylcholine Receptor Blocking Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG) and to distinguish between MG and other conditions with similar symptoms
Acetylcholine Receptor Blocking Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest MG, such as a drooping eyelid, double vision, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and/or weakness in specific muscles
Acetylcholine Receptor Blocking Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Acetylcholine Receptor Modulating Antibo.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG) and to distinguish between MG and other conditions with similar symptoms
Acetylcholine Receptor Modulating Antibo.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest MG, such as a drooping eyelid, double vision, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and/or weakness in specific muscles
Acetylcholine Receptor Modulating Antibo.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Acetylsalicylic acid.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
Acetylsalicylic acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
Acetylsalicylic acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
Acetylsalicylic acid.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

AChE.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
AChE.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
AChE.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

AChR Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG) and to distinguish between MG and other conditions with similar symptoms
AChR Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest MG, such as a drooping eyelid, double vision, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and/or weakness in specific muscles
AChR Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Acid-Fast Bacillus (AFB) Testing.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose tuberculosis (TB) and infections caused by other Mycobacterium species, which are known as acid-fast bacilli (AFB), in people at risk of developing mycobacterial infections; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Acid-Fast Bacillus (AFB) Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a lung infection, such as a chronic cough, weight loss, fever, chills, and weakness, that may be due to TB or a nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection; when you have a positive IGRA blood test or Tuberculin skin test (TST) and you are in a high-risk group for progressing to active TB; when you have a skin or other body site infection that may be due to mycobacteria; when you are undergoing treatment for TB
Acid-Fast Bacillus (AFB) Testing.Sample Required?: For suspected cases of tuberculosis lung infections, usually three sputum samples are collected early in the morning on different days. If you are unable to produce sputum, a bronchoscope may be used to collect fluid during a procedure called a bronchoscopy. In children, gastric washings/aspirates may be collected. Depending on symptoms, urine, an aspirate from the site of suspected infection, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), other body fluids, or biopsied tissue samples may be collected for AFB testing.

Acid-Fast Bacillus Smear and Culture and.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose tuberculosis (TB) and infections caused by other Mycobacterium species, which are known as acid-fast bacilli (AFB), in people at risk of developing mycobacterial infections; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Acid-Fast Bacillus Smear and Culture and.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a lung infection, such as a chronic cough, weight loss, fever, chills, and weakness, that may be due to TB or a nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection; when you have a positive IGRA blood test or Tuberculin skin test (TST) and you are in a high-risk group for progressing to active TB; when you have a skin or other body site infection that may be due to mycobacteria; when you are undergoing treatment for TB
Acid-Fast Bacillus Smear and Culture and.Sample Required?: For suspected cases of tuberculosis lung infections, usually three sputum samples are collected early in the morning on different days. If you are unable to produce sputum, a bronchoscope may be used to collect fluid during a procedure called a bronchoscopy. In children, gastric washings/aspirates may be collected. Depending on symptoms, urine, an aspirate from the site of suspected infection, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), other body fluids, or biopsied tissue samples may be collected for AFB testing.

aCL Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate inappropriate blood clot formation, to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriage, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome or sometimes other autoimmune diseases
aCL Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have had one or more unexplained blood clots (thrombotic episodes) in a vein or artery; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters; when you have symptoms consistent with an autoimmune disease
aCL Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ACPA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and differentiate it from other types of arthritis; to help evaluate the prognosis of a person with RA
ACPA.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner suspects RA in someone who has joint inflammation with symptoms that suggest but do not yet meet the criteria of RA
ACPA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ACR.Why Get Tested?: To detect early kidney disease in those with diabetes or other risk factors, such as high blood pressure (hypertension)
ACR.When To Get Tested?: Annually after a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes; annually 5 years after diagnosis of type 1 diabetes
ACR.Sample Required?: A random, timed, overnight, or 24-hour urine sample

ACT.Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment with heparin or other blood-thinning medications (anticoagulants) when undergoing heart bypass surgery, coronary angioplasty, or dialysis
ACT.When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving high doses of heparin to prevent clotting during surgical procedures such as a heart bypass; when heparin levels are too high to allow monitoring with a PTT and/or when a rapid result is necessary to monitor treatment
ACT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ACTA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
ACTA.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
ACTA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ACTH Stimulation Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose Cushing syndrome or primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease); to detect conditions affecting the pituitary or adrenal glands
ACTH Stimulation Test.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects excess or deficient cortisol production
ACTH Stimulation Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a saliva sample may be used
ACTH Stimulation Test.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be required to rest before sample collection. For a salivary cortisol test, you may be instructed to refrain from eating, drinking, or brushing your teeth for a period of time (may be some time between 15 to 30 minutes) prior to the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

Actin Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Actin Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Actin Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Activated Clotting Time (ACT).Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment with heparin or other blood-thinning medications (anticoagulants) when undergoing heart bypass surgery, coronary angioplasty, or dialysis
Activated Clotting Time (ACT).When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving high doses of heparin to prevent clotting during surgical procedures such as a heart bypass; when heparin levels are too high to allow monitoring with a PTT and/or when a rapid result is necessary to monitor treatment
Activated Clotting Time (ACT).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Activated Coagulation Time.Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment with heparin or other blood-thinning medications (anticoagulants) when undergoing heart bypass surgery, coronary angioplasty, or dialysis
Activated Coagulation Time.When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving high doses of heparin to prevent clotting during surgical procedures such as a heart bypass; when heparin levels are too high to allow monitoring with a PTT and/or when a rapid result is necessary to monitor treatment
Activated Coagulation Time.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode); to monitor unfractionated (standard) heparin anticoagulant therapy; as part of screening before surgery or other invasive procedure
Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained bleeding, inappropriate blood clotting, or recurrent miscarriages; when you are on standard heparin anticoagulant therapy; sometimes as part of a pre-surgical screen
Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

Activated Protein C Resistance.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an inherited gene mutation that increases your risk of developing a blood clot, including a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and/or venous thromboembolism (VTE)
Activated Protein C Resistance.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot (thrombotic episode), especially when you are less than 50 years old, have recurrent DVT or VTE episodes, experienced DVT or VTE during pregnancy, had DVT at unusual sites, or have a strong family history of thrombosis
Activated Protein C Resistance.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML); to help guide and/or monitor treatment of APL or to monitor for leukemia cells that remain after treatment (minimal residual disease) or for disease recurrence
Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia.When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for APL and/or when you are in remission but need follow up
Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration procedure

Acute Viral Hepatitis Panel.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose an infection with a hepatitis virus
Acute Viral Hepatitis Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of acute hepatitis and a viral infection is suspected to be the cause; when you have been exposed to one or more of the three most common hepatitis viruses: hepatitis A, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C
Acute Viral Hepatitis Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Acute Viral Hepatitis Serology Panel.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose an infection with a hepatitis virus
Acute Viral Hepatitis Serology Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of acute hepatitis and a viral infection is suspected to be the cause; when you have been exposed to one or more of the three most common hepatitis viruses: hepatitis A, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C
Acute Viral Hepatitis Serology Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

AD.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate adrenal gland function; to detect adrenal tumors or cancers; to help determine the cause of male physical characteristics (virilization) in females or early puberty in boys; to evaluate androgen production and function of ovaries in women or testicular function in men; when congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is suspected; to monitor treatment for CAH
AD.When To Get Tested?: When a woman has excess facial and body hair (hirsutism), acne, no monthly menstrual periods (amenorrhea), fewer than 6-8 menstrual cycle per year (oligomenorrhea), or infertility; when a boy is undergoing very early (precocious) puberty or a girl is showing signs of virilization; when puberty is delayed; when diagnosing CAH; periodically when being treated for CAH
AD.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
AD.Test Preparation Needed?: In menstruating women, there may be specific instructions as to timing of the sample collection.

ADA.Why Get Tested?: To help detect or rule out a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection in pleural fluid in order to assist in the diagnosis of tuberculosis; rarely to detect the infection in other body fluids such as peritoneal fluid or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
ADA.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that someone with chest pain, coughing, and/or difficulty breathing has tuberculosis that has spread to their pleurae (lining around the lungs)
ADA.Sample Required?: A volume of pleural fluid is collected by a healthcare practitioner using a procedure called thoracentesis; other body fluids are collected using other procedures

ADB.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you have had a prior strep infection with the bacteria group A Streptococcus; to help diagnose complications resulting from a recent strep infection, such as rheumatic fever and glomerulonephritis, a form of kidney disease
ADB.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as fever, chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath that suggest rheumatic fever, or symptoms such as edema and dark urine that are associated with glomerulonephritis, especially when you recently may have had a group A streptococcal infection that was not diagnosed and treated appropriately; may be done along with or following an ASO test
ADB.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Adenosine Deaminase.Why Get Tested?: To help detect or rule out a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection in pleural fluid in order to assist in the diagnosis of tuberculosis; rarely to detect the infection in other body fluids such as peritoneal fluid or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
Adenosine Deaminase.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that someone with chest pain, coughing, and/or difficulty breathing has tuberculosis that has spread to their pleurae (lining around the lungs)
Adenosine Deaminase.Sample Required?: A volume of pleural fluid is collected by a healthcare practitioner using a procedure called thoracentesis; other body fluids are collected using other procedures

Adenosine Deaminase, fluid.Why Get Tested?: To help detect or rule out a Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection in pleural fluid in order to assist in the diagnosis of tuberculosis; rarely to detect the infection in other body fluids such as peritoneal fluid or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
Adenosine Deaminase, fluid.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that someone with chest pain, coughing, and/or difficulty breathing has tuberculosis that has spread to their pleurae (lining around the lungs)
Adenosine Deaminase, fluid.Sample Required?: A volume of pleural fluid is collected by a healthcare practitioner using a procedure called thoracentesis; other body fluids are collected using other procedures

ADN-B.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you have had a prior strep infection with the bacteria group A Streptococcus; to help diagnose complications resulting from a recent strep infection, such as rheumatic fever and glomerulonephritis, a form of kidney disease
ADN-B.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as fever, chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath that suggest rheumatic fever, or symptoms such as edema and dark urine that are associated with glomerulonephritis, especially when you recently may have had a group A streptococcal infection that was not diagnosed and treated appropriately; may be done along with or following an ASO test
ADN-B.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ADNase-B.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you have had a prior strep infection with the bacteria group A Streptococcus; to help diagnose complications resulting from a recent strep infection, such as rheumatic fever and glomerulonephritis, a form of kidney disease
ADNase-B.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as fever, chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath that suggest rheumatic fever, or symptoms such as edema and dark urine that are associated with glomerulonephritis, especially when you recently may have had a group A streptococcal infection that was not diagnosed and treated appropriately; may be done along with or following an ASO test
ADNase-B.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Adrenocorticotropic Hormone.Why Get Tested?: In conjunction with cortisol testing, to help diagnose adrenal gland problems and pituitary diseases such as Cushing syndrome, Cushing disease, Addison disease, adrenal tumors, and pituitary tumors
Adrenocorticotropic Hormone.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms associated with excess or deficient cortisol production; when your healthcare provider suspects that you have a hormone imbalance that could be caused by a problem with your pituitary or adrenal glands
Adrenocorticotropic Hormone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Adrenocorticotropic Hormone.Test Preparation Needed?: The healthcare practitioner may request that you fast overnight before testing. Blood is typically drawn in the morning, about 8 a.m.

Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH).Why Get Tested?: In conjunction with cortisol testing, to help diagnose adrenal gland problems and pituitary diseases such as Cushing syndrome, Cushing disease, Addison disease, adrenal tumors, and pituitary tumors
Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH).When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms associated with excess or deficient cortisol production; when your healthcare provider suspects that you have a hormone imbalance that could be caused by a problem with your pituitary or adrenal glands
Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH).Test Preparation Needed?: The healthcare practitioner may request that you fast overnight before testing. Blood is typically drawn in the morning, about 8 a.m.

Aerobic Wound Culture.Why Get Tested?: To detect and identify the bacteria causing an infection of your wound and to help guide treatment of your wound infection
Aerobic Wound Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a wound infection, such as a wound that is tender, red, swollen, draining fluid or pus, and slow to heal
Aerobic Wound Culture.Sample Required?: A sterile swab used to collect cells or pus from the site of the suspected infection; may also include aspirations of fluid from deeper wounds into a syringe and/or a tissue biopsy

AFB Smear and Culture.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose tuberculosis (TB) and infections caused by other Mycobacterium species, which are known as acid-fast bacilli (AFB), in people at risk of developing mycobacterial infections; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
AFB Smear and Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a lung infection, such as a chronic cough, weight loss, fever, chills, and weakness, that may be due to TB or a nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection; when you have a positive IGRA blood test or Tuberculin skin test (TST) and you are in a high-risk group for progressing to active TB; when you have a skin or other body site infection that may be due to mycobacteria; when you are undergoing treatment for TB
AFB Smear and Culture.Sample Required?: For suspected cases of tuberculosis lung infections, usually three sputum samples are collected early in the morning on different days. If you are unable to produce sputum, a bronchoscope may be used to collect fluid during a procedure called a bronchoscopy. In children, gastric washings/aspirates may be collected. Depending on symptoms, urine, an aspirate from the site of suspected infection, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), other body fluids, or biopsied tissue samples may be collected for AFB testing.

AFP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor therapy for certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries
AFP.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries; at intervals during and after treatment for one of these cancers; sometimes when you have cancer-predisposing diseases such as chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis
AFP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

AFP Maternal.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
AFP Maternal.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
AFP Maternal.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

AFP-L3%.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor therapy for certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries
AFP-L3%.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries; at intervals during and after treatment for one of these cancers; sometimes when you have cancer-predisposing diseases such as chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis
AFP-L3%.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Agglutinins.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of hemolytic anemia; to help diagnose cold agglutinin disease
Agglutinins.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with anemia and/or pain, pale skin, and bluing in the fingers, toes and tips of the ears that occurs after exposure to cold temperatures; when you have been diagnosed with hemolytic anemia and your healthcare practitioner is investigating the cause
Agglutinins.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

AGPA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
AGPA.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
AGPA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

AIDS Screen.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you are infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
AIDS Screen.When To Get Tested?: At least once, when you are 13 to 64 years old; when you think you may have been exposed to the virus; before becoming pregnant or when pregnant; once a year if you are at increased risk of being exposed to the virus
AIDS Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample collected from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick; there are also HIV antibody tests available that can be performed on oral fluid.

AIDS Test.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you are infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
AIDS Test.When To Get Tested?: At least once, when you are 13 to 64 years old; when you think you may have been exposed to the virus; before becoming pregnant or when pregnant; once a year if you are at increased risk of being exposed to the virus
AIDS Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample collected from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick; there are also HIV antibody tests available that can be performed on oral fluid.

ALA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
ALA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
ALA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
ALA.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

Alanine Aminotransferase.Why Get Tested?: To screen for liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
Alanine Aminotransferase.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) when you have a routine health exam
Alanine Aminotransferase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT).Why Get Tested?: To screen for liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT).When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) when you have a routine health exam
Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Alanine Transaminase.Why Get Tested?: To screen for liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
Alanine Transaminase.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) when you have a routine health exam
Alanine Transaminase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ALB.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and help diagnose a liver disorder or kidney disease; sometimes to evaluate nutritional status, especially in hospitalized patients
ALB.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of the blood tests done for a physical; when a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder or kidney disease; sometimes when you have unintended weight loss, have symptoms associated with malnutrition, or prior to a planned surgery
ALB.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Albumin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and help diagnose a liver disorder or kidney disease; sometimes to evaluate nutritional status, especially in hospitalized patients
Albumin.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of the blood tests done for a physical; when a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder or kidney disease; sometimes when you have unintended weight loss, have symptoms associated with malnutrition, or prior to a planned surgery
Albumin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Albumin, serum.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and help diagnose a liver disorder or kidney disease; sometimes to evaluate nutritional status, especially in hospitalized patients
Albumin, serum.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of the blood tests done for a physical; when a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder or kidney disease; sometimes when you have unintended weight loss, have symptoms associated with malnutrition, or prior to a planned surgery
Albumin, serum.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Albumin/Globulin Ratio.Why Get Tested?: As part of a general health checkup, to determine your nutritional status or to screen for and help diagnose certain liver and kidney disorders as well as other diseases
Albumin/Globulin Ratio.When To Get Tested?: When you have a routine physical exam or when you experience unexpected weight loss or fatigue, or when a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver or kidney disorder
Albumin/Globulin Ratio.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick (adults and children) or heelstick (newborns)

Alcohol.Why Get Tested?: To determine if a person has consumed ethanol and to measure the amount of ethanol present
Alcohol.When To Get Tested?: When someone has signs and symptoms that suggest intoxication or ethanol poisoning; when a person is suspected of violating drinking-related laws, or as part of a drug testing panel
Alcohol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva is collected. Blood, urine, and saliva samples must be sent to a laboratory for analysis. A breath sample is analyzed immediately on site using a breathalyzer.

Aldosterone and Plasma Renin Activity.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your aldosterone and renin levels are abnormal, to help diagnose a hormonal (endocrine) disorder such as primary aldosteronism (PA, Conn syndrome)
Aldosterone and Plasma Renin Activity.When To Get Tested?: When you develop symptoms or signs associated with increased aldosterone production, such as elevated blood pressure, muscle weakness, and low potassium, or low aldosterone production, such as low blood pressure, high potassium, and low sodium
Aldosterone and Plasma Renin Activity.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes at specialized medical centers, blood from the kidney (renal) or adrenal veins is also collected.
Aldosterone and Plasma Renin Activity.Test Preparation Needed?: For a blood aldosterone and renin measurement, the healthcare practitioner may ask you to be upright or lying down (e.g., for 15-30 minutes) prior to drawing blood. You may also be instructed to avoid certain foods, beverages, or medications before the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

Aldosterone and Renin.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your aldosterone and renin levels are abnormal, to help diagnose a hormonal (endocrine) disorder such as primary aldosteronism (PA, Conn syndrome)
Aldosterone and Renin.When To Get Tested?: When you develop symptoms or signs associated with increased aldosterone production, such as elevated blood pressure, muscle weakness, and low potassium, or low aldosterone production, such as low blood pressure, high potassium, and low sodium
Aldosterone and Renin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes at specialized medical centers, blood from the kidney (renal) or adrenal veins is also collected.
Aldosterone and Renin.Test Preparation Needed?: For a blood aldosterone and renin measurement, the healthcare practitioner may ask you to be upright or lying down (e.g., for 15-30 minutes) prior to drawing blood. You may also be instructed to avoid certain foods, beverages, or medications before the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

Aldosterone, Serum; Aldosterone, Urine;.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your aldosterone and renin levels are abnormal, to help diagnose a hormonal (endocrine) disorder such as primary aldosteronism (PA, Conn syndrome)
Aldosterone, Serum; Aldosterone, Urine;.When To Get Tested?: When you develop symptoms or signs associated with increased aldosterone production, such as elevated blood pressure, muscle weakness, and low potassium, or low aldosterone production, such as low blood pressure, high potassium, and low sodium
Aldosterone, Serum; Aldosterone, Urine;.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes at specialized medical centers, blood from the kidney (renal) or adrenal veins is also collected.
Aldosterone, Serum; Aldosterone, Urine;.Test Preparation Needed?: For a blood aldosterone and renin measurement, the healthcare practitioner may ask you to be upright or lying down (e.g., for 15-30 minutes) prior to drawing blood. You may also be instructed to avoid certain foods, beverages, or medications before the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

ALK (Anaplastic Lymphoma Receptor Tyrosi.Why Get Tested?: To detect an ALK gene rearrangement in tumor tissue in order to guide non-small cell lung cancer therapy
ALK (Anaplastic Lymphoma Receptor Tyrosi.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer and your healthcare practitioner is considering a therapeutic management plan that may include an ALK kinase inhibitor such as crizotinib
ALK (Anaplastic Lymphoma Receptor Tyrosi.Sample Required?: A tumor tissue sample is obtained through a biopsy procedure or sometimes collected during surgery. The tumor tissue is typically evaluated by a pathologist prior to testing.

ALK Gene Fusion.Why Get Tested?: To detect an ALK gene rearrangement in tumor tissue in order to guide non-small cell lung cancer therapy
ALK Gene Fusion.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer and your healthcare practitioner is considering a therapeutic management plan that may include an ALK kinase inhibitor such as crizotinib
ALK Gene Fusion.Sample Required?: A tumor tissue sample is obtained through a biopsy procedure or sometimes collected during surgery. The tumor tissue is typically evaluated by a pathologist prior to testing.

ALK Gene Rearrangement.Why Get Tested?: To detect an ALK gene rearrangement in tumor tissue in order to guide non-small cell lung cancer therapy
ALK Gene Rearrangement.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer and your healthcare practitioner is considering a therapeutic management plan that may include an ALK kinase inhibitor such as crizotinib
ALK Gene Rearrangement.Sample Required?: A tumor tissue sample is obtained through a biopsy procedure or sometimes collected during surgery. The tumor tissue is typically evaluated by a pathologist prior to testing.

ALK Mutation (Gene Rearrangement).Why Get Tested?: To detect an ALK gene rearrangement in tumor tissue in order to guide non-small cell lung cancer therapy
ALK Mutation (Gene Rearrangement).When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer and your healthcare practitioner is considering a therapeutic management plan that may include an ALK kinase inhibitor such as crizotinib
ALK Mutation (Gene Rearrangement).Sample Required?: A tumor tissue sample is obtained through a biopsy procedure or sometimes collected during surgery. The tumor tissue is typically evaluated by a pathologist prior to testing.

Alk Phos.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor treatment for a liver or bone disorder
Alk Phos.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine liver panel or when you have symptoms of a liver or bone disorder
Alk Phos.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Alk Phos.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting overnight preferred but not required

Alkaline Phosphatase.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor treatment for a liver or bone disorder
Alkaline Phosphatase.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine liver panel or when you have symptoms of a liver or bone disorder
Alkaline Phosphatase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Alkaline Phosphatase.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting overnight preferred but not required

Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP).Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor treatment for a liver or bone disorder
Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP).When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine liver panel or when you have symptoms of a liver or bone disorder
Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP).Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting overnight preferred but not required

Alkaline phosphatase isoenzymes.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor treatment for a liver or bone disorder
Alkaline phosphatase isoenzymes.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine liver panel or when you have symptoms of a liver or bone disorder
Alkaline phosphatase isoenzymes.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Alkaline phosphatase isoenzymes.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting overnight preferred but not required

Alkp.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor treatment for a liver or bone disorder
Alkp.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine liver panel or when you have symptoms of a liver or bone disorder
Alkp.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Alkp.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting overnight preferred but not required

Allergen-specific IgE Antibody Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose allergies; sometimes to monitor the effectiveness of immunotherapy (desensitization) treatment
Allergen-specific IgE Antibody Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as hives, dermatitis, nasal congestion, red itchy eyes, asthma, or abdominal pain that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be caused by an allergy
Allergen-specific IgE Antibody Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Allergy Blood Testing.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose allergies; sometimes to monitor the effectiveness of immunotherapy (desensitization) treatment
Allergy Blood Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as hives, dermatitis, nasal congestion, red itchy eyes, asthma, or abdominal pain that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be caused by an allergy
Allergy Blood Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Allergy Screen.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose allergies; sometimes to monitor the effectiveness of immunotherapy (desensitization) treatment
Allergy Screen.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as hives, dermatitis, nasal congestion, red itchy eyes, asthma, or abdominal pain that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be caused by an allergy
Allergy Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Alloantibody Identification.Why Get Tested?: To identify the specific antibody detected by a direct antiglobulin test (DAT) or RBC antibody screen; to help identify the cause of a transfusion reaction, hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), or hemolytic anemia
Alloantibody Identification.When To Get Tested?: When a DAT or RBC antibody screen is positive; when a transfusion reaction is suspected or when a newborn has HDN
Alloantibody Identification.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ALP.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor treatment for a liver or bone disorder
ALP.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine liver panel or when you have symptoms of a liver or bone disorder
ALP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
ALP.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting overnight preferred but not required

Alpha Tryptase.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose anaphylaxis, mastocytosis (too many mast cells), or mast cell activation
Alpha Tryptase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as flushing, nausea, throat swelling, or low blood pressure that may be due to a life-threatening allergic reaction; when your healthcare provider suspects that you have mastocytosis or mast cell activation
Alpha Tryptase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Alpha Tryptase.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample soon after the beginning of symptoms can be important.

Alpha-1 Antitrypsin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of early onset emphysema and/or liver dysfunction; to establish the risk of emphysema and/or liver disease due to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency and determine the likelihood that children might inherit the risk
Alpha-1 Antitrypsin.When To Get Tested?: When your infant or young child show signs of liver disease; when you develop emphysema before age 40; when you have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or unexplained liver disease at any age; when you have a close relative with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Alpha-1 Antitrypsin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) Tumor Marker.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor therapy for certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) Tumor Marker.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries; at intervals during and after treatment for one of these cancers; sometimes when you have cancer-predisposing diseases such as chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) Tumor Marker.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Alpha-fetoprotein, Total; Alpha-fetoprot.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor therapy for certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries
Alpha-fetoprotein, Total; Alpha-fetoprot.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries; at intervals during and after treatment for one of these cancers; sometimes when you have cancer-predisposing diseases such as chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis
Alpha-fetoprotein, Total; Alpha-fetoprot.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Alpha1 Antitrypsin; α1-antitrypsin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of early onset emphysema and/or liver dysfunction; to establish the risk of emphysema and/or liver disease due to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency and determine the likelihood that children might inherit the risk
Alpha1 Antitrypsin; α1-antitrypsin.When To Get Tested?: When your infant or young child show signs of liver disease; when you develop emphysema before age 40; when you have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or unexplained liver disease at any age; when you have a close relative with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Alpha1 Antitrypsin; α1-antitrypsin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Alpha1-antitrypsin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of early onset emphysema and/or liver dysfunction; to establish the risk of emphysema and/or liver disease due to alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency and determine the likelihood that children might inherit the risk
Alpha1-antitrypsin.When To Get Tested?: When your infant or young child show signs of liver disease; when you develop emphysema before age 40; when you have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or unexplained liver disease at any age; when you have a close relative with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Alpha1-antitrypsin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ALT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
ALT.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) when you have a routine health exam
ALT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Alzheimer Biomarkers.Why Get Tested?: To help distinguish between Alzheimer disease and other forms of dementia
Alzheimer Biomarkers.When To Get Tested?: These tests may be ordered along with cognitive and brain-imaging tests in people who demonstrate some form of dementia. These tests are not routine laboratory tests and are typically available only in research settings or memory clinics.
Alzheimer Biomarkers.Sample Required?: A sample of cerebrospinal fluid collected using a spinal tap
Alzheimer Biomarkers.Test Preparation Needed?: Your healthcare practitioner will advise you of any preparatory requirements.

Amethopterin.Why Get Tested?:
To detect, monitor and evaluate toxic concentrations of methotrexate
To measure methotrexate levels in blood to determine the initial dosage requirement in individuals with immune disease
Amethopterin.When To Get Tested?: At specific timed intervals after a high dose of methotrexate to monitor blood levels and guide treatment and whenever symptoms suggest methotrexate toxicity
Amethopterin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Amethopterin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample for testing is important; your healthcare practitioner may specify collection at a certain number of hours after a methotrexate dose; when having your blood drawn, tell the person collecting your blood sample when you took your last dose of methotrexate.

AMH.Why Get Tested?: In women, to evaluate ovarian function and fertility; sometimes in the evaluation of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or to evaluate the effectiveness of ovarian cancer treatment; in an infant, to evaluate the presence of external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or function of the testicles in an infant boy
AMH.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner wants to evaluate a woman's fertility, predict onset of menopause, or suspects PCOS; sometimes prior to some assisted reproductive procedures; periodically when a woman is undergoing treatment for an AMH-producing ovarian cancer; when it is suspected that the testicles of an infant boy are absent or not functioning properly
AMH.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

AMH Hormone Test.Why Get Tested?: In women, to evaluate ovarian function and fertility; sometimes in the evaluation of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or to evaluate the effectiveness of ovarian cancer treatment; in an infant, to evaluate the presence of external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or function of the testicles in an infant boy
AMH Hormone Test.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner wants to evaluate a woman's fertility, predict onset of menopause, or suspects PCOS; sometimes prior to some assisted reproductive procedures; periodically when a woman is undergoing treatment for an AMH-producing ovarian cancer; when it is suspected that the testicles of an infant boy are absent or not functioning properly
AMH Hormone Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Aminoglycoside Antibiotics.Why Get Tested?: To monitor the level of an aminoglycoside antibiotic such as gentamicin, tobramycin, or amikacin in the blood to ensure adequate dosing and help avoid toxic side effects
Aminoglycoside Antibiotics.When To Get Tested?: At regular intervals during treatment with an aminoglycoside
Aminoglycoside Antibiotics.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Aminoglycoside Antibiotics.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample for testing is important; follow your healthcare provider's directions.

Aminophylline.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of theophylline or caffeine in the blood to establish an appropriate dose and to maintain a therapeutic level
Aminophylline.When To Get Tested?: At the start of drug therapy and at regular intervals to monitor the drug's concentration; when indicated, to detect low or excessive (potentially toxic) concentrations
Aminophylline.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from pricking an infant's heel

AML-M3.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML); to help guide and/or monitor treatment of APL or to monitor for leukemia cells that remain after treatment (minimal residual disease) or for disease recurrence
AML-M3.When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for APL and/or when you are in remission but need follow up
AML-M3.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration procedure

Ammonia.Why Get Tested?: To detect an elevated level of ammonia in the blood that may be caused by severe liver disease, kidney failure, or certain rare genetic urea cycle disorders; to help investigate the cause of changes in behavior and consciousness; to support the diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy or Reye syndrome
Ammonia.When To Get Tested?: When someone with liver disease or kidney failure experiences mental changes or lapses into a coma; when a newborn experiences frequent vomiting and increased lethargy or when a child has continuous vomiting and unusual sleepiness about a week after a viral illness, such as the flu or chickenpox
Ammonia.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Ammonia.Test Preparation Needed?: You should not smoke cigarettes prior to collection of the specimen.

Ammonia, plasma.Why Get Tested?: To detect an elevated level of ammonia in the blood that may be caused by severe liver disease, kidney failure, or certain rare genetic urea cycle disorders; to help investigate the cause of changes in behavior and consciousness; to support the diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy or Reye syndrome
Ammonia, plasma.When To Get Tested?: When someone with liver disease or kidney failure experiences mental changes or lapses into a coma; when a newborn experiences frequent vomiting and increased lethargy or when a child has continuous vomiting and unusual sleepiness about a week after a viral illness, such as the flu or chickenpox
Ammonia, plasma.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Ammonia, plasma.Test Preparation Needed?: You should not smoke cigarettes prior to collection of the specimen.

Amnio.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose certain birth defects, genetic diseases, and chromosomal abnormalities in a fetus, especially if prenatal screening tests are abnormal; if there is a family history or high risk of inherited disease; sometimes to diagnose a fetal infection and occasionally to help diagnose and monitor hemolytic disease in a fetus; rarely, to evaluate fetal lung maturity when there is an increased risk of premature delivery
Amnio.When To Get Tested?: Testing is most commonly offered between 15 and 20 weeks of pregnancy to test for genetic diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, and open neural tube defects and is recommended after a pregnant woman has an abnormality on an initial prenatal screening test; when it is suspected that a fetus has an infection or other illness or when a fetus has hemolytic disease; rarely it may be done after 32 weeks to evaluate fetal lung maturity
Amnio.Sample Required?: A sample (about 1 ounce) of amniotic fluid is obtained using a procedure called amniocentesis that involves inserting a thin needle through the belly and uterus into the amniotic sac (see Common Questions below).
Amnio.Test Preparation Needed?: Depending upon the stage of pregnancy, either a full or empty bladder may be required at the time the amniocentesis is performed. Be sure to follow any instructions provided.

Amniocentesis.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose certain birth defects, genetic diseases, and chromosomal abnormalities in a fetus, especially if prenatal screening tests are abnormal; if there is a family history or high risk of inherited disease; sometimes to diagnose a fetal infection and occasionally to help diagnose and monitor hemolytic disease in a fetus; rarely, to evaluate fetal lung maturity when there is an increased risk of premature delivery
Amniocentesis.When To Get Tested?: Testing is most commonly offered between 15 and 20 weeks of pregnancy to test for genetic diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, and open neural tube defects and is recommended after a pregnant woman has an abnormality on an initial prenatal screening test; when it is suspected that a fetus has an infection or other illness or when a fetus has hemolytic disease; rarely it may be done after 32 weeks to evaluate fetal lung maturity
Amniocentesis.Sample Required?: A sample (about 1 ounce) of amniotic fluid is obtained using a procedure called amniocentesis that involves inserting a thin needle through the belly and uterus into the amniotic sac (see Common Questions below).
Amniocentesis.Test Preparation Needed?: Depending upon the stage of pregnancy, either a full or empty bladder may be required at the time the amniocentesis is performed. Be sure to follow any instructions provided.

Amniotic Fluid Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose certain birth defects, genetic diseases, and chromosomal abnormalities in a fetus, especially if prenatal screening tests are abnormal; if there is a family history or high risk of inherited disease; sometimes to diagnose a fetal infection and occasionally to help diagnose and monitor hemolytic disease in a fetus; rarely, to evaluate fetal lung maturity when there is an increased risk of premature delivery
Amniotic Fluid Analysis.When To Get Tested?: Testing is most commonly offered between 15 and 20 weeks of pregnancy to test for genetic diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, and open neural tube defects and is recommended after a pregnant woman has an abnormality on an initial prenatal screening test; when it is suspected that a fetus has an infection or other illness or when a fetus has hemolytic disease; rarely it may be done after 32 weeks to evaluate fetal lung maturity
Amniotic Fluid Analysis.Sample Required?: A sample (about 1 ounce) of amniotic fluid is obtained using a procedure called amniocentesis that involves inserting a thin needle through the belly and uterus into the amniotic sac (see Common Questions below).
Amniotic Fluid Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: Depending upon the stage of pregnancy, either a full or empty bladder may be required at the time the amniocentesis is performed. Be sure to follow any instructions provided.

Amy.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to diagnose and monitor acute pancreatitis; also sometimes to diagnose and monitor chronic pancreatitis or other pancreatic diseases
Amy.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a pancreatic disorder, such as severe abdominal pain, fever, loss of appetite, or nausea
Amy.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample, a 24-hour urine sample, or a sample of peritoneal fluid

Amylase.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to diagnose and monitor acute pancreatitis; also sometimes to diagnose and monitor chronic pancreatitis or other pancreatic diseases
Amylase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a pancreatic disorder, such as severe abdominal pain, fever, loss of appetite, or nausea
Amylase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample, a 24-hour urine sample, or a sample of peritoneal fluid

ANA.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose certain autoimmune disorders, such as lupus and Sjögren syndrome, among other types
ANA.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of certain autoimmune disorders
ANA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
ANA.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, certain medications can affect ANA test results, so tell your healthcare provider about any prescription medications, nonprescription medications, or street drugs you use.

Anaerobic Wound Culture.Why Get Tested?: To detect and identify the bacteria causing an infection of your wound and to help guide treatment of your wound infection
Anaerobic Wound Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a wound infection, such as a wound that is tender, red, swollen, draining fluid or pus, and slow to heal
Anaerobic Wound Culture.Sample Required?: A sterile swab used to collect cells or pus from the site of the suspected infection; may also include aspirations of fluid from deeper wounds into a syringe and/or a tissue biopsy

ANCA Antibodies.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
ANCA Antibodies.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
ANCA Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ANCA/MPO/PR3 Antibodies.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
ANCA/MPO/PR3 Antibodies.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
ANCA/MPO/PR3 Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Androstenedione.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate adrenal gland function; to detect adrenal tumors or cancers; to help determine the cause of male physical characteristics (virilization) in females or early puberty in boys; to evaluate androgen production and function of ovaries in women or testicular function in men; when congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is suspected; to monitor treatment for CAH
Androstenedione.When To Get Tested?: When a woman has excess facial and body hair (hirsutism), acne, no monthly menstrual periods (amenorrhea), fewer than 6-8 menstrual cycle per year (oligomenorrhea), or infertility; when a boy is undergoing very early (precocious) puberty or a girl is showing signs of virilization; when puberty is delayed; when diagnosing CAH; periodically when being treated for CAH
Androstenedione.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Androstenedione.Test Preparation Needed?: In menstruating women, there may be specific instructions as to timing of the sample collection.

Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor sarcoidosis; to help differentiate this systemic condition from other disorders causing similar symptoms
Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme.When To Get Tested?: When you have granulomas that produce small bumps under the skin, a lingering cough, red watery eyes, and/or other symptoms suggestive of sarcoidosis; regularly when you have active sarcoidosis to monitor its course
Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor sarcoidosis; to help differentiate this systemic condition from other disorders causing similar symptoms
Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE).When To Get Tested?: When you have granulomas that produce small bumps under the skin, a lingering cough, red watery eyes, and/or other symptoms suggestive of sarcoidosis; regularly when you have active sarcoidosis to monitor its course
Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anion Gap.Why Get Tested?: To detect a problem with the body's electrolyte balance
Anion Gap.When To Get Tested?: As part of routine health screening or when your healthcare provider suspects that you have an imbalance of one of the electrolytes (usually sodium or potassium) or an acid-base imbalance
Anion Gap.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
