Anti-Beta-2 Glycoprotein 1.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or venous thromboembolism); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriage; as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
Anti-Beta-2 Glycoprotein 1.When To Get Tested?: When you have had one or more unexplained blood clots in a vein or artery; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters
Anti-Beta-2 Glycoprotein 1.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-CCP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and differentiate it from other types of arthritis; to help evaluate the prognosis of a person with RA
Anti-CCP.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner suspects RA in someone who has joint inflammation with symptoms that suggest but do not yet meet the criteria of RA
Anti-CCP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-citrulline Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and differentiate it from other types of arthritis; to help evaluate the prognosis of a person with RA
Anti-citrulline Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner suspects RA in someone who has joint inflammation with symptoms that suggest but do not yet meet the criteria of RA
Anti-citrulline Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-cyclic Citrullinated Peptide.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and differentiate it from other types of arthritis; to help evaluate the prognosis of a person with RA
Anti-cyclic Citrullinated Peptide.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner suspects RA in someone who has joint inflammation with symptoms that suggest but do not yet meet the criteria of RA
Anti-cyclic Citrullinated Peptide.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

anti-DNA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus, SLE)
anti-DNA.When To Get Tested?: When you have a positive ANA test and signs and symptoms associated with lupus, such as persistent fatigue, pain in your joints and a red rash resembling a butterfly across the nose and cheeks; periodically used to assess disease activity in those who have been diagnosed with lupus
anti-DNA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-DNase B.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you have had a prior strep infection with the bacteria group A Streptococcus; to help diagnose complications resulting from a recent strep infection, such as rheumatic fever and glomerulonephritis, a form of kidney disease
Anti-DNase B.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as fever, chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath that suggest rheumatic fever, or symptoms such as edema and dark urine that are associated with glomerulonephritis, especially when you recently may have had a group A streptococcal infection that was not diagnosed and treated appropriately; may be done along with or following an ASO test
Anti-DNase B.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-double-stranded DNA, IgG.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus, SLE)
Anti-double-stranded DNA, IgG.When To Get Tested?: When you have a positive ANA test and signs and symptoms associated with lupus, such as persistent fatigue, pain in your joints and a red rash resembling a butterfly across the nose and cheeks; periodically used to assess disease activity in those who have been diagnosed with lupus
Anti-double-stranded DNA, IgG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-dsDNA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus, SLE)
Anti-dsDNA.When To Get Tested?: When you have a positive ANA test and signs and symptoms associated with lupus, such as persistent fatigue, pain in your joints and a red rash resembling a butterfly across the nose and cheeks; periodically used to assess disease activity in those who have been diagnosed with lupus
Anti-dsDNA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-factor Xa Heparin.Why Get Tested?: To monitor standard, unfractionated heparin (UFH) therapy and sometimes to monitor low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) therapy
Anti-factor Xa Heparin.When To Get Tested?: When you are being treated with UFH or LMWH and your healthcare provider wants to monitor the amount of heparin in your blood
Anti-factor Xa Heparin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-FXa.Why Get Tested?: To monitor standard, unfractionated heparin (UFH) therapy and sometimes to monitor low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) therapy
Anti-FXa.When To Get Tested?: When you are being treated with UFH or LMWH and your healthcare provider wants to monitor the amount of heparin in your blood
Anti-FXa.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-GPA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
Anti-GPA.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
Anti-GPA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-HAV.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of acute hepatitis; as part of a viral hepatitis panel to identify the type of hepatitis virus causing an infection; sometimes to evaluate the need for the hepatitis A vaccine
Anti-HAV.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an acute hepatitis infection, such as jaundice, or when you may have been exposed to hepatitis A virus (HAV)
Anti-HAV.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

anti-HBc.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
anti-HBc.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
anti-HBc.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

anti-HBc, IgM.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
anti-HBc, IgM.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
anti-HBc, IgM.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

anti-HBe.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
anti-HBe.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
anti-HBe.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

anti-HBs.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
anti-HBs.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
anti-HBs.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-HCV.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and diagnose a hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and to monitor treatment of the infection
To learn more about hepatitis C, read the article on Viral Hepatitis.
Anti-HCV.When To Get Tested?:
For screening: when you have risk factors for HCV infection or were born between 1945 and 1965, per 2012 CDC recommendations
For diagnosis: when you may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus, such as through contact with infected blood, or have symptoms associated with liver disease
Anti-HCV.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Intrinsic Factor.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
Anti-Intrinsic Factor.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
Anti-Intrinsic Factor.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Anti-Intrinsic Factor.Test Preparation Needed?: You should wait at least 48 hours after receiving a vitamin B12 injection to have a blood sample taken. Some healthcare providers may prefer not to draw a blood sample for the test within 2 weeks of an injection.

Anti-Jo-1.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-Jo-1.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-Jo-1.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Liver/Kidney Microsomal Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Anti-Liver/Kidney Microsomal Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Anti-Liver/Kidney Microsomal Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-LKM-1.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Anti-LKM-1.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Anti-LKM-1.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-LKM1.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Anti-LKM1.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Anti-LKM1.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Müllerian Hormone.Why Get Tested?: In women, to evaluate ovarian function and fertility; sometimes in the evaluation of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or to evaluate the effectiveness of ovarian cancer treatment; in an infant, to evaluate the presence of external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or function of the testicles in an infant boy
Anti-Müllerian Hormone.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner wants to evaluate a woman's fertility, predict onset of menopause, or suspects PCOS; sometimes prior to some assisted reproductive procedures; periodically when a woman is undergoing treatment for an AMH-producing ovarian cancer; when it is suspected that the testicles of an infant boy are absent or not functioning properly
Anti-Müllerian Hormone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-P450 2D6 Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Anti-P450 2D6 Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Anti-P450 2D6 Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-parietal Cell Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
Anti-parietal Cell Antibody.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
Anti-parietal Cell Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-retroviral Drug Resistance Testing.Why Get Tested?: If you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), to determine whether the strain causing your infection is resistant or has developed resistance to one or more antiretroviral therapy (ART) drugs
Anti-retroviral Drug Resistance Testing.When To Get Tested?: When first diagnosed with HIV, immediately prior to the start of antiretroviral therapy, or when you are receiving ART but the amount of virus in your blood (HIV viral load) does not decrease or rises steadily
Anti-retroviral Drug Resistance Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Ribonucleoprotein.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-Ribonucleoprotein.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-Ribonucleoprotein.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-RNP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-RNP.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-RNP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your healthcare practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae mannan ant.Why Get Tested?: To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae mannan ant.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your healthcare practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae mannan ant.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Sjögren Syndrome A.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-Sjögren Syndrome A.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-Sjögren Syndrome A.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Sjögren Syndrome B.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-Sjögren Syndrome B.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-Sjögren Syndrome B.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Sm (Sm).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-Sm (Sm).When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-Sm (Sm).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Smooth Muscle Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Anti-Smooth Muscle Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Anti-Smooth Muscle Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-SmRNP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-SmRNP.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-SmRNP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-SSA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-SSA.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-SSA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-SSB.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-SSB.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-SSB.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-tissue Transglutaminase Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
Anti-tissue Transglutaminase Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
Anti-tissue Transglutaminase Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Anti-tissue Transglutaminase Antibody.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

Anti-Topoisomerase.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-Topoisomerase.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-Topoisomerase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-TPO.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Anti-TPO.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Anti-TPO.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-U(1)RNP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Anti-U(1)RNP.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Anti-U(1)RNP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anti-Xa chromogenic.Why Get Tested?: To monitor standard, unfractionated heparin (UFH) therapy and sometimes to monitor low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) therapy
Anti-Xa chromogenic.When To Get Tested?: When you are being treated with UFH or LMWH and your healthcare provider wants to monitor the amount of heparin in your blood
Anti-Xa chromogenic.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antibiotic Susceptibility Testing.Why Get Tested?: To determine the likelihood that a particular antibiotic or antifungal drug will be effective in stopping the growth of the bacteria or fungi causing your infection
Antibiotic Susceptibility Testing.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to a positive bacterial or fungal culture; when selecting the best treatment for a bacterial or fungal infection requires laboratory testing; when your infection is not responding to treatment
Antibiotic Susceptibility Testing.Sample Required?: A sample from an infected site is cultured on specialized media to recover the bacteria or fungus that is causing the infection. The method used to collect a sample from an individual depends on the type of culture performed (e.g., urine culture, blood culture, sputum culture, etc.).

Antibodies to Saline-extracted Antigens.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Antibodies to Saline-extracted Antigens.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Antibodies to Saline-extracted Antigens.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antibody ID, RBC.Why Get Tested?: To identify the specific antibody detected by a direct antiglobulin test (DAT) or RBC antibody screen; to help identify the cause of a transfusion reaction, hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), or hemolytic anemia
Antibody ID, RBC.When To Get Tested?: When a DAT or RBC antibody screen is positive; when a transfusion reaction is suspected or when a newborn has HDN
Antibody ID, RBC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antibody Screen.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies directed against red blood cell antigens
Antibody Screen.When To Get Tested?: When preparing for a blood transfusion; during pregnancy and at delivery
Antibody Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antibody to ds-DNA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus, SLE)
Antibody to ds-DNA.When To Get Tested?: When you have a positive ANA test and signs and symptoms associated with lupus, such as persistent fatigue, pain in your joints and a red rash resembling a butterfly across the nose and cheeks; periodically used to assess disease activity in those who have been diagnosed with lupus
Antibody to ds-DNA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anticardiolipin Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate inappropriate blood clot formation, to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriage, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome or sometimes other autoimmune diseases
Anticardiolipin Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have had one or more unexplained blood clots (thrombotic episodes) in a vein or artery; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters; when you have symptoms consistent with an autoimmune disease
Anticardiolipin Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anticentromere Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of anticentromere antibodies; to help diagnose limited cutaneous scleroderma
Anticentromere Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have one or more symptoms that suggest CREST syndrome
Anticentromere Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Anticytoplasmic Autoantibodies.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
Anticytoplasmic Autoantibodies.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
Anticytoplasmic Autoantibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antideoxyribonuclease-B Titer.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you have had a prior strep infection with the bacteria group A Streptococcus; to help diagnose complications resulting from a recent strep infection, such as rheumatic fever and glomerulonephritis, a form of kidney disease
Antideoxyribonuclease-B Titer.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as fever, chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath that suggest rheumatic fever, or symptoms such as edema and dark urine that are associated with glomerulonephritis, especially when you recently may have had a group A streptococcal infection that was not diagnosed and treated appropriately; may be done along with or following an ASO test
Antideoxyribonuclease-B Titer.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH).Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and determine the cause of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) deficiency or excess; to investigate low blood sodium levels (hyponatremia); to distinguish between the two types of diabetes insipidus
Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH).When To Get Tested?: When you have low blood sodium or have persistent thirst, frequent urination, and dehydration
Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH).Test Preparation Needed?: None needed for an ADH test; however, talk to your health care provider about required preparation when the ADH test is performed as part of a water deprivation ADH stimulation test or a water loading ADH suppression test.

Antidiuretic Hormone; Arginine Vasopress.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and determine the cause of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) deficiency or excess; to investigate low blood sodium levels (hyponatremia); to distinguish between the two types of diabetes insipidus
Antidiuretic Hormone; Arginine Vasopress.When To Get Tested?: When you have low blood sodium or have persistent thirst, frequent urination, and dehydration
Antidiuretic Hormone; Arginine Vasopress.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Antidiuretic Hormone; Arginine Vasopress.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed for an ADH test; however, talk to your health care provider about required preparation when the ADH test is performed as part of a water deprivation ADH stimulation test or a water loading ADH suppression test.

Antihistidyl Transfer RNA Synthase Antib.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Antihistidyl Transfer RNA Synthase Antib.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Antihistidyl Transfer RNA Synthase Antib.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antihistone Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help in the diagnosis and monitoring of drug-induced lupus
Antihistone Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with lupus that may be due to a drug that you are taking
Antihistone Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antimicrobial Susceptibility.Why Get Tested?: To determine the likelihood that a particular antibiotic or antifungal drug will be effective in stopping the growth of the bacteria or fungi causing your infection
Antimicrobial Susceptibility.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to a positive bacterial or fungal culture; when selecting the best treatment for a bacterial or fungal infection requires laboratory testing; when your infection is not responding to treatment
Antimicrobial Susceptibility.Sample Required?: A sample from an infected site is cultured on specialized media to recover the bacteria or fungus that is causing the infection. The method used to collect a sample from an individual depends on the type of culture performed (e.g., urine culture, blood culture, sputum culture, etc.).

Antimicrosomal Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Antimicrosomal Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Antimicrosomal Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antimitochondrial Antibody and AMA M2.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose primary biliary cholangitis, also sometimes called primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
Antimitochondrial Antibody and AMA M2.When To Get Tested?: When you have abnormal results on a liver panel and/or symptoms that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to PBC
Antimitochondrial Antibody and AMA M2.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antimitochondrial Antibody and Antimitoc.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose primary biliary cholangitis, also sometimes called primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
Antimitochondrial Antibody and Antimitoc.When To Get Tested?: When you have abnormal results on a liver panel and/or symptoms that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to PBC
Antimitochondrial Antibody and Antimitoc.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antineutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
Antineutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
Antineutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antinuclear Antibody (ANA).Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose certain autoimmune disorders, such as lupus and Sjögren syndrome, among other types
Antinuclear Antibody (ANA).When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of certain autoimmune disorders
Antinuclear Antibody (ANA).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Antinuclear Antibody (ANA).Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, certain medications can affect ANA test results, so tell your healthcare provider about any prescription medications, nonprescription medications, or street drugs you use.

Antinuclear Antibody Screen.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose certain autoimmune disorders, such as lupus and Sjögren syndrome, among other types
Antinuclear Antibody Screen.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of certain autoimmune disorders
Antinuclear Antibody Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Antinuclear Antibody Screen.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, certain medications can affect ANA test results, so tell your healthcare provider about any prescription medications, nonprescription medications, or street drugs you use.

Antiphospholipid Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the presence of blood clots or an unexpectedly prolonged PTT (partial thromboplastin time), especially if you have had recurrent miscarriages; as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS); sometimes to help diagnose or evaluate an autoimmune disorder
Antiphospholipid Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have an unexplained prolonged PTT test; when you have had recurrent unexplained blood clots; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters
Antiphospholipid Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antistreptolysin O (ASO).Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you have had a recent strep infection with the bacteria group A Streptococcus; to help diagnose complications resulting from a strep infection such as rheumatic fever or glomerulonephritis, a form of kidney disease
Antistreptolysin O (ASO).When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as fever, chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath that suggest rheumatic fever or symptoms such as edema and dark urine that are associated with glomerulonephritis, especially when you recently may have had a group A streptococcal infection that was not diagnosed and treated appropriately
Antistreptolysin O (ASO).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antistreptolysin O Titer.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you have had a recent strep infection with the bacteria group A Streptococcus; to help diagnose complications resulting from a strep infection such as rheumatic fever or glomerulonephritis, a form of kidney disease
Antistreptolysin O Titer.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as fever, chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath that suggest rheumatic fever or symptoms such as edema and dark urine that are associated with glomerulonephritis, especially when you recently may have had a group A streptococcal infection that was not diagnosed and treated appropriately
Antistreptolysin O Titer.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antithrombin.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of recurrent inappropriate blood clotting; to help diagnose an antithrombin deficiency
Antithrombin.When To Get Tested?: A couple of months after getting a blood clot (thrombotic episode) or when you are not responding as expected to heparin anticoagulation therapy
Antithrombin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antithrombin (Activity and Antigen).Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of recurrent inappropriate blood clotting; to help diagnose an antithrombin deficiency
Antithrombin (Activity and Antigen).When To Get Tested?: A couple of months after getting a blood clot (thrombotic episode) or when you are not responding as expected to heparin anticoagulation therapy
Antithrombin (Activity and Antigen).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antithyroglobulin Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Antithyroglobulin Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Antithyroglobulin Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Antithyroid Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Antithyroid Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Antithyroid Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

APA.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the presence of blood clots or an unexpectedly prolonged PTT (partial thromboplastin time), especially if you have had recurrent miscarriages; as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS); sometimes to help diagnose or evaluate an autoimmune disorder
APA.When To Get Tested?: When you have an unexplained prolonged PTT test; when you have had recurrent unexplained blood clots; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters
APA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

APC Resistance.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an inherited gene mutation that increases your risk of developing a blood clot, including a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and/or venous thromboembolism (VTE)
APC Resistance.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot (thrombotic episode), especially when you are less than 50 years old, have recurrent DVT or VTE episodes, experienced DVT or VTE during pregnancy, had DVT at unusual sites, or have a strong family history of thrombosis
APC Resistance.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

APCA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
APCA.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
APCA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Apo A.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an adequate level of apo A-I, especially if you have a low level of high-density lipoprotein (HDL-C), and to help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
Apo A.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low value of HDL-C, high cholesterol and triglycerides (hyperlipidemia), and/or a family history of CVD; when your healthcare provider is trying to assess your risk of developing heart disease; when monitoring the effectiveness of lipid treatment and/or lifestyle changes
Apo A.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; blood from the prick of a baby's heel or finger
Apo A.Test Preparation Needed?: No test preparation is needed; however, since this test may be performed at the same time as a complete lipid profile, fasting for at least 12 hours may be required.

Apo A-I.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an adequate level of apo A-I, especially if you have a low level of high-density lipoprotein (HDL-C), and to help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
Apo A-I.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low value of HDL-C, high cholesterol and triglycerides (hyperlipidemia), and/or a family history of CVD; when your healthcare provider is trying to assess your risk of developing heart disease; when monitoring the effectiveness of lipid treatment and/or lifestyle changes
Apo A-I.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; blood from the prick of a baby's heel or finger
Apo A-I.Test Preparation Needed?: No test preparation is needed; however, since this test may be performed at the same time as a complete lipid profile, fasting for at least 12 hours may be required.

Apo B.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD); sometimes to help monitor treatment for high cholesterol or to help diagnose a rare inherited apolipoprotein B (apo B) deficiency
Apo B.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal or family history of heart disease and/or high cholesterol and triglyceride levels and your health care provider is trying to determine your risk of developing CVD; sometimes on a regular basis when you are being treated for high cholesterol; rarely when your health practitioner suspects that you have an inherited apo B deficiency
Apo B.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Apo B.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, this test is often ordered at the same time as other tests that require fasting, so you may be instructed to fast for 12 hours prior to having this test.

APOE Cardiac Risk.Why Get Tested?: APOE genotype tests are most often done as part of research protocols to help understand the role of genetic factors in cardiovascular disease. However, the testing is sometimes used in clinical settings to help confirm a diagnosis of type III hyperlipoproteinemia (also known as familial dysbetalipoproteinemia).
APOE Cardiac Risk.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that you have an inherited component to your high cholesterol and triglyceride levels or if you have yellowish lesions called xanthomas on your skin
APOE Cardiac Risk.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

APOE Genotyping, Alzheimer Disease.Why Get Tested?: APOE genotyping is not widely used. The clinical usefulness of this test is still being researched, but it may be used as an aid in the diagnosis of probable late onset Alzheimer disease (AD) in a symptomatic adult
APOE Genotyping, Alzheimer Disease.When To Get Tested?: When you have progressive symptoms of dementia and your health practitioner wants to determine the likelihood that this is due to AD
APOE Genotyping, Alzheimer Disease.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

APOE Genotyping, Cardiovascular Disease.Why Get Tested?: APOE genotype tests are most often done as part of research protocols to help understand the role of genetic factors in cardiovascular disease. However, the testing is sometimes used in clinical settings to help confirm a diagnosis of type III hyperlipoproteinemia (also known as familial dysbetalipoproteinemia).
APOE Genotyping, Cardiovascular Disease.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that you have an inherited component to your high cholesterol and triglyceride levels or if you have yellowish lesions called xanthomas on your skin
APOE Genotyping, Cardiovascular Disease.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Apolipoprotein A-I.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an adequate level of apo A-I, especially if you have a low level of high-density lipoprotein (HDL-C), and to help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
Apolipoprotein A-I.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low value of HDL-C, high cholesterol and triglycerides (hyperlipidemia), and/or a family history of CVD; when your healthcare provider is trying to assess your risk of developing heart disease; when monitoring the effectiveness of lipid treatment and/or lifestyle changes
Apolipoprotein A-I.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; blood from the prick of a baby's heel or finger
Apolipoprotein A-I.Test Preparation Needed?: No test preparation is needed; however, since this test may be performed at the same time as a complete lipid profile, fasting for at least 12 hours may be required.

Apolipoprotein B.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD); sometimes to help monitor treatment for high cholesterol or to help diagnose a rare inherited apolipoprotein B (apo B) deficiency
Apolipoprotein B.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal or family history of heart disease and/or high cholesterol and triglyceride levels and your health care provider is trying to determine your risk of developing CVD; sometimes on a regular basis when you are being treated for high cholesterol; rarely when your health practitioner suspects that you have an inherited apo B deficiency
Apolipoprotein B.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Apolipoprotein B.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, this test is often ordered at the same time as other tests that require fasting, so you may be instructed to fast for 12 hours prior to having this test.

Apolipoprotein B-100.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD); sometimes to help monitor treatment for high cholesterol or to help diagnose a rare inherited apolipoprotein B (apo B) deficiency
Apolipoprotein B-100.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal or family history of heart disease and/or high cholesterol and triglyceride levels and your health care provider is trying to determine your risk of developing CVD; sometimes on a regular basis when you are being treated for high cholesterol; rarely when your health practitioner suspects that you have an inherited apo B deficiency
Apolipoprotein B-100.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Apolipoprotein B-100.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, this test is often ordered at the same time as other tests that require fasting, so you may be instructed to fast for 12 hours prior to having this test.

Apolipoprotein E Genotyping.Why Get Tested?: APOE genotyping is not widely used. The clinical usefulness of this test is still being researched, but it may be used as an aid in the diagnosis of probable late onset Alzheimer disease (AD) in a symptomatic adult
Apolipoprotein E Genotyping.When To Get Tested?: When you have progressive symptoms of dementia and your health practitioner wants to determine the likelihood that this is due to AD
Apolipoprotein E Genotyping.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

aPTT.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode); to monitor unfractionated (standard) heparin anticoagulant therapy; as part of screening before surgery or other invasive procedure
aPTT.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained bleeding, inappropriate blood clotting, or recurrent miscarriages; when you are on standard heparin anticoagulant therapy; sometimes as part of a pre-surgical screen
aPTT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

APTT.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode); to monitor unfractionated (standard) heparin anticoagulant therapy; as part of screening before surgery or other invasive procedure
APTT.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained bleeding, inappropriate blood clotting, or recurrent miscarriages; when you are on standard heparin anticoagulant therapy; sometimes as part of a pre-surgical screen
APTT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

ARA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
ARA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
ARA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
ARA.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

Arbovirus Nucleic Acid Amplification Tes.Why Get Tested?: To determine the cause of viral meningitis or encephalitis or illness causing a fever that occurs during the warmer months of the year; to investigate the source of epidemics and track their spread
Arbovirus Nucleic Acid Amplification Tes.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting an arbovirus infection, such as fever, headache, stiff neck, muscular weakness and a diagnosis of encephalitis and/or meningitis
Arbovirus Nucleic Acid Amplification Tes.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or cerebrospinal fluid collected from a spinal tap

Arbovirus Serology IgM and IgG Antibodie.Why Get Tested?: To determine the cause of viral meningitis or encephalitis or illness causing a fever that occurs during the warmer months of the year; to investigate the source of epidemics and track their spread
Arbovirus Serology IgM and IgG Antibodie.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting an arbovirus infection, such as fever, headache, stiff neck, muscular weakness and a diagnosis of encephalitis and/or meningitis
Arbovirus Serology IgM and IgG Antibodie.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or cerebrospinal fluid collected from a spinal tap

Arbovirus Testing.Why Get Tested?: To determine the cause of viral meningitis or encephalitis or illness causing a fever that occurs during the warmer months of the year; to investigate the source of epidemics and track their spread
Arbovirus Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting an arbovirus infection, such as fever, headache, stiff neck, muscular weakness and a diagnosis of encephalitis and/or meningitis
Arbovirus Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or cerebrospinal fluid collected from a spinal tap

Arterial Blood Gas Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate lung function by measuring blood pH, oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2); to monitor treatment for lung diseases; to detect an acid-base imbalance in your blood, which may indicate a respiratory, metabolic, or kidney disorder; to evaluate the effectiveness of oxygen therapy
Arterial Blood Gas Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a respiratory problem such as difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, or rapid breathing; when you are being treated for a lung disease; when an acid-base imbalance is suspected; periodically when you have a condition that causes an acute or chronic oxygen shortage and you are on oxygen therapy; during certain surgeries to monitor your blood's O2 and CO2 levels
Arterial Blood Gas Analysis.Sample Required?: Most often a blood sample collected from an artery, usually the radial artery in your wrist; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; capillary blood from a heelstick may be used for babies.
Arterial Blood Gas Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, none; however, if you are on oxygen therapy, the O2 may either be turned off for 20 to 30 minutes before the collection for a "Room Air" test. If this cannot be tolerated, or if your healthcare practitioner wants to check your oxygen levels with the O2 on, the amount of oxygen being delivered will be recorded.

Arterial Blood Gases.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate lung function by measuring blood pH, oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2); to monitor treatment for lung diseases; to detect an acid-base imbalance in your blood, which may indicate a respiratory, metabolic, or kidney disorder; to evaluate the effectiveness of oxygen therapy
Arterial Blood Gases.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a respiratory problem such as difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, or rapid breathing; when you are being treated for a lung disease; when an acid-base imbalance is suspected; periodically when you have a condition that causes an acute or chronic oxygen shortage and you are on oxygen therapy; during certain surgeries to monitor your blood's O2 and CO2 levels
Arterial Blood Gases.Sample Required?: Most often a blood sample collected from an artery, usually the radial artery in your wrist; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; capillary blood from a heelstick may be used for babies.
Arterial Blood Gases.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, none; however, if you are on oxygen therapy, the O2 may either be turned off for 20 to 30 minutes before the collection for a "Room Air" test. If this cannot be tolerated, or if your healthcare practitioner wants to check your oxygen levels with the O2 on, the amount of oxygen being delivered will be recorded.

Arthropod-borne Virus Testing.Why Get Tested?: To determine the cause of viral meningitis or encephalitis or illness causing a fever that occurs during the warmer months of the year; to investigate the source of epidemics and track their spread
Arthropod-borne Virus Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting an arbovirus infection, such as fever, headache, stiff neck, muscular weakness and a diagnosis of encephalitis and/or meningitis
Arthropod-borne Virus Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or cerebrospinal fluid collected from a spinal tap

ARV Resistance Testing.Why Get Tested?: If you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), to determine whether the strain causing your infection is resistant or has developed resistance to one or more antiretroviral therapy (ART) drugs
ARV Resistance Testing.When To Get Tested?: When first diagnosed with HIV, immediately prior to the start of antiretroviral therapy, or when you are receiving ART but the amount of virus in your blood (HIV viral load) does not decrease or rises steadily
ARV Resistance Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ASA.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
ASA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
ASA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
ASA.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

ASLO.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you have had a recent strep infection with the bacteria group A Streptococcus; to help diagnose complications resulting from a strep infection such as rheumatic fever or glomerulonephritis, a form of kidney disease
ASLO.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as fever, chest pain, fatigue and shortness of breath that suggest rheumatic fever or symptoms such as edema and dark urine that are associated with glomerulonephritis, especially when you recently may have had a group A streptococcal infection that was not diagnosed and treated appropriately
ASLO.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ASMA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
ASMA.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
ASMA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Aspartate Aminotransferase.Why Get Tested?: To detect liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
Aspartate Aminotransferase.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to a hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel when you have a routine health exam
Aspartate Aminotransferase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST).Why Get Tested?: To detect liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST).When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to a hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel when you have a routine health exam
Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Aspartate Transaminase.Why Get Tested?: To detect liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
Aspartate Transaminase.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to a hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel when you have a routine health exam
Aspartate Transaminase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Aspirin.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
Aspirin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
Aspirin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
Aspirin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

AST.Why Get Tested?: To detect liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
AST.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to a hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel when you have a routine health exam
AST.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

AT 3.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of recurrent inappropriate blood clotting; to help diagnose an antithrombin deficiency
AT 3.When To Get Tested?: A couple of months after getting a blood clot (thrombotic episode) or when you are not responding as expected to heparin anticoagulation therapy
AT 3.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

AT III.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of recurrent inappropriate blood clotting; to help diagnose an antithrombin deficiency
AT III.When To Get Tested?: A couple of months after getting a blood clot (thrombotic episode) or when you are not responding as expected to heparin anticoagulation therapy
AT III.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Automated Immunoassays for Syphilis Anti.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Automated Immunoassays for Syphilis Anti.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Automated Immunoassays for Syphilis Anti.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

AVP.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and determine the cause of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) deficiency or excess; to investigate low blood sodium levels (hyponatremia); to distinguish between the two types of diabetes insipidus
AVP.When To Get Tested?: When you have low blood sodium or have persistent thirst, frequent urination, and dehydration
AVP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
AVP.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed for an ADH test; however, talk to your health care provider about required preparation when the ADH test is performed as part of a water deprivation ADH stimulation test or a water loading ADH suppression test.

B Vitamins.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and detect moderate to severe vitamin B deficiencies
B Vitamins.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that may be due to a B vitamin deficiency, are at risk for a deficiency, or have a condition associated with malabsorption
B Vitamins.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a random or 24-hour urine sample may also be collected.
B Vitamins.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is usually required for blood testing.

B-cell Gene Clonality Molecular Genetic.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a B-cell lymphoma; to detect and evaluate residual cancer cells
B-cell Gene Clonality Molecular Genetic.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have a B-cell lymphoma; sometimes to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment or to evaluate for recurrent disease
B-cell Gene Clonality Molecular Genetic.Sample Required?: A bone marrow or other tissue biopsy procedure is performed by a doctor or other trained specialist. Body fluid samples are obtained by inserting a needle into the body cavity and withdrawing a portion of the fluid with a syringe. Sometimes, a blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm.

B-cell Gene Rearrangement.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a B-cell lymphoma; to detect and evaluate residual cancer cells
B-cell Gene Rearrangement.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have a B-cell lymphoma; sometimes to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment or to evaluate for recurrent disease
B-cell Gene Rearrangement.Sample Required?: A bone marrow or other tissue biopsy procedure is performed by a doctor or other trained specialist. Body fluid samples are obtained by inserting a needle into the body cavity and withdrawing a portion of the fluid with a syringe. Sometimes, a blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm.

B-cell Immunoglobulin Gene Rearrangement.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a B-cell lymphoma; to detect and evaluate residual cancer cells
B-cell Immunoglobulin Gene Rearrangement.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have a B-cell lymphoma; sometimes to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment or to evaluate for recurrent disease
B-cell Immunoglobulin Gene Rearrangement.Sample Required?: A bone marrow or other tissue biopsy procedure is performed by a doctor or other trained specialist. Body fluid samples are obtained by inserting a needle into the body cavity and withdrawing a portion of the fluid with a syringe. Sometimes, a blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm.

B-type Natriuretic Peptide; N-terminal p.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and evaluate the severity of congestive heart failure (CHF)
B-type Natriuretic Peptide; N-terminal p.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of heart failure, such as shortness of breath and fatigue, or when you are being treated for CHF
B-type Natriuretic Peptide; N-terminal p.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

B2M.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the severity and prognosis of certain cancers, including multiple myeloma and some lymphomas
B2M.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with multiple myeloma or certain other cancers; sometimes to monitor disease activity and treatment
B2M.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a 24-hour urine sample; rarely a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample

BAC.Why Get Tested?: To determine if a person has consumed ethanol and to measure the amount of ethanol present
BAC.When To Get Tested?: When someone has signs and symptoms that suggest intoxication or ethanol poisoning; when a person is suspected of violating drinking-related laws, or as part of a drug testing panel
BAC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva is collected. Blood, urine, and saliva samples must be sent to a laboratory for analysis. A breath sample is analyzed immediately on site using a breathalyzer.

Bacterial and Fungal Susceptibility Test.Why Get Tested?: To determine the likelihood that a particular antibiotic or antifungal drug will be effective in stopping the growth of the bacteria or fungi causing your infection
Bacterial and Fungal Susceptibility Test.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to a positive bacterial or fungal culture; when selecting the best treatment for a bacterial or fungal infection requires laboratory testing; when your infection is not responding to treatment
Bacterial and Fungal Susceptibility Test.Sample Required?: A sample from an infected site is cultured on specialized media to recover the bacteria or fungus that is causing the infection. The method used to collect a sample from an individual depends on the type of culture performed (e.g., urine culture, blood culture, sputum culture, etc.).

Bacterial Culture, respiratory.Why Get Tested?: To detect and identify the cause of bacterial pneumonia or some other lower respiratory tract infections; to monitor the efficacy of treatment
Bacterial Culture, respiratory.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with a lower respiratory tract infection; when you have been treated for bacterial pneumonia or any other lower respiratory tract infection
Bacterial Culture, respiratory.Sample Required?: A sputum sample (deep respiratory secretions, not saliva), usually collected first thing in the morning; sometimes, depending on the infection, up to 3 sputum samples might be collected over consecutive days.
Bacterial Culture, respiratory.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to rinse your mouth out with water prior to collection and to avoid food for 1-2 hours before the sample is collected.

Bacterial Culture, stool.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an infection of your digestive tract due to the presence of disease-causing (pathogenic) bacteria
Bacterial Culture, stool.When To Get Tested?: When you have diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea and/or vomiting that is severe or lasts more than a few days
Bacterial Culture, stool.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample transported to the laboratory within 2 hours or one that has been placed in a transport medium (a collection vial containing a preservative)

Bacterial Sputum Culture.Why Get Tested?: To detect and identify the cause of bacterial pneumonia or some other lower respiratory tract infections; to monitor the efficacy of treatment
Bacterial Sputum Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with a lower respiratory tract infection; when you have been treated for bacterial pneumonia or any other lower respiratory tract infection
Bacterial Sputum Culture.Sample Required?: A sputum sample (deep respiratory secretions, not saliva), usually collected first thing in the morning; sometimes, depending on the infection, up to 3 sputum samples might be collected over consecutive days.
Bacterial Sputum Culture.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to rinse your mouth out with water prior to collection and to avoid food for 1-2 hours before the sample is collected.

Bacterial Wound Culture.Why Get Tested?: To detect and identify the bacteria causing an infection of your wound and to help guide treatment of your wound infection
Bacterial Wound Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a wound infection, such as a wound that is tender, red, swollen, draining fluid or pus, and slow to heal
Bacterial Wound Culture.Sample Required?: A sterile swab used to collect cells or pus from the site of the suspected infection; may also include aspirations of fluid from deeper wounds into a syringe and/or a tissue biopsy

BAL.Why Get Tested?: To determine if a person has consumed ethanol and to measure the amount of ethanol present
BAL.When To Get Tested?: When someone has signs and symptoms that suggest intoxication or ethanol poisoning; when a person is suspected of violating drinking-related laws, or as part of a drug testing panel
BAL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva is collected. Blood, urine, and saliva samples must be sent to a laboratory for analysis. A breath sample is analyzed immediately on site using a breathalyzer.

Basic Metabolic Panel.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about your body's metabolism, including the current status of your kidneys as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and level of blood glucose
Basic Metabolic Panel.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are hospitalized, in the emergency room
Basic Metabolic Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Basic Metabolic Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the BMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP).Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about your body's metabolism, including the current status of your kidneys as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and level of blood glucose
Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP).When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are hospitalized, in the emergency room
Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP).Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the BMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

BCGR.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a B-cell lymphoma; to detect and evaluate residual cancer cells
BCGR.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have a B-cell lymphoma; sometimes to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment or to evaluate for recurrent disease
BCGR.Sample Required?: A bone marrow or other tissue biopsy procedure is performed by a doctor or other trained specialist. Body fluid samples are obtained by inserting a needle into the body cavity and withdrawing a portion of the fluid with a syringe. Sometimes, a blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm.

BChE.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
BChE.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
BChE.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

bcr-abl Oncogene.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and a type of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
bcr-abl Oncogene.When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for CML or BCR-ABL1-positive ALL
bcr-abl Oncogene.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

BCR-ABL1.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and a type of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
BCR-ABL1.When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for CML or BCR-ABL1-positive ALL
BCR-ABL1.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

BCR-ABL1 Fusion.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and a type of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
BCR-ABL1 Fusion.When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for CML or BCR-ABL1-positive ALL
BCR-ABL1 Fusion.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

BCR/ABL.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and a type of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
BCR/ABL.When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for CML or BCR-ABL1-positive ALL
BCR/ABL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

Beta 2GP1 Ab.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or venous thromboembolism); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriage; as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
Beta 2GP1 Ab.When To Get Tested?: When you have had one or more unexplained blood clots in a vein or artery; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters
Beta 2GP1 Ab.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Beta hCG.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors
Beta hCG.When To Get Tested?: When your symptoms suggest gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors; to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment for these conditions; to monitor for recurrence
Beta hCG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein

Beta Tryptase.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose anaphylaxis, mastocytosis (too many mast cells), or mast cell activation
Beta Tryptase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as flushing, nausea, throat swelling, or low blood pressure that may be due to a life-threatening allergic reaction; when your healthcare provider suspects that you have mastocytosis or mast cell activation
Beta Tryptase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Beta Tryptase.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample soon after the beginning of symptoms can be important.

Beta-2 Glycoprotein 1 Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or venous thromboembolism); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriage; as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
Beta-2 Glycoprotein 1 Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have had one or more unexplained blood clots in a vein or artery; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters
Beta-2 Glycoprotein 1 Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Beta-2 Glycoprotein 1 Antibodies IgG, Ig.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or venous thromboembolism); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriage; as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
Beta-2 Glycoprotein 1 Antibodies IgG, Ig.When To Get Tested?: When you have had one or more unexplained blood clots in a vein or artery; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters
