Beta-2 Glycoprotein 1 Antibodies IgG, Ig.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Beta-2 Microglobulin Kidney Disease.Why Get Tested?: To help detect kidney damage and follow kidney disorders; sometimes to monitor people who are exposed to cadmium
Beta-2 Microglobulin Kidney Disease.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms and signs associated with kidney dysfunction; periodically if you work with cadmium
Beta-2 Microglobulin Kidney Disease.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

Beta-2 Microglobulin Tumor Marker.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the severity and prognosis of certain cancers, including multiple myeloma and some lymphomas
Beta-2 Microglobulin Tumor Marker.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with multiple myeloma or certain other cancers; sometimes to monitor disease activity and treatment
Beta-2 Microglobulin Tumor Marker.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a 24-hour urine sample; rarely a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample

Beta-hemolytic Strep Culture.Why Get Tested?: To screen a pregnant woman for the presence of group B streptococcus (GBS) in her vagina or rectum to determine the risk that she will pass the bacteria on to her newborn during labor and delivery, possibly resulting in a serious infection in her newborn called early-onset GBS
Beta-hemolytic Strep Culture.When To Get Tested?: When a woman is between 35 and 37 weeks of pregnancy or has preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes
Beta-hemolytic Strep Culture.Sample Required?: A swab obtained from the vagina and rectum of a pregnant woman; a urine sample collected anytime during pregnancy may be used to detect significant numbers of GBS.

Beta-hydroxybutyrate.Why Get Tested?: To determine the amount of ketones (ketone bodies, acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood to help diagnose a life-threatening problem called diabetic ketoacidosis
Beta-hydroxybutyrate.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with ketoacidosis, such as increased urination, excessive thirst, dehydration, rapid breathing, and shortness of breath
Beta-hydroxybutyrate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

Beta-hydroxybutyric Acid.Why Get Tested?: To determine the amount of ketones (ketone bodies, acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood to help diagnose a life-threatening problem called diabetic ketoacidosis
Beta-hydroxybutyric Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with ketoacidosis, such as increased urination, excessive thirst, dehydration, rapid breathing, and shortness of breath
Beta-hydroxybutyric Acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

Beta2 Microglobulin, Serum or Urine.Why Get Tested?: To help detect kidney damage and follow kidney disorders; sometimes to monitor people who are exposed to cadmium
Beta2 Microglobulin, Serum or Urine.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms and signs associated with kidney dysfunction; periodically if you work with cadmium
Beta2 Microglobulin, Serum or Urine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

Beta2 Microglobulin, Serum, Urine, or CS.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the severity and prognosis of certain cancers, including multiple myeloma and some lymphomas
Beta2 Microglobulin, Serum, Urine, or CS.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with multiple myeloma or certain other cancers; sometimes to monitor disease activity and treatment
Beta2 Microglobulin, Serum, Urine, or CS.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a 24-hour urine sample; rarely a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample

Bicarb.Why Get Tested?: As part of an electrolyte panel to identify or monitor an electrolyte imbalance or acid-base (pH) imbalance
Bicarb.When To Get Tested?: During a routine physical or as recommended by your healthcare practitioner if you are experiencing symptoms such as weakness, confusion, prolonged vomiting, or breathing problems that could indicate an electrolyte imbalance or an acid-base imbalance (commonly described as acidosis or alkalosis)
Bicarb.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Bicarbonate.Why Get Tested?: As part of an electrolyte panel to identify or monitor an electrolyte imbalance or acid-base (pH) imbalance
Bicarbonate.When To Get Tested?: During a routine physical or as recommended by your healthcare practitioner if you are experiencing symptoms such as weakness, confusion, prolonged vomiting, or breathing problems that could indicate an electrolyte imbalance or an acid-base imbalance (commonly described as acidosis or alkalosis)
Bicarbonate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Bicarbonate (Total CO2).Why Get Tested?: As part of an electrolyte panel to identify or monitor an electrolyte imbalance or acid-base (pH) imbalance
Bicarbonate (Total CO2).When To Get Tested?: During a routine physical or as recommended by your healthcare practitioner if you are experiencing symptoms such as weakness, confusion, prolonged vomiting, or breathing problems that could indicate an electrolyte imbalance or an acid-base imbalance (commonly described as acidosis or alkalosis)
Bicarbonate (Total CO2).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Bilirubin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor liver disorders or hemolytic anemia; to monitor neonatal jaundice
Bilirubin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of liver damage, liver disease, bile duct blockage, hemolytic anemia, or a liver-related metabolic problem, or if a newborn has jaundice
Bilirubin.Sample Required?: In adults, a blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm; in newborns, a blood sample from a heelstick; non-invasive technology is available in some healthcare facilities that will measure bilirubin by using an instrument placed on the skin (transcutaneous bilirubin meter)
Bilirubin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for several hours before the test; fasting requirements vary by laboratory; ask your lab or healthcare provider for instructions.

Bilirubin - blood.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor liver disorders or hemolytic anemia; to monitor neonatal jaundice
Bilirubin - blood.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of liver damage, liver disease, bile duct blockage, hemolytic anemia, or a liver-related metabolic problem, or if a newborn has jaundice
Bilirubin - blood.Sample Required?: In adults, a blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm; in newborns, a blood sample from a heelstick; non-invasive technology is available in some healthcare facilities that will measure bilirubin by using an instrument placed on the skin (transcutaneous bilirubin meter)
Bilirubin - blood.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for several hours before the test; fasting requirements vary by laboratory; ask your lab or healthcare provider for instructions.

Bioavailable Testosterone.Why Get Tested?: To detect an abnormal testosterone level in males and females; in males, to help diagnose the cause of erectile dysfunction or the inability of your partner to get pregnant (infertility); in females, to help diagnose the cause of masculine physical features (virilization), infertility, or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS); in children, to help determine the cause of genitals that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) or delayed or early puberty
Bioavailable Testosterone.When To Get Tested?:
For males, when you may be infertile or are unable to get or maintain an erection; when you are a boy with either early or delayed sexual maturity (puberty) 
For females, when you have male traits, such as a low voice or excessive body hair (hirsutism), when you have abnormal uterine bleeding, do not menstruate (amenorrhea), or are infertile
Bioavailable Testosterone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a morning sample is preferred.

Biochemical Markers of Bone Remodeling.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Biochemical Markers of Bone Remodeling.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Biochemical Markers of Bone Remodeling.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Biochemical Markers of Bone Remodeling.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

biotin (B7).Why Get Tested?: To screen for and detect moderate to severe vitamin B deficiencies
biotin (B7).When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that may be due to a B vitamin deficiency, are at risk for a deficiency, or have a condition associated with malabsorption
biotin (B7).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a random or 24-hour urine sample may also be collected.
biotin (B7).Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is usually required for blood testing.

Bismuth subsalicylate.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
Bismuth subsalicylate.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
Bismuth subsalicylate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
Bismuth subsalicylate.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

BLL.Why Get Tested?: To screen for possible excessive exposure to lead
BLL.When To Get Tested?: As indicated by a child lead screening program or physician preference, such as at 1 and 2 years of age; children considered to be at risk may need additional testing from 18 months to 6 years of age; when your occupation or hobby may expose you or your family to lead; when you have symptoms suggesting lead poisoning
BLL.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick or heelstick (for infants)

Blood Alcohol Content.Why Get Tested?: To determine if a person has consumed ethanol and to measure the amount of ethanol present
Blood Alcohol Content.When To Get Tested?: When someone has signs and symptoms that suggest intoxication or ethanol poisoning; when a person is suspected of violating drinking-related laws, or as part of a drug testing panel
Blood Alcohol Content.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva is collected. Blood, urine, and saliva samples must be sent to a laboratory for analysis. A breath sample is analyzed immediately on site using a breathalyzer.

Blood Alcohol Level.Why Get Tested?: To determine if a person has consumed ethanol and to measure the amount of ethanol present
Blood Alcohol Level.When To Get Tested?: When someone has signs and symptoms that suggest intoxication or ethanol poisoning; when a person is suspected of violating drinking-related laws, or as part of a drug testing panel
Blood Alcohol Level.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva is collected. Blood, urine, and saliva samples must be sent to a laboratory for analysis. A breath sample is analyzed immediately on site using a breathalyzer.

Blood Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To screen for risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
Blood Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a regular health exam with a lipid profile when no risk factors for heart disease are present; adults should be tested once every four to six years; children, teens, and young adults should be tested once between the ages of 9 and 11 and then again between the ages of 17 and 21.
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
Blood Cholesterol.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample is collected from a vein in the arm. Sometimes cholesterol is measured using a drop of blood collected by puncturing the skin on a finger. A fingerstick sample is typically used when cholesterol is being measured on a portable testing device, for example, at a health fair.
Blood Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: Cholesterol tests typically require fasting for 9-12 hours before the test; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

Blood Clotting Factors.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether levels of one or more of your coagulation factors are increased, normal, or decreased
Blood Clotting Factors.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding, abnormal results on coagulation screening tests such as prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT), or have a relative with a hereditary coagulation factor deficiency; you may be tested when your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor the severity of a factor deficiency and/or the effectiveness of treatment.
Blood Clotting Factors.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Blood Copper.Why Get Tested?: To measure the amount of copper in the blood, urine, or liver tissue; to help diagnose and monitor Wilson disease; sometimes to identify copper deficiency or excess
Blood Copper.When To Get Tested?: When you have jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, behavioral changes, tremors, or other symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to Wilson disease or, rarely, to copper deficiency or excess; at intervals when you are being treated for a copper-related condition
Blood Copper.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a liver biopsy sample

Blood Creatinine.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor treatment for kidney disease
Blood Creatinine.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of a comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when your have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or damage or when you have a condition that may affect your kidneys and/or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at intervals to monitor treatment for kidney disease or kidney function while on certain medications
Blood Creatinine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample
Blood Creatinine.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Blood Culture.Why Get Tested?: To check for the presence of a systemic infection; to detect and identify bacteria or yeast in the blood
Blood Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of sepsis, which may include fever, chills, fatigue, rapid breathing and/or heart rate, and/or an elevated white blood cell count
Blood Culture.Sample Required?: Two or more blood samples drawn from separate venipuncture sites, typically from different veins in your arms

Blood Culture (bacterial, fungal and/or.Why Get Tested?: To check for the presence of a systemic infection; to detect and identify bacteria or yeast in the blood
Blood Culture (bacterial, fungal and/or.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of sepsis, which may include fever, chills, fatigue, rapid breathing and/or heart rate, and/or an elevated white blood cell count
Blood Culture (bacterial, fungal and/or.Sample Required?: Two or more blood samples drawn from separate venipuncture sites, typically from different veins in your arms

Blood Differential.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of abnormal results on a white blood cell (WBC) count; to help diagnose and/or monitor an illness affecting your immune system, such as an infection or inflammatory condition, or cancers that affect your white blood cells, such as leukemia
Blood Differential.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when results of a CBC fall outside the reference range; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting white blood cells, such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs, such as chemotherapy
Blood Differential.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (infants)

Blood Film.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets, to distinguish between the different types of WBCs, and to determine their relative percentages in the blood; to help detect, diagnose, and/or monitor a range of deficiencies, diseases, and disorders involving blood cell production, function, and lifespan
Blood Film.When To Get Tested?: When complete blood count (CBC) and/or automated WBC differential results are abnormal or when you have signs and symptoms that a healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a condition affecting your blood cells
Blood Film.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by pricking a finger or, in the case of an infant, a heelstick

Blood Gases.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate lung function by measuring blood pH, oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2); to monitor treatment for lung diseases; to detect an acid-base imbalance in your blood, which may indicate a respiratory, metabolic, or kidney disorder; to evaluate the effectiveness of oxygen therapy
Blood Gases.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a respiratory problem such as difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, or rapid breathing; when you are being treated for a lung disease; when an acid-base imbalance is suspected; periodically when you have a condition that causes an acute or chronic oxygen shortage and you are on oxygen therapy; during certain surgeries to monitor your blood's O2 and CO2 levels
Blood Gases.Sample Required?: Most often a blood sample collected from an artery, usually the radial artery in your wrist; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; capillary blood from a heelstick may be used for babies.
Blood Gases.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, none; however, if you are on oxygen therapy, the O2 may either be turned off for 20 to 30 minutes before the collection for a "Room Air" test. If this cannot be tolerated, or if your healthcare practitioner wants to check your oxygen levels with the O2 on, the amount of oxygen being delivered will be recorded.

Blood Glucose.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
Blood Glucose.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
Blood Glucose.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
Blood Glucose.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Blood Glucose; Urine Glucose.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
Blood Glucose; Urine Glucose.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
Blood Glucose; Urine Glucose.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
Blood Glucose; Urine Glucose.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Blood Group.Why Get Tested?: To determine your ABO blood group and Rh type
Blood Group.When To Get Tested?: When you need a transfusion of blood or blood components; when you donate blood at a collection facility or donate an organ, tissue, or bone marrow for transplantation; before or during a woman's pregnancy to determine the risk of Rh incompatibility with the fetus
Blood Group.Sample Required?: A sample of blood is drawn from a vein or from the tip of the finger (fingerstick). In newborns, blood from the umbilical cord or a small amount of blood from a heelstick may be used for testing.

Blood Ketones.Why Get Tested?: To determine the amount of ketones (ketone bodies, acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood to help diagnose a life-threatening problem called diabetic ketoacidosis
Blood Ketones.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with ketoacidosis, such as increased urination, excessive thirst, dehydration, rapid breathing, and shortness of breath
Blood Ketones.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

Blood Lead Level.Why Get Tested?: To screen for possible excessive exposure to lead
Blood Lead Level.When To Get Tested?: As indicated by a child lead screening program or physician preference, such as at 1 and 2 years of age; children considered to be at risk may need additional testing from 18 months to 6 years of age; when your occupation or hobby may expose you or your family to lead; when you have symptoms suggesting lead poisoning
Blood Lead Level.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick or heelstick (for infants)

Blood Lead Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for possible excessive exposure to lead
Blood Lead Test.When To Get Tested?: As indicated by a child lead screening program or physician preference, such as at 1 and 2 years of age; children considered to be at risk may need additional testing from 18 months to 6 years of age; when your occupation or hobby may expose you or your family to lead; when you have symptoms suggesting lead poisoning
Blood Lead Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick or heelstick (for infants)

Blood Smear.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets, to distinguish between the different types of WBCs, and to determine their relative percentages in the blood; to help detect, diagnose, and/or monitor a range of deficiencies, diseases, and disorders involving blood cell production, function, and lifespan
Blood Smear.When To Get Tested?: When complete blood count (CBC) and/or automated WBC differential results are abnormal or when you have signs and symptoms that a healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a condition affecting your blood cells
Blood Smear.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by pricking a finger or, in the case of an infant, a heelstick

Blood Sugar.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
Blood Sugar.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
Blood Sugar.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
Blood Sugar.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Blood Typing.Why Get Tested?: To determine your ABO blood group and Rh type
Blood Typing.When To Get Tested?: When you need a transfusion of blood or blood components; when you donate blood at a collection facility or donate an organ, tissue, or bone marrow for transplantation; before or during a woman's pregnancy to determine the risk of Rh incompatibility with the fetus
Blood Typing.Sample Required?: A sample of blood is drawn from a vein or from the tip of the finger (fingerstick). In newborns, blood from the umbilical cord or a small amount of blood from a heelstick may be used for testing.

Blood Urea Nitrogen.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor the effectiveness of dialysis and other treatments related to kidney disease or damage
Blood Urea Nitrogen.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or you have a condition that may cause or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at regular intervals when you are being treated for kidney disease or damage
Blood Urea Nitrogen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN).Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor the effectiveness of dialysis and other treatments related to kidney disease or damage
Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN).When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or you have a condition that may cause or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at regular intervals when you are being treated for kidney disease or damage
Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

BMP.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about your body's metabolism, including the current status of your kidneys as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and level of blood glucose
BMP.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are hospitalized, in the emergency room
BMP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
BMP.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the BMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

BNP and NT-proBNP.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and evaluate the severity of congestive heart failure (CHF)
BNP and NT-proBNP.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of heart failure, such as shortness of breath and fatigue, or when you are being treated for CHF
BNP and NT-proBNP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Bone Formation Markers.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Bone Formation Markers.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Bone Formation Markers.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Bone Formation Markers.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Bone Markers.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Bone Markers.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Bone Markers.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Bone Markers.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate or diagnose a disease or condition affecting the bone marrow or blood cell production; sometimes for staging of a lymphoma or solid tumor; to measure response to treatment for a previously diagnosed condition like leukemia
Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy.When To Get Tested?: When you are anemic without an obvious cause; when you have or are suspected of having a blood-related disorder or cancer that may be affecting blood cell production; sometimes when a healthcare practitioner is investigating a fever of unknown origin, especially when you have a weakened immune system (immunocompromised)
Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy.Sample Required?: A bone marrow sample collected primarily from the hip bone (pelvis)

Bone Marrow Examination.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate or diagnose a disease or condition affecting the bone marrow or blood cell production; sometimes for staging of a lymphoma or solid tumor; to measure response to treatment for a previously diagnosed condition like leukemia
Bone Marrow Examination.When To Get Tested?: When you are anemic without an obvious cause; when you have or are suspected of having a blood-related disorder or cancer that may be affecting blood cell production; sometimes when a healthcare practitioner is investigating a fever of unknown origin, especially when you have a weakened immune system (immunocompromised)
Bone Marrow Examination.Sample Required?: A bone marrow sample collected primarily from the hip bone (pelvis)

Bone Resorption Markers.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Bone Resorption Markers.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Bone Resorption Markers.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Bone Resorption Markers.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Bone specific ALP.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor treatment for a liver or bone disorder
Bone specific ALP.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine liver panel or when you have symptoms of a liver or bone disorder
Bone specific ALP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Bone specific ALP.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting overnight preferred but not required

Bone Turnover Tests.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Bone Turnover Tests.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Bone Turnover Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Bone Turnover Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Bone-specific Alkaline Phosphatase.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Bone-specific Alkaline Phosphatase.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Bone-specific Alkaline Phosphatase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Bone-specific Alkaline Phosphatase.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Bordetella pertussis Culture, PCR, Antib.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose a Bordetella pertussis infection, commonly known as whooping cough
Bordetella pertussis Culture, PCR, Antib.When To Get Tested?: When you have persistent spasms or fits of coughing (paroxysms) that the healthcare practitioner suspects is due to pertussis (whooping cough); when you have symptoms of a cold and have been exposed to someone with pertussis
Bordetella pertussis Culture, PCR, Antib.Sample Required?: A nasopharyngeal (NP) swab or a nasal aspirate; occasionally, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Borrelia Antibodies, IgM/IgG; Borrelia D.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have been infected with the bacteria that cause Lyme disease
Borrelia Antibodies, IgM/IgG; Borrelia D.When To Get Tested?: When you show symptoms of Lyme disease, especially when you live in or have recently visited an area where black-legged ticks are endemic and suspect that you have been bitten by a tick
Borrelia Antibodies, IgM/IgG; Borrelia D.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample

Brain Natriuretic Peptide.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and evaluate the severity of congestive heart failure (CHF)
Brain Natriuretic Peptide.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of heart failure, such as shortness of breath and fatigue, or when you are being treated for CHF
Brain Natriuretic Peptide.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

BRCA.Why Get Tested?: To assess the risk of developing breast or ovarian cancer associated with hereditary mutations in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes
BRCA.When To Get Tested?: When your personal or family history suggests the presence of a harmful BRCA mutation, such as you or someone in your family has had breast cancer before the age of 50 or ovarian cancer at any age, is a male with breast cancer, or when a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation has been identified in a family member
BRCA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or an oral rinse that collects cells from your mouth
BRCA.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but genetic counseling is strongly recommended to confirm that you meet the testing criteria. If the sample is a saliva-based specimen, it is recommended that you not eat, drink, or chew gum for at least an hour prior to your testing appointment. Furthermore, kissing should also be avoided immediately prior to testing.

BRCA Gene Mutation Testing.Why Get Tested?: To assess the risk of developing breast or ovarian cancer associated with hereditary mutations in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes
BRCA Gene Mutation Testing.When To Get Tested?: When your personal or family history suggests the presence of a harmful BRCA mutation, such as you or someone in your family has had breast cancer before the age of 50 or ovarian cancer at any age, is a male with breast cancer, or when a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation has been identified in a family member
BRCA Gene Mutation Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or an oral rinse that collects cells from your mouth
BRCA Gene Mutation Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but genetic counseling is strongly recommended to confirm that you meet the testing criteria. If the sample is a saliva-based specimen, it is recommended that you not eat, drink, or chew gum for at least an hour prior to your testing appointment. Furthermore, kissing should also be avoided immediately prior to testing.

Breast Cancer Gene 1; Breast Cancer Gene.Why Get Tested?: To assess the risk of developing breast or ovarian cancer associated with hereditary mutations in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes
Breast Cancer Gene 1; Breast Cancer Gene.When To Get Tested?: When your personal or family history suggests the presence of a harmful BRCA mutation, such as you or someone in your family has had breast cancer before the age of 50 or ovarian cancer at any age, is a male with breast cancer, or when a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation has been identified in a family member
Breast Cancer Gene 1; Breast Cancer Gene.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or an oral rinse that collects cells from your mouth
Breast Cancer Gene 1; Breast Cancer Gene.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but genetic counseling is strongly recommended to confirm that you meet the testing criteria. If the sample is a saliva-based specimen, it is recommended that you not eat, drink, or chew gum for at least an hour prior to your testing appointment. Furthermore, kissing should also be avoided immediately prior to testing.

Breast Cancer Susceptibility Genes 1 and.Why Get Tested?: To assess the risk of developing breast or ovarian cancer associated with hereditary mutations in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes
Breast Cancer Susceptibility Genes 1 and.When To Get Tested?: When your personal or family history suggests the presence of a harmful BRCA mutation, such as you or someone in your family has had breast cancer before the age of 50 or ovarian cancer at any age, is a male with breast cancer, or when a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation has been identified in a family member
Breast Cancer Susceptibility Genes 1 and.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or an oral rinse that collects cells from your mouth
Breast Cancer Susceptibility Genes 1 and.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but genetic counseling is strongly recommended to confirm that you meet the testing criteria. If the sample is a saliva-based specimen, it is recommended that you not eat, drink, or chew gum for at least an hour prior to your testing appointment. Furthermore, kissing should also be avoided immediately prior to testing.

BUN.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor the effectiveness of dialysis and other treatments related to kidney disease or damage
BUN.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or you have a condition that may cause or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at regular intervals when you are being treated for kidney disease or damage
BUN.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

C & S.Why Get Tested?: To determine the likelihood that a particular antibiotic or antifungal drug will be effective in stopping the growth of the bacteria or fungi causing your infection
C & S.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to a positive bacterial or fungal culture; when selecting the best treatment for a bacterial or fungal infection requires laboratory testing; when your infection is not responding to treatment
C & S.Sample Required?: A sample from an infected site is cultured on specialized media to recover the bacteria or fungus that is causing the infection. The method used to collect a sample from an individual depends on the type of culture performed (e.g., urine culture, blood culture, sputum culture, etc.).

C diff antigen.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of an infection caused by toxin-producing Clostridium difficile bacteria
C diff antigen.When To Get Tested?: When a person has mild, moderate, or severe diarrhea that persists for several days with abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and fever, following antibiotic therapy
C diff antigen.Sample Required?: A fresh or refrigerated liquid or unformed stool sample that has not been contaminated with urine or water

c-erbB-2.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether a tumor is positive for particular HER2 (ERBB2) mutations, which helps to guide treatment and predict the course of the disease (prognosis); sometimes to monitor treatment and for cancer recurrence
c-erbB-2.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or you had an invasive breast cancer that was treated but the tumor reoccurs or spreads (metastasizes), or when you have been diagnosed with certain types of stomach and esophagus cancer that are inoperable, locally advanced, recurrent, or metastatic
c-erbB-2.Sample Required?: A sample of tumor tissue is obtained by doing a fine needle aspiration, needle biopsy, or surgical biopsy (a tumor removed surgically)
c-erbB-2.Test Preparation Needed?: Before a biopsy, the physician who will obtain the sample of tumor tissue will provide instructions.

C-peptide.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate insulin production by the beta cells in the pancreas or to help determine the cause of low blood glucose (hypoglycemia)
C-peptide.When To Get Tested?: When you have diabetes and your health practitioner wants to determine if you are producing enough of your own insulin or if it is time to supplement oral medication with insulin injections or an insulin pump; when your health practitioner suspects that you have insulin resistance; when you have documented hypoglycemia
C-peptide.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and sometimes a 24-hour urine sample
C-peptide.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting for 8 to 10 hours before blood testing is usually required.

C-Reactive Protein.Why Get Tested?: To identify the presence of inflammation and to monitor response to treatment for an inflammatory disorder
C-Reactive Protein.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that you have an acute condition causing inflammation, such as a serious bacterial or fungal infection or when you are suffering from an inflammatory disorder such as arthritis, an autoimmune disorder, or inflammatory bowel disease
C-Reactive Protein.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm

C-Reactive Protein (CRP).Why Get Tested?: To identify the presence of inflammation and to monitor response to treatment for an inflammatory disorder
C-Reactive Protein (CRP).When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that you have an acute condition causing inflammation, such as a serious bacterial or fungal infection or when you are suffering from an inflammatory disorder such as arthritis, an autoimmune disorder, or inflammatory bowel disease
C-Reactive Protein (CRP).Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm

C-telopeptide.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
C-telopeptide.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
C-telopeptide.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
C-telopeptide.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

C. difficile culture, toxin A and B, cyt.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of an infection caused by toxin-producing Clostridium difficile bacteria
C. difficile culture, toxin A and B, cyt.When To Get Tested?: When a person has mild, moderate, or severe diarrhea that persists for several days with abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and fever, following antibiotic therapy
C. difficile culture, toxin A and B, cyt.Sample Required?: A fresh or refrigerated liquid or unformed stool sample that has not been contaminated with urine or water

C1.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
C1.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
C1.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

C1q.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
C1q.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
C1q.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

C2.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
C2.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
C2.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

C3.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
C3.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
C3.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

C4.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
C4.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
C4.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CA 125 Tumor Marker.Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment for ovarian cancer or to detect recurrence; sometimes to evaluate a lump located in the pelvic area (pelvic mass); not recommended for screening asymptomatic women but sometimes ordered to help detect early ovarian cancer in those identified as being at high risk
CA 125 Tumor Marker.When To Get Tested?: Before starting therapy for ovarian cancer and at intervals during and after treatment; sometimes when you have a pelvic mass or are at a high risk for developing ovarian cancer
CA 125 Tumor Marker.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CA 15-3.Why Get Tested?: To monitor the response to treatment of invasive breast cancer and to help watch for recurrence of the disease
CA 15-3.When To Get Tested?: When you have been or are being treated for invasive breast cancer
CA 15-3.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CA 19-9.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to monitor response to pancreatic cancer treatment and to watch for recurrence; sometimes to aid in the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer
CA 19-9.When To Get Tested?: During and/or following pancreatic cancer treatment
CA 19-9.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes samples of other types of body fluids

CA-125.Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment for ovarian cancer or to detect recurrence; sometimes to evaluate a lump located in the pelvic area (pelvic mass); not recommended for screening asymptomatic women but sometimes ordered to help detect early ovarian cancer in those identified as being at high risk
CA-125.When To Get Tested?: Before starting therapy for ovarian cancer and at intervals during and after treatment; sometimes when you have a pelvic mass or are at a high risk for developing ovarian cancer
CA-125.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CA-Breast.Why Get Tested?: To monitor the response to treatment of invasive breast cancer and to help watch for recurrence of the disease
CA-Breast.When To Get Tested?: When you have been or are being treated for invasive breast cancer
CA-Breast.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CA-GI.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to monitor response to pancreatic cancer treatment and to watch for recurrence; sometimes to aid in the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer
CA-GI.When To Get Tested?: During and/or following pancreatic cancer treatment
CA-GI.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes samples of other types of body fluids

Calcidiol (25-hydroxyvitamin D).Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have a vitamin D deficiency; if you are receiving vitamin D supplementation, to determine if it is adequate
Calcidiol (25-hydroxyvitamin D).When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal calcium, phosphorus, and/or parathyroid hormone level; when you have evidence of bone disease or bone weakness; when you are at high risk of deficiency or a healthcare practitioner suspects that you might have a vitamin D deficiency; prior to starting drug treatment for osteoporosis; periodically to monitor treatment of vitamin D deficiency
Calcidiol (25-hydroxyvitamin D).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Calcifidiol (25-hydroxy-vitamin D).Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have a vitamin D deficiency; if you are receiving vitamin D supplementation, to determine if it is adequate
Calcifidiol (25-hydroxy-vitamin D).When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal calcium, phosphorus, and/or parathyroid hormone level; when you have evidence of bone disease or bone weakness; when you are at high risk of deficiency or a healthcare practitioner suspects that you might have a vitamin D deficiency; prior to starting drug treatment for osteoporosis; periodically to monitor treatment of vitamin D deficiency
Calcifidiol (25-hydroxy-vitamin D).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Calcitonin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor C-cell hyperplasia and medullary thyroid cancer; to screen those at risk for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2)
Calcitonin.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have or when you are being treated for medullary thyroid cancer, or when a family member has medullary thyroid cancer or MEN 2
Calcitonin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Calcitonin.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting may be required; follow instructions provided by your healthcare practitioner or the laboratory.

Calcitriol (1,25 dihydroxy-vitamin D).Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have a vitamin D deficiency; if you are receiving vitamin D supplementation, to determine if it is adequate
Calcitriol (1,25 dihydroxy-vitamin D).When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal calcium, phosphorus, and/or parathyroid hormone level; when you have evidence of bone disease or bone weakness; when you are at high risk of deficiency or a healthcare practitioner suspects that you might have a vitamin D deficiency; prior to starting drug treatment for osteoporosis; periodically to monitor treatment of vitamin D deficiency
Calcitriol (1,25 dihydroxy-vitamin D).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Calcium.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, diagnose, and monitor a range of medical conditions
Calcium.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine metabolic panel; when you have symptoms of a disorder, or known presence of one, affecting your kidneys, bones, thyroid, parathyroid, or nerves or when symptoms of significantly increased or decreased calcium concentrations are present; when someone is critically ill, to monitor ionized calcium levels; when someone has certain types of cancer; when someone is being treated for abnormal calcium levels, to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment
Calcium.Sample Required?: A blood sample is taken by needle from a vein in the arm. If a urine collection is required, a 24-hour urine sample or a timed collection of a shorter duration is obtained. Sometimes a random urine collection may be used, although a timed collection is preferred.
Calcium.Test Preparation Needed?: Current practices do not require fasting. You may be instructed to stop taking certain medications, such as lithium, antacids, diuretics, and vitamin D supplements, among others, to ensure the most accurate test results.

Calcofluor White Stain.Why Get Tested?: To detect a fungal infection, to determine which specific fungus or fungi are present, and to help guide treatment
Calcofluor White Stain.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a skin, lung, or systemic fungal infection; sometimes after treatment to monitor its effectiveness
Calcofluor White Stain.Sample Required?: The sample collected depends upon the suspected location(s) of the infection. Some examples include: scrapings of the skin, nail and hair samples, body fluids, blood, and/or a tissue biopsy.

Calculated Glomerular Filtration Rate.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
Calculated Glomerular Filtration Rate.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
Calculated Glomerular Filtration Rate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
Calculated Glomerular Filtration Rate.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Calprotectin.Why Get Tested?: To detect inflammation in the intestines; to distinguish between inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and non-inflammatory bowel conditions; to monitor IBD activity
Calprotectin.When To Get Tested?: When you have bloody or watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, with or without fever, lasting more than a few days
Calprotectin.Sample Required?: A stool sample collected in a clean container

CALR Gene Mutation Exon 9.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose bone marrow disorders known as myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), in which the bone marrow produces too many of one or more types of blood cells
CALR Gene Mutation Exon 9.When To Get Tested?: When you have abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have a bone marrow disorder, especially essential thrombocythemia (ET) or primary myelofibrosis (PMF)
CALR Gene Mutation Exon 9.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a sample of bone marrow

CALR Mutation.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose bone marrow disorders known as myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), in which the bone marrow produces too many of one or more types of blood cells
CALR Mutation.When To Get Tested?: When you have abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have a bone marrow disorder, especially essential thrombocythemia (ET) or primary myelofibrosis (PMF)
CALR Mutation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a sample of bone marrow

Calreticulin Mutation Analysis (myelopro.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose bone marrow disorders known as myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), in which the bone marrow produces too many of one or more types of blood cells
Calreticulin Mutation Analysis (myelopro.When To Get Tested?: When you have abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have a bone marrow disorder, especially essential thrombocythemia (ET) or primary myelofibrosis (PMF)
Calreticulin Mutation Analysis (myelopro.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a sample of bone marrow

cANCA.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
cANCA.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
cANCA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cancer Antigen 125.Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment for ovarian cancer or to detect recurrence; sometimes to evaluate a lump located in the pelvic area (pelvic mass); not recommended for screening asymptomatic women but sometimes ordered to help detect early ovarian cancer in those identified as being at high risk
Cancer Antigen 125.When To Get Tested?: Before starting therapy for ovarian cancer and at intervals during and after treatment; sometimes when you have a pelvic mass or are at a high risk for developing ovarian cancer
Cancer Antigen 125.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cancer Antigen 15-3.Why Get Tested?: To monitor the response to treatment of invasive breast cancer and to help watch for recurrence of the disease
Cancer Antigen 15-3.When To Get Tested?: When you have been or are being treated for invasive breast cancer
Cancer Antigen 15-3.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cancer Antigen 19-9.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to monitor response to pancreatic cancer treatment and to watch for recurrence; sometimes to aid in the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer
Cancer Antigen 19-9.When To Get Tested?: During and/or following pancreatic cancer treatment
Cancer Antigen 19-9.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes samples of other types of body fluids

Cancer Antigen-Breast.Why Get Tested?: To monitor the response to treatment of invasive breast cancer and to help watch for recurrence of the disease
Cancer Antigen-Breast.When To Get Tested?: When you have been or are being treated for invasive breast cancer
Cancer Antigen-Breast.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cancer Antigen-GI.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to monitor response to pancreatic cancer treatment and to watch for recurrence; sometimes to aid in the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer
Cancer Antigen-GI.When To Get Tested?: During and/or following pancreatic cancer treatment
Cancer Antigen-GI.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes samples of other types of body fluids

Cannabinoid or cannabis testing.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and/or confirm marijuana use
As part of a panel of tests to help detect drug use, impairment, intoxication and/or overdose
To monitor for drug abuse
To monitor compliance with prescription drugs
Cannabinoid or cannabis testing.When To Get Tested?:
During medical screening, such as upon admission to the emergency room or when pregnant or after giving birth
When being treated for chronic pain or for cancer
During random drug screening in the workplace or during the hiring process
As part of a drug rehabilitation program or upon court order
To test for impairment, such as during a traffic stop, or after an accident
Cannabinoid or cannabis testing.Sample Required?:
A random urine specimen is the most commonly tested sample for marijuana. Urine is collected in a clean, sterile container.
Sometimes, saliva is collected in an absorbent pad or swab placed between the lower cheek and gums. This technique is increasingly used in workplace marijuana testing.
Other types of samples that are used less frequently include blood and hair. For newborns, samples may include the umbilical cord or meconium, a newborn's first bowel movement. For more information on these, see Common Questions below.
Cannabinoid or cannabis testing.Test Preparation Needed?:
Prior to testing, declare any prescriptions you are currently taking, including those for medical marijuana.
If saliva is to be collected for testing, you typically should not put anything in your mouth for the 10 minutes prior to the collection of the sample. Follow the directions provided with the sample container.

Carbamazepine.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of carbamazepine in the blood to establish an appropriate dose and maintain a therapeutic level
Carbamazepine.When To Get Tested?: At regular intervals to monitor the drug's level; when indicated to detect low or excessive (potentially toxic) concentrations
Carbamazepine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to monitor response to pancreatic cancer treatment and to watch for recurrence; sometimes to aid in the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer
Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9.When To Get Tested?: During and/or following pancreatic cancer treatment
Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes samples of other types of body fluids

Carbon Dioxide Content.Why Get Tested?: As part of an electrolyte panel to identify or monitor an electrolyte imbalance or acid-base (pH) imbalance
Carbon Dioxide Content.When To Get Tested?: During a routine physical or as recommended by your healthcare practitioner if you are experiencing symptoms such as weakness, confusion, prolonged vomiting, or breathing problems that could indicate an electrolyte imbalance or an acid-base imbalance (commonly described as acidosis or alkalosis)
Carbon Dioxide Content.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Carcinoembryonic Antigen.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to monitor cancer treatment, including response to therapy and recurrence; as an indicator of the amount of cancer or size of tumor present (tumor burden) and to assist in cancer staging; occasionally as follow up to a positive screening test for cancer, to compare whether the level falls to normal (indicating that the cancer was all likely removed) after treatment for the cancer
Carcinoembryonic Antigen.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with colon, pancreas, breast, lung, ovarian, medullary thyroid or other cancer prior to starting cancer treatment and then, if elevated, at intervals during and after therapy; occasionally when cancer is suspected but not confirmed – to aid in its detection
Carcinoembryonic Antigen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; occasionally another body fluid such as fluid from the abdomen (peritoneal), the chest (pleural), or from the spinal cord (cerebrospinal, CSF)

Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA).Why Get Tested?: Primarily to monitor cancer treatment, including response to therapy and recurrence; as an indicator of the amount of cancer or size of tumor present (tumor burden) and to assist in cancer staging; occasionally as follow up to a positive screening test for cancer, to compare whether the level falls to normal (indicating that the cancer was all likely removed) after treatment for the cancer
Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA).When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with colon, pancreas, breast, lung, ovarian, medullary thyroid or other cancer prior to starting cancer treatment and then, if elevated, at intervals during and after therapy; occasionally when cancer is suspected but not confirmed – to aid in its detection
Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; occasionally another body fluid such as fluid from the abdomen (peritoneal), the chest (pleural), or from the spinal cord (cerebrospinal, CSF)

Cardiac CRP.Why Get Tested?: To help assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Cardiac CRP.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested; hs-CRP is often ordered in conjunction with other tests that are performed to assess risk of heart disease, such as a lipid profile (cholesterol, triglycerides, HDL-C, LDL-C) when your healthcare provider would like additional information on your risk.
Cardiac CRP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Cardiac CRP.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 9-12 hours before the blood sample is taken if a lipid profile also is going to be done at the same time. You should be healthy at the time of the sample collection, without any recent illnesses, infections, inflammation, or injuries.

Cardiac-specific Troponin I and Troponin.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have had a heart attack or injury to heart muscle; to determine if your angina (chest pain related to heart trouble) is worsening
Cardiac-specific Troponin I and Troponin.When To Get Tested?: Immediately, then followed by a series of troponin tests over several hours when you are having signs and symptoms that may be due to a heart attack, such as pain in your chest, shoulders, neck, jaw and/or shortness of breath; when your angina worsens, especially if it does not resolve with rest
Cardiac-specific Troponin I and Troponin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
Cardiac-specific Troponin I and Troponin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but tell your healthcare practitioner or emergency department personnel about any over-the-counter or prescription medications and/or supplements you take.

Cardiolipin Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate inappropriate blood clot formation, to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriage, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome or sometimes other autoimmune diseases
Cardiolipin Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have had one or more unexplained blood clots (thrombotic episodes) in a vein or artery; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters; when you have symptoms consistent with an autoimmune disease
Cardiolipin Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cardiolipin Antibodies (IgG, IgM, and Ig.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate inappropriate blood clot formation, to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriage, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome or sometimes other autoimmune diseases
Cardiolipin Antibodies (IgG, IgM, and Ig.When To Get Tested?: When you have had one or more unexplained blood clots (thrombotic episodes) in a vein or artery; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters; when you have symptoms consistent with an autoimmune disease
Cardiolipin Antibodies (IgG, IgM, and Ig.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

cardiology.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
cardiology.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
cardiology.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
cardiology.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Catecholamines.Why Get Tested?: To help confirm or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Catecholamines.When To Get Tested?: After or in conjunction with plasma free metanephrines and/or urine metanephrines tests and when your healthcare provider needs additional information regarding a possible catecholamine-secreting tumor
Catecholamines.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Catecholamines.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection. Although you may be seated for collection of the blood sample, it is recommended that you be lying down. Your healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.

Catecholamines, Plasma and Urine.Why Get Tested?: To help confirm or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Catecholamines, Plasma and Urine.When To Get Tested?: After or in conjunction with plasma free metanephrines and/or urine metanephrines tests and when your healthcare provider needs additional information regarding a possible catecholamine-secreting tumor
Catecholamines, Plasma and Urine.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Catecholamines, Plasma and Urine.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection. Although you may be seated for collection of the blood sample, it is recommended that you be lying down. Your healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.

CBC.Why Get Tested?: To determine your general health status; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor any one of a variety of diseases and conditions that affect blood cells, such as anemia, infection, inflammation, bleeding disorder or cancer
CBC.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine medical exam; when you have signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition that affects blood cells; at regular intervals to monitor treatment or when you are receiving treatment known to affect blood cells
CBC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a fingerstick or heelstick (newborns)

CBC with Differential.Why Get Tested?: To determine your general health status; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor any one of a variety of diseases and conditions that affect blood cells, such as anemia, infection, inflammation, bleeding disorder or cancer
CBC with Differential.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine medical exam; when you have signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition that affects blood cells; at regular intervals to monitor treatment or when you are receiving treatment known to affect blood cells
CBC with Differential.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a fingerstick or heelstick (newborns)

CCP Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and differentiate it from other types of arthritis; to help evaluate the prognosis of a person with RA
CCP Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner suspects RA in someone who has joint inflammation with symptoms that suggest but do not yet meet the criteria of RA
CCP Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CCT.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney dysfunction or disease; to detect decreased blood flow to the kidneys
CCT.When To Get Tested?: When your results of a routine blood creatinine test and/or estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) are not within the normal ranges; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or damage or when you have a problem affecting the function of your kidneys, such as an obstruction within the kidney or acute or chronic kidney failure, or dysfunction due to another disease, such as congestive heart failure
CCT.Sample Required?: Both a urine sample (24-hour collection) and a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
CCT.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

CD4 Count.Why Get Tested?: Most often, this test is done to measure the strength of your immune system if you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and to monitor treatment; occasionally, it may be used with other conditions (see Common Questions below).
CD4 Count.When To Get Tested?: When you are first diagnosed with HIV infection to get a baseline assessment of your immune system; about every 3 to 6 months after starting antiretroviral therapy (ART) to check whether you are responding to treatment; if you have responded well to treatment, you may then be tested every 6 to 12 months.
CD4 Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CD4 Lymphocyte Count; CD4 Percent.Why Get Tested?: Most often, this test is done to measure the strength of your immune system if you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and to monitor treatment; occasionally, it may be used with other conditions (see Common Questions below).
CD4 Lymphocyte Count; CD4 Percent.When To Get Tested?: When you are first diagnosed with HIV infection to get a baseline assessment of your immune system; about every 3 to 6 months after starting antiretroviral therapy (ART) to check whether you are responding to treatment; if you have responded well to treatment, you may then be tested every 6 to 12 months.
CD4 Lymphocyte Count; CD4 Percent.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
