CEA.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to monitor cancer treatment, including response to therapy and recurrence; as an indicator of the amount of cancer or size of tumor present (tumor burden) and to assist in cancer staging; occasionally as follow up to a positive screening test for cancer, to compare whether the level falls to normal (indicating that the cancer was all likely removed) after treatment for the cancer
CEA.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with colon, pancreas, breast, lung, ovarian, medullary thyroid or other cancer prior to starting cancer treatment and then, if elevated, at intervals during and after therapy; occasionally when cancer is suspected but not confirmed – to aid in its detection
CEA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; occasionally another body fluid such as fluid from the abdomen (peritoneal), the chest (pleural), or from the spinal cord (cerebrospinal, CSF)

Celiac Disease Antibody Tests.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
Celiac Disease Antibody Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
Celiac Disease Antibody Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Celiac Disease Antibody Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

Cell-Free Fetal DNA.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of your developing baby (fetus) having certain chromosome disorders
Cell-Free Fetal DNA.When To Get Tested?: During or after the 10th week of pregnancy
Cell-Free Fetal DNA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the mother's arm

Cell-Free Fetal DNA Testing for Fetal Ch.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of your developing baby (fetus) having certain chromosome disorders
Cell-Free Fetal DNA Testing for Fetal Ch.When To Get Tested?: During or after the 10th week of pregnancy
Cell-Free Fetal DNA Testing for Fetal Ch.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the mother's arm

Centromere Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of anticentromere antibodies; to help diagnose limited cutaneous scleroderma
Centromere Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have one or more symptoms that suggest CREST syndrome
Centromere Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a disease or condition affecting the central nervous system such as infection, bleeding within the brain or skull, cancer, or autoimmune disorder
Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that your symptoms are due to a condition or disease involving your central nervous system
Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis.Sample Required?: A sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected by a health practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap
Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: You will be instructed to empty your bladder and bowels prior to sample collection. It will be necessary to lie still in a curled-up fetal position during the collection and to lie flat and still for a time period after the collection.

Cerebrospinal Fluid Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a disease or condition affecting the central nervous system such as infection, bleeding within the brain or skull, cancer, or autoimmune disorder
Cerebrospinal Fluid Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that your symptoms are due to a condition or disease involving your central nervous system
Cerebrospinal Fluid Analysis.Sample Required?: A sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected by a health practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap
Cerebrospinal Fluid Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: You will be instructed to empty your bladder and bowels prior to sample collection. It will be necessary to lie still in a curled-up fetal position during the collection and to lie flat and still for a time period after the collection.

Ceruloplasmin.Why Get Tested?: To measure the amount of ceruloplasmin in the blood; to help diagnose Wilson disease; sometimes to help identify conditions associated with copper deficiencies
Ceruloplasmin.When To Get Tested?: When you have jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, behavioral changes, tremors, or other symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to Wilson disease or, rarely, to copper deficiency; at intervals when monitoring is recommended
Ceruloplasmin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Ceruloplasmin, serum.Why Get Tested?: To measure the amount of ceruloplasmin in the blood; to help diagnose Wilson disease; sometimes to help identify conditions associated with copper deficiencies
Ceruloplasmin, serum.When To Get Tested?: When you have jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, behavioral changes, tremors, or other symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to Wilson disease or, rarely, to copper deficiency; at intervals when monitoring is recommended
Ceruloplasmin, serum.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cervical Smear.Why Get Tested?: To screen for cervical cancer and certain vaginal or uterine infections
Cervical Smear.When To Get Tested?: For women age 21 or older, once every 3 to 5 years depending on your age, risk factors, use of other screening tests, and your healthcare provider's advice
Cervical Smear.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed not to douche or tub bathe for 24 hours before the Pap test is to be performed. You may also be asked to refrain from sexual intercourse for 24 to 48 hours before the test. Do not use any vaginal creams or foams for 48 hours prior to the exam and do not schedule the test during your menstrual period.

Cervical/Vaginal Cytology.Why Get Tested?: To screen for cervical cancer and certain vaginal or uterine infections
Cervical/Vaginal Cytology.When To Get Tested?: For women age 21 or older, once every 3 to 5 years depending on your age, risk factors, use of other screening tests, and your healthcare provider's advice
Cervical/Vaginal Cytology.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed not to douche or tub bathe for 24 hours before the Pap test is to be performed. You may also be asked to refrain from sexual intercourse for 24 to 48 hours before the test. Do not use any vaginal creams or foams for 48 hours prior to the exam and do not schedule the test during your menstrual period.

CF DNA Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To detect cystic fibrosis (CF) gene mutations; to screen for or help diagnose CF; to determine whether you are a carrier of a CF genetic mutation and to evaluate the risk of having a baby with CF
CF DNA Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When screening newborns for CF (all U.S. states screen for CF and some states use this test for screening); when an older child or adult has signs and symptoms of CF or a positive CF screening test; when someone wants to know their carrier status, such as a woman who is pregnant or considering pregnancy for the first time
CF DNA Analysis.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel by collecting a spot of blood onto filter paper; for older children or adults, a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm; sometimes a scraping of the inner cheek (buccal swab) or, for prenatal testing, amniotic fluid obtained through amniocentesis or a chorionic villus sample

CF Gene Mutation Panel.Why Get Tested?: To detect cystic fibrosis (CF) gene mutations; to screen for or help diagnose CF; to determine whether you are a carrier of a CF genetic mutation and to evaluate the risk of having a baby with CF
CF Gene Mutation Panel.When To Get Tested?: When screening newborns for CF (all U.S. states screen for CF and some states use this test for screening); when an older child or adult has signs and symptoms of CF or a positive CF screening test; when someone wants to know their carrier status, such as a woman who is pregnant or considering pregnancy for the first time
CF Gene Mutation Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel by collecting a spot of blood onto filter paper; for older children or adults, a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm; sometimes a scraping of the inner cheek (buccal swab) or, for prenatal testing, amniotic fluid obtained through amniocentesis or a chorionic villus sample

CF Molecular Genetic Testing.Why Get Tested?: To detect cystic fibrosis (CF) gene mutations; to screen for or help diagnose CF; to determine whether you are a carrier of a CF genetic mutation and to evaluate the risk of having a baby with CF
CF Molecular Genetic Testing.When To Get Tested?: When screening newborns for CF (all U.S. states screen for CF and some states use this test for screening); when an older child or adult has signs and symptoms of CF or a positive CF screening test; when someone wants to know their carrier status, such as a woman who is pregnant or considering pregnancy for the first time
CF Molecular Genetic Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel by collecting a spot of blood onto filter paper; for older children or adults, a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm; sometimes a scraping of the inner cheek (buccal swab) or, for prenatal testing, amniotic fluid obtained through amniocentesis or a chorionic villus sample

cffDNA.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of your developing baby (fetus) having certain chromosome disorders
cffDNA.When To Get Tested?: During or after the 10th week of pregnancy
cffDNA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the mother's arm

CFTR Mutation Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To detect cystic fibrosis (CF) gene mutations; to screen for or help diagnose CF; to determine whether you are a carrier of a CF genetic mutation and to evaluate the risk of having a baby with CF
CFTR Mutation Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When screening newborns for CF (all U.S. states screen for CF and some states use this test for screening); when an older child or adult has signs and symptoms of CF or a positive CF screening test; when someone wants to know their carrier status, such as a woman who is pregnant or considering pregnancy for the first time
CFTR Mutation Analysis.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel by collecting a spot of blood onto filter paper; for older children or adults, a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm; sometimes a scraping of the inner cheek (buccal swab) or, for prenatal testing, amniotic fluid obtained through amniocentesis or a chorionic villus sample

CgA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor carcinoid tumors and other neuroendocrine tumors
CgA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggestive of a carcinoid tumor, such as flushing, diarrhea, and/or wheezing; when your healthcare provider thinks that you may have a carcinoid or other neuroendocrine tumor
CgA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
CgA.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required; follow any instructions from your healthcare provider or laboratory

cGFR.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
cGFR.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
cGFR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
cGFR.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

CH100.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
CH100.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
CH100.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CH50.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
CH50.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
CH50.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Chem 12.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about the current status of your metabolism, including the health of your kidneys and liver as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and levels of blood glucose and blood proteins; to monitor known conditions, such as hypertension, and to monitor the use of medications to check for any kidney- or liver-related side effects
Chem 12.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are being monitored for a specific condition or are taking medications that may impact your kidney or liver
Chem 12.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Chem 12.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the CMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

Chem 7.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about your body's metabolism, including the current status of your kidneys as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and level of blood glucose
Chem 7.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are hospitalized, in the emergency room
Chem 7.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Chem 7.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the BMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

Chemistry Panel.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about the current status of your metabolism, including the health of your kidneys and liver as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and levels of blood glucose and blood proteins; to monitor known conditions, such as hypertension, and to monitor the use of medications to check for any kidney- or liver-related side effects
Chemistry Panel.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are being monitored for a specific condition or are taking medications that may impact your kidney or liver
Chemistry Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Chemistry Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the CMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

Chemistry Screen.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about the current status of your metabolism, including the health of your kidneys and liver as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and levels of blood glucose and blood proteins; to monitor known conditions, such as hypertension, and to monitor the use of medications to check for any kidney- or liver-related side effects
Chemistry Screen.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are being monitored for a specific condition or are taking medications that may impact your kidney or liver
Chemistry Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Chemistry Screen.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the CMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

Chickenpox and Shingles Tests.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose, as necessary, a current, recent, or past case of chickenpox or shingles; to determine whether you have developed immunity to the varicella zoster virus (VZV) or whether there is the potential for reactivating a VZV infection prior to receiving immunosuppressive drugs
Chickenpox and Shingles Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have atypical and/or severe symptoms and your healthcare practitioner wants to distinguish between a VZV infection and another cause; when a healthcare practitioner wants to check whether or not you are immune to VZV; sometimes prior to an organ transplant or when a child, pregnant woman, or a person with a weakened immune system has been exposed to someone with chickenpox
Chickenpox and Shingles Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for VZV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, a sample of fluid from a blister (vesicle), blood, cerebrospinal fluid, or other body fluid or tissue

Chlamydia Culture.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a chlamydia infection
Chlamydia Culture.When To Get Tested?:
For women, yearly screening is recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); when you are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly screening is recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge and abdominal pain (for women) or unusual discharge from the penis, pain on urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
Chlamydia Culture.Sample Required?: For women, a swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina; for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
Chlamydia Culture.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams; you may be asked to avoid using these within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow any instructions you are given.

Chlamydia Nucleic Acid Amplification Tes.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a chlamydia infection
Chlamydia Nucleic Acid Amplification Tes.When To Get Tested?:
For women, yearly screening is recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); when you are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly screening is recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge and abdominal pain (for women) or unusual discharge from the penis, pain on urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
Chlamydia Nucleic Acid Amplification Tes.Sample Required?: For women, a swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina; for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
Chlamydia Nucleic Acid Amplification Tes.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams; you may be asked to avoid using these within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow any instructions you are given.

Chlamydia Testing.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a chlamydia infection
Chlamydia Testing.When To Get Tested?:
For women, yearly screening is recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); when you are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly screening is recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge and abdominal pain (for women) or unusual discharge from the penis, pain on urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
Chlamydia Testing.Sample Required?: For women, a swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina; for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
Chlamydia Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams; you may be asked to avoid using these within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow any instructions you are given.

Chlamydia trachomatis Testing.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a chlamydia infection
Chlamydia trachomatis Testing.When To Get Tested?:
For women, yearly screening is recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); when you are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly screening is recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge and abdominal pain (for women) or unusual discharge from the penis, pain on urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
Chlamydia trachomatis Testing.Sample Required?: For women, a swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina; for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
Chlamydia trachomatis Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams; you may be asked to avoid using these within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow any instructions you are given.

Chlamydia/GC STD Panel.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a chlamydia infection
Chlamydia/GC STD Panel.When To Get Tested?:
For women, yearly screening is recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); when you are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly screening is recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge and abdominal pain (for women) or unusual discharge from the penis, pain on urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
Chlamydia/GC STD Panel.Sample Required?: For women, a swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina; for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
Chlamydia/GC STD Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams; you may be asked to avoid using these within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow any instructions you are given.

Chloride.Why Get Tested?: To determine if there is a problem with your body's electrolyte balance or acid-base (pH) balance and to monitor treatment; as part of a routine health checkup
Chloride.When To Get Tested?: As part of a standard electrolyte panel or metabolic panel or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that your signs and symptoms may be due to an electrolyte imbalance
Chloride.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3).Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have a vitamin D deficiency; if you are receiving vitamin D supplementation, to determine if it is adequate
Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3).When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal calcium, phosphorus, and/or parathyroid hormone level; when you have evidence of bone disease or bone weakness; when you are at high risk of deficiency or a healthcare practitioner suspects that you might have a vitamin D deficiency; prior to starting drug treatment for osteoporosis; periodically to monitor treatment of vitamin D deficiency
Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To screen for risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a regular health exam with a lipid profile when no risk factors for heart disease are present; adults should be tested once every four to six years; children, teens, and young adults should be tested once between the ages of 9 and 11 and then again between the ages of 17 and 21.
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
Cholesterol.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample is collected from a vein in the arm. Sometimes cholesterol is measured using a drop of blood collected by puncturing the skin on a finger. A fingerstick sample is typically used when cholesterol is being measured on a portable testing device, for example, at a health fair.
Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: Cholesterol tests typically require fasting for 9-12 hours before the test; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

Cholinesterase Tests.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
Cholinesterase Tests.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
Cholinesterase Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Chromogranin A.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor carcinoid tumors and other neuroendocrine tumors
Chromogranin A.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggestive of a carcinoid tumor, such as flushing, diarrhea, and/or wheezing; when your healthcare provider thinks that you may have a carcinoid or other neuroendocrine tumor
Chromogranin A.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Chromogranin A.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required; follow any instructions from your healthcare provider or laboratory

Chromosome Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To detect chromosome abnormalities, thus to help diagnose genetic diseases, some birth defects, and certain disorders of the blood and lymphatic system
Chromosome Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When pregnancy screening tests are abnormal; whenever signs of a chromosomal abnormality-associated disorder are present; as indicated to detect chromosomal abnormalities in a person and/or detect a specific abnormality in family members; sometimes when a person has leukemia, lymphoma, myeloma, myelodysplasia or another cancer and an acquired chromosome abnormality is suspected
Chromosome Analysis.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a sample of amniotic fluid or chorionic villus from a pregnant woman; a bone marrow or tissue sample

Chromosome Analysis (Karyotyping).Why Get Tested?: To detect chromosome abnormalities, thus to help diagnose genetic diseases, some birth defects, and certain disorders of the blood and lymphatic system
Chromosome Analysis (Karyotyping).When To Get Tested?: When pregnancy screening tests are abnormal; whenever signs of a chromosomal abnormality-associated disorder are present; as indicated to detect chromosomal abnormalities in a person and/or detect a specific abnormality in family members; sometimes when a person has leukemia, lymphoma, myeloma, myelodysplasia or another cancer and an acquired chromosome abnormality is suspected
Chromosome Analysis (Karyotyping).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a sample of amniotic fluid or chorionic villus from a pregnant woman; a bone marrow or tissue sample

Chromosome Karyotype.Why Get Tested?: To detect chromosome abnormalities, thus to help diagnose genetic diseases, some birth defects, and certain disorders of the blood and lymphatic system
Chromosome Karyotype.When To Get Tested?: When pregnancy screening tests are abnormal; whenever signs of a chromosomal abnormality-associated disorder are present; as indicated to detect chromosomal abnormalities in a person and/or detect a specific abnormality in family members; sometimes when a person has leukemia, lymphoma, myeloma, myelodysplasia or another cancer and an acquired chromosome abnormality is suspected
Chromosome Karyotype.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a sample of amniotic fluid or chorionic villus from a pregnant woman; a bone marrow or tissue sample

Chromosome Studies.Why Get Tested?: To detect chromosome abnormalities, thus to help diagnose genetic diseases, some birth defects, and certain disorders of the blood and lymphatic system
Chromosome Studies.When To Get Tested?: When pregnancy screening tests are abnormal; whenever signs of a chromosomal abnormality-associated disorder are present; as indicated to detect chromosomal abnormalities in a person and/or detect a specific abnormality in family members; sometimes when a person has leukemia, lymphoma, myeloma, myelodysplasia or another cancer and an acquired chromosome abnormality is suspected
Chromosome Studies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a sample of amniotic fluid or chorionic villus from a pregnant woman; a bone marrow or tissue sample

CHS.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
CHS.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
CHS.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Chymotrypsin.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
Chymotrypsin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as persistent diarrhea; foul-smelling, bulky, greasy stools; malnutrition; malabsorption; and vitamin deficiency and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
Chymotrypsin.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample, uncontaminated with urine
Chymotrypsin.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be instructed to discontinue taking the enzymes 5 days before providing the stool sample.

Chymotrypsin, fecal.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
Chymotrypsin, fecal.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as persistent diarrhea; foul-smelling, bulky, greasy stools; malnutrition; malabsorption; and vitamin deficiency and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
Chymotrypsin, fecal.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample, uncontaminated with urine
Chymotrypsin, fecal.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be instructed to discontinue taking the enzymes 5 days before providing the stool sample.

Citrulline Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and differentiate it from other types of arthritis; to help evaluate the prognosis of a person with RA
Citrulline Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner suspects RA in someone who has joint inflammation with symptoms that suggest but do not yet meet the criteria of RA
Citrulline Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CK.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor muscle damage; to help diagnose conditions associated with muscle damage; for heart attack detection, this test has been largely replaced by troponin T and I – markers more specific to cardiac tissue; however, it may sometimes be used to help detect a second or subsequent heart attack (see Common Questions #4).
CK.When To Get Tested?: When you have muscle weakness, muscle aches, and/or dark urine and your healthcare practitioner suspects muscle damage; sometimes to monitor for muscle injury resolution or persistence
CK.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CK MB.Why Get Tested?: To distinguish between skeletal muscle and heart muscle damage; sometimes to determine if you have had a heart attack (if the troponin test is not available); sometimes to detect a second or subsequent heart attack or to monitor for additional heart damage
CK MB.When To Get Tested?: When you have an increased creatine kinase (CK) level and the healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether it is due to skeletal or heart muscle damage; when it is suspected that you have had a second heart attack or have ongoing heart damage
CK MB.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CK-MB.Why Get Tested?: To distinguish between skeletal muscle and heart muscle damage; sometimes to determine if you have had a heart attack (if the troponin test is not available); sometimes to detect a second or subsequent heart attack or to monitor for additional heart damage
CK-MB.When To Get Tested?: When you have an increased creatine kinase (CK) level and the healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether it is due to skeletal or heart muscle damage; when it is suspected that you have had a second heart attack or have ongoing heart damage
CK-MB.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cl.Why Get Tested?: To determine if there is a problem with your body's electrolyte balance or acid-base (pH) balance and to monitor treatment; as part of a routine health checkup
Cl.When To Get Tested?: As part of a standard electrolyte panel or metabolic panel or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that your signs and symptoms may be due to an electrolyte imbalance
Cl.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

CLO test.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with Helicobacter pylori, bacteria that can cause peptic ulcers
CLO test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an ulcer, such as gastrointestinal pain that comes and goes, unexplained weight loss, nausea and/or vomiting
CLO test.Sample Required?: A stool sample, a breath sample, or a tissue biopsy of the stomach lining
CLO test.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to avoid certain medications; follow any instructions you are given.

Clopidogrel (CYP2C19 Genotyping).Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your likely response to the antiplatelet drug clopidogrel by detecting variations in the gene (CYP2C19) that codes for one of the enzymes that metabolizes the drug; clopidogrel is prescribed for people who are at risk of a heart attack or stroke to help prevent harmful blood clots from forming.
Clopidogrel (CYP2C19 Genotyping).When To Get Tested?: A health practitioner might order this test prior to prescribing clopidogrel for you or during the initial treatment phase and sometimes when you are taking clopidogrel and are not responding as expected.
Clopidogrel (CYP2C19 Genotyping).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Clopidogrel Pharmacogenetic Testing.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your likely response to the antiplatelet drug clopidogrel by detecting variations in the gene (CYP2C19) that codes for one of the enzymes that metabolizes the drug; clopidogrel is prescribed for people who are at risk of a heart attack or stroke to help prevent harmful blood clots from forming.
Clopidogrel Pharmacogenetic Testing.When To Get Tested?: A health practitioner might order this test prior to prescribing clopidogrel for you or during the initial treatment phase and sometimes when you are taking clopidogrel and are not responding as expected.
Clopidogrel Pharmacogenetic Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Clostridium difficile and C. difficile T.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of an infection caused by toxin-producing Clostridium difficile bacteria
Clostridium difficile and C. difficile T.When To Get Tested?: When a person has mild, moderate, or severe diarrhea that persists for several days with abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and fever, following antibiotic therapy
Clostridium difficile and C. difficile T.Sample Required?: A fresh or refrigerated liquid or unformed stool sample that has not been contaminated with urine or water

Clostridium difficile Culture, Toxin A a.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of an infection caused by toxin-producing Clostridium difficile bacteria
Clostridium difficile Culture, Toxin A a.When To Get Tested?: When a person has mild, moderate, or severe diarrhea that persists for several days with abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and fever, following antibiotic therapy
Clostridium difficile Culture, Toxin A a.Sample Required?: A fresh or refrigerated liquid or unformed stool sample that has not been contaminated with urine or water

Clotting Factors.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether levels of one or more of your coagulation factors are increased, normal, or decreased
Clotting Factors.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding, abnormal results on coagulation screening tests such as prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT), or have a relative with a hereditary coagulation factor deficiency; you may be tested when your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor the severity of a factor deficiency and/or the effectiveness of treatment.
Clotting Factors.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CMP.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about the current status of your metabolism, including the health of your kidneys and liver as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and levels of blood glucose and blood proteins; to monitor known conditions, such as hypertension, and to monitor the use of medications to check for any kidney- or liver-related side effects
CMP.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are being monitored for a specific condition or are taking medications that may impact your kidney or liver
CMP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
CMP.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the CMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

CMV Blood Test.Why Get Tested?: If your health practitioner suspects that you presently have, or recently had, a cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection or if it is important to know if you have ever had a CMV infection, such as prior to receiving an organ transplant
CMV Blood Test.When To Get Tested?: When a young adult, a pregnant woman, or an immune-compromised person has flu-like symptoms that suggest a CMV infection; when a newborn has multiple congenital abnormalities, unexplained jaundice or anemia, and/or when an infant has seizures or developmental problems that may be due to CMV; prior to receiving an organ transplant
CMV Blood Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for CMV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, the sample may be blood, urine, sputum, amniotic fluid, cerebrospinal fluid, duodenal fluid, or other body tissue

CMV IgG and IgM.Why Get Tested?: If your health practitioner suspects that you presently have, or recently had, a cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection or if it is important to know if you have ever had a CMV infection, such as prior to receiving an organ transplant
CMV IgG and IgM.When To Get Tested?: When a young adult, a pregnant woman, or an immune-compromised person has flu-like symptoms that suggest a CMV infection; when a newborn has multiple congenital abnormalities, unexplained jaundice or anemia, and/or when an infant has seizures or developmental problems that may be due to CMV; prior to receiving an organ transplant
CMV IgG and IgM.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for CMV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, the sample may be blood, urine, sputum, amniotic fluid, cerebrospinal fluid, duodenal fluid, or other body tissue

CO2 Content.Why Get Tested?: As part of an electrolyte panel to identify or monitor an electrolyte imbalance or acid-base (pH) imbalance
CO2 Content.When To Get Tested?: During a routine physical or as recommended by your healthcare practitioner if you are experiencing symptoms such as weakness, confusion, prolonged vomiting, or breathing problems that could indicate an electrolyte imbalance or an acid-base imbalance (commonly described as acidosis or alkalosis)
CO2 Content.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Coagulation Factors.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether levels of one or more of your coagulation factors are increased, normal, or decreased
Coagulation Factors.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding, abnormal results on coagulation screening tests such as prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT), or have a relative with a hereditary coagulation factor deficiency; you may be tested when your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor the severity of a factor deficiency and/or the effectiveness of treatment.
Coagulation Factors.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Coagulation Factors Activity Assays.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether levels of one or more of your coagulation factors are increased, normal, or decreased
Coagulation Factors Activity Assays.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding, abnormal results on coagulation screening tests such as prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT), or have a relative with a hereditary coagulation factor deficiency; you may be tested when your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor the severity of a factor deficiency and/or the effectiveness of treatment.
Coagulation Factors Activity Assays.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cobalamin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose one cause of anemia or neuropathy; to evaluate nutritional status in some people; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
Cobalamin.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal complete blood count (CBC) with a blood smear showing large red blood cells (macrocytosis) or abnormal (hypersegmented) neutrophils; when you have symptoms of anemia (weakness, tiredness, pale skin) and/or of neuropathy (tingling or itching sensations, eye twitching, memory loss, altered mental status); when you are being treated for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
Cobalamin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Cobalamin.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting for 6-8 hours before sample collection may be required. Certain medicines may affect the test results; your healthcare provider will advise you on which ones to stop taking.

Cold Agglutinins.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of hemolytic anemia; to help diagnose cold agglutinin disease
Cold Agglutinins.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with anemia and/or pain, pale skin, and bluing in the fingers, toes and tips of the ears that occurs after exposure to cold temperatures; when you have been diagnosed with hemolytic anemia and your healthcare practitioner is investigating the cause
Cold Agglutinins.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cold Autoantibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of hemolytic anemia; to help diagnose cold agglutinin disease
Cold Autoantibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with anemia and/or pain, pale skin, and bluing in the fingers, toes and tips of the ears that occurs after exposure to cold temperatures; when you have been diagnosed with hemolytic anemia and your healthcare practitioner is investigating the cause
Cold Autoantibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cold-Reacting Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of hemolytic anemia; to help diagnose cold agglutinin disease
Cold-Reacting Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with anemia and/or pain, pale skin, and bluing in the fingers, toes and tips of the ears that occurs after exposure to cold temperatures; when you have been diagnosed with hemolytic anemia and your healthcare practitioner is investigating the cause
Cold-Reacting Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Complement.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
Complement.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
Complement.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Complement (Antigen, Functional or Activ.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
Complement (Antigen, Functional or Activ.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
Complement (Antigen, Functional or Activ.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Complete Blood Count.Why Get Tested?: To determine your general health status; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor any one of a variety of diseases and conditions that affect blood cells, such as anemia, infection, inflammation, bleeding disorder or cancer
Complete Blood Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine medical exam; when you have signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition that affects blood cells; at regular intervals to monitor treatment or when you are receiving treatment known to affect blood cells
Complete Blood Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a fingerstick or heelstick (newborns)

Complete Blood Count (CBC).Why Get Tested?: To determine your general health status; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor any one of a variety of diseases and conditions that affect blood cells, such as anemia, infection, inflammation, bleeding disorder or cancer
Complete Blood Count (CBC).When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine medical exam; when you have signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition that affects blood cells; at regular intervals to monitor treatment or when you are receiving treatment known to affect blood cells
Complete Blood Count (CBC).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a fingerstick or heelstick (newborns)

Comprehensive Metabolic Panel.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about the current status of your metabolism, including the health of your kidneys and liver as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and levels of blood glucose and blood proteins; to monitor known conditions, such as hypertension, and to monitor the use of medications to check for any kidney- or liver-related side effects
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are being monitored for a specific condition or are taking medications that may impact your kidney or liver
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the CMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP).Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about the current status of your metabolism, including the health of your kidneys and liver as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and levels of blood glucose and blood proteins; to monitor known conditions, such as hypertension, and to monitor the use of medications to check for any kidney- or liver-related side effects
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP).When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are being monitored for a specific condition or are taking medications that may impact your kidney or liver
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP).Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the CMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

Conjugated Bilirubin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor liver disorders or hemolytic anemia; to monitor neonatal jaundice
Conjugated Bilirubin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of liver damage, liver disease, bile duct blockage, hemolytic anemia, or a liver-related metabolic problem, or if a newborn has jaundice
Conjugated Bilirubin.Sample Required?: In adults, a blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm; in newborns, a blood sample from a heelstick; non-invasive technology is available in some healthcare facilities that will measure bilirubin by using an instrument placed on the skin (transcutaneous bilirubin meter)
Conjugated Bilirubin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for several hours before the test; fasting requirements vary by laboratory; ask your lab or healthcare provider for instructions.

Connecting Peptide Insulin.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate insulin production by the beta cells in the pancreas or to help determine the cause of low blood glucose (hypoglycemia)
Connecting Peptide Insulin.When To Get Tested?: When you have diabetes and your health practitioner wants to determine if you are producing enough of your own insulin or if it is time to supplement oral medication with insulin injections or an insulin pump; when your health practitioner suspects that you have insulin resistance; when you have documented hypoglycemia
Connecting Peptide Insulin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and sometimes a 24-hour urine sample
Connecting Peptide Insulin.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting for 8 to 10 hours before blood testing is usually required.

Copper.Why Get Tested?: To measure the amount of copper in the blood, urine, or liver tissue; to help diagnose and monitor Wilson disease; sometimes to identify copper deficiency or excess
Copper.When To Get Tested?: When you have jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, behavioral changes, tremors, or other symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to Wilson disease or, rarely, to copper deficiency or excess; at intervals when you are being treated for a copper-related condition
Copper.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a liver biopsy sample

Copper, 24-hour urine, blood, and liver.Why Get Tested?: To measure the amount of copper in the blood, urine, or liver tissue; to help diagnose and monitor Wilson disease; sometimes to identify copper deficiency or excess
Copper, 24-hour urine, blood, and liver.When To Get Tested?: When you have jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, behavioral changes, tremors, or other symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to Wilson disease or, rarely, to copper deficiency or excess; at intervals when you are being treated for a copper-related condition
Copper, 24-hour urine, blood, and liver.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a liver biopsy sample

Coproporphyrin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
Coproporphyrin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
Coproporphyrin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
Coproporphyrin.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

Coronary Risk Panel.Why Get Tested?: To assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD); to monitor treatment
Coronary Risk Panel.When To Get Tested?:
Screening when no risk factors present: for adults, every four to six years; for youths, once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between ages 17 and 21
Monitoring: at regular intervals when risk factors are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or to monitor effectiveness of treatment
Coronary Risk Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
Coronary Risk Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, fasting for 9-12 hours (water only) before having your blood drawn is required, but some labs offer non-fasting lipid testing. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

Corrected Reticulocyte.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the bone marrow's ability to produce red blood cells (RBCs); to help distinguish between various causes of anemia; to help monitor bone marrow response and the return of normal marrow function following chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant, or post-treatment follow-up for iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia, or renal failure
Corrected Reticulocyte.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit and/or symptoms of anemia; when a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your bone marrow function; sometimes as part of a complete blood count (CBC)
Corrected Reticulocyte.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick or heelstick (infant)

Corticotropin.Why Get Tested?: In conjunction with cortisol testing, to help diagnose adrenal gland problems and pituitary diseases such as Cushing syndrome, Cushing disease, Addison disease, adrenal tumors, and pituitary tumors
Corticotropin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms associated with excess or deficient cortisol production; when your healthcare provider suspects that you have a hormone imbalance that could be caused by a problem with your pituitary or adrenal glands
Corticotropin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Corticotropin.Test Preparation Needed?: The healthcare practitioner may request that you fast overnight before testing. Blood is typically drawn in the morning, about 8 a.m.

Cortisol.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose Cushing syndrome or primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease); to detect conditions affecting the pituitary or adrenal glands
Cortisol.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects excess or deficient cortisol production
Cortisol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a saliva sample may be used
Cortisol.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be required to rest before sample collection. For a salivary cortisol test, you may be instructed to refrain from eating, drinking, or brushing your teeth for a period of time (may be some time between 15 to 30 minutes) prior to the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

CPK.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor muscle damage; to help diagnose conditions associated with muscle damage; for heart attack detection, this test has been largely replaced by troponin T and I – markers more specific to cardiac tissue; however, it may sometimes be used to help detect a second or subsequent heart attack (see Common Questions #4).
CPK.When To Get Tested?: When you have muscle weakness, muscle aches, and/or dark urine and your healthcare practitioner suspects muscle damage; sometimes to monitor for muscle injury resolution or persistence
CPK.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CPK MB.Why Get Tested?: To distinguish between skeletal muscle and heart muscle damage; sometimes to determine if you have had a heart attack (if the troponin test is not available); sometimes to detect a second or subsequent heart attack or to monitor for additional heart damage
CPK MB.When To Get Tested?: When you have an increased creatine kinase (CK) level and the healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether it is due to skeletal or heart muscle damage; when it is suspected that you have had a second heart attack or have ongoing heart damage
CPK MB.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CRCL.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney dysfunction or disease; to detect decreased blood flow to the kidneys
CRCL.When To Get Tested?: When your results of a routine blood creatinine test and/or estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) are not within the normal ranges; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or damage or when you have a problem affecting the function of your kidneys, such as an obstruction within the kidney or acute or chronic kidney failure, or dysfunction due to another disease, such as congestive heart failure
CRCL.Sample Required?: Both a urine sample (24-hour collection) and a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
CRCL.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Creat.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor treatment for kidney disease
Creat.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of a comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when your have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or damage or when you have a condition that may affect your kidneys and/or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at intervals to monitor treatment for kidney disease or kidney function while on certain medications
Creat.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample
Creat.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Creatine Kinase.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor muscle damage; to help diagnose conditions associated with muscle damage; for heart attack detection, this test has been largely replaced by troponin T and I – markers more specific to cardiac tissue; however, it may sometimes be used to help detect a second or subsequent heart attack (see Common Questions #4).
Creatine Kinase.When To Get Tested?: When you have muscle weakness, muscle aches, and/or dark urine and your healthcare practitioner suspects muscle damage; sometimes to monitor for muscle injury resolution or persistence
Creatine Kinase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Creatine Kinase (CK).Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor muscle damage; to help diagnose conditions associated with muscle damage; for heart attack detection, this test has been largely replaced by troponin T and I – markers more specific to cardiac tissue; however, it may sometimes be used to help detect a second or subsequent heart attack (see Common Questions #4).
Creatine Kinase (CK).When To Get Tested?: When you have muscle weakness, muscle aches, and/or dark urine and your healthcare practitioner suspects muscle damage; sometimes to monitor for muscle injury resolution or persistence
Creatine Kinase (CK).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Creatine Kinase-MB.Why Get Tested?: To distinguish between skeletal muscle and heart muscle damage; sometimes to determine if you have had a heart attack (if the troponin test is not available); sometimes to detect a second or subsequent heart attack or to monitor for additional heart damage
Creatine Kinase-MB.When To Get Tested?: When you have an increased creatine kinase (CK) level and the healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether it is due to skeletal or heart muscle damage; when it is suspected that you have had a second heart attack or have ongoing heart damage
Creatine Kinase-MB.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Creatine Phosphokinase.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor muscle damage; to help diagnose conditions associated with muscle damage; for heart attack detection, this test has been largely replaced by troponin T and I – markers more specific to cardiac tissue; however, it may sometimes be used to help detect a second or subsequent heart attack (see Common Questions #4).
Creatine Phosphokinase.When To Get Tested?: When you have muscle weakness, muscle aches, and/or dark urine and your healthcare practitioner suspects muscle damage; sometimes to monitor for muscle injury resolution or persistence
Creatine Phosphokinase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Creatinine.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor treatment for kidney disease
Creatinine.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of a comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when your have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or damage or when you have a condition that may affect your kidneys and/or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at intervals to monitor treatment for kidney disease or kidney function while on certain medications
Creatinine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample
Creatinine.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Creatinine Clearance.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney dysfunction or disease; to detect decreased blood flow to the kidneys
Creatinine Clearance.When To Get Tested?: When your results of a routine blood creatinine test and/or estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) are not within the normal ranges; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or damage or when you have a problem affecting the function of your kidneys, such as an obstruction within the kidney or acute or chronic kidney failure, or dysfunction due to another disease, such as congestive heart failure
Creatinine Clearance.Sample Required?: Both a urine sample (24-hour collection) and a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Creatinine Clearance.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Creatinine Clearance, Urine.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney dysfunction or disease; to detect decreased blood flow to the kidneys
Creatinine Clearance, Urine.When To Get Tested?: When your results of a routine blood creatinine test and/or estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) are not within the normal ranges; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or damage or when you have a problem affecting the function of your kidneys, such as an obstruction within the kidney or acute or chronic kidney failure, or dysfunction due to another disease, such as congestive heart failure
Creatinine Clearance, Urine.Sample Required?: Both a urine sample (24-hour collection) and a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Creatinine Clearance, Urine.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Crit.Why Get Tested?: To determine the proportion of your blood that is made up of red blood cells (RBCs) in order to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect RBCs; as part of a routine health examination or if your healthcare provider suspects that you have anemia or polycythemia
Crit.When To Get Tested?: With a test for hemoglobin or as part of a complete blood count (CBC) during a routine health exam or when you have signs and symptoms of anemia (weakness, fatigue) or polycythemia (dizziness, headache); at regular intervals to monitor a disorder that affects RBCs and to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment
Crit.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

CRP.Why Get Tested?: To identify the presence of inflammation and to monitor response to treatment for an inflammatory disorder
CRP.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that you have an acute condition causing inflammation, such as a serious bacterial or fungal infection or when you are suffering from an inflammatory disorder such as arthritis, an autoimmune disorder, or inflammatory bowel disease
CRP.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm

CRP for heart disease.Why Get Tested?: To help assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
CRP for heart disease.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested; hs-CRP is often ordered in conjunction with other tests that are performed to assess risk of heart disease, such as a lipid profile (cholesterol, triglycerides, HDL-C, LDL-C) when your healthcare provider would like additional information on your risk.
CRP for heart disease.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
CRP for heart disease.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 9-12 hours before the blood sample is taken if a lipid profile also is going to be done at the same time. You should be healthy at the time of the sample collection, without any recent illnesses, infections, inflammation, or injuries.

Cryocrit.Why Get Tested?: To determine if symptoms, like sensitivity of extremities to cold, are due to the presence of abnormal proteins called cryoglobulins in the blood, which can be associated with a variety of diseases
Cryocrit.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as a rash, bruising, pain, weakness, joint pain, and/or paleness and coolness of the extremities that occur at cold temperatures
Cryocrit.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm and collecting the blood in a pre-warmed tube. The sample is kept at or near body temperature during sample preparation.
Cryocrit.Test Preparation Needed?: No test preparation is usually needed. An 8-hour fast before sample collection may be instructed to minimize the potential for turbidity (cloudiness) in the sample due to triglycerides.

Cryoglobulins.Why Get Tested?: To determine if symptoms, like sensitivity of extremities to cold, are due to the presence of abnormal proteins called cryoglobulins in the blood, which can be associated with a variety of diseases
Cryoglobulins.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as a rash, bruising, pain, weakness, joint pain, and/or paleness and coolness of the extremities that occur at cold temperatures
Cryoglobulins.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm and collecting the blood in a pre-warmed tube. The sample is kept at or near body temperature during sample preparation.
Cryoglobulins.Test Preparation Needed?: No test preparation is usually needed. An 8-hour fast before sample collection may be instructed to minimize the potential for turbidity (cloudiness) in the sample due to triglycerides.

Cryoprotein.Why Get Tested?: To determine if symptoms, like sensitivity of extremities to cold, are due to the presence of abnormal proteins called cryoglobulins in the blood, which can be associated with a variety of diseases
Cryoprotein.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as a rash, bruising, pain, weakness, joint pain, and/or paleness and coolness of the extremities that occur at cold temperatures
Cryoprotein.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm and collecting the blood in a pre-warmed tube. The sample is kept at or near body temperature during sample preparation.
Cryoprotein.Test Preparation Needed?: No test preparation is usually needed. An 8-hour fast before sample collection may be instructed to minimize the potential for turbidity (cloudiness) in the sample due to triglycerides.

CSF Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a disease or condition affecting the central nervous system such as infection, bleeding within the brain or skull, cancer, or autoimmune disorder
CSF Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that your symptoms are due to a condition or disease involving your central nervous system
CSF Analysis.Sample Required?: A sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected by a health practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap
CSF Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: You will be instructed to empty your bladder and bowels prior to sample collection. It will be necessary to lie still in a curled-up fetal position during the collection and to lie flat and still for a time period after the collection.

CSF Lactate.Why Get Tested?: To detect high levels of lactate in the blood, which may be an indication of lack of oxygen (hypoxia) or the presence of other conditions that cause excess production or insufficient clearing of lactate from the blood; this test is not meant to be used for screening for health status.
CSF Lactate.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as rapid breathing, nausea, and sweating that suggest a lack of oxygen or an abnormal blood pH (acid/base imbalance); when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you may be experiencing sepsis, shock, heart attack, severe congestive heart failure, kidney failure, or inadequately treated (uncontrolled) diabetes; when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have inherited a rare metabolic or mitochondrial disorder; when you have symptoms of lactic acidosis such as sweet-smelling breath, belly pain, confusion or cool and clammy skin
CSF Lactate.Sample Required?:
A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes, an arterial sample is collected by inserting a needle into an artery. Occasionally, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid is collected from the spinal column during a procedure called a spinal tap.
Blood lactate levels will usually be drawn either without the use of a tourniquet or with a tourniquet that is not released during the blood draw. Tourniquet use and release and clenching of the fist can increase lactate levels in the blood sample.
CSF Lactate.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, no test preparation is needed. In some cases, a healthcare practitioner may request that you don't exercise for several hours before the test or refrain from eating or drinking anything other than water for 8 to 10 hours prior to the test.

CSF Protein Electrophoresis.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
CSF Protein Electrophoresis.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
CSF Protein Electrophoresis.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

cTnI.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have had a heart attack or injury to heart muscle; to determine if your angina (chest pain related to heart trouble) is worsening
cTnI.When To Get Tested?: Immediately, then followed by a series of troponin tests over several hours when you are having signs and symptoms that may be due to a heart attack, such as pain in your chest, shoulders, neck, jaw and/or shortness of breath; when your angina worsens, especially if it does not resolve with rest
cTnI.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
cTnI.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but tell your healthcare practitioner or emergency department personnel about any over-the-counter or prescription medications and/or supplements you take.

cTnT.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have had a heart attack or injury to heart muscle; to determine if your angina (chest pain related to heart trouble) is worsening
cTnT.When To Get Tested?: Immediately, then followed by a series of troponin tests over several hours when you are having signs and symptoms that may be due to a heart attack, such as pain in your chest, shoulders, neck, jaw and/or shortness of breath; when your angina worsens, especially if it does not resolve with rest
cTnT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
cTnT.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but tell your healthcare practitioner or emergency department personnel about any over-the-counter or prescription medications and/or supplements you take.

CTx.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
CTx.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
CTx.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
CTx.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Cu.Why Get Tested?: To measure the amount of copper in the blood, urine, or liver tissue; to help diagnose and monitor Wilson disease; sometimes to identify copper deficiency or excess
Cu.When To Get Tested?: When you have jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, behavioral changes, tremors, or other symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to Wilson disease or, rarely, to copper deficiency or excess; at intervals when you are being treated for a copper-related condition
Cu.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a liver biopsy sample
