Culture - amniotic cells.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose certain birth defects, genetic diseases, and chromosomal abnormalities in a fetus, especially if prenatal screening tests are abnormal; if there is a family history or high risk of inherited disease; sometimes to diagnose a fetal infection and occasionally to help diagnose and monitor hemolytic disease in a fetus; rarely, to evaluate fetal lung maturity when there is an increased risk of premature delivery
Culture - amniotic cells.When To Get Tested?: Testing is most commonly offered between 15 and 20 weeks of pregnancy to test for genetic diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, and open neural tube defects and is recommended after a pregnant woman has an abnormality on an initial prenatal screening test; when it is suspected that a fetus has an infection or other illness or when a fetus has hemolytic disease; rarely it may be done after 32 weeks to evaluate fetal lung maturity
Culture - amniotic cells.Sample Required?: A sample (about 1 ounce) of amniotic fluid is obtained using a procedure called amniocentesis that involves inserting a thin needle through the belly and uterus into the amniotic sac (see Common Questions below).
Culture - amniotic cells.Test Preparation Needed?: Depending upon the stage of pregnancy, either a full or empty bladder may be required at the time the amniocentesis is performed. Be sure to follow any instructions provided.

Culture - amniotic fluid.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose certain birth defects, genetic diseases, and chromosomal abnormalities in a fetus, especially if prenatal screening tests are abnormal; if there is a family history or high risk of inherited disease; sometimes to diagnose a fetal infection and occasionally to help diagnose and monitor hemolytic disease in a fetus; rarely, to evaluate fetal lung maturity when there is an increased risk of premature delivery
Culture - amniotic fluid.When To Get Tested?: Testing is most commonly offered between 15 and 20 weeks of pregnancy to test for genetic diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, and open neural tube defects and is recommended after a pregnant woman has an abnormality on an initial prenatal screening test; when it is suspected that a fetus has an infection or other illness or when a fetus has hemolytic disease; rarely it may be done after 32 weeks to evaluate fetal lung maturity
Culture - amniotic fluid.Sample Required?: A sample (about 1 ounce) of amniotic fluid is obtained using a procedure called amniocentesis that involves inserting a thin needle through the belly and uterus into the amniotic sac (see Common Questions below).
Culture - amniotic fluid.Test Preparation Needed?: Depending upon the stage of pregnancy, either a full or empty bladder may be required at the time the amniocentesis is performed. Be sure to follow any instructions provided.

Culture and Sensitivity.Why Get Tested?: To determine the likelihood that a particular antibiotic or antifungal drug will be effective in stopping the growth of the bacteria or fungi causing your infection
Culture and Sensitivity.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to a positive bacterial or fungal culture; when selecting the best treatment for a bacterial or fungal infection requires laboratory testing; when your infection is not responding to treatment
Culture and Sensitivity.Sample Required?: A sample from an infected site is cultured on specialized media to recover the bacteria or fungus that is causing the infection. The method used to collect a sample from an individual depends on the type of culture performed (e.g., urine culture, blood culture, sputum culture, etc.).

Culture, blood.Why Get Tested?: To check for the presence of a systemic infection; to detect and identify bacteria or yeast in the blood
Culture, blood.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of sepsis, which may include fever, chills, fatigue, rapid breathing and/or heart rate, and/or an elevated white blood cell count
Culture, blood.Sample Required?: Two or more blood samples drawn from separate venipuncture sites, typically from different veins in your arms

Culture, sputum.Why Get Tested?: To detect and identify the cause of bacterial pneumonia or some other lower respiratory tract infections; to monitor the efficacy of treatment
Culture, sputum.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with a lower respiratory tract infection; when you have been treated for bacterial pneumonia or any other lower respiratory tract infection
Culture, sputum.Sample Required?: A sputum sample (deep respiratory secretions, not saliva), usually collected first thing in the morning; sometimes, depending on the infection, up to 3 sputum samples might be collected over consecutive days.
Culture, sputum.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to rinse your mouth out with water prior to collection and to avoid food for 1-2 hours before the sample is collected.

Culture, Throat.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your sore throat is "strep throat" that is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) bacteria
Culture, Throat.When To Get Tested?: When you have a sore throat that starts quickly and lasts more than a week and/or other symptoms such as a fever of 101° F or higher, or reddened throat and/or tonsils with white or yellow patches or streaks
Culture, Throat.Sample Required?: A swab rubbed against the back of your throat and tonsils

Culture, Urine.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a urinary tract infection (UTI)
Culture, Urine.When To Get Tested?: When you experience symptoms of a UTI, such as frequent and painful urination, and/or when a urinalysis indicates you may have a UTI
Culture, Urine.Sample Required?: A mid-stream clean catch urine sample (women should spread the labia of the vagina and clean from front to back; men should wipe the tip of the penis; start to urinate, let some urine fall into the toilet, then collect one to two ounces of urine in the container provided, then void the rest into the toilet); sometimes a urine sample obtained via catheter
Culture, Urine.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally none, but you may be instructed not to urinate for at least one hour before the test and/or to drink a glass of water 15-20 minutes before sample collection.

Culture, wound.Why Get Tested?: To detect and identify the bacteria causing an infection of your wound and to help guide treatment of your wound infection
Culture, wound.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a wound infection, such as a wound that is tender, red, swollen, draining fluid or pus, and slow to heal
Culture, wound.Sample Required?: A sterile swab used to collect cells or pus from the site of the suspected infection; may also include aspirations of fluid from deeper wounds into a syringe and/or a tissue biopsy

Cyclic Citrullinated Peptide Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and differentiate it from other types of arthritis; to help evaluate the prognosis of a person with RA
Cyclic Citrullinated Peptide Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner suspects RA in someone who has joint inflammation with symptoms that suggest but do not yet meet the criteria of RA
Cyclic Citrullinated Peptide Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cyclosporine.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of cyclosporine in your blood in order to establish a dosing regimen, maintain therapeutic levels, and detect toxic levels
Cyclosporine.When To Get Tested?: As soon as cyclosporine therapy begins, usually daily or 2-3 times a week, and periodically after that as the dose is adjusted or maintained
Cyclosporine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Cyclosporine.Test Preparation Needed?: None. Typically a trough level is monitored. A trough level is the lowest concentration reached by a drug before the next dose is administered. For example, if cyclosporine is given twice a day, a blood sample is usually drawn 12 hours after the last dose, before a new dose is given. On mornings when you are scheduled to have your cyclosporine level checked, do not take the medicine until after your blood is drawn.

CYP2C19 Genotype.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your likely response to the antiplatelet drug clopidogrel by detecting variations in the gene (CYP2C19) that codes for one of the enzymes that metabolizes the drug; clopidogrel is prescribed for people who are at risk of a heart attack or stroke to help prevent harmful blood clots from forming.
CYP2C19 Genotype.When To Get Tested?: A health practitioner might order this test prior to prescribing clopidogrel for you or during the initial treatment phase and sometimes when you are taking clopidogrel and are not responding as expected.
CYP2C19 Genotype.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CYP2C19 Sequence Genotype.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your likely response to the antiplatelet drug clopidogrel by detecting variations in the gene (CYP2C19) that codes for one of the enzymes that metabolizes the drug; clopidogrel is prescribed for people who are at risk of a heart attack or stroke to help prevent harmful blood clots from forming.
CYP2C19 Sequence Genotype.When To Get Tested?: A health practitioner might order this test prior to prescribing clopidogrel for you or during the initial treatment phase and sometimes when you are taking clopidogrel and are not responding as expected.
CYP2C19 Sequence Genotype.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

CYP2C9 Genotype; VKORC1 Genotype.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have CYP2C9 and/or VKORC1 genetic variations and are likely to need lower, or less commonly, higher than average doses of the "blood-thinning" drug (anticoagulant) warfarin
CYP2C9 Genotype; VKORC1 Genotype.When To Get Tested?: A health practitioner might order this test prior to prescribing warfarin for you; a health practitioner may sometimes order it when you are being treated with warfarin and have had bleeding or clotting episodes or dosing difficulties
CYP2C9 Genotype; VKORC1 Genotype.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cystatin C.Why Get Tested?: To assess your kidney function if you have known or suspected kidney disease, but only in specific settings when traditional kidney function tests are misleading
Cystatin C.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have decreased kidney function, but serum creatinine measurements are not reliable; it may be ordered at regular intervals when you have known kidney dysfunction.
Cystatin C.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Cystic Fibrosis (CF) Gene Mutations Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect cystic fibrosis (CF) gene mutations; to screen for or help diagnose CF; to determine whether you are a carrier of a CF genetic mutation and to evaluate the risk of having a baby with CF
Cystic Fibrosis (CF) Gene Mutations Test.When To Get Tested?: When screening newborns for CF (all U.S. states screen for CF and some states use this test for screening); when an older child or adult has signs and symptoms of CF or a positive CF screening test; when someone wants to know their carrier status, such as a woman who is pregnant or considering pregnancy for the first time
Cystic Fibrosis (CF) Gene Mutations Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel by collecting a spot of blood onto filter paper; for older children or adults, a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm; sometimes a scraping of the inner cheek (buccal swab) or, for prenatal testing, amniotic fluid obtained through amniocentesis or a chorionic villus sample

Cystic Fibrosis Gene Mutation Panel.Why Get Tested?: To detect cystic fibrosis (CF) gene mutations; to screen for or help diagnose CF; to determine whether you are a carrier of a CF genetic mutation and to evaluate the risk of having a baby with CF
Cystic Fibrosis Gene Mutation Panel.When To Get Tested?: When screening newborns for CF (all U.S. states screen for CF and some states use this test for screening); when an older child or adult has signs and symptoms of CF or a positive CF screening test; when someone wants to know their carrier status, such as a woman who is pregnant or considering pregnancy for the first time
Cystic Fibrosis Gene Mutation Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel by collecting a spot of blood onto filter paper; for older children or adults, a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm; sometimes a scraping of the inner cheek (buccal swab) or, for prenatal testing, amniotic fluid obtained through amniocentesis or a chorionic villus sample

Cystic Fibrosis Genotyping.Why Get Tested?: To detect cystic fibrosis (CF) gene mutations; to screen for or help diagnose CF; to determine whether you are a carrier of a CF genetic mutation and to evaluate the risk of having a baby with CF
Cystic Fibrosis Genotyping.When To Get Tested?: When screening newborns for CF (all U.S. states screen for CF and some states use this test for screening); when an older child or adult has signs and symptoms of CF or a positive CF screening test; when someone wants to know their carrier status, such as a woman who is pregnant or considering pregnancy for the first time
Cystic Fibrosis Genotyping.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel by collecting a spot of blood onto filter paper; for older children or adults, a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm; sometimes a scraping of the inner cheek (buccal swab) or, for prenatal testing, amniotic fluid obtained through amniocentesis or a chorionic villus sample

Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductanc.Why Get Tested?: To detect cystic fibrosis (CF) gene mutations; to screen for or help diagnose CF; to determine whether you are a carrier of a CF genetic mutation and to evaluate the risk of having a baby with CF
Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductanc.When To Get Tested?: When screening newborns for CF (all U.S. states screen for CF and some states use this test for screening); when an older child or adult has signs and symptoms of CF or a positive CF screening test; when someone wants to know their carrier status, such as a woman who is pregnant or considering pregnancy for the first time
Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductanc.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel by collecting a spot of blood onto filter paper; for older children or adults, a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm; sometimes a scraping of the inner cheek (buccal swab) or, for prenatal testing, amniotic fluid obtained through amniocentesis or a chorionic villus sample

Cytogenetic Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To detect chromosome abnormalities, thus to help diagnose genetic diseases, some birth defects, and certain disorders of the blood and lymphatic system
Cytogenetic Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When pregnancy screening tests are abnormal; whenever signs of a chromosomal abnormality-associated disorder are present; as indicated to detect chromosomal abnormalities in a person and/or detect a specific abnormality in family members; sometimes when a person has leukemia, lymphoma, myeloma, myelodysplasia or another cancer and an acquired chromosome abnormality is suspected
Cytogenetic Analysis.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a sample of amniotic fluid or chorionic villus from a pregnant woman; a bone marrow or tissue sample

Cytogenetics.Why Get Tested?: To detect chromosome abnormalities, thus to help diagnose genetic diseases, some birth defects, and certain disorders of the blood and lymphatic system
Cytogenetics.When To Get Tested?: When pregnancy screening tests are abnormal; whenever signs of a chromosomal abnormality-associated disorder are present; as indicated to detect chromosomal abnormalities in a person and/or detect a specific abnormality in family members; sometimes when a person has leukemia, lymphoma, myeloma, myelodysplasia or another cancer and an acquired chromosome abnormality is suspected
Cytogenetics.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a sample of amniotic fluid or chorionic villus from a pregnant woman; a bone marrow or tissue sample

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Tests.Why Get Tested?: If your health practitioner suspects that you presently have, or recently had, a cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection or if it is important to know if you have ever had a CMV infection, such as prior to receiving an organ transplant
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Tests.When To Get Tested?: When a young adult, a pregnant woman, or an immune-compromised person has flu-like symptoms that suggest a CMV infection; when a newborn has multiple congenital abnormalities, unexplained jaundice or anemia, and/or when an infant has seizures or developmental problems that may be due to CMV; prior to receiving an organ transplant
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for CMV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, the sample may be blood, urine, sputum, amniotic fluid, cerebrospinal fluid, duodenal fluid, or other body tissue

Cytomegalovirus Antibody (IgG and IgM),.Why Get Tested?: If your health practitioner suspects that you presently have, or recently had, a cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection or if it is important to know if you have ever had a CMV infection, such as prior to receiving an organ transplant
Cytomegalovirus Antibody (IgG and IgM),.When To Get Tested?: When a young adult, a pregnant woman, or an immune-compromised person has flu-like symptoms that suggest a CMV infection; when a newborn has multiple congenital abnormalities, unexplained jaundice or anemia, and/or when an infant has seizures or developmental problems that may be due to CMV; prior to receiving an organ transplant
Cytomegalovirus Antibody (IgG and IgM),.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for CMV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, the sample may be blood, urine, sputum, amniotic fluid, cerebrospinal fluid, duodenal fluid, or other body tissue

D-dimer.Why Get Tested?: To help rule out clotting (thrombotic) episodes and to help diagnose conditions related to thrombosis
D-dimer.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a blood clot or a condition that causes inappropriate blood clots, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and to monitor treatment of DIC and excessive clotting conditions
D-dimer.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

D-Xylose Absorption Test.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your ability to absorb carbohydrates and help determine the cause of malabsorption
D-Xylose Absorption Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
D-Xylose Absorption Test.Sample Required?: Timed blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm and timed urine collection
D-Xylose Absorption Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Fast for 8 hours and avoid foods high in pentose, such as jams, fruits, and pastries, for 24 hours prior to the test. Ask your healthcare provider if there are any changes to your medications that you should make.

Darkfield Microscopy.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Darkfield Microscopy.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Darkfield Microscopy.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

DAT.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of hemolytic anemia as caused by autoimmune disease or induced by drugs; to investigate a blood transfusion reaction; to diagnose hemolytic disease of the newborn
DAT.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider wants to find out the cause of your hemolytic anemia; when you have had a blood transfusion recently and are experiencing symptoms of a transfusion reaction; or when a newborn shows signs of hemolytic disease of the newborn
DAT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

DD3.Why Get Tested?: To help determine if a repeat prostate biopsy is indicated to help detect prostate cancer
DD3.Sample Required?: The first amount of urine collected after a healthcare practitioner performs a digital rectal exam (DRE)

Dehydroepiandrosterone Sulfate.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate adrenal gland function; to detect adrenal tumors or cancers; to help determine the cause of masculine physical characteristics (virilization) in girls and women or early puberty in boys
Dehydroepiandrosterone Sulfate.When To Get Tested?: When a girl or woman has excess facial and body hair (hirsutism), acne, absence of menstrual periods (amenorrhea), or a woman has infertility; when a boy shows signs of very early (precocious) puberty such as deeper voice, pubic hair, or muscle development
Dehydroepiandrosterone Sulfate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Dehydroepiandrosterone Sulfate.Test Preparation Needed?: None, although women should talk to their health practitioner about the timing of the test; your healthcare provider may want to have the sample collected a week before or after your menstrual period.

Delta-aminolevulinic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
Delta-aminolevulinic Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
Delta-aminolevulinic Acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
Delta-aminolevulinic Acid.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

Dengue Antibodies (IgG, IgM); Dengue Vir.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose dengue fever, particularly if you are experiencing fever after travel to a tropical or subtropical destination
Dengue Antibodies (IgG, IgM); Dengue Vir.When To Get Tested?: When you develop a high fever within 2 weeks of travel to an area where dengue fever is endemic or an outbreak is occurring
Dengue Antibodies (IgG, IgM); Dengue Vir.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Dengue Fever Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose dengue fever, particularly if you are experiencing fever after travel to a tropical or subtropical destination
Dengue Fever Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you develop a high fever within 2 weeks of travel to an area where dengue fever is endemic or an outbreak is occurring
Dengue Fever Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Dengue Fever Testing.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose dengue fever, particularly if you are experiencing fever after travel to a tropical or subtropical destination
Dengue Fever Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you develop a high fever within 2 weeks of travel to an area where dengue fever is endemic or an outbreak is occurring
Dengue Fever Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Dengue Fever Virus.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose dengue fever, particularly if you are experiencing fever after travel to a tropical or subtropical destination
Dengue Fever Virus.When To Get Tested?: When you develop a high fever within 2 weeks of travel to an area where dengue fever is endemic or an outbreak is occurring
Dengue Fever Virus.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Deoxypyridinoline.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Deoxypyridinoline.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Deoxypyridinoline.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Deoxypyridinoline.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate effectiveness of treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), a type of liver cancer, if the level of des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin is elevated prior to treatment; to monitor for recurrence of HCC
Des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin.When To Get Tested?: Periodically when you have been treated for HCC
Des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin (DCP).Why Get Tested?: To evaluate effectiveness of treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), a type of liver cancer, if the level of des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin is elevated prior to treatment; to monitor for recurrence of HCC
Des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin (DCP).When To Get Tested?: Periodically when you have been treated for HCC
Des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin (DCP).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Dexamethasone Suppression Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose Cushing syndrome or primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease); to detect conditions affecting the pituitary or adrenal glands
Dexamethasone Suppression Test.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects excess or deficient cortisol production
Dexamethasone Suppression Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a saliva sample may be used
Dexamethasone Suppression Test.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be required to rest before sample collection. For a salivary cortisol test, you may be instructed to refrain from eating, drinking, or brushing your teeth for a period of time (may be some time between 15 to 30 minutes) prior to the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

DGP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
DGP.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
DGP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
DGP.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

DHEA Sulfate.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate adrenal gland function; to detect adrenal tumors or cancers; to help determine the cause of masculine physical characteristics (virilization) in girls and women or early puberty in boys
DHEA Sulfate.When To Get Tested?: When a girl or woman has excess facial and body hair (hirsutism), acne, absence of menstrual periods (amenorrhea), or a woman has infertility; when a boy shows signs of very early (precocious) puberty such as deeper voice, pubic hair, or muscle development
DHEA Sulfate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
DHEA Sulfate.Test Preparation Needed?: None, although women should talk to their health practitioner about the timing of the test; your healthcare provider may want to have the sample collected a week before or after your menstrual period.

DHEA-SO4.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate adrenal gland function; to detect adrenal tumors or cancers; to help determine the cause of masculine physical characteristics (virilization) in girls and women or early puberty in boys
DHEA-SO4.When To Get Tested?: When a girl or woman has excess facial and body hair (hirsutism), acne, absence of menstrual periods (amenorrhea), or a woman has infertility; when a boy shows signs of very early (precocious) puberty such as deeper voice, pubic hair, or muscle development
DHEA-SO4.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
DHEA-SO4.Test Preparation Needed?: None, although women should talk to their health practitioner about the timing of the test; your healthcare provider may want to have the sample collected a week before or after your menstrual period.

DHEAS.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate adrenal gland function; to detect adrenal tumors or cancers; to help determine the cause of masculine physical characteristics (virilization) in girls and women or early puberty in boys
DHEAS.When To Get Tested?: When a girl or woman has excess facial and body hair (hirsutism), acne, absence of menstrual periods (amenorrhea), or a woman has infertility; when a boy shows signs of very early (precocious) puberty such as deeper voice, pubic hair, or muscle development
DHEAS.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
DHEAS.Test Preparation Needed?: None, although women should talk to their health practitioner about the timing of the test; your healthcare provider may want to have the sample collected a week before or after your menstrual period.

diabetes.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
diabetes.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
diabetes.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
diabetes.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

diabetes (1771).Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
diabetes (1771).When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
diabetes (1771).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
diabetes (1771).Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

diabetes (282).Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
diabetes (282).When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
diabetes (282).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
diabetes (282).Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Diabetes Autoantibodies.Why Get Tested?: To identify people at increased risk for developing type 1 diabetes or requiring insulin treatment; to aid in the classification of diabetes. Note: testing for islet autoantibodies in non-diabetic individuals Is not advised unless the person is a participant in a research study that requires islet autoantibody testing.
Diabetes Autoantibodies.When To Get Tested?: Any time that you have diabetes and your healthcare practitioner cannot clearly determine if you have type 1 diabetes or type 2 diabetes, your healthcare practitioner may order tests for islet autoantibodies.
Diabetes Autoantibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Diabetes Mellitus Autoantibody Panel.Why Get Tested?: To identify people at increased risk for developing type 1 diabetes or requiring insulin treatment; to aid in the classification of diabetes. Note: testing for islet autoantibodies in non-diabetic individuals Is not advised unless the person is a participant in a research study that requires islet autoantibody testing.
Diabetes Mellitus Autoantibody Panel.When To Get Tested?: Any time that you have diabetes and your healthcare practitioner cannot clearly determine if you have type 1 diabetes or type 2 diabetes, your healthcare practitioner may order tests for islet autoantibodies.
Diabetes Mellitus Autoantibody Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Diff.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of abnormal results on a white blood cell (WBC) count; to help diagnose and/or monitor an illness affecting your immune system, such as an infection or inflammatory condition, or cancers that affect your white blood cells, such as leukemia
Diff.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when results of a CBC fall outside the reference range; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting white blood cells, such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs, such as chemotherapy
Diff.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (infants)

Differential Blood Count.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of abnormal results on a white blood cell (WBC) count; to help diagnose and/or monitor an illness affecting your immune system, such as an infection or inflammatory condition, or cancers that affect your white blood cells, such as leukemia
Differential Blood Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when results of a CBC fall outside the reference range; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting white blood cells, such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs, such as chemotherapy
Differential Blood Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (infants)

Differential Display Code 3.Why Get Tested?: To help determine if a repeat prostate biopsy is indicated to help detect prostate cancer
Differential Display Code 3.Sample Required?: The first amount of urine collected after a healthcare practitioner performs a digital rectal exam (DRE)

Differential Slide.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets, to distinguish between the different types of WBCs, and to determine their relative percentages in the blood; to help detect, diagnose, and/or monitor a range of deficiencies, diseases, and disorders involving blood cell production, function, and lifespan
Differential Slide.When To Get Tested?: When complete blood count (CBC) and/or automated WBC differential results are abnormal or when you have signs and symptoms that a healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a condition affecting your blood cells
Differential Slide.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by pricking a finger or, in the case of an infant, a heelstick

Digoxin.Why Get Tested?: To determine if the concentration of digoxin in your blood is at a therapeutic level or to detect toxic levels of the drug
Digoxin.When To Get Tested?: After the start of digoxin therapy and at regular intervals to ensure that drug levels are within therapeutic range (not too low or too high as to be toxic)
Digoxin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Digoxin.Test Preparation Needed?: No special preparation is needed, but timing of sample collection is important. When having your blood drawn, tell the person taking your sample when you took your last dose of digoxin.

Dilute Russell Viper Venom Test.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
Dilute Russell Viper Venom Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
Dilute Russell Viper Venom Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

Direct Anti-human Globulin Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of hemolytic anemia as caused by autoimmune disease or induced by drugs; to investigate a blood transfusion reaction; to diagnose hemolytic disease of the newborn
Direct Anti-human Globulin Test.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider wants to find out the cause of your hemolytic anemia; when you have had a blood transfusion recently and are experiencing symptoms of a transfusion reaction; or when a newborn shows signs of hemolytic disease of the newborn
Direct Anti-human Globulin Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Direct Antiglobulin Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of hemolytic anemia as caused by autoimmune disease or induced by drugs; to investigate a blood transfusion reaction; to diagnose hemolytic disease of the newborn
Direct Antiglobulin Test.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider wants to find out the cause of your hemolytic anemia; when you have had a blood transfusion recently and are experiencing symptoms of a transfusion reaction; or when a newborn shows signs of hemolytic disease of the newborn
Direct Antiglobulin Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Direct Bilirubin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor liver disorders or hemolytic anemia; to monitor neonatal jaundice
Direct Bilirubin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of liver damage, liver disease, bile duct blockage, hemolytic anemia, or a liver-related metabolic problem, or if a newborn has jaundice
Direct Bilirubin.Sample Required?: In adults, a blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm; in newborns, a blood sample from a heelstick; non-invasive technology is available in some healthcare facilities that will measure bilirubin by using an instrument placed on the skin (transcutaneous bilirubin meter)
Direct Bilirubin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for several hours before the test; fasting requirements vary by laboratory; ask your lab or healthcare provider for instructions.

Direct Coombs Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of hemolytic anemia as caused by autoimmune disease or induced by drugs; to investigate a blood transfusion reaction; to diagnose hemolytic disease of the newborn
Direct Coombs Test.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider wants to find out the cause of your hemolytic anemia; when you have had a blood transfusion recently and are experiencing symptoms of a transfusion reaction; or when a newborn shows signs of hemolytic disease of the newborn
Direct Coombs Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Direct LDL.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing heart disease and to monitor lipid-lowering lifestyle changes and drug therapies; to accurately determine your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level when you are not fasting
Direct LDL.When To Get Tested?: As a follow-up to a lipid profile if your triglycerides are significantly elevated; at regular intervals to monitor efforts to lower LDL levels
Direct LDL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Direct LDL.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, your health practitioner may request that you fast.

Direct LDL Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing heart disease and to monitor lipid-lowering lifestyle changes and drug therapies; to accurately determine your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level when you are not fasting
Direct LDL Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?: As a follow-up to a lipid profile if your triglycerides are significantly elevated; at regular intervals to monitor efforts to lower LDL levels
Direct LDL Cholesterol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Direct LDL Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, your health practitioner may request that you fast.

Direct LDL-C.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing heart disease and to monitor lipid-lowering lifestyle changes and drug therapies; to accurately determine your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level when you are not fasting
Direct LDL-C.When To Get Tested?: As a follow-up to a lipid profile if your triglycerides are significantly elevated; at regular intervals to monitor efforts to lower LDL levels
Direct LDL-C.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Direct LDL-C.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, your health practitioner may request that you fast.

Direct Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholester.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing heart disease and to monitor lipid-lowering lifestyle changes and drug therapies; to accurately determine your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level when you are not fasting
Direct Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholester.When To Get Tested?: As a follow-up to a lipid profile if your triglycerides are significantly elevated; at regular intervals to monitor efforts to lower LDL levels
Direct Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholester.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Direct Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholester.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, your health practitioner may request that you fast.

Disaccharide Absorption Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose lactose intolerance in individuals who have difficulties digesting dairy products, or sometimes as part of an investigation of malabsorption
Disaccharide Absorption Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming milk and other dairy products
Disaccharide Absorption Test.Sample Required?: A series of breath samples exhaled into a collector, or a series of blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm
Disaccharide Absorption Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting is required; nothing but water is permitted. Two weeks prior to the test, you must be off antibiotics and stomach medications, such as laxatives, antacids and stool softeners. Tell your healthcare practitioner about any other medications you are taking. Avoid strenuous activities. You may be instructed to brush your teeth and/or rinse your mouth with water prior to and during the breath test.

DLDL.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing heart disease and to monitor lipid-lowering lifestyle changes and drug therapies; to accurately determine your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level when you are not fasting
DLDL.When To Get Tested?: As a follow-up to a lipid profile if your triglycerides are significantly elevated; at regular intervals to monitor efforts to lower LDL levels
DLDL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
DLDL.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, your health practitioner may request that you fast.

Dopamine.Why Get Tested?: To help confirm or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Dopamine.When To Get Tested?: After or in conjunction with plasma free metanephrines and/or urine metanephrines tests and when your healthcare provider needs additional information regarding a possible catecholamine-secreting tumor
Dopamine.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Dopamine.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection. Although you may be seated for collection of the blood sample, it is recommended that you be lying down. Your healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.

Double stranded DNA Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus, SLE)
Double stranded DNA Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have a positive ANA test and signs and symptoms associated with lupus, such as persistent fatigue, pain in your joints and a red rash resembling a butterfly across the nose and cheeks; periodically used to assess disease activity in those who have been diagnosed with lupus
Double stranded DNA Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

DPD.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
DPD.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
DPD.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
DPD.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Drug Abuse Testing.Why Get Tested?: To screen for drug abuse, to monitor someone with a substance abuse problem, to monitor compliance with prescribed medications, or to detect and evaluate drug intoxication or overdose
Drug Abuse Testing.When To Get Tested?: Sometimes required prior to the start of a new job or insurance policy; randomly for workplace drug testing or athletic drug testing programs; as mandated when court-ordered; as indicated when ordered by a health practitioner to monitor a known or suspected substance abuse patient; sometimes when you are pregnant, will be receiving an organ transplant, when you are prescribed pain medication, or when you have symptoms suggesting drug intoxication or overdose
Drug Abuse Testing.Sample Required?: A random urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; hair, saliva, or sweat
Drug Abuse Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: Some prescription and over-the-counter drugs may give a positive screening result; prior to testing, indicate any medications that you have taken and/or for which you have prescriptions.

Drug Resistance Testing.Why Get Tested?: To determine the likelihood that a particular antibiotic or antifungal drug will be effective in stopping the growth of the bacteria or fungi causing your infection
Drug Resistance Testing.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to a positive bacterial or fungal culture; when selecting the best treatment for a bacterial or fungal infection requires laboratory testing; when your infection is not responding to treatment
Drug Resistance Testing.Sample Required?: A sample from an infected site is cultured on specialized media to recover the bacteria or fungus that is causing the infection. The method used to collect a sample from an individual depends on the type of culture performed (e.g., urine culture, blood culture, sputum culture, etc.).

Drug Screen.Why Get Tested?: To detect, quantify, and occasionally monitor drugs that are causing acute overdose symptoms; results from emergency and overdose testing are used primarily for treatment purposes; if results are needed for legal proceedings, then specific legal (forensic) procedures must be followed for sample collection, storage, and testing.
Drug Screen.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms such as delirium, difficulty breathing, nausea, agitation, seizures, changes in heart rhythm, characteristic odors, or increased temperature that an emergency room health practitioner thinks may be drug-related; at intervals to monitor a drug overdose
Drug Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva or another body fluid

Drug Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for drug abuse, to monitor someone with a substance abuse problem, to monitor compliance with prescribed medications, or to detect and evaluate drug intoxication or overdose
Drug Test.When To Get Tested?: Sometimes required prior to the start of a new job or insurance policy; randomly for workplace drug testing or athletic drug testing programs; as mandated when court-ordered; as indicated when ordered by a health practitioner to monitor a known or suspected substance abuse patient; sometimes when you are pregnant, will be receiving an organ transplant, when you are prescribed pain medication, or when you have symptoms suggesting drug intoxication or overdose
Drug Test.Sample Required?: A random urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; hair, saliva, or sweat
Drug Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Some prescription and over-the-counter drugs may give a positive screening result; prior to testing, indicate any medications that you have taken and/or for which you have prescriptions.

Drug Testing.Why Get Tested?: To detect, quantify, and occasionally monitor drugs that are causing acute overdose symptoms; results from emergency and overdose testing are used primarily for treatment purposes; if results are needed for legal proceedings, then specific legal (forensic) procedures must be followed for sample collection, storage, and testing.
Drug Testing.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms such as delirium, difficulty breathing, nausea, agitation, seizures, changes in heart rhythm, characteristic odors, or increased temperature that an emergency room health practitioner thinks may be drug-related; at intervals to monitor a drug overdose
Drug Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva or another body fluid

Drugs of Abuse Screen.Why Get Tested?: To screen for drug abuse, to monitor someone with a substance abuse problem, to monitor compliance with prescribed medications, or to detect and evaluate drug intoxication or overdose
Drugs of Abuse Screen.When To Get Tested?: Sometimes required prior to the start of a new job or insurance policy; randomly for workplace drug testing or athletic drug testing programs; as mandated when court-ordered; as indicated when ordered by a health practitioner to monitor a known or suspected substance abuse patient; sometimes when you are pregnant, will be receiving an organ transplant, when you are prescribed pain medication, or when you have symptoms suggesting drug intoxication or overdose
Drugs of Abuse Screen.Sample Required?: A random urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; hair, saliva, or sweat
Drugs of Abuse Screen.Test Preparation Needed?: Some prescription and over-the-counter drugs may give a positive screening result; prior to testing, indicate any medications that you have taken and/or for which you have prescriptions.

DRVVT.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
DRVVT.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
DRVVT.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

DST.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose Cushing syndrome or primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease); to detect conditions affecting the pituitary or adrenal glands
DST.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects excess or deficient cortisol production
DST.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a saliva sample may be used
DST.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be required to rest before sample collection. For a salivary cortisol test, you may be instructed to refrain from eating, drinking, or brushing your teeth for a period of time (may be some time between 15 to 30 minutes) prior to the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

E. coli.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your gastrointestinal symptoms are due to an infection caused by Escherichia coli bacteria that produce Shiga toxin
E. coli.When To Get Tested?: When you have acute diarrhea that is persistent, severe and/or bloody
E. coli.Sample Required?: A fresh liquid or unformed stool sample that does not contain urine or water, collected in a clean dry container; a rectal swab may be collected from infants. The stool or rectal swab may be placed in transport media for delivery to the laboratory.

E. coli non-O157.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your gastrointestinal symptoms are due to an infection caused by Escherichia coli bacteria that produce Shiga toxin
E. coli non-O157.When To Get Tested?: When you have acute diarrhea that is persistent, severe and/or bloody
E. coli non-O157.Sample Required?: A fresh liquid or unformed stool sample that does not contain urine or water, collected in a clean dry container; a rectal swab may be collected from infants. The stool or rectal swab may be placed in transport media for delivery to the laboratory.

E. coli O157.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your gastrointestinal symptoms are due to an infection caused by Escherichia coli bacteria that produce Shiga toxin
E. coli O157.When To Get Tested?: When you have acute diarrhea that is persistent, severe and/or bloody
E. coli O157.Sample Required?: A fresh liquid or unformed stool sample that does not contain urine or water, collected in a clean dry container; a rectal swab may be collected from infants. The stool or rectal swab may be placed in transport media for delivery to the laboratory.

E. coli O157 culture; Shiga-like toxin b.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your gastrointestinal symptoms are due to an infection caused by Escherichia coli bacteria that produce Shiga toxin
E. coli O157 culture; Shiga-like toxin b.When To Get Tested?: When you have acute diarrhea that is persistent, severe and/or bloody
E. coli O157 culture; Shiga-like toxin b.Sample Required?: A fresh liquid or unformed stool sample that does not contain urine or water, collected in a clean dry container; a rectal swab may be collected from infants. The stool or rectal swab may be placed in transport media for delivery to the laboratory.

EBV Ab to Early Antigen D, EA-D IgG Ab.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono); to distinguish between an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection and another illness with similar symptoms; to help evaluate susceptibility to EBV
EBV Ab to Early Antigen D, EA-D IgG Ab.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of mono but a negative mono test; when a pregnant woman has flu-like symptoms; occasionally when an asymptomatic person has been exposed to someone with mono; or possibly as a means to check immune system function
EBV Ab to Early Antigen D, EA-D IgG Ab.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

EBV Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono); to distinguish between an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection and another illness with similar symptoms; to help evaluate susceptibility to EBV
EBV Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of mono but a negative mono test; when a pregnant woman has flu-like symptoms; occasionally when an asymptomatic person has been exposed to someone with mono; or possibly as a means to check immune system function
EBV Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

EBV Nuclear Antigen Antibody EBNA-IgG Ab.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono); to distinguish between an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection and another illness with similar symptoms; to help evaluate susceptibility to EBV
EBV Nuclear Antigen Antibody EBNA-IgG Ab.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of mono but a negative mono test; when a pregnant woman has flu-like symptoms; occasionally when an asymptomatic person has been exposed to someone with mono; or possibly as a means to check immune system function
EBV Nuclear Antigen Antibody EBNA-IgG Ab.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

EBV Viral Capsid Antigen Antibody (VCA).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono); to distinguish between an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection and another illness with similar symptoms; to help evaluate susceptibility to EBV
EBV Viral Capsid Antigen Antibody (VCA).When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of mono but a negative mono test; when a pregnant woman has flu-like symptoms; occasionally when an asymptomatic person has been exposed to someone with mono; or possibly as a means to check immune system function
EBV Viral Capsid Antigen Antibody (VCA).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

eGFR.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
eGFR.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
eGFR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
eGFR.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

EGFR Mutation Testing.Why Get Tested?: To detect EGFR gene mutations in non-small cell lung cancer tumor cells; knowing whether a mutation is present in the cells can help determine if EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as gefitinib and erlotinib may be beneficial for treating the tumor.
EGFR Mutation Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer; when you are being treated with an EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor, but the cancer progresses
EGFR Mutation Testing.Sample Required?: A sample of cancer cells from a biopsy or surgical removal of cancerous tissue; if insufficient cells are obtained for testing by one of these methods, then a blood sample may be used as an alternative in some situations.
EGFR Mutation Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: In many cases preparation is minimal, but it will depend upon how the cancer cells are being obtained. You will receive instructions from your healthcare practitioner based on the procedure being used to obtain the sample.

Elastase, stool.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
Elastase, stool.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as stomach cramps, weight loss, malnutrition, malabsorption, delayed growth (in children) and fatty, foul-smelling stools and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
Elastase, stool.Sample Required?: A fresh formed stool sample that is not contaminated with urine
Elastase, stool.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be asked to discontinue them for 5 days prior to stool collection.

Electrolyte Panel.Why Get Tested?: To detect a problem with the body's electrolyte balance
Electrolyte Panel.When To Get Tested?: As part of routine health screening or when your healthcare provider suspects that you have an imbalance of one of the electrolytes (usually sodium or potassium) or an acid-base imbalance
Electrolyte Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Electrolytes.Why Get Tested?: To detect a problem with the body's electrolyte balance
Electrolytes.When To Get Tested?: As part of routine health screening or when your healthcare provider suspects that you have an imbalance of one of the electrolytes (usually sodium or potassium) or an acid-base imbalance
Electrolytes.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

EMA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
EMA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
EMA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
EMA.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

Emergency and Overdose Drug Testing.Why Get Tested?: To detect, quantify, and occasionally monitor drugs that are causing acute overdose symptoms; results from emergency and overdose testing are used primarily for treatment purposes; if results are needed for legal proceedings, then specific legal (forensic) procedures must be followed for sample collection, storage, and testing.
Emergency and Overdose Drug Testing.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms such as delirium, difficulty breathing, nausea, agitation, seizures, changes in heart rhythm, characteristic odors, or increased temperature that an emergency room health practitioner thinks may be drug-related; at intervals to monitor a drug overdose
Emergency and Overdose Drug Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva or another body fluid

EML4-ALK Fusion Protein.Why Get Tested?: To detect an ALK gene rearrangement in tumor tissue in order to guide non-small cell lung cancer therapy
EML4-ALK Fusion Protein.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer and your healthcare practitioner is considering a therapeutic management plan that may include an ALK kinase inhibitor such as crizotinib
EML4-ALK Fusion Protein.Sample Required?: A tumor tissue sample is obtained through a biopsy procedure or sometimes collected during surgery. The tumor tissue is typically evaluated by a pathologist prior to testing.

Endomysial Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
Endomysial Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
Endomysial Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Endomysial Antibody.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

Enteric Pathogen Panel.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an infection of your digestive tract due to disease-causing (pathogenic) bacteria, parasites, or viruses
Enteric Pathogen Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea and/or vomiting; when you have blood or mucus in your loose stools
Enteric Pathogen Panel.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample collected in a clean container; the stool sample should not be contaminated with urine or water; once it has been collected, the stool should either be taken to the laboratory within two hours after collection or transferred into special transport vials containing preservative solutions

Enteric Pathogens Culture, stool.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an infection of your digestive tract due to the presence of disease-causing (pathogenic) bacteria
Enteric Pathogens Culture, stool.When To Get Tested?: When you have diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea and/or vomiting that is severe or lasts more than a few days
Enteric Pathogens Culture, stool.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample transported to the laboratory within 2 hours or one that has been placed in a transport medium (a collection vial containing a preservative)

Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor.Why Get Tested?: To detect EGFR gene mutations in non-small cell lung cancer tumor cells; knowing whether a mutation is present in the cells can help determine if EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as gefitinib and erlotinib may be beneficial for treating the tumor.
Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer; when you are being treated with an EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor, but the cancer progresses
Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor.Sample Required?: A sample of cancer cells from a biopsy or surgical removal of cancerous tissue; if insufficient cells are obtained for testing by one of these methods, then a blood sample may be used as an alternative in some situations.
Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor.Test Preparation Needed?: In many cases preparation is minimal, but it will depend upon how the cancer cells are being obtained. You will receive instructions from your healthcare practitioner based on the procedure being used to obtain the sample.

Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Mutatio.Why Get Tested?: To detect EGFR gene mutations in non-small cell lung cancer tumor cells; knowing whether a mutation is present in the cells can help determine if EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as gefitinib and erlotinib may be beneficial for treating the tumor.
Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Mutatio.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer; when you are being treated with an EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor, but the cancer progresses
Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Mutatio.Sample Required?: A sample of cancer cells from a biopsy or surgical removal of cancerous tissue; if insufficient cells are obtained for testing by one of these methods, then a blood sample may be used as an alternative in some situations.
Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Mutatio.Test Preparation Needed?: In many cases preparation is minimal, but it will depend upon how the cancer cells are being obtained. You will receive instructions from your healthcare practitioner based on the procedure being used to obtain the sample.

Epinephrine.Why Get Tested?: To help confirm or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Epinephrine.When To Get Tested?: After or in conjunction with plasma free metanephrines and/or urine metanephrines tests and when your healthcare provider needs additional information regarding a possible catecholamine-secreting tumor
Epinephrine.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Epinephrine.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection. Although you may be seated for collection of the blood sample, it is recommended that you be lying down. Your healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.

EPO.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of anemia; to help diagnose a bone marrow disorder or a condition causing the production of too many red blood cells (polycythemia or erythrocytosis)
EPO.When To Get Tested?: When you have anemia that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be caused by decreased red blood cell production; when you are producing too many red blood cells
EPO.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) Antibody Tests.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono); to distinguish between an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection and another illness with similar symptoms; to help evaluate susceptibility to EBV
Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) Antibody Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of mono but a negative mono test; when a pregnant woman has flu-like symptoms; occasionally when an asymptomatic person has been exposed to someone with mono; or possibly as a means to check immune system function
Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) Antibody Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Epstein-Barr Virus Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono); to distinguish between an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection and another illness with similar symptoms; to help evaluate susceptibility to EBV
Epstein-Barr Virus Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of mono but a negative mono test; when a pregnant woman has flu-like symptoms; occasionally when an asymptomatic person has been exposed to someone with mono; or possibly as a means to check immune system function
Epstein-Barr Virus Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

ER and PR Status.Why Get Tested?: The hormone receptor test determines if a breast cancer tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, helping to guide treatment and determine prognosis
ER and PR Status.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or when your cancer has recurred
ER and PR Status.Sample Required?: A sample of breast cancer tissue obtained during a biopsy or a tumor removed surgically during a lumpectomy or mastectomy
ER and PR Status.Test Preparation Needed?: Your health practitioner may have you discontinue taking hormones for a time period before your sample is collected.

erb-b2 receptor tyrosine kinase 2.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether a tumor is positive for particular HER2 (ERBB2) mutations, which helps to guide treatment and predict the course of the disease (prognosis); sometimes to monitor treatment and for cancer recurrence
erb-b2 receptor tyrosine kinase 2.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or you had an invasive breast cancer that was treated but the tumor reoccurs or spreads (metastasizes), or when you have been diagnosed with certain types of stomach and esophagus cancer that are inoperable, locally advanced, recurrent, or metastatic
erb-b2 receptor tyrosine kinase 2.Sample Required?: A sample of tumor tissue is obtained by doing a fine needle aspiration, needle biopsy, or surgical biopsy (a tumor removed surgically)
erb-b2 receptor tyrosine kinase 2.Test Preparation Needed?: Before a biopsy, the physician who will obtain the sample of tumor tissue will provide instructions.

erbB-1.Why Get Tested?: To detect EGFR gene mutations in non-small cell lung cancer tumor cells; knowing whether a mutation is present in the cells can help determine if EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as gefitinib and erlotinib may be beneficial for treating the tumor.
erbB-1.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer; when you are being treated with an EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor, but the cancer progresses
erbB-1.Sample Required?: A sample of cancer cells from a biopsy or surgical removal of cancerous tissue; if insufficient cells are obtained for testing by one of these methods, then a blood sample may be used as an alternative in some situations.
erbB-1.Test Preparation Needed?: In many cases preparation is minimal, but it will depend upon how the cancer cells are being obtained. You will receive instructions from your healthcare practitioner based on the procedure being used to obtain the sample.

ERBB2.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether a tumor is positive for particular HER2 (ERBB2) mutations, which helps to guide treatment and predict the course of the disease (prognosis); sometimes to monitor treatment and for cancer recurrence
ERBB2.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or you had an invasive breast cancer that was treated but the tumor reoccurs or spreads (metastasizes), or when you have been diagnosed with certain types of stomach and esophagus cancer that are inoperable, locally advanced, recurrent, or metastatic
ERBB2.Sample Required?: A sample of tumor tissue is obtained by doing a fine needle aspiration, needle biopsy, or surgical biopsy (a tumor removed surgically)
ERBB2.Test Preparation Needed?: Before a biopsy, the physician who will obtain the sample of tumor tissue will provide instructions.

Ergocalciferol (Vitamin D2).Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have a vitamin D deficiency; if you are receiving vitamin D supplementation, to determine if it is adequate
Ergocalciferol (Vitamin D2).When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal calcium, phosphorus, and/or parathyroid hormone level; when you have evidence of bone disease or bone weakness; when you are at high risk of deficiency or a healthcare practitioner suspects that you might have a vitamin D deficiency; prior to starting drug treatment for osteoporosis; periodically to monitor treatment of vitamin D deficiency
Ergocalciferol (Vitamin D2).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Erythrocyte Acetylcholinesterase; Butyry.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
Erythrocyte Acetylcholinesterase; Butyry.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
Erythrocyte Acetylcholinesterase; Butyry.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Erythrocyte Count.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the number of red blood cells (RBCs); used to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions affecting red blood cells
Erythrocyte Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), during a health examination, or when you have signs and symptoms of a condition such as anemia or polycythemia
Erythrocyte Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Erythrocyte Morphology.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets, to distinguish between the different types of WBCs, and to determine their relative percentages in the blood; to help detect, diagnose, and/or monitor a range of deficiencies, diseases, and disorders involving blood cell production, function, and lifespan
Erythrocyte Morphology.When To Get Tested?: When complete blood count (CBC) and/or automated WBC differential results are abnormal or when you have signs and symptoms that a healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a condition affecting your blood cells
Erythrocyte Morphology.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by pricking a finger or, in the case of an infant, a heelstick

Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of inflammation caused by one or more conditions such as infections, tumors or autoimmune diseases; to help diagnose and monitor specific conditions such as temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate.When To Get Tested?: When your health practitioner thinks that you might have a condition causing inflammation; when you have signs and symptoms associated with temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis such as headaches, neck or shoulder pain, pelvic pain, anemia, poor appetite, unexplained weight loss, and joint stiffness
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR).Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of inflammation caused by one or more conditions such as infections, tumors or autoimmune diseases; to help diagnose and monitor specific conditions such as temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis
