Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR).When To Get Tested?: When your health practitioner thinks that you might have a condition causing inflammation; when you have signs and symptoms associated with temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis such as headaches, neck or shoulder pain, pelvic pain, anemia, poor appetite, unexplained weight loss, and joint stiffness
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Erythropoietin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of anemia; to help diagnose a bone marrow disorder or a condition causing the production of too many red blood cells (polycythemia or erythrocytosis)
Erythropoietin.When To Get Tested?: When you have anemia that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be caused by decreased red blood cell production; when you are producing too many red blood cells
Erythropoietin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Essential Minerals.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor a mineral deficiency or excess; sometimes to evaluate your nutritional status
Essential Minerals.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms or signs of a mineral deficiency or excess; as indicated by your healthcare provider when you have a condition that affects mineral absorption, use, or storage
Essential Minerals.Sample Required?: Trace mineral testing is usually performed on a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes a 24-hour urine collection is obtained. Special metal-free blood or acid-washed urine containers are used to minimize the potential for sample contamination by any outside sources of minerals. Rarely, hair may be collected or a biopsy may be performed to obtain a tissue sample to evaluate mineral deficiencies, excesses, and storage that have occurred over time.
Essential Minerals.Test Preparation Needed?: Check with your healthcare practitioner to find out if fasting is needed before your test.

Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eG.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eG.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eG.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Estradiol (E2).Why Get Tested?: To measure or monitor your estrogen levels; to detect an abnormal level or hormone imbalance as a cause of your signs and symptoms; to monitor treatment for infertility or symptoms of menopause; sometimes to test for fetal-placental status during early stages of pregnancy
Estradiol (E2).When To Get Tested?:
Women: when you show symptoms of a hormone imbalance, such as abnormal vaginal bleeding, lack of menstrual periods, unusual and/or early or late sex organ development; when you are undergoing infertility treatment or therapy for menopause symptoms; when you are pregnant and your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor the health of your placenta and developing baby, if it is a high-risk pregnancy
Men: when you have signs of feminization, such as enlarged breasts (gynecomastia)
Estradiol (E2).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein or a 24-hour urine sample
Estradiol (E2).Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle or, if pregnant, with the gestational age of the baby.

Estriol (E3).Why Get Tested?: To measure or monitor your estrogen levels; to detect an abnormal level or hormone imbalance as a cause of your signs and symptoms; to monitor treatment for infertility or symptoms of menopause; sometimes to test for fetal-placental status during early stages of pregnancy
Estriol (E3).When To Get Tested?:
Women: when you show symptoms of a hormone imbalance, such as abnormal vaginal bleeding, lack of menstrual periods, unusual and/or early or late sex organ development; when you are undergoing infertility treatment or therapy for menopause symptoms; when you are pregnant and your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor the health of your placenta and developing baby, if it is a high-risk pregnancy
Men: when you have signs of feminization, such as enlarged breasts (gynecomastia)
Estriol (E3).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein or a 24-hour urine sample
Estriol (E3).Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle or, if pregnant, with the gestational age of the baby.

Estrogen and Progesterone Receptor Statu.Why Get Tested?: The hormone receptor test determines if a breast cancer tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, helping to guide treatment and determine prognosis
Estrogen and Progesterone Receptor Statu.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or when your cancer has recurred
Estrogen and Progesterone Receptor Statu.Sample Required?: A sample of breast cancer tissue obtained during a biopsy or a tumor removed surgically during a lumpectomy or mastectomy
Estrogen and Progesterone Receptor Statu.Test Preparation Needed?: Your health practitioner may have you discontinue taking hormones for a time period before your sample is collected.

Estrogen Fractions/fractionated.Why Get Tested?: To measure or monitor your estrogen levels; to detect an abnormal level or hormone imbalance as a cause of your signs and symptoms; to monitor treatment for infertility or symptoms of menopause; sometimes to test for fetal-placental status during early stages of pregnancy
Estrogen Fractions/fractionated.When To Get Tested?:

Estrogen Fractions/fractionated.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle or, if pregnant, with the gestational age of the baby.

Estrogen Receptors.Test Preparation Needed?: Your health practitioner may have you discontinue taking hormones for a time period before your sample is collected.

Ethanol.Why Get Tested?: To determine if a person has consumed ethanol and to measure the amount of ethanol present
Ethanol.When To Get Tested?: When someone has signs and symptoms that suggest intoxication or ethanol poisoning; when a person is suspected of violating drinking-related laws, or as part of a drug testing panel
Ethanol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva is collected. Blood, urine, and saliva samples must be sent to a laboratory for analysis. A breath sample is analyzed immediately on site using a breathalyzer.

Ethyl Alcohol.Why Get Tested?: To determine if a person has consumed ethanol and to measure the amount of ethanol present
Ethyl Alcohol.When To Get Tested?: When someone has signs and symptoms that suggest intoxication or ethanol poisoning; when a person is suspected of violating drinking-related laws, or as part of a drug testing panel
Ethyl Alcohol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva is collected. Blood, urine, and saliva samples must be sent to a laboratory for analysis. A breath sample is analyzed immediately on site using a breathalyzer.

EtOH.Why Get Tested?: To determine if a person has consumed ethanol and to measure the amount of ethanol present
EtOH.When To Get Tested?: When someone has signs and symptoms that suggest intoxication or ethanol poisoning; when a person is suspected of violating drinking-related laws, or as part of a drug testing panel
EtOH.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva is collected. Blood, urine, and saliva samples must be sent to a laboratory for analysis. A breath sample is analyzed immediately on site using a breathalyzer.

Extractable Nuclear Antigen Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Extractable Nuclear Antigen Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Extractable Nuclear Antigen Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Extractable Nuclear Antigen Antibodies (.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Extractable Nuclear Antigen Antibodies (.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Extractable Nuclear Antigen Antibodies (.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

F-Actin Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
F-Actin Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
F-Actin Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Factor Assays.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether levels of one or more of your coagulation factors are increased, normal, or decreased
Factor Assays.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding, abnormal results on coagulation screening tests such as prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT), or have a relative with a hereditary coagulation factor deficiency; you may be tested when your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor the severity of a factor deficiency and/or the effectiveness of treatment.
Factor Assays.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Factor I.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; sometimes used to help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Factor I.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged; when you have a relative with a hereditary fibrinogen deficiency or abnormality; when your health care provider wants additional information to help evaluate your risk of developing heart disease
Factor I.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Factor II.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether levels of one or more of your coagulation factors are increased, normal, or decreased
Factor II.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding, abnormal results on coagulation screening tests such as prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT), or have a relative with a hereditary coagulation factor deficiency; you may be tested when your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor the severity of a factor deficiency and/or the effectiveness of treatment.
Factor II.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Factor II 20210.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an inherited gene mutation that increases your risk of developing a blood clot, including a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and/or venous thromboembolism (VTE)
Factor II 20210.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot (thrombotic episode), especially when you are less than 50 years old, have recurrent DVT or VTE episodes, experienced DVT or VTE during pregnancy, had DVT at unusual sites, or have a strong family history of thrombosis
Factor II 20210.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Factor II Mutation.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an inherited gene mutation that increases your risk of developing a blood clot, including a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and/or venous thromboembolism (VTE)
Factor II Mutation.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot (thrombotic episode), especially when you are less than 50 years old, have recurrent DVT or VTE episodes, experienced DVT or VTE during pregnancy, had DVT at unusual sites, or have a strong family history of thrombosis
Factor II Mutation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Factor VII.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Factor XIII.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

FANA.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose certain autoimmune disorders, such as lupus and Sjögren syndrome, among other types
FANA.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of certain autoimmune disorders
FANA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
FANA.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, certain medications can affect ANA test results, so tell your healthcare provider about any prescription medications, nonprescription medications, or street drugs you use.

Fasting Blood Glucose.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
Fasting Blood Glucose.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
Fasting Blood Glucose.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
Fasting Blood Glucose.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Fasting Blood Sugar.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
Fasting Blood Sugar.When To Get Tested?:

Fasting Insulin.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate insulin production by the beta cells in the pancreas; to help diagnose the presence of an insulin-producing tumor in the islet cells of the pancreas (insulinoma); to help determine the cause of low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to help identify insulin resistance, or to help determine when a type 2 diabetic might need to start taking insulin to supplement oral medications
Fasting Insulin.When To Get Tested?: When you have low blood glucose levels with symptoms such as sweating, palpitations, dizziness, fainting; when you have diabetes and your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor your insulin production; sometimes when it is suspected that you have insulin resistance
Fasting Insulin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Fasting Insulin.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, you will be asked to fast for 8 hours before the blood sample is collected. Occasionally, a healthcare practitioner may do testing when fasting is not possible, such as when a glucose tolerance test is done. In some cases, a healthcare practitioner may request that you fast longer than 8 hours.

Fasting Plasma Glucose.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine

Fat Stain Oil Red O.Why Get Tested?: To detect and measure excess fat in the stool; to help diagnose conditions causing malabsorption
Fat Stain Oil Red O.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
Fat Stain Oil Red O.Sample Required?: A random stool collection; sometimes a 72-hour stool collection
Fat Stain Oil Red O.Test Preparation Needed?: For a 72-hour stool collection, follow your healthcare practitioner's instructions; this may include consuming 50-150 grams of fat a day in your diet for 2-3 days prior to and during the stool collection period.

Fat, Fecal Qualitative or Quantitative.Why Get Tested?: To detect and measure excess fat in the stool; to help diagnose conditions causing malabsorption
Fat, Fecal Qualitative or Quantitative.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
Fat, Fecal Qualitative or Quantitative.Sample Required?: A random stool collection; sometimes a 72-hour stool collection
Fat, Fecal Qualitative or Quantitative.Test Preparation Needed?: For a 72-hour stool collection, follow your healthcare practitioner's instructions; this may include consuming 50-150 grams of fat a day in your diet for 2-3 days prior to and during the stool collection period.

Fat, Feces.Why Get Tested?: To detect and measure excess fat in the stool; to help diagnose conditions causing malabsorption
Fat, Feces.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
Fat, Feces.Sample Required?: A random stool collection; sometimes a 72-hour stool collection
Fat, Feces.Test Preparation Needed?: For a 72-hour stool collection, follow your healthcare practitioner's instructions; this may include consuming 50-150 grams of fat a day in your diet for 2-3 days prior to and during the stool collection period.

Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
FBG.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

FBS.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Fe Tests.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your body's current level of iron; to help diagnose iron deficiency or iron overload
Fe Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (deficiency) or too much iron (overload) in your body
Fe Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Fe Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

FE-1.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
FE-1.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as stomach cramps, weight loss, malnutrition, malabsorption, delayed growth (in children) and fatty, foul-smelling stools and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
FE-1.Sample Required?: A fresh formed stool sample that is not contaminated with urine
FE-1.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be asked to discontinue them for 5 days prior to stool collection.

Fecal Calprotectin.Why Get Tested?: To detect inflammation in the intestines; to distinguish between inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and non-inflammatory bowel conditions; to monitor IBD activity
Fecal Calprotectin.When To Get Tested?: When you have bloody or watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, with or without fever, lasting more than a few days
Fecal Calprotectin.Sample Required?: A stool sample collected in a clean container

Fecal Elastase-1.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
Fecal Elastase-1.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as stomach cramps, weight loss, malnutrition, malabsorption, delayed growth (in children) and fatty, foul-smelling stools and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
Fecal Elastase-1.Sample Required?: A fresh formed stool sample that is not contaminated with urine
Fecal Elastase-1.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be asked to discontinue them for 5 days prior to stool collection.

Fecal Fat.Why Get Tested?: To detect and measure excess fat in the stool; to help diagnose conditions causing malabsorption
Fecal Fat.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
Fecal Fat.Sample Required?: A random stool collection; sometimes a 72-hour stool collection
Fecal Fat.Test Preparation Needed?: For a 72-hour stool collection, follow your healthcare practitioner's instructions; this may include consuming 50-150 grams of fat a day in your diet for 2-3 days prior to and during the stool collection period.

Fecal Immunochemical Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
Fecal Immunochemical Test.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
Fecal Immunochemical Test.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
Fecal Immunochemical Test.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

Fecal Immunochemical Test and Fecal Occu.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
Fecal Immunochemical Test and Fecal Occu.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
Fecal Immunochemical Test and Fecal Occu.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
Fecal Immunochemical Test and Fecal Occu.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

Fecal Lactoferrin.Why Get Tested?: To detect inflammation in the intestines; to help identify active inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); to distinguish between IBD and non-inflammatory bowel conditions; to monitor IBD activity
Fecal Lactoferrin.When To Get Tested?: When you have bloody or watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, with or without fever, lasting more than a few days
Fecal Lactoferrin.Sample Required?: A stool sample collected in a clean container

Fecal Occult Blood Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
Fecal Occult Blood Test.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
Fecal Occult Blood Test.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
Fecal Occult Blood Test.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

Fecal Pancreatic Elastase.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
Fecal Pancreatic Elastase.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as stomach cramps, weight loss, malnutrition, malabsorption, delayed growth (in children) and fatty, foul-smelling stools and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
Fecal Pancreatic Elastase.Sample Required?: A fresh formed stool sample that is not contaminated with urine
Fecal Pancreatic Elastase.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be asked to discontinue them for 5 days prior to stool collection.

Fecal WBC Non-microscopic.Why Get Tested?: To detect inflammation in the intestines; to help identify active inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); to distinguish between IBD and non-inflammatory bowel conditions; to monitor IBD activity
Fecal WBC Non-microscopic.When To Get Tested?: When you have bloody or watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, with or without fever, lasting more than a few days
Fecal WBC Non-microscopic.Sample Required?: A stool sample collected in a clean container

Feces Culture.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an infection of your digestive tract due to the presence of disease-causing (pathogenic) bacteria
Feces Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea and/or vomiting that is severe or lasts more than a few days
Feces Culture.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample transported to the laboratory within 2 hours or one that has been placed in a transport medium (a collection vial containing a preservative)

FEP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
FEP.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
FEP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
FEP.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

Ferritin.Why Get Tested?: To determine your body's total iron storage capacity; to help diagnose iron deficiency or iron overload
Ferritin.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (iron deficiency) or too much iron (iron overload) in the body
Ferritin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Ferritin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is permitted. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Ferritin, serum.Why Get Tested?: To determine your body's total iron storage capacity; to help diagnose iron deficiency or iron overload
Ferritin, serum.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (iron deficiency) or too much iron (iron overload) in the body
Ferritin, serum.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Ferritin, serum.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is permitted. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Fetal Fibronectin.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a pregnant woman's risk of preterm delivery
Fetal Fibronectin.When To Get Tested?: When you are 22 to 35 weeks pregnant and are having symptoms of premature labor; sometimes if you are at high risk, such as if you have had a previous preterm delivery or have a short cervix
Fetal Fibronectin.Sample Required?: A swab is used to take a sample of cervical or vaginal fluid from the posterior portion of the vagina or from the area just outside the opening of the cervix.
Fetal Fibronectin.Test Preparation Needed?: Anything that physically disturbs the cervix or uterus has the potential to elevate fFN levels. Therefore, your healthcare practitioner should collect the sample before a pelvic examination or vaginal ultrasound. Semen may contain enough fFN to create a positive test result, so sexual intercourse should be avoided within 24 hours of sample collection. Avoid lubricants, lotions, soaps, and douches at least a day before the test.

Fetal Fibronectin (fFN).Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a pregnant woman's risk of preterm delivery
Fetal Fibronectin (fFN).When To Get Tested?: When you are 22 to 35 weeks pregnant and are having symptoms of premature labor; sometimes if you are at high risk, such as if you have had a previous preterm delivery or have a short cervix
Fetal Fibronectin (fFN).Sample Required?: A swab is used to take a sample of cervical or vaginal fluid from the posterior portion of the vagina or from the area just outside the opening of the cervix.
Fetal Fibronectin (fFN).Test Preparation Needed?: Anything that physically disturbs the cervix or uterus has the potential to elevate fFN levels. Therefore, your healthcare practitioner should collect the sample before a pelvic examination or vaginal ultrasound. Semen may contain enough fFN to create a positive test result, so sexual intercourse should be avoided within 24 hours of sample collection. Avoid lubricants, lotions, soaps, and douches at least a day before the test.

Fetal Lung Maturity Tests.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose certain birth defects, genetic diseases, and chromosomal abnormalities in a fetus, especially if prenatal screening tests are abnormal; if there is a family history or high risk of inherited disease; sometimes to diagnose a fetal infection and occasionally to help diagnose and monitor hemolytic disease in a fetus; rarely, to evaluate fetal lung maturity when there is an increased risk of premature delivery
Fetal Lung Maturity Tests.When To Get Tested?: Testing is most commonly offered between 15 and 20 weeks of pregnancy to test for genetic diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, and open neural tube defects and is recommended after a pregnant woman has an abnormality on an initial prenatal screening test; when it is suspected that a fetus has an infection or other illness or when a fetus has hemolytic disease; rarely it may be done after 32 weeks to evaluate fetal lung maturity
Fetal Lung Maturity Tests.Sample Required?: A sample (about 1 ounce) of amniotic fluid is obtained using a procedure called amniocentesis that involves inserting a thin needle through the belly and uterus into the amniotic sac (see Common Questions below).
Fetal Lung Maturity Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: Depending upon the stage of pregnancy, either a full or empty bladder may be required at the time the amniocentesis is performed. Be sure to follow any instructions provided.

fFN.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a pregnant woman's risk of preterm delivery
fFN.When To Get Tested?: When you are 22 to 35 weeks pregnant and are having symptoms of premature labor; sometimes if you are at high risk, such as if you have had a previous preterm delivery or have a short cervix
fFN.Sample Required?: A swab is used to take a sample of cervical or vaginal fluid from the posterior portion of the vagina or from the area just outside the opening of the cervix.
fFN.Test Preparation Needed?: Anything that physically disturbs the cervix or uterus has the potential to elevate fFN levels. Therefore, your healthcare practitioner should collect the sample before a pelvic examination or vaginal ultrasound. Semen may contain enough fFN to create a positive test result, so sexual intercourse should be avoided within 24 hours of sample collection. Avoid lubricants, lotions, soaps, and douches at least a day before the test.

Fibrin Degradation Fragment.Why Get Tested?: To help rule out clotting (thrombotic) episodes and to help diagnose conditions related to thrombosis
Fibrin Degradation Fragment.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a blood clot or a condition that causes inappropriate blood clots, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and to monitor treatment of DIC and excessive clotting conditions
Fibrin Degradation Fragment.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Fibrinogen.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; sometimes used to help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Fibrinogen.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged; when you have a relative with a hereditary fibrinogen deficiency or abnormality; when your health care provider wants additional information to help evaluate your risk of developing heart disease
Fibrinogen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Fibrinogen Activity.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; sometimes used to help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Fibrinogen Activity.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged; when you have a relative with a hereditary fibrinogen deficiency or abnormality; when your health care provider wants additional information to help evaluate your risk of developing heart disease
Fibrinogen Activity.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Fibrinogen Activity and Fibrinogen Antig.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; sometimes used to help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Fibrinogen Activity and Fibrinogen Antig.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged; when you have a relative with a hereditary fibrinogen deficiency or abnormality; when your health care provider wants additional information to help evaluate your risk of developing heart disease
Fibrinogen Activity and Fibrinogen Antig.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Fibrinogen Antigen.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; sometimes used to help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Fibrinogen Antigen.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged; when you have a relative with a hereditary fibrinogen deficiency or abnormality; when your health care provider wants additional information to help evaluate your risk of developing heart disease
Fibrinogen Antigen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

FIP1-like-1/platelet-derived growth fact.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of hypereosinophilia (HE), a condition with persistent increase in the number of eosinophils, a specific type of white blood cell, or hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES), which is HE with associated tissue or organ damage; to help determine if someone with HE or HES can be treated with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) such as imatinib
FIP1-like-1/platelet-derived growth fact.When To Get Tested?: After complete blood counts (CBC) indicate that you have persistently elevated eosinophils and your health practitioner has ruled out other causes such as allergies, parasitic infection, or medication; at regular intervals when you are being treated for HE or HES with imatinib
FIP1-like-1/platelet-derived growth fact.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

FIP1L1-PDGFRA.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of hypereosinophilia (HE), a condition with persistent increase in the number of eosinophils, a specific type of white blood cell, or hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES), which is HE with associated tissue or organ damage; to help determine if someone with HE or HES can be treated with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) such as imatinib
FIP1L1-PDGFRA.When To Get Tested?: After complete blood counts (CBC) indicate that you have persistently elevated eosinophils and your health practitioner has ruled out other causes such as allergies, parasitic infection, or medication; at regular intervals when you are being treated for HE or HES with imatinib
FIP1L1-PDGFRA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

FIP1L1-PDGFRA Fusion by FISH or RT-PCR.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of hypereosinophilia (HE), a condition with persistent increase in the number of eosinophils, a specific type of white blood cell, or hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES), which is HE with associated tissue or organ damage; to help determine if someone with HE or HES can be treated with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) such as imatinib
FIP1L1-PDGFRA Fusion by FISH or RT-PCR.When To Get Tested?: After complete blood counts (CBC) indicate that you have persistently elevated eosinophils and your health practitioner has ruled out other causes such as allergies, parasitic infection, or medication; at regular intervals when you are being treated for HE or HES with imatinib
FIP1L1-PDGFRA Fusion by FISH or RT-PCR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

First Trimester Screening.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of your baby having a chromosome disorder, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18)
First Trimester Screening.When To Get Tested?: Usually between 11 and 14 weeks of pregnancy
First Trimester Screening.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a blood spot collected on special paper from a finger stick; a nuchal translucency requires a special ultrasound exam.
First Trimester Screening.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have a full bladder when having the nuchal translucency ultrasound performed.

FIT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
FIT.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
FIT.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
FIT.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

FK506.Why Get Tested?: To determine the level of the drug tacrolimus in your blood in order to establish a dosing regimen, maintain therapeutic levels, and detect toxic levels
FK506.When To Get Tested?: As soon as tacrolimus therapy begins, frequently at first, then at regular intervals to monitor concentrations over time
FK506.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
FK506.Test Preparation Needed?: The sample should be collected 12 hours after your last dose and immediately prior to your next dose or as directed by your healthcare practitioner.

FLC.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and monitor plasma cell disorders (dyscrasias) such as multiple myeloma, primary amyloidosis, and related diseases or to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
FLC.When To Get Tested?: When you have bone pain, fractures, anemia (with normal size and shape red blood cells (normocytic)), kidney disease, and recurrent infections that your healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a plasma cell disorder; when you are being treated for a plasma cell disorder
FLC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Flu Test.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an influenza infection (flu), especially if you are hospitalized, have a weakened immune system, or are otherwise at an increased risk of serious complications from influenza; to help your healthcare practitioner make treatment decisions; to help determine whether or not the flu has spread to your community
Flu Test.When To Get Tested?: When it is flu season and a healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether your symptoms are due to seasonal influenza A or B or to another cause; within 3 to 4 days of the onset of signs and symptoms, such as fever, headache, muscle aches, sore throat, weakness, fatigue, cough, sore throat, stuffy nose and sometimes runny nose
Flu Test.Sample Required?: Depending on the test used, a respiratory sample collected on a swab from the nasopharynx or a nasal aspirate; sometimes, a nasal or throat swab

Fluorescent Antinuclear Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose certain autoimmune disorders, such as lupus and Sjögren syndrome, among other types
Fluorescent Antinuclear Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of certain autoimmune disorders
Fluorescent Antinuclear Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Fluorescent Antinuclear Antibody.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, certain medications can affect ANA test results, so tell your healthcare provider about any prescription medications, nonprescription medications, or street drugs you use.

Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorpti.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorpti.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorpti.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

FOBT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
FOBT.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
FOBT.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
FOBT.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

Folic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose one cause of anemia or neuropathy; to evaluate nutritional status in some people; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
Folic Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal complete blood count (CBC) with a blood smear showing large red blood cells (macrocytosis) or abnormal (hypersegmented) neutrophils; when you have symptoms of anemia (weakness, tiredness, pale skin) and/or of neuropathy (tingling or itching sensations, eye twitching, memory loss, altered mental status); when you are being treated for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
Folic Acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Folic Acid.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting for 6-8 hours before sample collection may be required. Certain medicines may affect the test results; your healthcare provider will advise you on which ones to stop taking.

Follicle-stimulating Hormone.Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
Follicle-stimulating Hormone.When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or absence of menstrual periods
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant, or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
Follicle-stimulating Hormone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or 24-hour urine collection may be taken
Follicle-stimulating Hormone.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

Follicle-stimulating Hormone (FSH).Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
Follicle-stimulating Hormone (FSH).When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or absence of menstrual periods
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant, or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
Follicle-stimulating Hormone (FSH).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or 24-hour urine collection may be taken
Follicle-stimulating Hormone (FSH).Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

Follicle-stimulating Hormone, serum or u.Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
Follicle-stimulating Hormone, serum or u.When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or absence of menstrual periods
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant, or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
Follicle-stimulating Hormone, serum or u.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or 24-hour urine collection may be taken
Follicle-stimulating Hormone, serum or u.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

Follitropin.Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
Follitropin.When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or absence of menstrual periods
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant, or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
Follitropin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or 24-hour urine collection may be taken
Follitropin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

FPG.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
FPG.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
FPG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
FPG.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Fractionated Catecholamines.Why Get Tested?: To help confirm or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Fractionated Catecholamines.When To Get Tested?: After or in conjunction with plasma free metanephrines and/or urine metanephrines tests and when your healthcare provider needs additional information regarding a possible catecholamine-secreting tumor
Fractionated Catecholamines.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Fractionated Catecholamines.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection. Although you may be seated for collection of the blood sample, it is recommended that you be lying down. Your healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.

Fractionated Plasma Free Metanephrines (.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Fractionated Plasma Free Metanephrines (.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of increased catecholamines release such as sudden bursts (paroxysms) of high blood pressure (hypertension), severe headaches, rapid heart rate (palpitations), sweating, and tremors; when hypertension does not respond to standard treatment; when the signs and symptoms occur in a relatively young person (younger than age 40) and when there is a family history of hypertension; when a health practitioner suspects you may have a tumor that is releasing or may release excess catecholamines
Fractionated Plasma Free Metanephrines (.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Fractionated Plasma Free Metanephrines (.Test Preparation Needed?:
Blood for plasma metanephrine testing is collected by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm. Although you may be seated for the collection, it is recommended that you be lying down. The healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.
These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection.

Fragment D-dimer.Why Get Tested?: To help rule out clotting (thrombotic) episodes and to help diagnose conditions related to thrombosis
Fragment D-dimer.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a blood clot or a condition that causes inappropriate blood clots, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and to monitor treatment of DIC and excessive clotting conditions
Fragment D-dimer.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Free Catecholamines, plasma and urine.Why Get Tested?: To help confirm or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Free Catecholamines, plasma and urine.When To Get Tested?: After or in conjunction with plasma free metanephrines and/or urine metanephrines tests and when your healthcare provider needs additional information regarding a possible catecholamine-secreting tumor
Free Catecholamines, plasma and urine.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Free Catecholamines, plasma and urine.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection. Although you may be seated for collection of the blood sample, it is recommended that you be lying down. Your healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.

Free Copper.Why Get Tested?: To measure the amount of copper in the blood, urine, or liver tissue; to help diagnose and monitor Wilson disease; sometimes to identify copper deficiency or excess
Free Copper.When To Get Tested?: When you have jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, behavioral changes, tremors, or other symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to Wilson disease or, rarely, to copper deficiency or excess; at intervals when you are being treated for a copper-related condition
Free Copper.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a liver biopsy sample

Free Cortisol.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose Cushing syndrome or primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease); to detect conditions affecting the pituitary or adrenal glands
Free Cortisol.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects excess or deficient cortisol production
Free Cortisol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a saliva sample may be used
Free Cortisol.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be required to rest before sample collection. For a salivary cortisol test, you may be instructed to refrain from eating, drinking, or brushing your teeth for a period of time (may be some time between 15 to 30 minutes) prior to the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

Free Erythrocyte Protoporphyrin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
Free Erythrocyte Protoporphyrin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
Free Erythrocyte Protoporphyrin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
Free Erythrocyte Protoporphyrin.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

Free Light Chains.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and monitor plasma cell disorders (dyscrasias) such as multiple myeloma, primary amyloidosis, and related diseases or to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Free Light Chains.When To Get Tested?: When you have bone pain, fractures, anemia (with normal size and shape red blood cells (normocytic)), kidney disease, and recurrent infections that your healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a plasma cell disorder; when you are being treated for a plasma cell disorder
Free Light Chains.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Free PSA.Why Get Tested?: To screen men for prostate cancer, to help determine the necessity for a biopsy of the prostate, to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for prostate cancer, and/or to detect recurrence of prostate cancer
Free PSA.When To Get Tested?: When a man has symptoms suggestive of prostate cancer such as difficult, painful, and/or frequent urination; may also be ordered during and at regular intervals after prostate cancer treatment; in asymptomatic men, after a discussion with your healthcare provider about the benefits and harms of screening and you make an informed decision to undergo screening (For specific details, see prostate cancer screening for Adults and Adults 50 and Up).
Free PSA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Free PSA.Test Preparation Needed?: Avoid ejaculation for 24 hours before sample collection as it has been associated with elevated PSA levels; the sample should also be collected prior to your health practitioner performing a digital rectal exam (DRE) and prior to (or several weeks after) a prostate biopsy.

Free Testosterone.Why Get Tested?: To detect an abnormal testosterone level in males and females; in males, to help diagnose the cause of erectile dysfunction or the inability of your partner to get pregnant (infertility); in females, to help diagnose the cause of masculine physical features (virilization), infertility, or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS); in children, to help determine the cause of genitals that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) or delayed or early puberty
Free Testosterone.When To Get Tested?:
For males, when you may be infertile or are unable to get or maintain an erection; when you are a boy with either early or delayed sexual maturity (puberty) 
For females, when you have male traits, such as a low voice or excessive body hair (hirsutism), when you have abnormal uterine bleeding, do not menstruate (amenorrhea), or are infertile
Free Testosterone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a morning sample is preferred.

Free Thyroxine.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate thyroid gland function; to help diagnose thyroid disease; to monitor effectiveness of thyroid treatment; sometimes a free T4 is used to help diagnose congenital hypothyroidism in newborns
Free Thyroxine.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of thyroid disease and/or an enlarged thyroid (goiter) or when you have a thyroid nodule (a small lump on the thyroid gland that may be solid or fluid-filled cyst), usually after an abnormal result on a TSH test; when you are being treated for a thyroid disorder
Free Thyroxine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from pricking the heel of an infant
Free Thyroxine.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed; however, certain medications, multivitamins and supplements can interfere with the free T4 test, so tell your healthcare provider about any prescribed or over-the-counter drugs and/or supplements that you are taking. If you take thyroid hormone as treatment for thyroid disease, it is recommended that your blood sample be drawn before you take your dose for that day. Acute illness may affect thyroid testing results. It is generally recommended that thyroid testing be avoided in hospitalized patients or deferred until after a person has recovered from an acute illness.

Free Triiodothyronine; Total Triiodothyr.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate thyroid gland function; to diagnose thyroid disease, including hyperthyroidism, and determine the cause; to monitor effectiveness of treatment of a thyroid disorder
Free Triiodothyronine; Total Triiodothyr.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), particularly with a normal free thyroxine (T4) result, and/or signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism
Free Triiodothyronine; Total Triiodothyr.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm
Free Triiodothyronine; Total Triiodothyr.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed; however, certain medications, multivitamins and supplements can interfere with the free T3 and total T3 tests, so tell your healthcare practitioner about any prescribed or over-the-counter drugs and/or supplements that you are taking. Acute illness may affect thyroid testing test results. It is generally recommended that thyroid testing be avoided in hospitalized patients or deferred until after a person has recovered from an acute illness.

Free Valproic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of valproic acid in your blood; the purpose is to maintain a therapeutic level and monitor toxicity.
Free Valproic Acid.When To Get Tested?: At regular intervals to monitor the drug's level or when a person shows signs of toxicity
Free Valproic Acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
Free Valproic Acid.Test Preparation Needed?: No special test preparation is needed, but talk to your healthcare practitioner about the timing of sample collection. Since dosage timing varies and some formulations are time-released, collection specifics may vary. Often, the recommended time for sample collection is just before the next dose is received, when the drug level is at its lowest (trough level). This ensures that the minimum amount of drug to be effective is maintained in the blood.

Fructosamine.Why Get Tested?: To help monitor your blood glucose (sugar) levels over time if you have diabetes mellitus, especially if it is not possible to monitor your diabetes using the A1c test; to help determine the effectiveness of changes to your diabetic treatment plan that might include changes in diet, exercise or medications, especially if they were made recently
Fructosamine.When To Get Tested?: When you are diabetic and your healthcare provider wants to evaluate your average blood glucose level over the last 2-3 weeks
Fructosamine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick

FT3.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate thyroid gland function; to diagnose thyroid disease, including hyperthyroidism, and determine the cause; to monitor effectiveness of treatment of a thyroid disorder
FT3.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), particularly with a normal free thyroxine (T4) result, and/or signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism
FT3.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm
FT3.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed; however, certain medications, multivitamins and supplements can interfere with the free T3 and total T3 tests, so tell your healthcare practitioner about any prescribed or over-the-counter drugs and/or supplements that you are taking. Acute illness may affect thyroid testing test results. It is generally recommended that thyroid testing be avoided in hospitalized patients or deferred until after a person has recovered from an acute illness.

FTA-ABS.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
FTA-ABS.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
FTA-ABS.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Functional Antithrombin III.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of recurrent inappropriate blood clotting; to help diagnose an antithrombin deficiency
Functional Antithrombin III.When To Get Tested?: A couple of months after getting a blood clot (thrombotic episode) or when you are not responding as expected to heparin anticoagulation therapy
Functional Antithrombin III.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Functional Fibrinogen.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; sometimes used to help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Functional Fibrinogen.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged; when you have a relative with a hereditary fibrinogen deficiency or abnormality; when your health care provider wants additional information to help evaluate your risk of developing heart disease
Functional Fibrinogen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Fungal Molecular Tests.Why Get Tested?: To detect a fungal infection, to determine which specific fungus or fungi are present, and to help guide treatment
Fungal Molecular Tests.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a skin, lung, or systemic fungal infection; sometimes after treatment to monitor its effectiveness
Fungal Molecular Tests.Sample Required?: The sample collected depends upon the suspected location(s) of the infection. Some examples include: scrapings of the skin, nail and hair samples, body fluids, blood, and/or a tissue biopsy.

Fungal Smear, Culture, Antigen and Antib.Why Get Tested?: To detect a fungal infection, to determine which specific fungus or fungi are present, and to help guide treatment
Fungal Smear, Culture, Antigen and Antib.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a skin, lung, or systemic fungal infection; sometimes after treatment to monitor its effectiveness
Fungal Smear, Culture, Antigen and Antib.Sample Required?: The sample collected depends upon the suspected location(s) of the infection. Some examples include: scrapings of the skin, nail and hair samples, body fluids, blood, and/or a tissue biopsy.

Fungal Tests.Why Get Tested?: To detect a fungal infection, to determine which specific fungus or fungi are present, and to help guide treatment
Fungal Tests.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a skin, lung, or systemic fungal infection; sometimes after treatment to monitor its effectiveness
Fungal Tests.Sample Required?: The sample collected depends upon the suspected location(s) of the infection. Some examples include: scrapings of the skin, nail and hair samples, body fluids, blood, and/or a tissue biopsy.

G-6-PD.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an inherited G6PD deficiency
G-6-PD.When To Get Tested?: When a child experienced persistent jaundice as a newborn for unknown reasons; when you have had one or more intermittent bouts of hemolytic anemia that may be triggered by an infection or certain medications
G-6-PD.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, by fingerstick, or by heelstick (newborns)
G-6-PD.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally, none; however, if symptoms are acute, it is advised that you wait to be tested for at least several weeks after the episode has resolved.

G6PD.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an inherited G6PD deficiency
G6PD.When To Get Tested?: When a child experienced persistent jaundice as a newborn for unknown reasons; when you have had one or more intermittent bouts of hemolytic anemia that may be triggered by an infection or certain medications
G6PD.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, by fingerstick, or by heelstick (newborns)
G6PD.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally, none; however, if symptoms are acute, it is advised that you wait to be tested for at least several weeks after the episode has resolved.

Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate for a possible liver disease or bile duct disease or to differentiate between liver and bone disease as a cause of elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP); sometimes to screen for or monitor alcohol abuse
Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a liver or bile duct disorder or as follow up when you have an increased ALP level
Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase.Test Preparation Needed?: GGT levels fall after meals; you may be instructed to fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours prior to the test. You may also be asked to stop drinking alcohol or taking certain prescription medications.

Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT).Why Get Tested?: To evaluate for a possible liver disease or bile duct disease or to differentiate between liver and bone disease as a cause of elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP); sometimes to screen for or monitor alcohol abuse
Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT).When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a liver or bile duct disorder or as follow up when you have an increased ALP level
Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT).Test Preparation Needed?: GGT levels fall after meals; you may be instructed to fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours prior to the test. You may also be asked to stop drinking alcohol or taking certain prescription medications.

Gamma-Glutamyl Transpeptidase.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate for a possible liver disease or bile duct disease or to differentiate between liver and bone disease as a cause of elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP); sometimes to screen for or monitor alcohol abuse
Gamma-Glutamyl Transpeptidase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a liver or bile duct disorder or as follow up when you have an increased ALP level
Gamma-Glutamyl Transpeptidase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Gamma-Glutamyl Transpeptidase.Test Preparation Needed?: GGT levels fall after meals; you may be instructed to fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours prior to the test. You may also be asked to stop drinking alcohol or taking certain prescription medications.

Gamma-GT.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate for a possible liver disease or bile duct disease or to differentiate between liver and bone disease as a cause of elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP); sometimes to screen for or monitor alcohol abuse
Gamma-GT.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a liver or bile duct disorder or as follow up when you have an increased ALP level
Gamma-GT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Gamma-GT.Test Preparation Needed?: GGT levels fall after meals; you may be instructed to fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours prior to the test. You may also be asked to stop drinking alcohol or taking certain prescription medications.

Gastric Parietal Cell Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
Gastric Parietal Cell Antibody.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
Gastric Parietal Cell Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Gastric Parietal Cell Antibody, IgG.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
Gastric Parietal Cell Antibody, IgG.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
Gastric Parietal Cell Antibody, IgG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Gastrin.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you are producing too much gastrin; to help diagnose Zollinger-Ellison syndrome and gastrin-producing tumors (gastrinomas) or G-cell hyperplasia; to monitor for recurrence of a gastrinoma
Gastrin.When To Get Tested?: When you have peptic ulcers and/or diarrhea and abdominal pain that your healthcare practitioner suspects is caused by excess gastrin; periodically to monitor for a gastrinoma recurrence
Gastrin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Gastrin.Test Preparation Needed?: You should fast for 12 hours, including avoiding coffee and caffeine-containing drinks, and avoid alcohol for 24 hours prior to the test. Your healthcare practitioner may also ask you to refrain from taking certain stomach medications for several days prior to the test. Medications that can increase gastrin levels include antacids, H2-blocking agents (such as cimetidine), and proton pump inhibitors (such as omeprazole).

Gastrointestinal Pathogens Panel.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an infection of your digestive tract due to disease-causing (pathogenic) bacteria, parasites, or viruses
Gastrointestinal Pathogens Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea and/or vomiting; when you have blood or mucus in your loose stools
Gastrointestinal Pathogens Panel.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample collected in a clean container; the stool sample should not be contaminated with urine or water; once it has been collected, the stool should either be taken to the laboratory within two hours after collection or transferred into special transport vials containing preservative solutions

GBS.Why Get Tested?: To screen a pregnant woman for the presence of group B streptococcus (GBS) in her vagina or rectum to determine the risk that she will pass the bacteria on to her newborn during labor and delivery, possibly resulting in a serious infection in her newborn called early-onset GBS
GBS.When To Get Tested?: When a woman is between 35 and 37 weeks of pregnancy or has preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes
