GBS.Sample Required?: A swab obtained from the vagina and rectum of a pregnant woman; a urine sample collected anytime during pregnancy may be used to detect significant numbers of GBS.

GC Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a gonorrhea infection
GC Test.When To Get Tested?:
Screening:
For women, yearly testing recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); if you fall into one of these groups and are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly testing recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
Diagnosis:
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge or vaginal bleeding between menstrual periods (for women), or unusual discharge from the penis, pain during urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
GC Test.Sample Required?: A swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina (for women) or from your penis (for men); for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
GC Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow the instructions you are given.

GDH.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of an infection caused by toxin-producing Clostridium difficile bacteria
GDH.When To Get Tested?: When a person has mild, moderate, or severe diarrhea that persists for several days with abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and fever, following antibiotic therapy
GDH.Sample Required?: A fresh or refrigerated liquid or unformed stool sample that has not been contaminated with urine or water

Genital Human Papillomavirus.Why Get Tested?: To screen for infections in women with the high-risk types of HPV (hrHPV) that are associated with cervical cancer or to follow up on an abnormal Pap test
Genital Human Papillomavirus.When To Get Tested?: If you are a woman aged 30 to 65; if you are a woman aged 21 to 29 and have an abnormal Pap test
Genital Human Papillomavirus.Sample Required?: A sampling of cells from the cervical area
Genital Human Papillomavirus.Test Preparation Needed?: It is recommended that you do not douche or use tampons or vaginal creams, deodorants, or medications for 2 days before the test. Some health practitioners may request that you refrain from sex for 24 to 48 hours before the test. Reschedule the test if you are having your period (menstruating). You may be asked to empty your bladder before the examination.

Gentamicin; Tobramycin; Amikacin.Why Get Tested?: To monitor the level of an aminoglycoside antibiotic such as gentamicin, tobramycin, or amikacin in the blood to ensure adequate dosing and help avoid toxic side effects
Gentamicin; Tobramycin; Amikacin.When To Get Tested?: At regular intervals during treatment with an aminoglycoside
Gentamicin; Tobramycin; Amikacin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Gentamicin; Tobramycin; Amikacin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample for testing is important; follow your healthcare provider's directions.

German Measles.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sufficient rubella antibodies to protect you from the rubella virus; to verify a past infection or detect a recent infection
German Measles.When To Get Tested?: Prior to or at the beginning of a pregnancy to verify immunity; when a pregnant woman has symptoms of rubella, such as fever and rash; when a newborn shows signs of abnormal development or birth defects that may be caused by an in utero infection; whenever there is need to verify a recent rubella infection or to verify immunity
German Measles.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm of an adult or blood drawn from a heelprick or from the umbilical cord of a newborn

gFOBT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
gFOBT.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
gFOBT.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
gFOBT.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

GFR.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
GFR.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
GFR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
GFR.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

GGTP.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate for a possible liver disease or bile duct disease or to differentiate between liver and bone disease as a cause of elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP); sometimes to screen for or monitor alcohol abuse
GGTP.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a liver or bile duct disorder or as follow up when you have an increased ALP level
GGTP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
GGTP.Test Preparation Needed?: GGT levels fall after meals; you may be instructed to fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours prior to the test. You may also be asked to stop drinking alcohol or taking certain prescription medications.

GH.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for excess production of GH
GH.When To Get Tested?: When a child has slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or sometimes when an adult has decreased bone density and/or muscle strength and elevated blood lipid levels that could be related to insufficient GH production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms suggestive of GH excess, which can cause two rare conditions, gigantism and acromegaly, respectively; when a pituitary disorder is suspected and other pituitary hormone levels are abnormal
GH.Sample Required?: Usually several blood samples, drawn at timed intervals from veins in your arms; sometimes a single sample of blood, drawn following a fast and rest, after a period of strenuous exercise, or after ingesting a glucose (sugar) solution
GH.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow any instructions you are given, such as to fast, in order to prepare for this test.

GI Panel.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an infection of your digestive tract due to disease-causing (pathogenic) bacteria, parasites, or viruses
GI Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea and/or vomiting; when you have blood or mucus in your loose stools
GI Panel.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample collected in a clean container; the stool sample should not be contaminated with urine or water; once it has been collected, the stool should either be taken to the laboratory within two hours after collection or transferred into special transport vials containing preservative solutions

Glomerular Filtration Rate, Estimated.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
Glomerular Filtration Rate, Estimated.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
Glomerular Filtration Rate, Estimated.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
Glomerular Filtration Rate, Estimated.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Glucose Tests.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
Glucose Tests.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
Glucose Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
Glucose Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an inherited G6PD deficiency
Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase.When To Get Tested?: When a child experienced persistent jaundice as a newborn for unknown reasons; when you have had one or more intermittent bouts of hemolytic anemia that may be triggered by an infection or certain medications
Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, by fingerstick, or by heelstick (newborns)
Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally, none; however, if symptoms are acute, it is advised that you wait to be tested for at least several weeks after the episode has resolved.

Glutamate Dehydrogenase Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of an infection caused by toxin-producing Clostridium difficile bacteria
Glutamate Dehydrogenase Test.When To Get Tested?: When a person has mild, moderate, or severe diarrhea that persists for several days with abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and fever, following antibiotic therapy
Glutamate Dehydrogenase Test.Sample Required?: A fresh or refrigerated liquid or unformed stool sample that has not been contaminated with urine or water

Glycated Hemoglobin.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you are at an increased risk of developing diabetes; to help diagnose diabetes and prediabetes; to monitor diabetes and to aid in treatment decisions
Glycated Hemoglobin.When To Get Tested?: As part of a health checkup or when you have risk factors for or symptoms of diabetes; after first diagnosis with diabetes, every 3-4 months or about 120 days to ensure that your glycemic goals are met and/or maintained or when your therapy plan has changed
Glycated Hemoglobin.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein or a drop of blood is taken from a finger by pricking it with a small, pointed lancet.

Glycated Serum Protein.Why Get Tested?: To help monitor your blood glucose (sugar) levels over time if you have diabetes mellitus, especially if it is not possible to monitor your diabetes using the A1c test; to help determine the effectiveness of changes to your diabetic treatment plan that might include changes in diet, exercise or medications, especially if they were made recently
Glycated Serum Protein.When To Get Tested?: When you are diabetic and your healthcare provider wants to evaluate your average blood glucose level over the last 2-3 weeks
Glycated Serum Protein.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick

Glycohemoglobin.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you are at an increased risk of developing diabetes; to help diagnose diabetes and prediabetes; to monitor diabetes and to aid in treatment decisions
Glycohemoglobin.When To Get Tested?: As part of a health checkup or when you have risk factors for or symptoms of diabetes; after first diagnosis with diabetes, every 3-4 months or about 120 days to ensure that your glycemic goals are met and/or maintained or when your therapy plan has changed
Glycohemoglobin.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein or a drop of blood is taken from a finger by pricking it with a small, pointed lancet.

Glycosylated Hemoglobin.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you are at an increased risk of developing diabetes; to help diagnose diabetes and prediabetes; to monitor diabetes and to aid in treatment decisions
Glycosylated Hemoglobin.When To Get Tested?: As part of a health checkup or when you have risk factors for or symptoms of diabetes; after first diagnosis with diabetes, every 3-4 months or about 120 days to ensure that your glycemic goals are met and/or maintained or when your therapy plan has changed
Glycosylated Hemoglobin.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein or a drop of blood is taken from a finger by pricking it with a small, pointed lancet.

Gonorrhea NAAT or NAT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a gonorrhea infection
Gonorrhea NAAT or NAT.When To Get Tested?:
Screening:
For women, yearly testing recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); if you fall into one of these groups and are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly testing recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
Diagnosis:
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge or vaginal bleeding between menstrual periods (for women), or unusual discharge from the penis, pain during urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
Gonorrhea NAAT or NAT.Sample Required?: A swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina (for women) or from your penis (for men); for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
Gonorrhea NAAT or NAT.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow the instructions you are given.

Gonorrhea Testing.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a gonorrhea infection
Gonorrhea Testing.When To Get Tested?:
Screening:
For women, yearly testing recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); if you fall into one of these groups and are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly testing recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
Diagnosis:
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge or vaginal bleeding between menstrual periods (for women), or unusual discharge from the penis, pain during urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
Gonorrhea Testing.Sample Required?: A swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina (for women) or from your penis (for men); for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
Gonorrhea Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow the instructions you are given.

GOT.Why Get Tested?: To detect liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
GOT.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to a hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel when you have a routine health exam
GOT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

GPT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
GPT.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) when you have a routine health exam
GPT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Gram Stain.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence and identify the general type of bacteria or sometimes fungi (microbes) in a sample taken from the site of a suspected infection; to generally classify bacteria grown in culture so that further identification tests can be performed and appropriate treatment given
Gram Stain.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a bacterial (or sometimes fungal) infection; often whenever a culture is requested
Gram Stain.Sample Required?: Pus, body fluid, sputum, or swab of cells taken from the site of an infection; a sample of bacteria or fungi grown and isolated in culture

Gram's Stain.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence and identify the general type of bacteria or sometimes fungi (microbes) in a sample taken from the site of a suspected infection; to generally classify bacteria grown in culture so that further identification tests can be performed and appropriate treatment given
Gram's Stain.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a bacterial (or sometimes fungal) infection; often whenever a culture is requested
Gram's Stain.Sample Required?: Pus, body fluid, sputum, or swab of cells taken from the site of an infection; a sample of bacteria or fungi grown and isolated in culture

Group A beta hemolytic streptococcus.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your sore throat is "strep throat" that is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) bacteria
Group A beta hemolytic streptococcus.When To Get Tested?: When you have a sore throat that starts quickly and lasts more than a week and/or other symptoms such as a fever of 101° F or higher, or reddened throat and/or tonsils with white or yellow patches or streaks
Group A beta hemolytic streptococcus.Sample Required?: A swab rubbed against the back of your throat and tonsils

Group A streptococcus (GAS).Why Get Tested?: To determine if your sore throat is "strep throat" that is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) bacteria
Group A streptococcus (GAS).When To Get Tested?: When you have a sore throat that starts quickly and lasts more than a week and/or other symptoms such as a fever of 101° F or higher, or reddened throat and/or tonsils with white or yellow patches or streaks
Group A streptococcus (GAS).Sample Required?: A swab rubbed against the back of your throat and tonsils

Group B Beta-hemolytic Streptococcus.Why Get Tested?: To screen a pregnant woman for the presence of group B streptococcus (GBS) in her vagina or rectum to determine the risk that she will pass the bacteria on to her newborn during labor and delivery, possibly resulting in a serious infection in her newborn called early-onset GBS
Group B Beta-hemolytic Streptococcus.When To Get Tested?: When a woman is between 35 and 37 weeks of pregnancy or has preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes
Group B Beta-hemolytic Streptococcus.Sample Required?: A swab obtained from the vagina and rectum of a pregnant woman; a urine sample collected anytime during pregnancy may be used to detect significant numbers of GBS.

Group B Strep.Why Get Tested?: To screen a pregnant woman for the presence of group B streptococcus (GBS) in her vagina or rectum to determine the risk that she will pass the bacteria on to her newborn during labor and delivery, possibly resulting in a serious infection in her newborn called early-onset GBS
Group B Strep.When To Get Tested?: When a woman is between 35 and 37 weeks of pregnancy or has preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes
Group B Strep.Sample Required?: A swab obtained from the vagina and rectum of a pregnant woman; a urine sample collected anytime during pregnancy may be used to detect significant numbers of GBS.

Group B Streptococcus.Why Get Tested?: To screen a pregnant woman for the presence of group B streptococcus (GBS) in her vagina or rectum to determine the risk that she will pass the bacteria on to her newborn during labor and delivery, possibly resulting in a serious infection in her newborn called early-onset GBS
Group B Streptococcus.When To Get Tested?: When a woman is between 35 and 37 weeks of pregnancy or has preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes
Group B Streptococcus.Sample Required?: A swab obtained from the vagina and rectum of a pregnant woman; a urine sample collected anytime during pregnancy may be used to detect significant numbers of GBS.

Growth Hormone.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for excess production of GH
Growth Hormone.When To Get Tested?: When a child has slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or sometimes when an adult has decreased bone density and/or muscle strength and elevated blood lipid levels that could be related to insufficient GH production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms suggestive of GH excess, which can cause two rare conditions, gigantism and acromegaly, respectively; when a pituitary disorder is suspected and other pituitary hormone levels are abnormal
Growth Hormone.Sample Required?: Usually several blood samples, drawn at timed intervals from veins in your arms; sometimes a single sample of blood, drawn following a fast and rest, after a period of strenuous exercise, or after ingesting a glucose (sugar) solution
Growth Hormone.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow any instructions you are given, such as to fast, in order to prepare for this test.

Growth Hormone Stimulation Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for excess production of GH
Growth Hormone Stimulation Test.When To Get Tested?: When a child has slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or sometimes when an adult has decreased bone density and/or muscle strength and elevated blood lipid levels that could be related to insufficient GH production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms suggestive of GH excess, which can cause two rare conditions, gigantism and acromegaly, respectively; when a pituitary disorder is suspected and other pituitary hormone levels are abnormal
Growth Hormone Stimulation Test.Sample Required?: Usually several blood samples, drawn at timed intervals from veins in your arms; sometimes a single sample of blood, drawn following a fast and rest, after a period of strenuous exercise, or after ingesting a glucose (sugar) solution
Growth Hormone Stimulation Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow any instructions you are given, such as to fast, in order to prepare for this test.

Growth Hormone Suppression Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for excess production of GH
Growth Hormone Suppression Test.When To Get Tested?: When a child has slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or sometimes when an adult has decreased bone density and/or muscle strength and elevated blood lipid levels that could be related to insufficient GH production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms suggestive of GH excess, which can cause two rare conditions, gigantism and acromegaly, respectively; when a pituitary disorder is suspected and other pituitary hormone levels are abnormal
Growth Hormone Suppression Test.Sample Required?: Usually several blood samples, drawn at timed intervals from veins in your arms; sometimes a single sample of blood, drawn following a fast and rest, after a period of strenuous exercise, or after ingesting a glucose (sugar) solution
Growth Hormone Suppression Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow any instructions you are given, such as to fast, in order to prepare for this test.

GSP.Why Get Tested?: To help monitor your blood glucose (sugar) levels over time if you have diabetes mellitus, especially if it is not possible to monitor your diabetes using the A1c test; to help determine the effectiveness of changes to your diabetic treatment plan that might include changes in diet, exercise or medications, especially if they were made recently
GSP.When To Get Tested?: When you are diabetic and your healthcare provider wants to evaluate your average blood glucose level over the last 2-3 weeks
GSP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick

GTP.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate for a possible liver disease or bile duct disease or to differentiate between liver and bone disease as a cause of elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP); sometimes to screen for or monitor alcohol abuse
GTP.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a liver or bile duct disorder or as follow up when you have an increased ALP level
GTP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
GTP.Test Preparation Needed?: GGT levels fall after meals; you may be instructed to fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours prior to the test. You may also be asked to stop drinking alcohol or taking certain prescription medications.

GTT.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
GTT.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
GTT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
GTT.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Guaiac-based FOBT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
Guaiac-based FOBT.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
Guaiac-based FOBT.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
Guaiac-based FOBT.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

H and H (Hemoglobin and Hematocrit).Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the hemoglobin content of your blood as part of a general health checkup; to screen for and help diagnose conditions that affect red blood cells (RBCs); if you have anemia (low hemoglobin) or polycythemia (high hemoglobin), to assess the severity of these conditions and to monitor response to treatment
H and H (Hemoglobin and Hematocrit).When To Get Tested?: With a hematocrit or as part of a complete blood count (CBC), which may be ordered as a component of a general health screen; when you have signs and symptoms of anemia (weakness, fatigue) or polycythemia (dizziness, headache); at regular intervals to monitor these conditions or response to treatment
H and H (Hemoglobin and Hematocrit).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

H. pylori antibody test, stool antigen,.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with Helicobacter pylori, bacteria that can cause peptic ulcers
H. pylori antibody test, stool antigen,.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an ulcer, such as gastrointestinal pain that comes and goes, unexplained weight loss, nausea and/or vomiting
H. pylori antibody test, stool antigen,.Sample Required?: A stool sample, a breath sample, or a tissue biopsy of the stomach lining
H. pylori antibody test, stool antigen,.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to avoid certain medications; follow any instructions you are given.

H1N1.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an influenza infection (flu), especially if you are hospitalized, have a weakened immune system, or are otherwise at an increased risk of serious complications from influenza; to help your healthcare practitioner make treatment decisions; to help determine whether or not the flu has spread to your community
H1N1.When To Get Tested?: When it is flu season and a healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether your symptoms are due to seasonal influenza A or B or to another cause; within 3 to 4 days of the onset of signs and symptoms, such as fever, headache, muscle aches, sore throat, weakness, fatigue, cough, sore throat, stuffy nose and sometimes runny nose
H1N1.Sample Required?: Depending on the test used, a respiratory sample collected on a swab from the nasopharynx or a nasal aspirate; sometimes, a nasal or throat swab

Haptoglobin.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate hemolytic anemia
Haptoglobin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs of anemia such as weakness, paleness, or jaundice that a healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to red blood cell destruction (hemolytic anemia)
Haptoglobin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HAV-Ab IgG.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of acute hepatitis; as part of a viral hepatitis panel to identify the type of hepatitis virus causing an infection; sometimes to evaluate the need for the hepatitis A vaccine
HAV-Ab IgG.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an acute hepatitis infection, such as jaundice, or when you may have been exposed to hepatitis A virus (HAV)
HAV-Ab IgG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HAV-Ab IgM.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of acute hepatitis; as part of a viral hepatitis panel to identify the type of hepatitis virus causing an infection; sometimes to evaluate the need for the hepatitis A vaccine
HAV-Ab IgM.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an acute hepatitis infection, such as jaundice, or when you may have been exposed to hepatitis A virus (HAV)
HAV-Ab IgM.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HAV-Ab total.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of acute hepatitis; as part of a viral hepatitis panel to identify the type of hepatitis virus causing an infection; sometimes to evaluate the need for the hepatitis A vaccine
HAV-Ab total.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an acute hepatitis infection, such as jaundice, or when you may have been exposed to hepatitis A virus (HAV)
HAV-Ab total.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hb.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the hemoglobin content of your blood as part of a general health checkup; to screen for and help diagnose conditions that affect red blood cells (RBCs); if you have anemia (low hemoglobin) or polycythemia (high hemoglobin), to assess the severity of these conditions and to monitor response to treatment
Hb.When To Get Tested?: With a hematocrit or as part of a complete blood count (CBC), which may be ordered as a component of a general health screen; when you have signs and symptoms of anemia (weakness, fatigue) or polycythemia (dizziness, headache); at regular intervals to monitor these conditions or response to treatment
Hb.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Hb ELP.Why Get Tested?: To investigate hemoglobinopathy as the cause of signs and symptoms; to screen for a hemoglobin disorder
Hb ELP.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and/or blood smear; when you have symptoms of hemolytic anemia such as weakness and fatigue and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have an abnormal form of hemoglobin (hemoglobinopathy); when you have a family history of hemoglobinopathy; as part of newborn screening
Hb ELP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or obtained from the heel or finger of an infant

Hb IEF.Why Get Tested?: To investigate hemoglobinopathy as the cause of signs and symptoms; to screen for a hemoglobin disorder
Hb IEF.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and/or blood smear; when you have symptoms of hemolytic anemia such as weakness and fatigue and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have an abnormal form of hemoglobin (hemoglobinopathy); when you have a family history of hemoglobinopathy; as part of newborn screening
Hb IEF.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or obtained from the heel or finger of an infant

Hb S.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sickle cell trait or sickle cell disease
Hb S.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of newborn screening; if you are in a high risk group and were born before newborn screening was mandated and want to know if you have sickle cell disease or are carrying the sickle cell trait; when you have signs and symptoms of anemia or abnormal results from a complete blood count (CBC) and your healthcare practitioner suspects sickle cell disease or trait
Hb S.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or, for infants, by pricking a heel or finger
Hb S.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, if this test is used for diagnosis, the sample should not be drawn after a recent blood transfusion.

HbA1c.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you are at an increased risk of developing diabetes; to help diagnose diabetes and prediabetes; to monitor diabetes and to aid in treatment decisions
HbA1c.When To Get Tested?: As part of a health checkup or when you have risk factors for or symptoms of diabetes; after first diagnosis with diabetes, every 3-4 months or about 120 days to ensure that your glycemic goals are met and/or maintained or when your therapy plan has changed
HbA1c.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein or a drop of blood is taken from a finger by pricking it with a small, pointed lancet.

HBeAg.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
HBeAg.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
HBeAg.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HBsAg.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
HBsAg.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
HBsAg.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HBV DNA.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
HBV DNA.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
HBV DNA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HBV Tests.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
HBV Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
HBV Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

hCG Pregnancy.Why Get Tested?: To confirm a pregnancy; to help identify an ectopic pregnancy; to monitor a pregnancy that may be at risk of failing; occasionally to screen a woman for pregnancy prior to some medical treatments; as part of a panel of tests used to screen for fetal abnormalities (see First Trimester Down Syndrome Screen and Second Trimester Maternal Serum Screening)
hCG Pregnancy.When To Get Tested?: When you suspect that you are pregnant (testing can be done reliably by 10 days after you miss your menstrual period and some methods can detect hCG even earlier); when you have signs and symptoms that suggest you may have an ectopic pregnancy or a pregnancy that is failing; prior to some medical treatments
hCG Pregnancy.Sample Required?: A urine sample collected first thing in the morning or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
hCG Pregnancy.Test Preparation Needed?: Do not drink large amounts of fluid before collecting a urine sample for a pregnancy test because overly diluted urine may result in a false negative; no preparation is needed for a blood sample.

hCG Tumor Marker.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors
hCG Tumor Marker.When To Get Tested?: When your symptoms suggest gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors; to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment for these conditions; to monitor for recurrence
hCG Tumor Marker.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein

HCO3-.Why Get Tested?: As part of an electrolyte panel to identify or monitor an electrolyte imbalance or acid-base (pH) imbalance
HCO3-.When To Get Tested?: During a routine physical or as recommended by your healthcare practitioner if you are experiencing symptoms such as weakness, confusion, prolonged vomiting, or breathing problems that could indicate an electrolyte imbalance or an acid-base imbalance (commonly described as acidosis or alkalosis)
HCO3-.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hct.Why Get Tested?: To determine the proportion of your blood that is made up of red blood cells (RBCs) in order to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect RBCs; as part of a routine health examination or if your healthcare provider suspects that you have anemia or polycythemia
Hct.When To Get Tested?: With a test for hemoglobin or as part of a complete blood count (CBC) during a routine health exam or when you have signs and symptoms of anemia (weakness, fatigue) or polycythemia (dizziness, headache); at regular intervals to monitor a disorder that affects RBCs and to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment
Hct.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

HCV-PCR.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and diagnose a hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and to monitor treatment of the infection
To learn more about hepatitis C, read the article on Viral Hepatitis.
HCV-PCR.When To Get Tested?:
For screening: when you have risk factors for HCV infection or were born between 1945 and 1965, per 2012 CDC recommendations
For diagnosis: when you may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus, such as through contact with infected blood, or have symptoms associated with liver disease
HCV-PCR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HCV-RNA.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and diagnose a hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and to monitor treatment of the infection
To learn more about hepatitis C, read the article on Viral Hepatitis.
HCV-RNA.When To Get Tested?:
For screening: when you have risk factors for HCV infection or were born between 1945 and 1965, per 2012 CDC recommendations
For diagnosis: when you may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus, such as through contact with infected blood, or have symptoms associated with liver disease
HCV-RNA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HDL.Why Get Tested?: To determine your risk of developing heart disease
HDL.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a regular health exam with a lipid profile when no risk factors for heart disease are present; once every four to six years in adults; children should have a lipid profile screening at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and then again between the ages of 17 and 21.
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals as part of a lipid profile when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
HDL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
HDL.Test Preparation Needed?: If this test is to be performed as part of a complete lipid profile, fasting for 9 to 12 hours typically will be required; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

HDL Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To determine your risk of developing heart disease
HDL Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a regular health exam with a lipid profile when no risk factors for heart disease are present; once every four to six years in adults; children should have a lipid profile screening at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and then again between the ages of 17 and 21.
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals as part of a lipid profile when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
HDL Cholesterol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
HDL Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: If this test is to be performed as part of a complete lipid profile, fasting for 9 to 12 hours typically will be required; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

HDL-C.Why Get Tested?: To determine your risk of developing heart disease
HDL-C.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a regular health exam with a lipid profile when no risk factors for heart disease are present; once every four to six years in adults; children should have a lipid profile screening at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and then again between the ages of 17 and 21.
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals as part of a lipid profile when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
HDL-C.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
HDL-C.Test Preparation Needed?: If this test is to be performed as part of a complete lipid profile, fasting for 9 to 12 hours typically will be required; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

HE4.Why Get Tested?: To help monitor epithelial ovarian cancer after treatment; to detect recurrence or disease progression; not recommended for screening asymptomatic women
HE4.When To Get Tested?: Before starting therapy for epithelial ovarian cancer and at intervals after treatment
HE4.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Heavy Metals.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, and monitor excessive exposure to specific heavy metals
Heavy Metals.When To Get Tested?: Periodically when you work with heavy metals, or when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have been exposed
Heavy Metals.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a 24-hour urine sample; rarely, a hair or nail sample, tissue sample, or other body fluid sample
Heavy Metals.Test Preparation Needed?: 48 hours before collection, you should not eat seafood. If you have had a procedure in which either gadolinium- or iodine-containing contrast media has been administered, wait 96 hours before sample collection.

Heavy Metals Panel.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, and monitor excessive exposure to specific heavy metals
Heavy Metals Panel.When To Get Tested?: Periodically when you work with heavy metals, or when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have been exposed
Heavy Metals Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a 24-hour urine sample; rarely, a hair or nail sample, tissue sample, or other body fluid sample
Heavy Metals Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: 48 hours before collection, you should not eat seafood. If you have had a procedure in which either gadolinium- or iodine-containing contrast media has been administered, wait 96 hours before sample collection.

Helicobacter pylori.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with Helicobacter pylori, bacteria that can cause peptic ulcers
Helicobacter pylori.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an ulcer, such as gastrointestinal pain that comes and goes, unexplained weight loss, nausea and/or vomiting
Helicobacter pylori.Sample Required?: A stool sample, a breath sample, or a tissue biopsy of the stomach lining
Helicobacter pylori.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to avoid certain medications; follow any instructions you are given.

Helicobacter pylori Testing.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with Helicobacter pylori, bacteria that can cause peptic ulcers
Helicobacter pylori Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an ulcer, such as gastrointestinal pain that comes and goes, unexplained weight loss, nausea and/or vomiting
Helicobacter pylori Testing.Sample Required?: A stool sample, a breath sample, or a tissue biopsy of the stomach lining
Helicobacter pylori Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to avoid certain medications; follow any instructions you are given.

Hematocrit.Why Get Tested?: To determine the proportion of your blood that is made up of red blood cells (RBCs) in order to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect RBCs; as part of a routine health examination or if your healthcare provider suspects that you have anemia or polycythemia
Hematocrit.When To Get Tested?: With a test for hemoglobin or as part of a complete blood count (CBC) during a routine health exam or when you have signs and symptoms of anemia (weakness, fatigue) or polycythemia (dizziness, headache); at regular intervals to monitor a disorder that affects RBCs and to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment
Hematocrit.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Hemoglobin.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the hemoglobin content of your blood as part of a general health checkup; to screen for and help diagnose conditions that affect red blood cells (RBCs); if you have anemia (low hemoglobin) or polycythemia (high hemoglobin), to assess the severity of these conditions and to monitor response to treatment
Hemoglobin.When To Get Tested?: With a hematocrit or as part of a complete blood count (CBC), which may be ordered as a component of a general health screen; when you have signs and symptoms of anemia (weakness, fatigue) or polycythemia (dizziness, headache); at regular intervals to monitor these conditions or response to treatment
Hemoglobin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Hemoglobin A1c.Why Get Tested?: To help determine whether you are at an increased risk of developing diabetes; to help diagnose diabetes and prediabetes; to monitor diabetes and to aid in treatment decisions
Hemoglobin A1c.When To Get Tested?: As part of a health checkup or when you have risk factors for or symptoms of diabetes; after first diagnosis with diabetes, every 3-4 months or about 120 days to ensure that your glycemic goals are met and/or maintained or when your therapy plan has changed
Hemoglobin A1c.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein or a drop of blood is taken from a finger by pricking it with a small, pointed lancet.

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis; Hemoglobin I.Why Get Tested?: To investigate hemoglobinopathy as the cause of signs and symptoms; to screen for a hemoglobin disorder
Hemoglobin Electrophoresis; Hemoglobin I.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and/or blood smear; when you have symptoms of hemolytic anemia such as weakness and fatigue and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have an abnormal form of hemoglobin (hemoglobinopathy); when you have a family history of hemoglobinopathy; as part of newborn screening
Hemoglobin Electrophoresis; Hemoglobin I.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or obtained from the heel or finger of an infant

Hemoglobin Evaluation.Why Get Tested?: To investigate hemoglobinopathy as the cause of signs and symptoms; to screen for a hemoglobin disorder
Hemoglobin Evaluation.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and/or blood smear; when you have symptoms of hemolytic anemia such as weakness and fatigue and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have an abnormal form of hemoglobin (hemoglobinopathy); when you have a family history of hemoglobinopathy; as part of newborn screening
Hemoglobin Evaluation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or obtained from the heel or finger of an infant

Hemoglobin Fractionation.Why Get Tested?: To investigate hemoglobinopathy as the cause of signs and symptoms; to screen for a hemoglobin disorder
Hemoglobin Fractionation.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and/or blood smear; when you have symptoms of hemolytic anemia such as weakness and fatigue and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have an abnormal form of hemoglobin (hemoglobinopathy); when you have a family history of hemoglobinopathy; as part of newborn screening
Hemoglobin Fractionation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or obtained from the heel or finger of an infant

Hemoglobin S.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sickle cell trait or sickle cell disease
Hemoglobin S.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of newborn screening; if you are in a high risk group and were born before newborn screening was mandated and want to know if you have sickle cell disease or are carrying the sickle cell trait; when you have signs and symptoms of anemia or abnormal results from a complete blood count (CBC) and your healthcare practitioner suspects sickle cell disease or trait
Hemoglobin S.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or, for infants, by pricking a heel or finger
Hemoglobin S.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, if this test is used for diagnosis, the sample should not be drawn after a recent blood transfusion.

Hemoglobin S Evaluation.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sickle cell trait or sickle cell disease
Hemoglobin S Evaluation.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of newborn screening; if you are in a high risk group and were born before newborn screening was mandated and want to know if you have sickle cell disease or are carrying the sickle cell trait; when you have signs and symptoms of anemia or abnormal results from a complete blood count (CBC) and your healthcare practitioner suspects sickle cell disease or trait
Hemoglobin S Evaluation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or, for infants, by pricking a heel or finger
Hemoglobin S Evaluation.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, if this test is used for diagnosis, the sample should not be drawn after a recent blood transfusion.

Hemoglobin-binding Protein.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate hemolytic anemia
Hemoglobin-binding Protein.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs of anemia such as weakness, paleness, or jaundice that a healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to red blood cell destruction (hemolytic anemia)
Hemoglobin-binding Protein.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hemoglobinopathy Evaluation.Why Get Tested?: To investigate hemoglobinopathy as the cause of signs and symptoms; to screen for a hemoglobin disorder
Hemoglobinopathy Evaluation.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and/or blood smear; when you have symptoms of hemolytic anemia such as weakness and fatigue and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have an abnormal form of hemoglobin (hemoglobinopathy); when you have a family history of hemoglobinopathy; as part of newborn screening
Hemoglobinopathy Evaluation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or obtained from the heel or finger of an infant

Hemogram.Why Get Tested?: To determine your general health status; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor any one of a variety of diseases and conditions that affect blood cells, such as anemia, infection, inflammation, bleeding disorder or cancer
Hemogram.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine medical exam; when you have signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition that affects blood cells; at regular intervals to monitor treatment or when you are receiving treatment known to affect blood cells
Hemogram.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a fingerstick or heelstick (newborns)

Hep B.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
Hep B.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
Hep B.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Heparin Activity.Why Get Tested?: To monitor standard, unfractionated heparin (UFH) therapy and sometimes to monitor low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) therapy
Heparin Activity.When To Get Tested?: When you are being treated with UFH or LMWH and your healthcare provider wants to monitor the amount of heparin in your blood
Heparin Activity.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Heparin Anti-Xa.Why Get Tested?: To monitor standard, unfractionated heparin (UFH) therapy and sometimes to monitor low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) therapy
Heparin Anti-Xa.When To Get Tested?: When you are being treated with UFH or LMWH and your healthcare provider wants to monitor the amount of heparin in your blood
Heparin Anti-Xa.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Heparin Associated Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies against the anticoagulant heparin, to help diagnose immune-mediated heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT II)
Heparin Associated Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving heparin therapy and your platelet count significantly decreases (thrombocytopenia), especially when you also have new blood clots (thrombosis)
Heparin Associated Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Heparin Induced Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies against the anticoagulant heparin, to help diagnose immune-mediated heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT II)
Heparin Induced Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving heparin therapy and your platelet count significantly decreases (thrombocytopenia), especially when you also have new blood clots (thrombosis)
Heparin Induced Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Heparin Level.Why Get Tested?: To monitor standard, unfractionated heparin (UFH) therapy and sometimes to monitor low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) therapy
Heparin Level.When To Get Tested?: When you are being treated with UFH or LMWH and your healthcare provider wants to monitor the amount of heparin in your blood
Heparin Level.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Heparin-induced Thrombocytopenia PF4 Ant.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies against the anticoagulant heparin, to help diagnose immune-mediated heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT II)
Heparin-induced Thrombocytopenia PF4 Ant.When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving heparin therapy and your platelet count significantly decreases (thrombocytopenia), especially when you also have new blood clots (thrombosis)
Heparin-induced Thrombocytopenia PF4 Ant.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Heparin-induced Thrombocytopenia Platele.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies against the anticoagulant heparin, to help diagnose immune-mediated heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT II)
Heparin-induced Thrombocytopenia Platele.When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving heparin therapy and your platelet count significantly decreases (thrombocytopenia), especially when you also have new blood clots (thrombosis)
Heparin-induced Thrombocytopenia Platele.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Heparin-PF4 Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies against the anticoagulant heparin, to help diagnose immune-mediated heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT II)
Heparin-PF4 Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving heparin therapy and your platelet count significantly decreases (thrombocytopenia), especially when you also have new blood clots (thrombosis)
Heparin-PF4 Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatic Copper.Why Get Tested?: To measure the amount of copper in the blood, urine, or liver tissue; to help diagnose and monitor Wilson disease; sometimes to identify copper deficiency or excess
Hepatic Copper.When To Get Tested?: When you have jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, behavioral changes, tremors, or other symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to Wilson disease or, rarely, to copper deficiency or excess; at intervals when you are being treated for a copper-related condition
Hepatic Copper.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a liver biopsy sample

Hepatic Function Panel.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, evaluate, and monitor acute and chronic liver inflammation (hepatitis), liver infection, liver disease and/or and damage
Hepatic Function Panel.When To Get Tested?: Periodically to evaluate liver function; whenever you are at risk for liver injury; when you are taking medications that may affect your liver; when you have a liver disease; when you have symptoms associated with liver damage, such as jaundice
Hepatic Function Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for infants, blood may be drawn by puncturing the heel with a lancet.
Hepatic Function Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight with only water permitted. Follow any instructions you are given. Inform the healthcare practitioner about all prescription and over-the-counter medications, herbal medications, vitamins and supplements you are taking.

Hepatitis A Testing.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of acute hepatitis; as part of a viral hepatitis panel to identify the type of hepatitis virus causing an infection; sometimes to evaluate the need for the hepatitis A vaccine
Hepatitis A Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an acute hepatitis infection, such as jaundice, or when you may have been exposed to hepatitis A virus (HAV)
Hepatitis A Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis B Core Antibody.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
Hepatitis B Core Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
Hepatitis B Core Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis B e Antibody.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
Hepatitis B e Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
Hepatitis B e Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis B e Antigen.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
Hepatitis B e Antigen.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
Hepatitis B e Antigen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis B Surface Antibody.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
Hepatitis B Surface Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
Hepatitis B Surface Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis B Surface Antigen.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
Hepatitis B Surface Antigen.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
Hepatitis B Surface Antigen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis B Testing.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
Hepatitis B Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
Hepatitis B Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis B Virus Testing.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to screen for and diagnose acute or chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, to detect a previous, resolved hepatitis B infection, or sometimes to guide and monitor treatment
Hepatitis B Virus Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have risk factors for HBV infection or when you have signs and symptoms of hepatitis, such as jaundice or unexplained elevated blood levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), a liver-associated enzyme; when you have a condition that requires chemotherapy or drugs that suppress your immune system; when you are being treated for HBV or hepatitis C (HCV); when it is unclear whether you have immunity and your healthcare practitioner is considering giving you the hepatitis B vaccine
Hepatitis B Virus Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis C Antibody.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and diagnose a hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and to monitor treatment of the infection
To learn more about hepatitis C, read the article on Viral Hepatitis.
Hepatitis C Antibody.When To Get Tested?:
For screening: when you have risk factors for HCV infection or were born between 1945 and 1965, per 2012 CDC recommendations
For diagnosis: when you may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus, such as through contact with infected blood, or have symptoms associated with liver disease
Hepatitis C Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis C Testing.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and diagnose a hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and to monitor treatment of the infection
To learn more about hepatitis C, read the article on Viral Hepatitis.
Hepatitis C Testing.When To Get Tested?:
For screening: when you have risk factors for HCV infection or were born between 1945 and 1965, per 2012 CDC recommendations
For diagnosis: when you may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus, such as through contact with infected blood, or have symptoms associated with liver disease
Hepatitis C Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis C Viral Load.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and diagnose a hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and to monitor treatment of the infection
To learn more about hepatitis C, read the article on Viral Hepatitis.
Hepatitis C Viral Load.When To Get Tested?:
For screening: when you have risk factors for HCV infection or were born between 1945 and 1965, per 2012 CDC recommendations
For diagnosis: when you may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus, such as through contact with infected blood, or have symptoms associated with liver disease
Hepatitis C Viral Load.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis Panel.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose an infection with a hepatitis virus
Hepatitis Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of acute hepatitis and a viral infection is suspected to be the cause; when you have been exposed to one or more of the three most common hepatitis viruses: hepatitis A, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C
Hepatitis Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Hepatitis Screening Panel.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose an infection with a hepatitis virus
Hepatitis Screening Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of acute hepatitis and a viral infection is suspected to be the cause; when you have been exposed to one or more of the three most common hepatitis viruses: hepatitis A, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C
Hepatitis Screening Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HER-1.Why Get Tested?: To detect EGFR gene mutations in non-small cell lung cancer tumor cells; knowing whether a mutation is present in the cells can help determine if EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as gefitinib and erlotinib may be beneficial for treating the tumor.
HER-1.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with non-small cell lung cancer; when you are being treated with an EGFR-targeted tyrosine kinase inhibitor, but the cancer progresses
HER-1.Sample Required?: A sample of cancer cells from a biopsy or surgical removal of cancerous tissue; if insufficient cells are obtained for testing by one of these methods, then a blood sample may be used as an alternative in some situations.
HER-1.Test Preparation Needed?: In many cases preparation is minimal, but it will depend upon how the cancer cells are being obtained. You will receive instructions from your healthcare practitioner based on the procedure being used to obtain the sample.

HER2.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether a tumor is positive for particular HER2 (ERBB2) mutations, which helps to guide treatment and predict the course of the disease (prognosis); sometimes to monitor treatment and for cancer recurrence
HER2.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or you had an invasive breast cancer that was treated but the tumor reoccurs or spreads (metastasizes), or when you have been diagnosed with certain types of stomach and esophagus cancer that are inoperable, locally advanced, recurrent, or metastatic
HER2.Sample Required?: A sample of tumor tissue is obtained by doing a fine needle aspiration, needle biopsy, or surgical biopsy (a tumor removed surgically)
HER2.Test Preparation Needed?: Before a biopsy, the physician who will obtain the sample of tumor tissue will provide instructions.

HER2(ERBB2) Amplification; HER2(ERBB2) O.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether a tumor is positive for particular HER2 (ERBB2) mutations, which helps to guide treatment and predict the course of the disease (prognosis); sometimes to monitor treatment and for cancer recurrence
HER2(ERBB2) Amplification; HER2(ERBB2) O.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or you had an invasive breast cancer that was treated but the tumor reoccurs or spreads (metastasizes), or when you have been diagnosed with certain types of stomach and esophagus cancer that are inoperable, locally advanced, recurrent, or metastatic
HER2(ERBB2) Amplification; HER2(ERBB2) O.Sample Required?: A sample of tumor tissue is obtained by doing a fine needle aspiration, needle biopsy, or surgical biopsy (a tumor removed surgically)
HER2(ERBB2) Amplification; HER2(ERBB2) O.Test Preparation Needed?: Before a biopsy, the physician who will obtain the sample of tumor tissue will provide instructions.

HER2/neu.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether a tumor is positive for particular HER2 (ERBB2) mutations, which helps to guide treatment and predict the course of the disease (prognosis); sometimes to monitor treatment and for cancer recurrence
HER2/neu.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or you had an invasive breast cancer that was treated but the tumor reoccurs or spreads (metastasizes), or when you have been diagnosed with certain types of stomach and esophagus cancer that are inoperable, locally advanced, recurrent, or metastatic
HER2/neu.Sample Required?: A sample of tumor tissue is obtained by doing a fine needle aspiration, needle biopsy, or surgical biopsy (a tumor removed surgically)
HER2/neu.Test Preparation Needed?: Before a biopsy, the physician who will obtain the sample of tumor tissue will provide instructions.

Herpes Culture.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
Herpes Culture.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
Herpes Culture.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Herpes Simplex Viral Culture.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
Herpes Simplex Viral Culture.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
Herpes Simplex Viral Culture.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Herpes Simplex Virus, Type 1 and Type 2.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
