Herpes Simplex Virus, Type 1 and Type 2.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
Herpes Simplex Virus, Type 1 and Type 2.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Herpes Testing.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
Herpes Testing.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
Herpes Testing.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Herpes Zoster.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose, as necessary, a current, recent, or past case of chickenpox or shingles; to determine whether you have developed immunity to the varicella zoster virus (VZV) or whether there is the potential for reactivating a VZV infection prior to receiving immunosuppressive drugs
Herpes Zoster.When To Get Tested?: When you have atypical and/or severe symptoms and your healthcare practitioner wants to distinguish between a VZV infection and another cause; when a healthcare practitioner wants to check whether or not you are immune to VZV; sometimes prior to an organ transplant or when a child, pregnant woman, or a person with a weakened immune system has been exposed to someone with chickenpox
Herpes Zoster.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for VZV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, a sample of fluid from a blister (vesicle), blood, cerebrospinal fluid, or other body fluid or tissue

HES/Leukemia.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of hypereosinophilia (HE), a condition with persistent increase in the number of eosinophils, a specific type of white blood cell, or hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES), which is HE with associated tissue or organ damage; to help determine if someone with HE or HES can be treated with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) such as imatinib
HES/Leukemia.When To Get Tested?: After complete blood counts (CBC) indicate that you have persistently elevated eosinophils and your health practitioner has ruled out other causes such as allergies, parasitic infection, or medication; at regular intervals when you are being treated for HE or HES with imatinib
HES/Leukemia.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

Heterophile Antibody Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono)
Heterophile Antibody Test.When To Get Tested?: When a person, especially an adolescent, has symptoms of mononucleosis, including fever, sore throat, swollen glands, and fatigue
Heterophile Antibody Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from pricking of your fingertip or from a vein in your arm

Hg (chemical symbol).Why Get Tested?: To detect excessive exposure to mercury
Hg (chemical symbol).When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of mercury poisoning or have been exposed to mercury; to monitor occupational exposure to mercury
Hg (chemical symbol).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine collection

Hgb.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the hemoglobin content of your blood as part of a general health checkup; to screen for and help diagnose conditions that affect red blood cells (RBCs); if you have anemia (low hemoglobin) or polycythemia (high hemoglobin), to assess the severity of these conditions and to monitor response to treatment
Hgb.When To Get Tested?: With a hematocrit or as part of a complete blood count (CBC), which may be ordered as a component of a general health screen; when you have signs and symptoms of anemia (weakness, fatigue) or polycythemia (dizziness, headache); at regular intervals to monitor these conditions or response to treatment
Hgb.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Hgb S.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sickle cell trait or sickle cell disease
Hgb S.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of newborn screening; if you are in a high risk group and were born before newborn screening was mandated and want to know if you have sickle cell disease or are carrying the sickle cell trait; when you have signs and symptoms of anemia or abnormal results from a complete blood count (CBC) and your healthcare practitioner suspects sickle cell disease or trait
Hgb S.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or, for infants, by pricking a heel or finger
Hgb S.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, if this test is used for diagnosis, the sample should not be drawn after a recent blood transfusion.

HGH.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for excess production of GH
HGH.When To Get Tested?: When a child has slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or sometimes when an adult has decreased bone density and/or muscle strength and elevated blood lipid levels that could be related to insufficient GH production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms suggestive of GH excess, which can cause two rare conditions, gigantism and acromegaly, respectively; when a pituitary disorder is suspected and other pituitary hormone levels are abnormal
HGH.Sample Required?: Usually several blood samples, drawn at timed intervals from veins in your arms; sometimes a single sample of blood, drawn following a fast and rest, after a period of strenuous exercise, or after ingesting a glucose (sugar) solution
HGH.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow any instructions you are given, such as to fast, in order to prepare for this test.

HHV1.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
HHV1.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
HHV1.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

HHV2.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
HHV2.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
HHV2.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

HIAA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor treatment for a carcinoid tumor that produces serotonin
HIAA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggestive of a carcinoid tumor, such as flushing, diarrhea, and/or wheezing; at intervals following treatment
HIAA.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; rarely, a random urine sample
HIAA.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to avoid certain foods and medications prior to this test.

High-density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To determine your risk of developing heart disease
High-density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a regular health exam with a lipid profile when no risk factors for heart disease are present; once every four to six years in adults; children should have a lipid profile screening at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and then again between the ages of 17 and 21.
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals as part of a lipid profile when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
High-density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
High-density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: If this test is to be performed as part of a complete lipid profile, fasting for 9 to 12 hours typically will be required; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

High-risk HPV.Why Get Tested?: To screen for infections in women with the high-risk types of HPV (hrHPV) that are associated with cervical cancer or to follow up on an abnormal Pap test
High-risk HPV.When To Get Tested?: If you are a woman aged 30 to 65; if you are a woman aged 21 to 29 and have an abnormal Pap test
High-risk HPV.Sample Required?: A sampling of cells from the cervical area
High-risk HPV.Test Preparation Needed?: It is recommended that you do not douche or use tampons or vaginal creams, deodorants, or medications for 2 days before the test. Some health practitioners may request that you refrain from sex for 24 to 48 hours before the test. Reschedule the test if you are having your period (menstruating). You may be asked to empty your bladder before the examination.

High-sensitivity C-reactive Protein.Why Get Tested?: To help assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
High-sensitivity C-reactive Protein.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested; hs-CRP is often ordered in conjunction with other tests that are performed to assess risk of heart disease, such as a lipid profile (cholesterol, triglycerides, HDL-C, LDL-C) when your healthcare provider would like additional information on your risk.
High-sensitivity C-reactive Protein.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
High-sensitivity C-reactive Protein.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 9-12 hours before the blood sample is taken if a lipid profile also is going to be done at the same time. You should be healthy at the time of the sample collection, without any recent illnesses, infections, inflammation, or injuries.

High-sensitivity C-reactive Protein (hs-.Why Get Tested?: To help assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
High-sensitivity C-reactive Protein (hs-.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested; hs-CRP is often ordered in conjunction with other tests that are performed to assess risk of heart disease, such as a lipid profile (cholesterol, triglycerides, HDL-C, LDL-C) when your healthcare provider would like additional information on your risk.
High-sensitivity C-reactive Protein (hs-.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
High-sensitivity C-reactive Protein (hs-.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 9-12 hours before the blood sample is taken if a lipid profile also is going to be done at the same time. You should be healthy at the time of the sample collection, without any recent illnesses, infections, inflammation, or injuries.

High-sensitivity CRP.Why Get Tested?: To help assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
High-sensitivity CRP.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested; hs-CRP is often ordered in conjunction with other tests that are performed to assess risk of heart disease, such as a lipid profile (cholesterol, triglycerides, HDL-C, LDL-C) when your healthcare provider would like additional information on your risk.
High-sensitivity CRP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
High-sensitivity CRP.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 9-12 hours before the blood sample is taken if a lipid profile also is going to be done at the same time. You should be healthy at the time of the sample collection, without any recent illnesses, infections, inflammation, or injuries.

high-sensitivity troponin.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have had a heart attack or injury to heart muscle; to determine if your angina (chest pain related to heart trouble) is worsening
high-sensitivity troponin.When To Get Tested?: Immediately, then followed by a series of troponin tests over several hours when you are having signs and symptoms that may be due to a heart attack, such as pain in your chest, shoulders, neck, jaw and/or shortness of breath; when your angina worsens, especially if it does not resolve with rest
high-sensitivity troponin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
high-sensitivity troponin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but tell your healthcare practitioner or emergency department personnel about any over-the-counter or prescription medications and/or supplements you take.

Histamine.Why Get Tested?: To help confirm a diagnosis of anaphylaxis, mastocytosis, or mast cell activation
Histamine.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as flushing, nausea, throat swelling or low blood pressure that may be due to a life-threatening allergic reaction; sometimes when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have mastocytosis or mast cell activation
Histamine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a 24-hour urine collection
Histamine.Test Preparation Needed?: None for anaphylaxis, but timing of the sample very soon after the beginning of symptoms is important. If testing is done for other conditions, you may be instructed to refrain from taking antihistamine and other medications. This should be discussed with your healthcare practitioner.

Histone Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help in the diagnosis and monitoring of drug-induced lupus
Histone Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with lupus that may be due to a drug that you are taking
Histone Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Histone Autoantibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help in the diagnosis and monitoring of drug-induced lupus
Histone Autoantibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with lupus that may be due to a drug that you are taking
Histone Autoantibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HIT Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies against the anticoagulant heparin, to help diagnose immune-mediated heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT II)
HIT Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving heparin therapy and your platelet count significantly decreases (thrombocytopenia), especially when you also have new blood clots (thrombosis)
HIT Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HIT PF4 Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies against the anticoagulant heparin, to help diagnose immune-mediated heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT II)
HIT PF4 Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you are receiving heparin therapy and your platelet count significantly decreases (thrombocytopenia), especially when you also have new blood clots (thrombosis)
HIT PF4 Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HIV Antibody and HIV Antigen (p24).Why Get Tested?: To determine if you are infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
HIV Antibody and HIV Antigen (p24).When To Get Tested?: At least once, when you are 13 to 64 years old; when you think you may have been exposed to the virus; before becoming pregnant or when pregnant; once a year if you are at increased risk of being exposed to the virus
HIV Antibody and HIV Antigen (p24).Sample Required?: A blood sample collected from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick; there are also HIV antibody tests available that can be performed on oral fluid.

HIV Antiretroviral Drug Resistance Testi.Why Get Tested?: If you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), to determine whether the strain causing your infection is resistant or has developed resistance to one or more antiretroviral therapy (ART) drugs
HIV Antiretroviral Drug Resistance Testi.When To Get Tested?: When first diagnosed with HIV, immediately prior to the start of antiretroviral therapy, or when you are receiving ART but the amount of virus in your blood (HIV viral load) does not decrease or rises steadily
HIV Antiretroviral Drug Resistance Testi.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HIV Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAA.Why Get Tested?: If you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), initially to determine the status of the infection and subsequently to monitor the effectiveness of antiretroviral treatment
HIV Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAA.When To Get Tested?: When first diagnosed with HIV; 2 to 8 weeks after the start of therapy or therapy changes, then every 4 to 8 weeks until the viral load is not detectable; then every 3 to 4 months if you are on stable therapy and the virus remains suppressed; after two years of this, viral load testing frequency may be decreased to every 6 months.
HIV Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HIV RNA Test.Why Get Tested?: If you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), initially to determine the status of the infection and subsequently to monitor the effectiveness of antiretroviral treatment
HIV RNA Test.When To Get Tested?: When first diagnosed with HIV; 2 to 8 weeks after the start of therapy or therapy changes, then every 4 to 8 weeks until the viral load is not detectable; then every 3 to 4 months if you are on stable therapy and the virus remains suppressed; after two years of this, viral load testing frequency may be decreased to every 6 months.
HIV RNA Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HIV Screening Tests.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you are infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
HIV Screening Tests.When To Get Tested?: At least once, when you are 13 to 64 years old; when you think you may have been exposed to the virus; before becoming pregnant or when pregnant; once a year if you are at increased risk of being exposed to the virus
HIV Screening Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample collected from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick; there are also HIV antibody tests available that can be performed on oral fluid.

HIV Serology.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you are infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
HIV Serology.When To Get Tested?: At least once, when you are 13 to 64 years old; when you think you may have been exposed to the virus; before becoming pregnant or when pregnant; once a year if you are at increased risk of being exposed to the virus
HIV Serology.Sample Required?: A blood sample collected from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick; there are also HIV antibody tests available that can be performed on oral fluid.

HIV Viral Load.Why Get Tested?: If you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), initially to determine the status of the infection and subsequently to monitor the effectiveness of antiretroviral treatment
HIV Viral Load.When To Get Tested?: When first diagnosed with HIV; 2 to 8 weeks after the start of therapy or therapy changes, then every 4 to 8 weeks until the viral load is not detectable; then every 3 to 4 months if you are on stable therapy and the virus remains suppressed; after two years of this, viral load testing frequency may be decreased to every 6 months.
HIV Viral Load.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HIV-1 and HIV-2 Antibody and Antigen Eva.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you are infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
HIV-1 and HIV-2 Antibody and Antigen Eva.When To Get Tested?: At least once, when you are 13 to 64 years old; when you think you may have been exposed to the virus; before becoming pregnant or when pregnant; once a year if you are at increased risk of being exposed to the virus
HIV-1 and HIV-2 Antibody and Antigen Eva.Sample Required?: A blood sample collected from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick; there are also HIV antibody tests available that can be performed on oral fluid.

HLA-B27.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have human leukocyte antigen B27 (HLA-B27) on the surface of your cells; to help assess the likelihood that you have an autoimmune disorder associated with the presence of HLA-B27
HLA-B27.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of arthritis-like chronic joint pain, stiffness, and inflammation in certain areas of your body, such as your lower back, hips, neck, and chest, or have painful inflammation of the eyes called uveitis, especially if you are male and the symptoms began in your early 30s
HLA-B27.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HLA-B27 Antigen.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have human leukocyte antigen B27 (HLA-B27) on the surface of your cells; to help assess the likelihood that you have an autoimmune disorder associated with the presence of HLA-B27
HLA-B27 Antigen.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of arthritis-like chronic joint pain, stiffness, and inflammation in certain areas of your body, such as your lower back, hips, neck, and chest, or have painful inflammation of the eyes called uveitis, especially if you are male and the symptoms began in your early 30s
HLA-B27 Antigen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Homocysteine.Why Get Tested?: To help determine if you are deficient in vitamins B6, B9 (folate) or B12; to determine if you are at increased risk of heart attack or stroke; to monitor those who have heart disease; sometimes to help diagnose a rare inherited disorder called homocystinuria in newborns
Homocysteine.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that you have a vitamin B6, B12 or folate deficiency; when you have had a heart attack or stroke and do not have traditional risk factors, such as unhealthy lipid levels
Homocysteine.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken by needle from a vein
Homocysteine.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 10 to 12 hours prior to this test; only water is permitted.

Homocysteine Cardiac Risk.Why Get Tested?: To help determine if you are deficient in vitamins B6, B9 (folate) or B12; to determine if you are at increased risk of heart attack or stroke; to monitor those who have heart disease; sometimes to help diagnose a rare inherited disorder called homocystinuria in newborns
Homocysteine Cardiac Risk.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that you have a vitamin B6, B12 or folate deficiency; when you have had a heart attack or stroke and do not have traditional risk factors, such as unhealthy lipid levels
Homocysteine Cardiac Risk.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken by needle from a vein
Homocysteine Cardiac Risk.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 10 to 12 hours prior to this test; only water is permitted.

Hormone Receptor Status.Why Get Tested?: The hormone receptor test determines if a breast cancer tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, helping to guide treatment and determine prognosis
Hormone Receptor Status.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or when your cancer has recurred
Hormone Receptor Status.Sample Required?: A sample of breast cancer tissue obtained during a biopsy or a tumor removed surgically during a lumpectomy or mastectomy
Hormone Receptor Status.Test Preparation Needed?: Your health practitioner may have you discontinue taking hormones for a time period before your sample is collected.

Hp.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate hemolytic anemia
Hp.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs of anemia such as weakness, paleness, or jaundice that a healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to red blood cell destruction (hemolytic anemia)
Hp.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HPT.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate hemolytic anemia
HPT.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs of anemia such as weakness, paleness, or jaundice that a healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to red blood cell destruction (hemolytic anemia)
HPT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

HPV DNA.Why Get Tested?: To screen for infections in women with the high-risk types of HPV (hrHPV) that are associated with cervical cancer or to follow up on an abnormal Pap test
HPV DNA.When To Get Tested?: If you are a woman aged 30 to 65; if you are a woman aged 21 to 29 and have an abnormal Pap test
HPV DNA.Sample Required?: A sampling of cells from the cervical area
HPV DNA.Test Preparation Needed?: It is recommended that you do not douche or use tampons or vaginal creams, deodorants, or medications for 2 days before the test. Some health practitioners may request that you refrain from sex for 24 to 48 hours before the test. Reschedule the test if you are having your period (menstruating). You may be asked to empty your bladder before the examination.

hrHPV.Why Get Tested?: To screen for infections in women with the high-risk types of HPV (hrHPV) that are associated with cervical cancer or to follow up on an abnormal Pap test
hrHPV.When To Get Tested?: If you are a woman aged 30 to 65; if you are a woman aged 21 to 29 and have an abnormal Pap test
hrHPV.Sample Required?: A sampling of cells from the cervical area
hrHPV.Test Preparation Needed?: It is recommended that you do not douche or use tampons or vaginal creams, deodorants, or medications for 2 days before the test. Some health practitioners may request that you refrain from sex for 24 to 48 hours before the test. Reschedule the test if you are having your period (menstruating). You may be asked to empty your bladder before the examination.

hs-troponin.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have had a heart attack or injury to heart muscle; to determine if your angina (chest pain related to heart trouble) is worsening
hs-troponin.When To Get Tested?: Immediately, then followed by a series of troponin tests over several hours when you are having signs and symptoms that may be due to a heart attack, such as pain in your chest, shoulders, neck, jaw and/or shortness of breath; when your angina worsens, especially if it does not resolve with rest
hs-troponin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
hs-troponin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but tell your healthcare practitioner or emergency department personnel about any over-the-counter or prescription medications and/or supplements you take.

hsCRP.Why Get Tested?: To help assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
hsCRP.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested; hs-CRP is often ordered in conjunction with other tests that are performed to assess risk of heart disease, such as a lipid profile (cholesterol, triglycerides, HDL-C, LDL-C) when your healthcare provider would like additional information on your risk.
hsCRP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
hsCRP.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 9-12 hours before the blood sample is taken if a lipid profile also is going to be done at the same time. You should be healthy at the time of the sample collection, without any recent illnesses, infections, inflammation, or injuries.

HSV by PCR.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
HSV by PCR.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
HSV by PCR.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

HSV DNA.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
HSV DNA.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
HSV DNA.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

HSV-1.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
HSV-1.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
HSV-1.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

HSV-1 or HSV-2 IgM or IgG.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
HSV-1 or HSV-2 IgM or IgG.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
HSV-1 or HSV-2 IgM or IgG.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

HSV-2.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose infection with the herpes simplex virus (HSV)
HSV-2.When To Get Tested?: If you have symptoms of an infection with HSV, such as blisters in the genital area, or symptoms of viral meningitis; if you have certain risk factors
HSV-2.Sample Required?: A swab or scraping from a blister or sore in the infected area or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for meningitis or encephalitis, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

HTLV-I/II Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To detect a human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV) infection; to help diagnose the cause of adult T-cell leukemia or lymphoma or HTLV-associated myelopathy
HTLV-I/II Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms that suggest that you may have an HTLV-associated neoplastic condition or demyelinating disorder, especially when you have identified risk factors; rarely when you have donated blood and been told that you are positive for HTLV antibodies
HTLV-I/II Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; rarely a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture (spinal tap)

HTLV-I/II by PCR.Why Get Tested?: To detect a human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV) infection; to help diagnose the cause of adult T-cell leukemia or lymphoma or HTLV-associated myelopathy
HTLV-I/II by PCR.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms that suggest that you may have an HTLV-associated neoplastic condition or demyelinating disorder, especially when you have identified risk factors; rarely when you have donated blood and been told that you are positive for HTLV antibodies
HTLV-I/II by PCR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; rarely a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture (spinal tap)

Human Calcitonin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor C-cell hyperplasia and medullary thyroid cancer; to screen those at risk for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2)
Human Calcitonin.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have or when you are being treated for medullary thyroid cancer, or when a family member has medullary thyroid cancer or MEN 2
Human Calcitonin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Human Calcitonin.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting may be required; follow instructions provided by your healthcare practitioner or the laboratory.

Human Chorionic Gonadotropin.Why Get Tested?: To confirm a pregnancy; to help identify an ectopic pregnancy; to monitor a pregnancy that may be at risk of failing; occasionally to screen a woman for pregnancy prior to some medical treatments; as part of a panel of tests used to screen for fetal abnormalities (see First Trimester Down Syndrome Screen and Second Trimester Maternal Serum Screening)
Human Chorionic Gonadotropin.When To Get Tested?: When you suspect that you are pregnant (testing can be done reliably by 10 days after you miss your menstrual period and some methods can detect hCG even earlier); when you have signs and symptoms that suggest you may have an ectopic pregnancy or a pregnancy that is failing; prior to some medical treatments
Human Chorionic Gonadotropin.Sample Required?: A urine sample collected first thing in the morning or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Human Chorionic Gonadotropin.Test Preparation Needed?: Do not drink large amounts of fluid before collecting a urine sample for a pregnancy test because overly diluted urine may result in a false negative; no preparation is needed for a blood sample.

Human Chorionic Gonadotropin, quantitati.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors
Human Chorionic Gonadotropin, quantitati.When To Get Tested?: When your symptoms suggest gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors; to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment for these conditions; to monitor for recurrence
Human Chorionic Gonadotropin, quantitati.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein

Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether a tumor is positive for particular HER2 (ERBB2) mutations, which helps to guide treatment and predict the course of the disease (prognosis); sometimes to monitor treatment and for cancer recurrence
Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or you had an invasive breast cancer that was treated but the tumor reoccurs or spreads (metastasizes), or when you have been diagnosed with certain types of stomach and esophagus cancer that are inoperable, locally advanced, recurrent, or metastatic
Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2.Sample Required?: A sample of tumor tissue is obtained by doing a fine needle aspiration, needle biopsy, or surgical biopsy (a tumor removed surgically)
Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2.Test Preparation Needed?: Before a biopsy, the physician who will obtain the sample of tumor tissue will provide instructions.

Human Epididymis Protein 4.Why Get Tested?: To help monitor epithelial ovarian cancer after treatment; to detect recurrence or disease progression; not recommended for screening asymptomatic women
Human Epididymis Protein 4.When To Get Tested?: Before starting therapy for epithelial ovarian cancer and at intervals after treatment
Human Epididymis Protein 4.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Human Epididymis Protein 4 (HE4).Why Get Tested?: To help monitor epithelial ovarian cancer after treatment; to detect recurrence or disease progression; not recommended for screening asymptomatic women
Human Epididymis Protein 4 (HE4).When To Get Tested?: Before starting therapy for epithelial ovarian cancer and at intervals after treatment
Human Epididymis Protein 4 (HE4).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Human Fecal Elastase-1.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
Human Fecal Elastase-1.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as stomach cramps, weight loss, malnutrition, malabsorption, delayed growth (in children) and fatty, foul-smelling stools and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
Human Fecal Elastase-1.Sample Required?: A fresh formed stool sample that is not contaminated with urine
Human Fecal Elastase-1.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be asked to discontinue them for 5 days prior to stool collection.

Human Growth Hormone.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for excess production of GH
Human Growth Hormone.When To Get Tested?: When a child has slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or sometimes when an adult has decreased bone density and/or muscle strength and elevated blood lipid levels that could be related to insufficient GH production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms suggestive of GH excess, which can cause two rare conditions, gigantism and acromegaly, respectively; when a pituitary disorder is suspected and other pituitary hormone levels are abnormal
Human Growth Hormone.Sample Required?: Usually several blood samples, drawn at timed intervals from veins in your arms; sometimes a single sample of blood, drawn following a fast and rest, after a period of strenuous exercise, or after ingesting a glucose (sugar) solution
Human Growth Hormone.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow any instructions you are given, such as to fast, in order to prepare for this test.

Human Immunodeficiency Virus Genotypic R.Why Get Tested?: If you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), to determine whether the strain causing your infection is resistant or has developed resistance to one or more antiretroviral therapy (ART) drugs
Human Immunodeficiency Virus Genotypic R.When To Get Tested?: When first diagnosed with HIV, immediately prior to the start of antiretroviral therapy, or when you are receiving ART but the amount of virus in your blood (HIV viral load) does not decrease or rises steadily
Human Immunodeficiency Virus Genotypic R.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Human Immunodeficiency Virus RNA, Quanti.Why Get Tested?: If you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), initially to determine the status of the infection and subsequently to monitor the effectiveness of antiretroviral treatment
Human Immunodeficiency Virus RNA, Quanti.When To Get Tested?: When first diagnosed with HIV; 2 to 8 weeks after the start of therapy or therapy changes, then every 4 to 8 weeks until the viral load is not detectable; then every 3 to 4 months if you are on stable therapy and the virus remains suppressed; after two years of this, viral load testing frequency may be decreased to every 6 months.
Human Immunodeficiency Virus RNA, Quanti.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Human Leukocyte Antigen B27.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have human leukocyte antigen B27 (HLA-B27) on the surface of your cells; to help assess the likelihood that you have an autoimmune disorder associated with the presence of HLA-B27
Human Leukocyte Antigen B27.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of arthritis-like chronic joint pain, stiffness, and inflammation in certain areas of your body, such as your lower back, hips, neck, and chest, or have painful inflammation of the eyes called uveitis, especially if you are male and the symptoms began in your early 30s
Human Leukocyte Antigen B27.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for infections in women with the high-risk types of HPV (hrHPV) that are associated with cervical cancer or to follow up on an abnormal Pap test
Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Test.When To Get Tested?: If you are a woman aged 30 to 65; if you are a woman aged 21 to 29 and have an abnormal Pap test
Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Test.Sample Required?: A sampling of cells from the cervical area
Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Test.Test Preparation Needed?: It is recommended that you do not douche or use tampons or vaginal creams, deodorants, or medications for 2 days before the test. Some health practitioners may request that you refrain from sex for 24 to 48 hours before the test. Reschedule the test if you are having your period (menstruating). You may be asked to empty your bladder before the examination.

Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus (HTLV) T.Why Get Tested?: To detect a human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV) infection; to help diagnose the cause of adult T-cell leukemia or lymphoma or HTLV-associated myelopathy
Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus (HTLV) T.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms that suggest that you may have an HTLV-associated neoplastic condition or demyelinating disorder, especially when you have identified risk factors; rarely when you have donated blood and been told that you are positive for HTLV antibodies
Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus (HTLV) T.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; rarely a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture (spinal tap)

Human T-Lymphotropic Virus Types I/II An.Why Get Tested?: To detect a human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV) infection; to help diagnose the cause of adult T-cell leukemia or lymphoma or HTLV-associated myelopathy
Human T-Lymphotropic Virus Types I/II An.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms that suggest that you may have an HTLV-associated neoplastic condition or demyelinating disorder, especially when you have identified risk factors; rarely when you have donated blood and been told that you are positive for HTLV antibodies
Human T-Lymphotropic Virus Types I/II An.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; rarely a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture (spinal tap)

Hydrogen Breath Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose lactose intolerance in individuals who have difficulties digesting dairy products, or sometimes as part of an investigation of malabsorption
Hydrogen Breath Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming milk and other dairy products
Hydrogen Breath Test.Sample Required?: A series of breath samples exhaled into a collector, or a series of blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm
Hydrogen Breath Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting is required; nothing but water is permitted. Two weeks prior to the test, you must be off antibiotics and stomach medications, such as laxatives, antacids and stool softeners. Tell your healthcare practitioner about any other medications you are taking. Avoid strenuous activities. You may be instructed to brush your teeth and/or rinse your mouth with water prior to and during the breath test.

Hydrogen Breath Test; Lactose Tolerance.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose lactose intolerance in individuals who have difficulties digesting dairy products, or sometimes as part of an investigation of malabsorption
Hydrogen Breath Test; Lactose Tolerance.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming milk and other dairy products
Hydrogen Breath Test; Lactose Tolerance.Sample Required?: A series of breath samples exhaled into a collector, or a series of blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm
Hydrogen Breath Test; Lactose Tolerance.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting is required; nothing but water is permitted. Two weeks prior to the test, you must be off antibiotics and stomach medications, such as laxatives, antacids and stool softeners. Tell your healthcare practitioner about any other medications you are taking. Avoid strenuous activities. You may be instructed to brush your teeth and/or rinse your mouth with water prior to and during the breath test.

hypertension.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
hypertension.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
hypertension.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
hypertension.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Hypofibrinogenemia Test.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; sometimes used to help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Hypofibrinogenemia Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged; when you have a relative with a hereditary fibrinogen deficiency or abnormality; when your health care provider wants additional information to help evaluate your risk of developing heart disease
Hypofibrinogenemia Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

IAT.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies directed against red blood cell antigens
IAT.When To Get Tested?: When preparing for a blood transfusion; during pregnancy and at delivery
IAT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

IBC.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to assess your body's ability to transport iron in the blood; to help diagnose iron-deficiency or iron overload
IBC.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects you may have too much iron (overload) or too little iron (deficiency) in the body
IBC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
IBC.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

ICSH.Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or to detect the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation); to evaluate pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
ICSH.When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or heavy menstrual periods; when you are tracking ovulation during your menstrual cycle
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
ICSH.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or a 24-hour urine collection may be taken
ICSH.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

IF Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
IF Antibody.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
IF Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
IF Antibody.Test Preparation Needed?: You should wait at least 48 hours after receiving a vitamin B12 injection to have a blood sample taken. Some healthcare providers may prefer not to draw a blood sample for the test within 2 weeks of an injection.

IF Antibody Type 1 or Type 2.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
IF Antibody Type 1 or Type 2.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
IF Antibody Type 1 or Type 2.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
IF Antibody Type 1 or Type 2.Test Preparation Needed?: You should wait at least 48 hours after receiving a vitamin B12 injection to have a blood sample taken. Some healthcare providers may prefer not to draw a blood sample for the test within 2 weeks of an injection.

IFE.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
IFE.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
IFE.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

iFOBT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
iFOBT.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
iFOBT.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
iFOBT.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

IgA.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's immune system status; to detect and monitor an excess or deficiency in one or more of the immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM)
IgA.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent infections and/or chronic diarrhea; when your healthcare practitioner suspects an immunoglobulin deficiency or excess of a particular immunoglobulin; periodically to monitor a condition that affects immunoglobulin levels that may be genetic (selective IgA deficiency) or acquired (HIV/AIDS, multiple myeloma)
IgA.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. When required, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected by a healthcare practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap. Saliva or other fluids are collected in a container provided by the laboratory.

IgG.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's immune system status; to detect and monitor an excess or deficiency in one or more of the immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM)
IgG.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent infections and/or chronic diarrhea; when your healthcare practitioner suspects an immunoglobulin deficiency or excess of a particular immunoglobulin; periodically to monitor a condition that affects immunoglobulin levels that may be genetic (selective IgA deficiency) or acquired (HIV/AIDS, multiple myeloma)
IgG.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. When required, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected by a healthcare practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap. Saliva or other fluids are collected in a container provided by the laboratory.

IgM.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's immune system status; to detect and monitor an excess or deficiency in one or more of the immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM)
IgM.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent infections and/or chronic diarrhea; when your healthcare practitioner suspects an immunoglobulin deficiency or excess of a particular immunoglobulin; periodically to monitor a condition that affects immunoglobulin levels that may be genetic (selective IgA deficiency) or acquired (HIV/AIDS, multiple myeloma)
IgM.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. When required, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected by a healthcare practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap. Saliva or other fluids are collected in a container provided by the laboratory.

IGRA TB Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
IGRA TB Test.When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
IGRA TB Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample is drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

IL-6.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate conditions such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease or conditions associated with inflammation such as lupus and rheumatoid arthritis or with infection, such as sepsis
IL-6.When To Get Tested?: Not commonly ordered, but may be used when an individual has been diagnosed with or has signs and symptoms associated with one of the conditions listed above
IL-6.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Immunoglobulin A.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's immune system status; to detect and monitor an excess or deficiency in one or more of the immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM)
Immunoglobulin A.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent infections and/or chronic diarrhea; when your healthcare practitioner suspects an immunoglobulin deficiency or excess of a particular immunoglobulin; periodically to monitor a condition that affects immunoglobulin levels that may be genetic (selective IgA deficiency) or acquired (HIV/AIDS, multiple myeloma)
Immunoglobulin A.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. When required, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected by a healthcare practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap. Saliva or other fluids are collected in a container provided by the laboratory.

Immunoglobulin E.Why Get Tested?: To screen for an allergic disease; sometimes to screen for a parasitic infection
Immunoglobulin E.When To Get Tested?: When you have periodic or persistent skin, lung, or digestive symptoms that suggest allergies; when a healthcare practitioner suspects a parasitic infection
Immunoglobulin E.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Immunoglobulin G.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's immune system status; to detect and monitor an excess or deficiency in one or more of the immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM)
Immunoglobulin G.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent infections and/or chronic diarrhea; when your healthcare practitioner suspects an immunoglobulin deficiency or excess of a particular immunoglobulin; periodically to monitor a condition that affects immunoglobulin levels that may be genetic (selective IgA deficiency) or acquired (HIV/AIDS, multiple myeloma)
Immunoglobulin G.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. When required, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected by a healthcare practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap. Saliva or other fluids are collected in a container provided by the laboratory.

Immunoglobulin Gene Rearrangement.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a B-cell lymphoma; to detect and evaluate residual cancer cells
Immunoglobulin Gene Rearrangement.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have a B-cell lymphoma; sometimes to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment or to evaluate for recurrent disease
Immunoglobulin Gene Rearrangement.Sample Required?: A bone marrow or other tissue biopsy procedure is performed by a doctor or other trained specialist. Body fluid samples are obtained by inserting a needle into the body cavity and withdrawing a portion of the fluid with a syringe. Sometimes, a blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm.

Immunoglobulin M.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's immune system status; to detect and monitor an excess or deficiency in one or more of the immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM)
Immunoglobulin M.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent infections and/or chronic diarrhea; when your healthcare practitioner suspects an immunoglobulin deficiency or excess of a particular immunoglobulin; periodically to monitor a condition that affects immunoglobulin levels that may be genetic (selective IgA deficiency) or acquired (HIV/AIDS, multiple myeloma)
Immunoglobulin M.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. When required, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected by a healthcare practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap. Saliva or other fluids are collected in a container provided by the laboratory.

Immunoglobulins (IgA, IgG, IgM).Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's immune system status; to detect and monitor an excess or deficiency in one or more of the immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM)
Immunoglobulins (IgA, IgG, IgM).When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent infections and/or chronic diarrhea; when your healthcare practitioner suspects an immunoglobulin deficiency or excess of a particular immunoglobulin; periodically to monitor a condition that affects immunoglobulin levels that may be genetic (selective IgA deficiency) or acquired (HIV/AIDS, multiple myeloma)
Immunoglobulins (IgA, IgG, IgM).Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. When required, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected by a healthcare practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap. Saliva or other fluids are collected in a container provided by the laboratory.

Immunoglobulins, Quantitative.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's immune system status; to detect and monitor an excess or deficiency in one or more of the immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM)
Immunoglobulins, Quantitative.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent infections and/or chronic diarrhea; when your healthcare practitioner suspects an immunoglobulin deficiency or excess of a particular immunoglobulin; periodically to monitor a condition that affects immunoglobulin levels that may be genetic (selective IgA deficiency) or acquired (HIV/AIDS, multiple myeloma)
Immunoglobulins, Quantitative.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. When required, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected by a healthcare practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap. Saliva or other fluids are collected in a container provided by the laboratory.

Immunophenotyping.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and classify a leukemia or lymphoma; to help guide treatment; to detect and evaluate leukocyte cancer cells that remain after treatment or disease relapse
Immunophenotyping.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to leukemia or lymphoma; when you have been diagnosed with leukemia or lymphoma but the specific subtype is unknown; sometimes to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment or to evaluate for recurrent disease
Immunophenotyping.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a bone marrow, tissue biopsy, or fluid sample collected by a health practitioner

Immunophenotyping by Flow Cytometry or I.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and classify a leukemia or lymphoma; to help guide treatment; to detect and evaluate leukocyte cancer cells that remain after treatment or disease relapse
Immunophenotyping by Flow Cytometry or I.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to leukemia or lymphoma; when you have been diagnosed with leukemia or lymphoma but the specific subtype is unknown; sometimes to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment or to evaluate for recurrent disease
Immunophenotyping by Flow Cytometry or I.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a bone marrow, tissue biopsy, or fluid sample collected by a health practitioner

Immunoreactive Trypsin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for cystic fibrosis (CF); sometimes to detect pancreatitis
Immunoreactive Trypsin.When To Get Tested?: As part of a newborn screening test; sometimes when you have symptoms of pancreatitis, such as severe abdominal pain that may be persistent or intermittent, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and jaundice
Immunoreactive Trypsin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel, a spot of blood that is put onto filter paper, or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Immunoreactive Trypsinogen.Why Get Tested?: To screen for cystic fibrosis (CF); sometimes to detect pancreatitis
Immunoreactive Trypsinogen.When To Get Tested?: As part of a newborn screening test; sometimes when you have symptoms of pancreatitis, such as severe abdominal pain that may be persistent or intermittent, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and jaundice
Immunoreactive Trypsinogen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel, a spot of blood that is put onto filter paper, or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT).Why Get Tested?: To screen for cystic fibrosis (CF); sometimes to detect pancreatitis
Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT).When To Get Tested?: As part of a newborn screening test; sometimes when you have symptoms of pancreatitis, such as severe abdominal pain that may be persistent or intermittent, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and jaundice
Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel, a spot of blood that is put onto filter paper, or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Indirect Anti-human Globulin Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies directed against red blood cell antigens
Indirect Anti-human Globulin Test.When To Get Tested?: When preparing for a blood transfusion; during pregnancy and at delivery
Indirect Anti-human Globulin Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Indirect Antiglobulin Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies directed against red blood cell antigens
Indirect Antiglobulin Test.When To Get Tested?: When preparing for a blood transfusion; during pregnancy and at delivery
Indirect Antiglobulin Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Indirect Bilirubin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor liver disorders or hemolytic anemia; to monitor neonatal jaundice
Indirect Bilirubin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of liver damage, liver disease, bile duct blockage, hemolytic anemia, or a liver-related metabolic problem, or if a newborn has jaundice
Indirect Bilirubin.Sample Required?: In adults, a blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm; in newborns, a blood sample from a heelstick; non-invasive technology is available in some healthcare facilities that will measure bilirubin by using an instrument placed on the skin (transcutaneous bilirubin meter)
Indirect Bilirubin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for several hours before the test; fasting requirements vary by laboratory; ask your lab or healthcare provider for instructions.

Indirect Coombs Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies directed against red blood cell antigens
Indirect Coombs Test.When To Get Tested?: When preparing for a blood transfusion; during pregnancy and at delivery
Indirect Coombs Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Infectious Mononucleosis Rapid Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono)
Infectious Mononucleosis Rapid Test.When To Get Tested?: When a person, especially an adolescent, has symptoms of mononucleosis, including fever, sore throat, swollen glands, and fatigue
Infectious Mononucleosis Rapid Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from pricking of your fingertip or from a vein in your arm

Influenza Rapid Antigen Test, Type A and.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an influenza infection (flu), especially if you are hospitalized, have a weakened immune system, or are otherwise at an increased risk of serious complications from influenza; to help your healthcare practitioner make treatment decisions; to help determine whether or not the flu has spread to your community
Influenza Rapid Antigen Test, Type A and.When To Get Tested?: When it is flu season and a healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether your symptoms are due to seasonal influenza A or B or to another cause; within 3 to 4 days of the onset of signs and symptoms, such as fever, headache, muscle aches, sore throat, weakness, fatigue, cough, sore throat, stuffy nose and sometimes runny nose
Influenza Rapid Antigen Test, Type A and.Sample Required?: Depending on the test used, a respiratory sample collected on a swab from the nasopharynx or a nasal aspirate; sometimes, a nasal or throat swab

Influenza Tests.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an influenza infection (flu), especially if you are hospitalized, have a weakened immune system, or are otherwise at an increased risk of serious complications from influenza; to help your healthcare practitioner make treatment decisions; to help determine whether or not the flu has spread to your community
Influenza Tests.When To Get Tested?: When it is flu season and a healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether your symptoms are due to seasonal influenza A or B or to another cause; within 3 to 4 days of the onset of signs and symptoms, such as fever, headache, muscle aches, sore throat, weakness, fatigue, cough, sore throat, stuffy nose and sometimes runny nose
Influenza Tests.Sample Required?: Depending on the test used, a respiratory sample collected on a swab from the nasopharynx or a nasal aspirate; sometimes, a nasal or throat swab

Influenza Viral Culture.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an influenza infection (flu), especially if you are hospitalized, have a weakened immune system, or are otherwise at an increased risk of serious complications from influenza; to help your healthcare practitioner make treatment decisions; to help determine whether or not the flu has spread to your community
Influenza Viral Culture.When To Get Tested?: When it is flu season and a healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether your symptoms are due to seasonal influenza A or B or to another cause; within 3 to 4 days of the onset of signs and symptoms, such as fever, headache, muscle aches, sore throat, weakness, fatigue, cough, sore throat, stuffy nose and sometimes runny nose
Influenza Viral Culture.Sample Required?: Depending on the test used, a respiratory sample collected on a swab from the nasopharynx or a nasal aspirate; sometimes, a nasal or throat swab

Influenza Virus by PCR.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an influenza infection (flu), especially if you are hospitalized, have a weakened immune system, or are otherwise at an increased risk of serious complications from influenza; to help your healthcare practitioner make treatment decisions; to help determine whether or not the flu has spread to your community
Influenza Virus by PCR.When To Get Tested?: When it is flu season and a healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether your symptoms are due to seasonal influenza A or B or to another cause; within 3 to 4 days of the onset of signs and symptoms, such as fever, headache, muscle aches, sore throat, weakness, fatigue, cough, sore throat, stuffy nose and sometimes runny nose
Influenza Virus by PCR.Sample Required?: Depending on the test used, a respiratory sample collected on a swab from the nasopharynx or a nasal aspirate; sometimes, a nasal or throat swab

Inorganic Phosphate.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the level of phosphorus in your blood and to aid in the diagnosis of conditions known to cause abnormally high or low levels of phosphorus
Inorganic Phosphate.When To Get Tested?: In follow up to an abnormal calcium level; when you have a kidney disorder or uncontrolled diabetes; when you are taking calcium or phosphate supplements
Inorganic Phosphate.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm. If a timed urine sample is required, you will be asked to save all of your urine over a set time period (usually 24 hours).
Inorganic Phosphate.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting may be required prior to collecting a blood sample; follow any instructions that you are given.

INR.Why Get Tested?: A prothrombin time (PT) is a test used to help detect and diagnose a bleeding disorder or excessive clotting disorder; the international normalized ratio (INR) is calculated from a PT result and is used to monitor how well the blood-thinning medication (anticoagulant) warfarin (Coumadin®) is working to prevent blood clots.
INR.When To Get Tested?: When you are taking warfarin or when you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding or inappropriate blood clotting
INR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes blood from a fingerstick
INR.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed, although if you are receiving anticoagulant therapy, the specimen should be collected before taking your daily dose.

Insulin.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate insulin production by the beta cells in the pancreas; to help diagnose the presence of an insulin-producing tumor in the islet cells of the pancreas (insulinoma); to help determine the cause of low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to help identify insulin resistance, or to help determine when a type 2 diabetic might need to start taking insulin to supplement oral medications
Insulin.When To Get Tested?: When you have low blood glucose levels with symptoms such as sweating, palpitations, dizziness, fainting; when you have diabetes and your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor your insulin production; sometimes when it is suspected that you have insulin resistance
Insulin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Insulin.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, you will be asked to fast for 8 hours before the blood sample is collected. Occasionally, a healthcare practitioner may do testing when fasting is not possible, such as when a glucose tolerance test is done. In some cases, a healthcare practitioner may request that you fast longer than 8 hours.

Insulin C-peptide.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate insulin production by the beta cells in the pancreas or to help determine the cause of low blood glucose (hypoglycemia)
Insulin C-peptide.When To Get Tested?: When you have diabetes and your health practitioner wants to determine if you are producing enough of your own insulin or if it is time to supplement oral medication with insulin injections or an insulin pump; when your health practitioner suspects that you have insulin resistance; when you have documented hypoglycemia
Insulin C-peptide.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and sometimes a 24-hour urine sample
Insulin C-peptide.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting for 8 to 10 hours before blood testing is usually required.

Insulin-like Growth Factor - 1.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of GH treatment
Insulin-like Growth Factor - 1.When To Get Tested?: When a child has signs and symptoms of slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or an adult has decreased bone density, reduced muscle strength, and increased lipids that suggest insufficient GH and IGF-1 production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms of gigantism or acromegaly, respectively, that suggest excess GH and IGF-1 production; during and after treatment for GH abnormalities; when a pituitary disorder is suspected
Insulin-like Growth Factor - 1.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Insulin-like Growth Factor - 1.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally none, unless instructed to fast

Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of GH treatment
Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1).When To Get Tested?: When a child has signs and symptoms of slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or an adult has decreased bone density, reduced muscle strength, and increased lipids that suggest insufficient GH and IGF-1 production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms of gigantism or acromegaly, respectively, that suggest excess GH and IGF-1 production; during and after treatment for GH abnormalities; when a pituitary disorder is suspected
Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1).Test Preparation Needed?: Generally none, unless instructed to fast

Insulin, serum.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate insulin production by the beta cells in the pancreas; to help diagnose the presence of an insulin-producing tumor in the islet cells of the pancreas (insulinoma); to help determine the cause of low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to help identify insulin resistance, or to help determine when a type 2 diabetic might need to start taking insulin to supplement oral medications
Insulin, serum.When To Get Tested?: When you have low blood glucose levels with symptoms such as sweating, palpitations, dizziness, fainting; when you have diabetes and your healthcare practitioner wants to monitor your insulin production; sometimes when it is suspected that you have insulin resistance
Insulin, serum.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Insulin, serum.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, you will be asked to fast for 8 hours before the blood sample is collected. Occasionally, a healthcare practitioner may do testing when fasting is not possible, such as when a glucose tolerance test is done. In some cases, a healthcare practitioner may request that you fast longer than 8 hours.

Intact hCG.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors
Intact hCG.When To Get Tested?: When your symptoms suggest gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors; to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment for these conditions; to monitor for recurrence
Intact hCG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein

Intact PTH.Why Get Tested?: To determine the cause of calcium imbalances; to evaluate parathyroid function; to diagnose and differentiate between primary, secondary, and tertiary hyperparathyroidism; to diagnose hypoparathyroidism; during surgery for hyperparathyroidism to confirm removal of the gland(s) causing the problem
Intact PTH.When To Get Tested?: When calcium blood levels are higher or lower than normal; when you are having surgery for hyperparathyroidism; when your healthcare practitioner wants to determine how well your parathyroid glands are functioning
Intact PTH.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Intact PTH.Test Preparation Needed?: Current practices do not require fasting. PTH levels peak during sleep hours and are lowest during mid-morning to late afternoon hours, the period when most samples are drawn. There may be seasonal fluctuations in PTH due to its inverse relationship with vitamin D. Talk to your healthcare practitioner about sample timing.

Interferon Gamma Release Assay.Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
Interferon Gamma Release Assay.When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
Interferon Gamma Release Assay.Sample Required?: A blood sample is drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

Interleukin-6.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate conditions such as diabetes and cardiovascular disease or conditions associated with inflammation such as lupus and rheumatoid arthritis or with infection, such as sepsis
Interleukin-6.When To Get Tested?: Not commonly ordered, but may be used when an individual has been diagnosed with or has signs and symptoms associated with one of the conditions listed above
Interleukin-6.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Interstitial Cell Stimulating Hormone.Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or to detect the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation); to evaluate pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
Interstitial Cell Stimulating Hormone.When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or heavy menstrual periods; when you are tracking ovulation during your menstrual cycle
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
Interstitial Cell Stimulating Hormone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or a 24-hour urine collection may be taken
Interstitial Cell Stimulating Hormone.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

Intrinsic Factor Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
Intrinsic Factor Antibody.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
Intrinsic Factor Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Intrinsic Factor Antibody.Test Preparation Needed?: You should wait at least 48 hours after receiving a vitamin B12 injection to have a blood sample taken. Some healthcare providers may prefer not to draw a blood sample for the test within 2 weeks of an injection.
