Intrinsic Factor Binding Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
Intrinsic Factor Binding Antibody.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
Intrinsic Factor Binding Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Intrinsic Factor Binding Antibody.Test Preparation Needed?: You should wait at least 48 hours after receiving a vitamin B12 injection to have a blood sample taken. Some healthcare providers may prefer not to draw a blood sample for the test within 2 weeks of an injection.

Intrinsic Factor Blocking Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
Intrinsic Factor Blocking Antibody.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
Intrinsic Factor Blocking Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Intrinsic Factor Blocking Antibody.Test Preparation Needed?: You should wait at least 48 hours after receiving a vitamin B12 injection to have a blood sample taken. Some healthcare providers may prefer not to draw a blood sample for the test within 2 weeks of an injection.

Ionized Calcium.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, diagnose, and monitor a range of medical conditions
Ionized Calcium.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine metabolic panel; when you have symptoms of a disorder, or known presence of one, affecting your kidneys, bones, thyroid, parathyroid, or nerves or when symptoms of significantly increased or decreased calcium concentrations are present; when someone is critically ill, to monitor ionized calcium levels; when someone has certain types of cancer; when someone is being treated for abnormal calcium levels, to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment
Ionized Calcium.Sample Required?: A blood sample is taken by needle from a vein in the arm. If a urine collection is required, a 24-hour urine sample or a timed collection of a shorter duration is obtained. Sometimes a random urine collection may be used, although a timed collection is preferred.
Ionized Calcium.Test Preparation Needed?: Current practices do not require fasting. You may be instructed to stop taking certain medications, such as lithium, antacids, diuretics, and vitamin D supplements, among others, to ensure the most accurate test results.

Iontophoretic Sweat Test.When To Get Tested?: When an infant has a positive newborn screening test for CF; when you or your child has signs and symptoms that suggest CF or tested positive or indeterminate for CF with other tests
Iontophoretic Sweat Test.Sample Required?: A sweat sample collected using a special sweat stimulation procedure (see below)
Iontophoretic Sweat Test.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, you may be instructed to avoid applying creams or lotions to your skin 24 hours before the test. Also, it is important to be well-hydrated before undergoing the procedure.

Iron.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to determine your blood iron level; along with other tests, to help diagnose iron-deficiency anemia or iron overload
Iron.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (deficiency) or too much iron (overload) in your body
Iron.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Iron.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before sample collection; in this case, only water is permitted. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Iron Binding Capacity.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to assess your body's ability to transport iron in the blood; to help diagnose iron-deficiency or iron overload
Iron Binding Capacity.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects you may have too much iron (overload) or too little iron (deficiency) in the body
Iron Binding Capacity.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Iron Binding Capacity.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Iron Indices.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your body's current level of iron; to help diagnose iron deficiency or iron overload
Iron Indices.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (deficiency) or too much iron (overload) in your body
Iron Indices.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Iron Indices.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Iron Tests.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your body's current level of iron; to help diagnose iron deficiency or iron overload
Iron Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (deficiency) or too much iron (overload) in your body
Iron Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Iron Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Iron, serum.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to determine your blood iron level; along with other tests, to help diagnose iron-deficiency anemia or iron overload
Iron, serum.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (deficiency) or too much iron (overload) in your body
Iron, serum.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Iron, serum.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before sample collection; in this case, only water is permitted. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

IRT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for cystic fibrosis (CF); sometimes to detect pancreatitis
IRT.When To Get Tested?: As part of a newborn screening test; sometimes when you have symptoms of pancreatitis, such as severe abdominal pain that may be persistent or intermittent, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and jaundice
IRT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel, a spot of blood that is put onto filter paper, or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Islet Autoantibodies in Diabetes.Why Get Tested?: To identify people at increased risk for developing type 1 diabetes or requiring insulin treatment; to aid in the classification of diabetes. Note: testing for islet autoantibodies in non-diabetic individuals Is not advised unless the person is a participant in a research study that requires islet autoantibody testing.
Islet Autoantibodies in Diabetes.When To Get Tested?: Any time that you have diabetes and your healthcare practitioner cannot clearly determine if you have type 1 diabetes or type 2 diabetes, your healthcare practitioner may order tests for islet autoantibodies.
Islet Autoantibodies in Diabetes.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Islet Cell Cytoplasmic Autoantibodies (I.Why Get Tested?: To identify people at increased risk for developing type 1 diabetes or requiring insulin treatment; to aid in the classification of diabetes. Note: testing for islet autoantibodies in non-diabetic individuals Is not advised unless the person is a participant in a research study that requires islet autoantibody testing.
Islet Cell Cytoplasmic Autoantibodies (I.When To Get Tested?: Any time that you have diabetes and your healthcare practitioner cannot clearly determine if you have type 1 diabetes or type 2 diabetes, your healthcare practitioner may order tests for islet autoantibodies.
Islet Cell Cytoplasmic Autoantibodies (I.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

JAK2 Mutation.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose bone marrow disorders known as myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) in which the bone marrow produces too many of one or more types of blood cells
JAK2 Mutation.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have a bone marrow disorder, including polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, or primary myelofibrosis
JAK2 Mutation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a sample of bone marrow

JAK2 V617F; JAK2 Exon 12 Mutation.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose bone marrow disorders known as myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) in which the bone marrow produces too many of one or more types of blood cells
JAK2 V617F; JAK2 Exon 12 Mutation.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have a bone marrow disorder, including polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, or primary myelofibrosis
JAK2 V617F; JAK2 Exon 12 Mutation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a sample of bone marrow

Janus Kinase 2.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose bone marrow disorders known as myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) in which the bone marrow produces too many of one or more types of blood cells
Janus Kinase 2.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have a bone marrow disorder, including polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, or primary myelofibrosis
Janus Kinase 2.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a sample of bone marrow

Joint Fluid Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of joint inflammation, pain, and/or swelling
Joint Fluid Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When one or more of your joints are swollen, red, and/or painful
Joint Fluid Analysis.Sample Required?: A synovial fluid sample is obtained by inserting a needle into the space between the bones at a joint
Joint Fluid Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: Consult with your healthcare provider; synovial fluid collection and analysis may be performed after fasting or at random.

K.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether your potassium level is within normal limits; to help evaluate electrolyte balance; to help determine the cause of and monitor treatment for illnesses associated with abnormal potassium levels in the body
K.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as muscle weakness and/or irregular heart beat (cardiac arrhythmia) or when an electrolyte imbalance is suspected; at regular intervals when you are taking a medication and/or have a disease or condition, such as high blood pressure (hypertension) or kidney disease, that can affect your potassium level; as part of a routine medical exam
K.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

K-Ras.Why Get Tested?: To detect a KRAS gene mutation in tumor tissue in order to guide cancer therapy and to evaluate prognosis
K-Ras.When To Get Tested?: When you have colon cancer that has spread (metastatic) or non-small cell lung cancer and your health practitioner is considering an anti-EGFR drug therapy

Kappa and Lambda Free Light Chains.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and monitor plasma cell disorders (dyscrasias) such as multiple myeloma, primary amyloidosis, and related diseases or to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Kappa and Lambda Free Light Chains.When To Get Tested?: When you have bone pain, fractures, anemia (with normal size and shape red blood cells (normocytic)), kidney disease, and recurrent infections that your healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a plasma cell disorder; when you are being treated for a plasma cell disorder
Kappa and Lambda Free Light Chains.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Karyotype.Why Get Tested?: To detect chromosome abnormalities, thus to help diagnose genetic diseases, some birth defects, and certain disorders of the blood and lymphatic system
Karyotype.When To Get Tested?: When pregnancy screening tests are abnormal; whenever signs of a chromosomal abnormality-associated disorder are present; as indicated to detect chromosomal abnormalities in a person and/or detect a specific abnormality in family members; sometimes when a person has leukemia, lymphoma, myeloma, myelodysplasia or another cancer and an acquired chromosome abnormality is suspected
Karyotype.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a sample of amniotic fluid or chorionic villus from a pregnant woman; a bone marrow or tissue sample

Ketone Bodies.Why Get Tested?: To determine the amount of ketones (ketone bodies, acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood to help diagnose a life-threatening problem called diabetic ketoacidosis
Ketone Bodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with ketoacidosis, such as increased urination, excessive thirst, dehydration, rapid breathing, and shortness of breath
Ketone Bodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

Kidney Function Panel.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and manage conditions affecting kidney function; may be used as part of general health screening or to screen someone who is at risk of developing kidney disease, or to follow someone with known kidney disease
Kidney Function Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have a condition affecting the function of your kidneys; when you are being treated for kidney disease; when you have certain risk factors for kidney disease, such as high blood pressure or diabetes
Kidney Function Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Kidney Function Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 8-12 hours (no food, only water) prior to the test.

Kidney Panel.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and manage conditions affecting kidney function; may be used as part of general health screening or to screen someone who is at risk of developing kidney disease, or to follow someone with known kidney disease
Kidney Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have a condition affecting the function of your kidneys; when you are being treated for kidney disease; when you have certain risk factors for kidney disease, such as high blood pressure or diabetes
Kidney Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Kidney Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 8-12 hours (no food, only water) prior to the test.

Kidney Stone Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the composition of a kidney stone, to help determine the cause of its formation and to guide treatment
Kidney Stone Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When a stone has passed through or been removed from your urinary tract
Kidney Stone Analysis.Sample Required?: A stone or stones filtered from your urine or surgically removed from your urinary tract by a health practitioner

Kidney Stone Risk Panel.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's risk of recurring kidney stone formation; to help determine the underlying reason for developing a kidney stone; to determine if there is a family history of kidney stone disease; to help guide and monitor treatment
Kidney Stone Risk Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have had kidney stones and a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your risk of developing additional kidney stones; when you have risk factors such as a family history of kidney stones, a single functional kidney, or a transplanted kidney
Kidney Stone Risk Panel.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine collection is required for this test. Frequently, two different 24-hour urine samples are collected and tested to determine whether elevated or decreased levels of a substance eliminated in the urine are temporary or persistent. Collection containers with preservative will be provided by your healthcare practitioner or the lab performing the testing.

KOH Prep.Why Get Tested?: To detect a fungal infection, to determine which specific fungus or fungi are present, and to help guide treatment
KOH Prep.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a skin, lung, or systemic fungal infection; sometimes after treatment to monitor its effectiveness
KOH Prep.Sample Required?: The sample collected depends upon the suspected location(s) of the infection. Some examples include: scrapings of the skin, nail and hair samples, body fluids, blood, and/or a tissue biopsy.

KRAS Mutation.Why Get Tested?: To detect a KRAS gene mutation in tumor tissue in order to guide cancer therapy and to evaluate prognosis
KRAS Mutation.When To Get Tested?: When you have colon cancer that has spread (metastatic) or non-small cell lung cancer and your health practitioner is considering an anti-EGFR drug therapy

KRAS Mutation Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To detect a KRAS gene mutation in tumor tissue in order to guide cancer therapy and to evaluate prognosis
KRAS Mutation Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When you have colon cancer that has spread (metastatic) or non-small cell lung cancer and your health practitioner is considering an anti-EGFR drug therapy

LA.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
LA.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
LA.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

LA Sensitive PTT.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
LA Sensitive PTT.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
LA Sensitive PTT.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

LAC.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
LAC.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
LAC.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

Lactate.Why Get Tested?: To detect high levels of lactate in the blood, which may be an indication of lack of oxygen (hypoxia) or the presence of other conditions that cause excess production or insufficient clearing of lactate from the blood; this test is not meant to be used for screening for health status.
Lactate.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as rapid breathing, nausea, and sweating that suggest a lack of oxygen or an abnormal blood pH (acid/base imbalance); when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you may be experiencing sepsis, shock, heart attack, severe congestive heart failure, kidney failure, or inadequately treated (uncontrolled) diabetes; when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have inherited a rare metabolic or mitochondrial disorder; when you have symptoms of lactic acidosis such as sweet-smelling breath, belly pain, confusion or cool and clammy skin
Lactate.Sample Required?:
A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes, an arterial sample is collected by inserting a needle into an artery. Occasionally, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid is collected from the spinal column during a procedure called a spinal tap.
Blood lactate levels will usually be drawn either without the use of a tourniquet or with a tourniquet that is not released during the blood draw. Tourniquet use and release and clenching of the fist can increase lactate levels in the blood sample.
Lactate.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, no test preparation is needed. In some cases, a healthcare practitioner may request that you don't exercise for several hours before the test or refrain from eating or drinking anything other than water for 8 to 10 hours prior to the test.

Lactate Dehydrogenase (LD).Why Get Tested?: To help detect a condition causing tissue damage, such as a blood or liver disease, and to monitor its progress; to help stage, determine prognosis, and/or response to treatment of certain cancers; to help evaluate body fluid (other than blood)
Lactate Dehydrogenase (LD).When To Get Tested?: Along with other tests, when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have an acute or chronic condition that is causing tissue damage or cellular destruction; sometimes when you have been diagnosed with cancer; when you have symptoms of meningitis or have fluid accumulation in a specific part of your body
Lactate Dehydrogenase (LD).Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes a special procedure may be performed to collect body fluid from the site affected (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid, pleural fluid, peritoneal fluid, etc.).

Lactic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To detect high levels of lactate in the blood, which may be an indication of lack of oxygen (hypoxia) or the presence of other conditions that cause excess production or insufficient clearing of lactate from the blood; this test is not meant to be used for screening for health status.
Lactic Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as rapid breathing, nausea, and sweating that suggest a lack of oxygen or an abnormal blood pH (acid/base imbalance); when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you may be experiencing sepsis, shock, heart attack, severe congestive heart failure, kidney failure, or inadequately treated (uncontrolled) diabetes; when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have inherited a rare metabolic or mitochondrial disorder; when you have symptoms of lactic acidosis such as sweet-smelling breath, belly pain, confusion or cool and clammy skin
Lactic Acid.Sample Required?:
A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes, an arterial sample is collected by inserting a needle into an artery. Occasionally, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid is collected from the spinal column during a procedure called a spinal tap.
Blood lactate levels will usually be drawn either without the use of a tourniquet or with a tourniquet that is not released during the blood draw. Tourniquet use and release and clenching of the fist can increase lactate levels in the blood sample.
Lactic Acid.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, no test preparation is needed. In some cases, a healthcare practitioner may request that you don't exercise for several hours before the test or refrain from eating or drinking anything other than water for 8 to 10 hours prior to the test.

Lactoferrin.Why Get Tested?: To detect inflammation in the intestines; to help identify active inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); to distinguish between IBD and non-inflammatory bowel conditions; to monitor IBD activity
Lactoferrin.When To Get Tested?: When you have bloody or watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, with or without fever, lasting more than a few days
Lactoferrin.Sample Required?: A stool sample collected in a clean container

Lactose Breath Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose lactose intolerance in individuals who have difficulties digesting dairy products, or sometimes as part of an investigation of malabsorption
Lactose Breath Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming milk and other dairy products
Lactose Breath Test.Sample Required?: A series of breath samples exhaled into a collector, or a series of blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm
Lactose Breath Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting is required; nothing but water is permitted. Two weeks prior to the test, you must be off antibiotics and stomach medications, such as laxatives, antacids and stool softeners. Tell your healthcare practitioner about any other medications you are taking. Avoid strenuous activities. You may be instructed to brush your teeth and/or rinse your mouth with water prior to and during the breath test.

Lactose Intolerance Test.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose lactose intolerance in individuals who have difficulties digesting dairy products, or sometimes as part of an investigation of malabsorption
Lactose Intolerance Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming milk and other dairy products
Lactose Intolerance Test.Sample Required?: A series of breath samples exhaled into a collector, or a series of blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm
Lactose Intolerance Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting is required; nothing but water is permitted. Two weeks prior to the test, you must be off antibiotics and stomach medications, such as laxatives, antacids and stool softeners. Tell your healthcare practitioner about any other medications you are taking. Avoid strenuous activities. You may be instructed to brush your teeth and/or rinse your mouth with water prior to and during the breath test.

Lactose Tolerance Tests.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose lactose intolerance in individuals who have difficulties digesting dairy products, or sometimes as part of an investigation of malabsorption
Lactose Tolerance Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming milk and other dairy products
Lactose Tolerance Tests.Sample Required?: A series of breath samples exhaled into a collector, or a series of blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm
Lactose Tolerance Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting is required; nothing but water is permitted. Two weeks prior to the test, you must be off antibiotics and stomach medications, such as laxatives, antacids and stool softeners. Tell your healthcare practitioner about any other medications you are taking. Avoid strenuous activities. You may be instructed to brush your teeth and/or rinse your mouth with water prior to and during the breath test.

Latent Tuberculosis Infection Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
Latent Tuberculosis Infection Test.When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
Latent Tuberculosis Infection Test.Sample Required?: No sample is required. A small amount of purified protein derivative (PPD) solution is injected with a tuberculin syringe just under the first layer of skin of your inner forearm.

LDH.Why Get Tested?: To help detect a condition causing tissue damage, such as a blood or liver disease, and to monitor its progress; to help stage, determine prognosis, and/or response to treatment of certain cancers; to help evaluate body fluid (other than blood)
LDH.When To Get Tested?: Along with other tests, when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have an acute or chronic condition that is causing tissue damage or cellular destruction; sometimes when you have been diagnosed with cancer; when you have symptoms of meningitis or have fluid accumulation in a specific part of your body
LDH.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes a special procedure may be performed to collect body fluid from the site affected (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid, pleural fluid, peritoneal fluid, etc.).

LDL.Why Get Tested?: To determine your risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
LDL.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a health exam with a lipid profile; every four to six years in adults with no risk factors for heart disease; youth should be tested at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and once again between the ages of 17 and 21
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
LDL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
LDL.Test Preparation Needed?: Laboratory tests for LDL-C typically require a 9 to 12-hour fast; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

LDL Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To determine your risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
LDL Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a health exam with a lipid profile; every four to six years in adults with no risk factors for heart disease; youth should be tested at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and once again between the ages of 17 and 21
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
LDL Cholesterol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
LDL Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: Laboratory tests for LDL-C typically require a 9 to 12-hour fast; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

LDL D.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing heart disease and to monitor lipid-lowering lifestyle changes and drug therapies; to accurately determine your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level when you are not fasting
LDL D.When To Get Tested?: As a follow-up to a lipid profile if your triglycerides are significantly elevated; at regular intervals to monitor efforts to lower LDL levels
LDL D.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
LDL D.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, your health practitioner may request that you fast.

LDL Particle Size or Number.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
LDL Particle Size or Number.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal and/or family history of CVD at an early age; when the result of your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) test is within a healthy range, but your healthcare provider thinks that you may have an increased risk of developing heart disease; sometimes to help monitor the effectiveness of lipid-lowering treatment and/or lifestyle changes
LDL Particle Size or Number.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
LDL Particle Size or Number.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast for 9-12 hours before this test; only water is permitted. Follow any instructions you are given.

LDL Particle Testing (LDL-P).Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
LDL Particle Testing (LDL-P).When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal and/or family history of CVD at an early age; when the result of your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) test is within a healthy range, but your healthcare provider thinks that you may have an increased risk of developing heart disease; sometimes to help monitor the effectiveness of lipid-lowering treatment and/or lifestyle changes
LDL Particle Testing (LDL-P).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
LDL Particle Testing (LDL-P).Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast for 9-12 hours before this test; only water is permitted. Follow any instructions you are given.

LDL Subclasses.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
LDL Subclasses.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal and/or family history of CVD at an early age; when the result of your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) test is within a healthy range, but your healthcare provider thinks that you may have an increased risk of developing heart disease; sometimes to help monitor the effectiveness of lipid-lowering treatment and/or lifestyle changes
LDL Subclasses.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
LDL Subclasses.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast for 9-12 hours before this test; only water is permitted. Follow any instructions you are given.

LDL Subfractions.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
LDL Subfractions.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal and/or family history of CVD at an early age; when the result of your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) test is within a healthy range, but your healthcare provider thinks that you may have an increased risk of developing heart disease; sometimes to help monitor the effectiveness of lipid-lowering treatment and/or lifestyle changes
LDL Subfractions.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
LDL Subfractions.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast for 9-12 hours before this test; only water is permitted. Follow any instructions you are given.

LDL-C.Why Get Tested?: To determine your risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
LDL-C.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a health exam with a lipid profile; every four to six years in adults with no risk factors for heart disease; youth should be tested at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and once again between the ages of 17 and 21
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
LDL-C.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
LDL-C.Test Preparation Needed?: Laboratory tests for LDL-C typically require a 9 to 12-hour fast; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

Lead.Why Get Tested?: To screen for possible excessive exposure to lead
Lead.When To Get Tested?: As indicated by a child lead screening program or physician preference, such as at 1 and 2 years of age; children considered to be at risk may need additional testing from 18 months to 6 years of age; when your occupation or hobby may expose you or your family to lead; when you have symptoms suggesting lead poisoning
Lead.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick or heelstick (for infants)

Lead, blood.Why Get Tested?: To screen for possible excessive exposure to lead
Lead, blood.When To Get Tested?: As indicated by a child lead screening program or physician preference, such as at 1 and 2 years of age; children considered to be at risk may need additional testing from 18 months to 6 years of age; when your occupation or hobby may expose you or your family to lead; when you have symptoms suggesting lead poisoning
Lead, blood.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick or heelstick (for infants)

Legionella pneumophila.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose Legionella bacteria as the cause of pneumonia or flu-like symptoms; to investigate an outbreak caused by Legionella
Legionella pneumophila.When To Get Tested?: When you have a cough, body aches, shortness of breath, headache, and fever with chills, and may have abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, and/or mental changes that a healthcare provider suspects may be due to an infection caused by Legionella
Legionella pneumophila.Sample Required?: A urine sample, a sputum sample, and/or respiratory secretions or other body fluids collected by a health practitioner

Legionella Testing.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose Legionella bacteria as the cause of pneumonia or flu-like symptoms; to investigate an outbreak caused by Legionella
Legionella Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have a cough, body aches, shortness of breath, headache, and fever with chills, and may have abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, and/or mental changes that a healthcare provider suspects may be due to an infection caused by Legionella
Legionella Testing.Sample Required?: A urine sample, a sputum sample, and/or respiratory secretions or other body fluids collected by a health practitioner

Legionnaires Disease Testing.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose Legionella bacteria as the cause of pneumonia or flu-like symptoms; to investigate an outbreak caused by Legionella
Legionnaires Disease Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have a cough, body aches, shortness of breath, headache, and fever with chills, and may have abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, and/or mental changes that a healthcare provider suspects may be due to an infection caused by Legionella
Legionnaires Disease Testing.Sample Required?: A urine sample, a sputum sample, and/or respiratory secretions or other body fluids collected by a health practitioner

Leptin.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have a leptin deficiency that is contributing to obesity; to identify increased leptin; on a research basis to help understand leptin's roles in the body and its ties to obesity
Leptin.When To Get Tested?: When a child has severe obesity that may be due to a very rare inherited leptin deficiency; sometimes to help evaluate obesity; when participating in a research study
Leptin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Leukocyte Count.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose a variety of conditions that can affect white blood cells (WBC) such as an infection, inflammation or a disease that affects the production or survival of WBCs; to monitor treatment of a blood disorder or to monitor therapy that is known to affect WBCs
Leukocyte Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting WBCs such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you have a condition or are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs
Leukocyte Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Leukocyte Differential.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets, to distinguish between the different types of WBCs, and to determine their relative percentages in the blood; to help detect, diagnose, and/or monitor a range of deficiencies, diseases, and disorders involving blood cell production, function, and lifespan
Leukocyte Differential.When To Get Tested?: When complete blood count (CBC) and/or automated WBC differential results are abnormal or when you have signs and symptoms that a healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a condition affecting your blood cells
Leukocyte Differential.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by pricking a finger or, in the case of an infant, a heelstick

Leukocyte Differential Count.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of abnormal results on a white blood cell (WBC) count; to help diagnose and/or monitor an illness affecting your immune system, such as an infection or inflammatory condition, or cancers that affect your white blood cells, such as leukemia
Leukocyte Differential Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when results of a CBC fall outside the reference range; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting white blood cells, such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs, such as chemotherapy
Leukocyte Differential Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (infants)

Levetiracetam.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of levetiracetam in the blood to establish an individualized dose; to detect toxicity or verify that you are taking the medication as prescribed (compliance); to monitor during health changes that may affect drug clearance and/or kidney function
Levetiracetam.When To Get Tested?: Initially when establishing dosage; when indicated to detect low or excessive (potentially toxic) concentrations; when you have decreased kidney function; sometimes to verify compliance
Levetiracetam.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, typically just before your next dose

LFTs.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, evaluate, and monitor acute and chronic liver inflammation (hepatitis), liver infection, liver disease and/or and damage
LFTs.When To Get Tested?: Periodically to evaluate liver function; whenever you are at risk for liver injury; when you are taking medications that may affect your liver; when you have a liver disease; when you have symptoms associated with liver damage, such as jaundice
LFTs.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for infants, blood may be drawn by puncturing the heel with a lancet.
LFTs.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight with only water permitted. Follow any instructions you are given. Inform the healthcare practitioner about all prescription and over-the-counter medications, herbal medications, vitamins and supplements you are taking.

Light Chains, Free; Free Kappa/Lambda Ra.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and monitor plasma cell disorders (dyscrasias) such as multiple myeloma, primary amyloidosis, and related diseases or to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Light Chains, Free; Free Kappa/Lambda Ra.When To Get Tested?: When you have bone pain, fractures, anemia (with normal size and shape red blood cells (normocytic)), kidney disease, and recurrent infections that your healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a plasma cell disorder; when you are being treated for a plasma cell disorder
Light Chains, Free; Free Kappa/Lambda Ra.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Lipase.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to diagnose and monitor acute pancreatitis; also sometimes to diagnose and monitor chronic pancreatitis or other pancreatic diseases
Lipase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a pancreatic disorder, such as severe abdominal pain, fever, loss of appetite, or nausea
Lipase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Lipid Panel.Why Get Tested?: To assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD); to monitor treatment
Lipid Panel.When To Get Tested?:
Screening when no risk factors present: for adults, every four to six years; for youths, once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between ages 17 and 21
Monitoring: at regular intervals when risk factors are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or to monitor effectiveness of treatment
Lipid Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
Lipid Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, fasting for 9-12 hours (water only) before having your blood drawn is required, but some labs offer non-fasting lipid testing. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

Lipid Profile.Why Get Tested?: To assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD); to monitor treatment
Lipid Profile.When To Get Tested?:
Screening when no risk factors present: for adults, every four to six years; for youths, once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between ages 17 and 21
Monitoring: at regular intervals when risk factors are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or to monitor effectiveness of treatment
Lipid Profile.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
Lipid Profile.Test Preparation Needed?: Typically, fasting for 9-12 hours (water only) before having your blood drawn is required, but some labs offer non-fasting lipid testing. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

Lipoprotein (a).Why Get Tested?: To give your health practitioner additional information about your risk of developing heart disease; as part of a targeted screen for cardiovascular disease (CVD)
Lipoprotein (a).When To Get Tested?: When you have a family history of CVD at a young age; when you have heart disease or have had a heart attack or stroke but your lipid profile is normal or shows only mildly elevated cholesterol and/or low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C)
Lipoprotein (a).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Lipoprotein (a).Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, Lp(a) is often performed at the same time as a lipid profile and fasting for 9-12 hours may be required for the lipid profile.

Lipoprotein (a).Why Get Tested?: To give your health practitioner additional information about your risk of developing heart disease; as part of a targeted screen for cardiovascular disease (CVD)
Lipoprotein (a).When To Get Tested?: When you have a family history of CVD at a young age; when you have heart disease or have had a heart attack or stroke but your lipid profile is normal or shows only mildly elevated cholesterol and/or low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C)
Lipoprotein (a).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Lipoprotein (a).Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, Lp(a) is often performed at the same time as a lipid profile and fasting for 9-12 hours may be required for the lipid profile.

Lipoprotein little a.Why Get Tested?: To give your health practitioner additional information about your risk of developing heart disease; as part of a targeted screen for cardiovascular disease (CVD)
Lipoprotein little a.When To Get Tested?: When you have a family history of CVD at a young age; when you have heart disease or have had a heart attack or stroke but your lipid profile is normal or shows only mildly elevated cholesterol and/or low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C)
Lipoprotein little a.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Lipoprotein little a.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, Lp(a) is often performed at the same time as a lipid profile and fasting for 9-12 hours may be required for the lipid profile.

Lipoprotein-associated Phospholipase A2.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD), including your risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) and ischemic stroke
Lipoprotein-associated Phospholipase A2.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider determines that you are at a moderate to high risk of developing CVD or of having an ischemic stroke; when you have a family history of CVD or CHD
Lipoprotein-associated Phospholipase A2.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Lithium.Why Get Tested?: To measure lithium levels in the blood in order to determine the therapeutic level when just starting lithium medication; to maintain the therapeutic level or to determine lithium toxicity
Lithium.When To Get Tested?: When beginning treatment with lithium as the dose is adjusted to achieve therapeutic blood levels; at regular intervals to monitor lithium levels; as needed to detect sub-therapeutic levels or high (toxic) concentrations
Lithium.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

liver.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
liver.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
liver.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
liver.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Liver Function Tests.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, evaluate, and monitor acute and chronic liver inflammation (hepatitis), liver infection, liver disease and/or and damage
Liver Function Tests.When To Get Tested?: Periodically to evaluate liver function; whenever you are at risk for liver injury; when you are taking medications that may affect your liver; when you have a liver disease; when you have symptoms associated with liver damage, such as jaundice
Liver Function Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for infants, blood may be drawn by puncturing the heel with a lancet.
Liver Function Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight with only water permitted. Follow any instructions you are given. Inform the healthcare practitioner about all prescription and over-the-counter medications, herbal medications, vitamins and supplements you are taking.

Liver Kidney Microsomal Type 1 Antibodie.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Liver Kidney Microsomal Type 1 Antibodie.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Liver Kidney Microsomal Type 1 Antibodie.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Liver Kidney Microsome Type 1 Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Liver Kidney Microsome Type 1 Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Liver Kidney Microsome Type 1 Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Liver Panel.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, evaluate, and monitor acute and chronic liver inflammation (hepatitis), liver infection, liver disease and/or and damage
Liver Panel.When To Get Tested?: Periodically to evaluate liver function; whenever you are at risk for liver injury; when you are taking medications that may affect your liver; when you have a liver disease; when you have symptoms associated with liver damage, such as jaundice
Liver Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for infants, blood may be drawn by puncturing the heel with a lancet.
Liver Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight with only water permitted. Follow any instructions you are given. Inform the healthcare practitioner about all prescription and over-the-counter medications, herbal medications, vitamins and supplements you are taking.

Liver Profile.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, evaluate, and monitor acute and chronic liver inflammation (hepatitis), liver infection, liver disease and/or and damage
Liver Profile.When To Get Tested?: Periodically to evaluate liver function; whenever you are at risk for liver injury; when you are taking medications that may affect your liver; when you have a liver disease; when you have symptoms associated with liver damage, such as jaundice
Liver Profile.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; for infants, blood may be drawn by puncturing the heel with a lancet.
Liver Profile.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight with only water permitted. Follow any instructions you are given. Inform the healthcare practitioner about all prescription and over-the-counter medications, herbal medications, vitamins and supplements you are taking.

LKM1 Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
LKM1 Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
LKM1 Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To determine your risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a health exam with a lipid profile; every four to six years in adults with no risk factors for heart disease; youth should be tested at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and once again between the ages of 17 and 21
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: Laboratory tests for LDL-C typically require a 9 to 12-hour fast; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

Low-Density Lipoprotein Subfraction Prof.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
Low-Density Lipoprotein Subfraction Prof.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal and/or family history of CVD at an early age; when the result of your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) test is within a healthy range, but your healthcare provider thinks that you may have an increased risk of developing heart disease; sometimes to help monitor the effectiveness of lipid-lowering treatment and/or lifestyle changes
Low-Density Lipoprotein Subfraction Prof.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Low-Density Lipoprotein Subfraction Prof.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast for 9-12 hours before this test; only water is permitted. Follow any instructions you are given.

Lp-PLA2.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD), including your risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) and ischemic stroke
Lp-PLA2.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider determines that you are at a moderate to high risk of developing CVD or of having an ischemic stroke; when you have a family history of CVD or CHD
Lp-PLA2.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Lp(a).Why Get Tested?: To give your health practitioner additional information about your risk of developing heart disease; as part of a targeted screen for cardiovascular disease (CVD)
Lp(a).When To Get Tested?: When you have a family history of CVD at a young age; when you have heart disease or have had a heart attack or stroke but your lipid profile is normal or shows only mildly elevated cholesterol and/or low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C)
Lp(a).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Lp(a).Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, Lp(a) is often performed at the same time as a lipid profile and fasting for 9-12 hours may be required for the lipid profile.

LPS.Why Get Tested?: Primarily to diagnose and monitor acute pancreatitis; also sometimes to diagnose and monitor chronic pancreatitis or other pancreatic diseases
LPS.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a pancreatic disorder, such as severe abdominal pain, fever, loss of appetite, or nausea
LPS.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Lupus Anticoagulant Testing.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
Lupus Anticoagulant Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
Lupus Anticoagulant Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

Lupus Inhibitor.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
Lupus Inhibitor.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
Lupus Inhibitor.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

Luteinizing Hormone.Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or to detect the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation); to evaluate pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
Luteinizing Hormone.When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or heavy menstrual periods; when you are tracking ovulation during your menstrual cycle
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
Luteinizing Hormone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or a 24-hour urine collection may be taken
Luteinizing Hormone.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

Luteinizing Hormone (LH).Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or to detect the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation); to evaluate pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
Luteinizing Hormone (LH).When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or heavy menstrual periods; when you are tracking ovulation during your menstrual cycle
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
Luteinizing Hormone (LH).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or a 24-hour urine collection may be taken
Luteinizing Hormone (LH).Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

Luteinizing Hormone, serum or urine.Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or to detect the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation); to evaluate pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
Luteinizing Hormone, serum or urine.When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or heavy menstrual periods; when you are tracking ovulation during your menstrual cycle
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
Luteinizing Hormone, serum or urine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or a 24-hour urine collection may be taken
Luteinizing Hormone, serum or urine.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

Lutropin.Why Get Tested?:
To evaluate fertility issues, function of reproductive organs (ovaries or testicles), or to detect the release of an egg from the ovary (ovulation); to evaluate pituitary function
In children, to evaluate early or delayed sexual maturation (puberty)
Lutropin.When To Get Tested?:
For women, when you are having difficulty getting pregnant or are having irregular or heavy menstrual periods; when you are tracking ovulation during your menstrual cycle
For men, when your partner cannot get pregnant or you have a low sperm count, low muscle mass or decreased sex drive
When your healthcare provider thinks that you have symptoms of a pituitary disorder or hypothalamic disorder
When a health practitioner suspects that a child has delayed or earlier than expected sexual maturation
Lutropin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random urine sample or a 24-hour urine collection may be taken
Lutropin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but the timing of a woman's sample will be correlated with her menstrual cycle.

Lyme Antibodies Detection.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have been infected with the bacteria that cause Lyme disease
Lyme Antibodies Detection.When To Get Tested?: When you show symptoms of Lyme disease, especially when you live in or have recently visited an area where black-legged ticks are endemic and suspect that you have been bitten by a tick
Lyme Antibodies Detection.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample

Lyme Antibodies IgM/IgG by Western Blot.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have been infected with the bacteria that cause Lyme disease
Lyme Antibodies IgM/IgG by Western Blot.When To Get Tested?: When you show symptoms of Lyme disease, especially when you live in or have recently visited an area where black-legged ticks are endemic and suspect that you have been bitten by a tick
Lyme Antibodies IgM/IgG by Western Blot.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample

Lyme Disease Tests.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have been infected with the bacteria that cause Lyme disease
Lyme Disease Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you show symptoms of Lyme disease, especially when you live in or have recently visited an area where black-legged ticks are endemic and suspect that you have been bitten by a tick
Lyme Disease Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample

Lytes.Why Get Tested?: To detect a problem with the body's electrolyte balance
Lytes.When To Get Tested?: As part of routine health screening or when your healthcare provider suspects that you have an imbalance of one of the electrolytes (usually sodium or potassium) or an acid-base imbalance
Lytes.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Mag.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the level of magnesium in your blood and to help determine the cause of abnormal levels of magnesium, calcium and/or potassium
Mag.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as weakness, irritability, cardiac arrhythmia, nausea, and/or diarrhea that may be due to too much or too little magnesium; when you have abnormal calcium or potassium levels; when magnesium is given for medical treatment
Mag.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a timed urine collection that most often requires a 24-hour sample collection
Mag.Test Preparation Needed?: For a blood sample, overnight fasting may be required; follow any instructions that you are given.

Magnesium.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the level of magnesium in your blood and to help determine the cause of abnormal levels of magnesium, calcium and/or potassium
Magnesium.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as weakness, irritability, cardiac arrhythmia, nausea, and/or diarrhea that may be due to too much or too little magnesium; when you have abnormal calcium or potassium levels; when magnesium is given for medical treatment
Magnesium.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a timed urine collection that most often requires a 24-hour sample collection
Magnesium.Test Preparation Needed?: For a blood sample, overnight fasting may be required; follow any instructions that you are given.

Magnesium salicylate.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
Magnesium salicylate.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
Magnesium salicylate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
Magnesium salicylate.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

Mantoux.Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
Mantoux.When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
Mantoux.Sample Required?: No sample is required. A small amount of purified protein derivative (PPD) solution is injected with a tuberculin syringe just under the first layer of skin of your inner forearm.

Manual Differential.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets, to distinguish between the different types of WBCs, and to determine their relative percentages in the blood; to help detect, diagnose, and/or monitor a range of deficiencies, diseases, and disorders involving blood cell production, function, and lifespan
Manual Differential.When To Get Tested?: When complete blood count (CBC) and/or automated WBC differential results are abnormal or when you have signs and symptoms that a healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a condition affecting your blood cells
Manual Differential.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by pricking a finger or, in the case of an infant, a heelstick

Marijuana (THC) Testing.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and/or confirm marijuana use
As part of a panel of tests to help detect drug use, impairment, intoxication and/or overdose
To monitor for drug abuse
To monitor compliance with prescription drugs
Marijuana (THC) Testing.When To Get Tested?:
During medical screening, such as upon admission to the emergency room or when pregnant or after giving birth
When being treated for chronic pain or for cancer
During random drug screening in the workplace or during the hiring process
As part of a drug rehabilitation program or upon court order
To test for impairment, such as during a traffic stop, or after an accident
Marijuana (THC) Testing.Sample Required?:
A random urine specimen is the most commonly tested sample for marijuana. Urine is collected in a clean, sterile container.
Sometimes, saliva is collected in an absorbent pad or swab placed between the lower cheek and gums. This technique is increasingly used in workplace marijuana testing.
Other types of samples that are used less frequently include blood and hair. For newborns, samples may include the umbilical cord or meconium, a newborn's first bowel movement. For more information on these, see Common Questions below.
Marijuana (THC) Testing.Test Preparation Needed?:
Prior to testing, declare any prescriptions you are currently taking, including those for medical marijuana.
If saliva is to be collected for testing, you typically should not put anything in your mouth for the 10 minutes prior to the collection of the sample. Follow the directions provided with the sample container.

Mast Cell Tryptase.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose anaphylaxis, mastocytosis (too many mast cells), or mast cell activation
Mast Cell Tryptase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as flushing, nausea, throat swelling, or low blood pressure that may be due to a life-threatening allergic reaction; when your healthcare provider suspects that you have mastocytosis or mast cell activation
Mast Cell Tryptase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Mast Cell Tryptase.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample soon after the beginning of symptoms can be important.

Maternal Serum AFP.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
Maternal Serum AFP.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
Maternal Serum AFP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Maternal Serum Screen.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
Maternal Serum Screen.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
Maternal Serum Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Maternal Serum Screening, Second Trimest.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
Maternal Serum Screening, Second Trimest.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
Maternal Serum Screening, Second Trimest.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Mature Tryptase.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose anaphylaxis, mastocytosis (too many mast cells), or mast cell activation
Mature Tryptase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as flushing, nausea, throat swelling, or low blood pressure that may be due to a life-threatening allergic reaction; when your healthcare provider suspects that you have mastocytosis or mast cell activation
Mature Tryptase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Mature Tryptase.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample soon after the beginning of symptoms can be important.

Mean Platelet Volume.Why Get Tested?: To determine the number of platelets in a sample of your blood as part of a health exam; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect the number of platelets, such as a bleeding disorder, a bone marrow disease, or other underlying condition
Mean Platelet Volume.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine complete blood count (CBC); when you have episodes of unexplained or prolonged bleeding or other symptoms that may be due to a platelet disorder
Mean Platelet Volume.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Measles and Mumps Tests.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a measles or mumps infection; to establish whether a person has immunity to measles or mumps due to a previous infection or to vaccination; to confirm a measles or mumps case and investigate its source
Measles and Mumps Tests.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms or complications that a health practitioner suspects are due to a measles or mumps infection; whenever it is necessary or desired to determine measles or mumps immunity; when an outbreak of measles or mumps is occurring in order to track and minimize it
Measles and Mumps Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for measles or mumps antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, sample may be blood, urine, nasopharyngeal (nasal) aspirate/washing, throat swab, swab of the inside of the cheek (buccal swab), cerebrospinal fluid, or other body tissue
Measles and Mumps Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: Prior to collection of a buccal swab for mumps, the salivary gland located in front of and below the ear (parotid gland) is massaged. For other specimens, no test preparation is needed.

Measles Antibody IgM, IgG.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a measles or mumps infection; to establish whether a person has immunity to measles or mumps due to a previous infection or to vaccination; to confirm a measles or mumps case and investigate its source
Measles Antibody IgM, IgG.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms or complications that a health practitioner suspects are due to a measles or mumps infection; whenever it is necessary or desired to determine measles or mumps immunity; when an outbreak of measles or mumps is occurring in order to track and minimize it
Measles Antibody IgM, IgG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for measles or mumps antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, sample may be blood, urine, nasopharyngeal (nasal) aspirate/washing, throat swab, swab of the inside of the cheek (buccal swab), cerebrospinal fluid, or other body tissue
Measles Antibody IgM, IgG.Test Preparation Needed?: Prior to collection of a buccal swab for mumps, the salivary gland located in front of and below the ear (parotid gland) is massaged. For other specimens, no test preparation is needed.

Measles Virus by Culture or RT-PCR.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a measles or mumps infection; to establish whether a person has immunity to measles or mumps due to a previous infection or to vaccination; to confirm a measles or mumps case and investigate its source
Measles Virus by Culture or RT-PCR.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms or complications that a health practitioner suspects are due to a measles or mumps infection; whenever it is necessary or desired to determine measles or mumps immunity; when an outbreak of measles or mumps is occurring in order to track and minimize it
Measles Virus by Culture or RT-PCR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for measles or mumps antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, sample may be blood, urine, nasopharyngeal (nasal) aspirate/washing, throat swab, swab of the inside of the cheek (buccal swab), cerebrospinal fluid, or other body tissue
Measles Virus by Culture or RT-PCR.Test Preparation Needed?: Prior to collection of a buccal swab for mumps, the salivary gland located in front of and below the ear (parotid gland) is massaged. For other specimens, no test preparation is needed.

Mercury.Why Get Tested?: To detect excessive exposure to mercury
Mercury.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of mercury poisoning or have been exposed to mercury; to monitor occupational exposure to mercury
Mercury.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine collection

Mercury, Urine and Blood.Why Get Tested?: To detect excessive exposure to mercury
Mercury, Urine and Blood.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of mercury poisoning or have been exposed to mercury; to monitor occupational exposure to mercury
Mercury, Urine and Blood.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine collection
