Metanephrine and Normetanephrine.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Metanephrine and Normetanephrine.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of increased catecholamines release, such as sudden bursts (paroxysms) of high blood pressure (hypertension), severe headaches, rapid heart rate (palpitations), sweating, tremors and pallor; when hypertension does not respond to standard treatments; when the signs and symptoms occur in a relatively young person (younger than age 40) and when there is a family history of hypertension; when your healthcare provider suspects you may have a tumor that is releasing or may release excess catecholamines
Metanephrine and Normetanephrine.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection.

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aur.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you are a carrier of the bacteria methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and could potentially spread it to other people
Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aur.When To Get Tested?: When you have no signs or symptoms of an active infection, but a healthcare practitioner wants to determine if you are a MRSA carrier, such as when you are hospitalized
Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aur.Sample Required?: Swab of the nose; occasionally, swab of wound infection site or skin lesion

Methotrexate.Why Get Tested?:
To detect, monitor and evaluate toxic concentrations of methotrexate
To measure methotrexate levels in blood to determine the initial dosage requirement in individuals with immune disease
Methotrexate.When To Get Tested?: At specific timed intervals after a high dose of methotrexate to monitor blood levels and guide treatment and whenever symptoms suggest methotrexate toxicity
Methotrexate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Methotrexate.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample for testing is important; your healthcare practitioner may specify collection at a certain number of hours after a methotrexate dose; when having your blood drawn, tell the person collecting your blood sample when you took your last dose of methotrexate.

Methyl salicylate.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
Methyl salicylate.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
Methyl salicylate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
Methyl salicylate.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

Methylenetetrahydrofolate Reductase Muta.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the cause of elevated homocysteine levels; sometimes to help determine your risk of thrombosis or premature cardiovascular disease (CVD), though some expert guidelines do not recommend it
Methylenetetrahydrofolate Reductase Muta.When To Get Tested?: When you have elevated homocysteine levels; sometimes when a close relative has MTHFR gene mutations or has developed CVD or thrombosis at an early age
Methylenetetrahydrofolate Reductase Muta.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein

Methylmalonic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To help detect early and/or mild vitamin B12 deficiency; to help diagnose methylmalonic acidemia, a rare inherited metabolic disorder
Methylmalonic Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low vitamin B12 level and/or have symptoms of B12 deficiency such as numbness, tingling in the hands or feet, trouble walking, swelling of body tissues, or yellowing of the skin or eyes; as part of newborn screening
Methylmalonic Acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a heelstick in newborns; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample
Methylmalonic Acid.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast before sample collection for this test.

Mg.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the level of magnesium in your blood and to help determine the cause of abnormal levels of magnesium, calcium and/or potassium
Mg.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as weakness, irritability, cardiac arrhythmia, nausea, and/or diarrhea that may be due to too much or too little magnesium; when you have abnormal calcium or potassium levels; when magnesium is given for medical treatment
Mg.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a timed urine collection that most often requires a 24-hour sample collection
Mg.Test Preparation Needed?: For a blood sample, overnight fasting may be required; follow any instructions that you are given.

MHA-TP.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
MHA-TP.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
MHA-TP.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Microalbumin.Why Get Tested?: To detect early kidney disease in those with diabetes or other risk factors, such as high blood pressure (hypertension)
Microalbumin.When To Get Tested?: Annually after a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes; annually 5 years after diagnosis of type 1 diabetes
Microalbumin.Sample Required?: A random, timed, overnight, or 24-hour urine sample

Microhemagglutination Assay.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Microhemagglutination Assay.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Microhemagglutination Assay.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Microminerals.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor a mineral deficiency or excess; sometimes to evaluate your nutritional status
Microminerals.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms or signs of a mineral deficiency or excess; as indicated by your healthcare provider when you have a condition that affects mineral absorption, use, or storage
Microminerals.Sample Required?: Trace mineral testing is usually performed on a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes a 24-hour urine collection is obtained. Special metal-free blood or acid-washed urine containers are used to minimize the potential for sample contamination by any outside sources of minerals. Rarely, hair may be collected or a biopsy may be performed to obtain a tissue sample to evaluate mineral deficiencies, excesses, and storage that have occurred over time.
Microminerals.Test Preparation Needed?: Check with your healthcare practitioner to find out if fasting is needed before your test.

Micronutrients.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor a mineral deficiency or excess; sometimes to evaluate your nutritional status
Micronutrients.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms or signs of a mineral deficiency or excess; as indicated by your healthcare provider when you have a condition that affects mineral absorption, use, or storage
Micronutrients.Sample Required?: Trace mineral testing is usually performed on a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes a 24-hour urine collection is obtained. Special metal-free blood or acid-washed urine containers are used to minimize the potential for sample contamination by any outside sources of minerals. Rarely, hair may be collected or a biopsy may be performed to obtain a tissue sample to evaluate mineral deficiencies, excesses, and storage that have occurred over time.
Micronutrients.Test Preparation Needed?: Check with your healthcare practitioner to find out if fasting is needed before your test.

MIF.Why Get Tested?: In women, to evaluate ovarian function and fertility; sometimes in the evaluation of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or to evaluate the effectiveness of ovarian cancer treatment; in an infant, to evaluate the presence of external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or function of the testicles in an infant boy
MIF.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner wants to evaluate a woman's fertility, predict onset of menopause, or suspects PCOS; sometimes prior to some assisted reproductive procedures; periodically when a woman is undergoing treatment for an AMH-producing ovarian cancer; when it is suspected that the testicles of an infant boy are absent or not functioning properly
MIF.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

MIH.Why Get Tested?: In women, to evaluate ovarian function and fertility; sometimes in the evaluation of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or to evaluate the effectiveness of ovarian cancer treatment; in an infant, to evaluate the presence of external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or function of the testicles in an infant boy
MIH.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner wants to evaluate a woman's fertility, predict onset of menopause, or suspects PCOS; sometimes prior to some assisted reproductive procedures; periodically when a woman is undergoing treatment for an AMH-producing ovarian cancer; when it is suspected that the testicles of an infant boy are absent or not functioning properly
MIH.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

MIS.Why Get Tested?: In women, to evaluate ovarian function and fertility; sometimes in the evaluation of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or to evaluate the effectiveness of ovarian cancer treatment; in an infant, to evaluate the presence of external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or function of the testicles in an infant boy
MIS.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner wants to evaluate a woman's fertility, predict onset of menopause, or suspects PCOS; sometimes prior to some assisted reproductive procedures; periodically when a woman is undergoing treatment for an AMH-producing ovarian cancer; when it is suspected that the testicles of an infant boy are absent or not functioning properly
MIS.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Mitochondrial Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose primary biliary cholangitis, also sometimes called primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
Mitochondrial Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have abnormal results on a liver panel and/or symptoms that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to PBC
Mitochondrial Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

MMA.Why Get Tested?: To help detect early and/or mild vitamin B12 deficiency; to help diagnose methylmalonic acidemia, a rare inherited metabolic disorder
MMA.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low vitamin B12 level and/or have symptoms of B12 deficiency such as numbness, tingling in the hands or feet, trouble walking, swelling of body tissues, or yellowing of the skin or eyes; as part of newborn screening
MMA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a heelstick in newborns; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample
MMA.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast before sample collection for this test.

MMF.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of mycophenolic acid (MPA), an immunosuppressant drug, in the blood in order to monitor levels in transplant recipients and prevent toxicity
MMF.When To Get Tested?: As soon as mycophenolate therapy begins and whenever the dose is changed; may be ordered frequently at first, then at regular intervals; whenever excess or deficient levels of MPA are suspected
MMF.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Modified Russell Viper Venom Test.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
Modified Russell Viper Venom Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
Modified Russell Viper Venom Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

Mononuclear Heterophile Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono)
Mononuclear Heterophile Test.When To Get Tested?: When a person, especially an adolescent, has symptoms of mononucleosis, including fever, sore throat, swollen glands, and fatigue
Mononuclear Heterophile Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from pricking of your fingertip or from a vein in your arm

Mononucleosis (Mono) Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono)
Mononucleosis (Mono) Test.When To Get Tested?: When a person, especially an adolescent, has symptoms of mononucleosis, including fever, sore throat, swollen glands, and fatigue
Mononucleosis (Mono) Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from pricking of your fingertip or from a vein in your arm

Mononucleosis Spot Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono)
Mononucleosis Spot Test.When To Get Tested?: When a person, especially an adolescent, has symptoms of mononucleosis, including fever, sore throat, swollen glands, and fatigue
Mononucleosis Spot Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from pricking of your fingertip or from a vein in your arm

Monospot.Why Get Tested?: To detect and help diagnose infectious mononucleosis (mono)
Monospot.When To Get Tested?: When a person, especially an adolescent, has symptoms of mononucleosis, including fever, sore throat, swollen glands, and fatigue
Monospot.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from pricking of your fingertip or from a vein in your arm

MPA.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of mycophenolic acid (MPA), an immunosuppressant drug, in the blood in order to monitor levels in transplant recipients and prevent toxicity
MPA.When To Get Tested?: As soon as mycophenolate therapy begins and whenever the dose is changed; may be ordered frequently at first, then at regular intervals; whenever excess or deficient levels of MPA are suspected
MPA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

MPO.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
MPO.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
MPO.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

MPO-ANCA.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
MPO-ANCA.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
MPO-ANCA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

MPV.Why Get Tested?: To determine the number of platelets in a sample of your blood as part of a health exam; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect the number of platelets, such as a bleeding disorder, a bone marrow disease, or other underlying condition
MPV.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine complete blood count (CBC); when you have episodes of unexplained or prolonged bleeding or other symptoms that may be due to a platelet disorder
MPV.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

MRSA Screening.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you are a carrier of the bacteria methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and could potentially spread it to other people
MRSA Screening.When To Get Tested?: When you have no signs or symptoms of an active infection, but a healthcare practitioner wants to determine if you are a MRSA carrier, such as when you are hospitalized
MRSA Screening.Sample Required?: Swab of the nose; occasionally, swab of wound infection site or skin lesion

MRVVT.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
MRVVT.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
MRVVT.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

msAFP.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
msAFP.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
msAFP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

MSAFP.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
MSAFP.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
MSAFP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

MTHFR DNA Testing.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the cause of elevated homocysteine levels; sometimes to help determine your risk of thrombosis or premature cardiovascular disease (CVD), though some expert guidelines do not recommend it
MTHFR DNA Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have elevated homocysteine levels; sometimes when a close relative has MTHFR gene mutations or has developed CVD or thrombosis at an early age
MTHFR DNA Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein

MTHFR Mutation.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the cause of elevated homocysteine levels; sometimes to help determine your risk of thrombosis or premature cardiovascular disease (CVD), though some expert guidelines do not recommend it
MTHFR Mutation.When To Get Tested?: When you have elevated homocysteine levels; sometimes when a close relative has MTHFR gene mutations or has developed CVD or thrombosis at an early age
MTHFR Mutation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein

MTX.Why Get Tested?:
To detect, monitor and evaluate toxic concentrations of methotrexate
To measure methotrexate levels in blood to determine the initial dosage requirement in individuals with immune disease
MTX.When To Get Tested?: At specific timed intervals after a high dose of methotrexate to monitor blood levels and guide treatment and whenever symptoms suggest methotrexate toxicity
MTX.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
MTX.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample for testing is important; your healthcare practitioner may specify collection at a certain number of hours after a methotrexate dose; when having your blood drawn, tell the person collecting your blood sample when you took your last dose of methotrexate.

Müllerian Inhibiting Factor.Why Get Tested?: In women, to evaluate ovarian function and fertility; sometimes in the evaluation of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or to evaluate the effectiveness of ovarian cancer treatment; in an infant, to evaluate the presence of external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or function of the testicles in an infant boy
Müllerian Inhibiting Factor.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner wants to evaluate a woman's fertility, predict onset of menopause, or suspects PCOS; sometimes prior to some assisted reproductive procedures; periodically when a woman is undergoing treatment for an AMH-producing ovarian cancer; when it is suspected that the testicles of an infant boy are absent or not functioning properly
Müllerian Inhibiting Factor.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Müllerian-inhibiting Hormone.Why Get Tested?: In women, to evaluate ovarian function and fertility; sometimes in the evaluation of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or to evaluate the effectiveness of ovarian cancer treatment; in an infant, to evaluate the presence of external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or function of the testicles in an infant boy
Müllerian-inhibiting Hormone.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner wants to evaluate a woman's fertility, predict onset of menopause, or suspects PCOS; sometimes prior to some assisted reproductive procedures; periodically when a woman is undergoing treatment for an AMH-producing ovarian cancer; when it is suspected that the testicles of an infant boy are absent or not functioning properly
Müllerian-inhibiting Hormone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Müllerian-Inhibiting Substance.Why Get Tested?: In women, to evaluate ovarian function and fertility; sometimes in the evaluation of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) or to evaluate the effectiveness of ovarian cancer treatment; in an infant, to evaluate the presence of external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or function of the testicles in an infant boy
Müllerian-Inhibiting Substance.When To Get Tested?: When a health practitioner wants to evaluate a woman's fertility, predict onset of menopause, or suspects PCOS; sometimes prior to some assisted reproductive procedures; periodically when a woman is undergoing treatment for an AMH-producing ovarian cancer; when it is suspected that the testicles of an infant boy are absent or not functioning properly
Müllerian-Inhibiting Substance.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Multiple Marker Test.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
Multiple Marker Test.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
Multiple Marker Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Mumps Antibody IgM, IgG.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a measles or mumps infection; to establish whether a person has immunity to measles or mumps due to a previous infection or to vaccination; to confirm a measles or mumps case and investigate its source
Mumps Antibody IgM, IgG.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms or complications that a health practitioner suspects are due to a measles or mumps infection; whenever it is necessary or desired to determine measles or mumps immunity; when an outbreak of measles or mumps is occurring in order to track and minimize it
Mumps Antibody IgM, IgG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for measles or mumps antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, sample may be blood, urine, nasopharyngeal (nasal) aspirate/washing, throat swab, swab of the inside of the cheek (buccal swab), cerebrospinal fluid, or other body tissue
Mumps Antibody IgM, IgG.Test Preparation Needed?: Prior to collection of a buccal swab for mumps, the salivary gland located in front of and below the ear (parotid gland) is massaged. For other specimens, no test preparation is needed.

Mumps Virus by Culture or RT-PCR.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a measles or mumps infection; to establish whether a person has immunity to measles or mumps due to a previous infection or to vaccination; to confirm a measles or mumps case and investigate its source
Mumps Virus by Culture or RT-PCR.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms or complications that a health practitioner suspects are due to a measles or mumps infection; whenever it is necessary or desired to determine measles or mumps immunity; when an outbreak of measles or mumps is occurring in order to track and minimize it
Mumps Virus by Culture or RT-PCR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for measles or mumps antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, sample may be blood, urine, nasopharyngeal (nasal) aspirate/washing, throat swab, swab of the inside of the cheek (buccal swab), cerebrospinal fluid, or other body tissue
Mumps Virus by Culture or RT-PCR.Test Preparation Needed?: Prior to collection of a buccal swab for mumps, the salivary gland located in front of and below the ear (parotid gland) is massaged. For other specimens, no test preparation is needed.

Muscle nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptor.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG) and to distinguish between MG and other conditions with similar symptoms
Muscle nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptor.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest MG, such as a drooping eyelid, double vision, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and/or weakness in specific muscles
Muscle nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptor.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Myasthenia Gravis Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose myasthenia gravis (MG) and to distinguish between MG and other conditions with similar symptoms
Myasthenia Gravis Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest MG, such as a drooping eyelid, double vision, difficulty chewing or swallowing, and/or weakness in specific muscles
Myasthenia Gravis Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Mycobacteria Smear and Culture.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose tuberculosis (TB) and infections caused by other Mycobacterium species, which are known as acid-fast bacilli (AFB), in people at risk of developing mycobacterial infections; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Mycobacteria Smear and Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a lung infection, such as a chronic cough, weight loss, fever, chills, and weakness, that may be due to TB or a nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection; when you have a positive IGRA blood test or Tuberculin skin test (TST) and you are in a high-risk group for progressing to active TB; when you have a skin or other body site infection that may be due to mycobacteria; when you are undergoing treatment for TB
Mycobacteria Smear and Culture.Sample Required?: For suspected cases of tuberculosis lung infections, usually three sputum samples are collected early in the morning on different days. If you are unable to produce sputum, a bronchoscope may be used to collect fluid during a procedure called a bronchoscopy. In children, gastric washings/aspirates may be collected. Depending on symptoms, urine, an aspirate from the site of suspected infection, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), other body fluids, or biopsied tissue samples may be collected for AFB testing.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis Nucleic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose tuberculosis (TB) and infections caused by other Mycobacterium species, which are known as acid-fast bacilli (AFB), in people at risk of developing mycobacterial infections; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Mycobacterium tuberculosis Nucleic Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a lung infection, such as a chronic cough, weight loss, fever, chills, and weakness, that may be due to TB or a nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection; when you have a positive IGRA blood test or Tuberculin skin test (TST) and you are in a high-risk group for progressing to active TB; when you have a skin or other body site infection that may be due to mycobacteria; when you are undergoing treatment for TB
Mycobacterium tuberculosis Nucleic Acid.Sample Required?: For suspected cases of tuberculosis lung infections, usually three sputum samples are collected early in the morning on different days. If you are unable to produce sputum, a bronchoscope may be used to collect fluid during a procedure called a bronchoscopy. In children, gastric washings/aspirates may be collected. Depending on symptoms, urine, an aspirate from the site of suspected infection, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), other body fluids, or biopsied tissue samples may be collected for AFB testing.

Mycology Tests.Why Get Tested?: To detect a fungal infection, to determine which specific fungus or fungi are present, and to help guide treatment
Mycology Tests.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a skin, lung, or systemic fungal infection; sometimes after treatment to monitor its effectiveness
Mycology Tests.Sample Required?: The sample collected depends upon the suspected location(s) of the infection. Some examples include: scrapings of the skin, nail and hair samples, body fluids, blood, and/or a tissue biopsy.

Mycophenolate Mofetil.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of mycophenolic acid (MPA), an immunosuppressant drug, in the blood in order to monitor levels in transplant recipients and prevent toxicity
Mycophenolate Mofetil.When To Get Tested?: As soon as mycophenolate therapy begins and whenever the dose is changed; may be ordered frequently at first, then at regular intervals; whenever excess or deficient levels of MPA are suspected
Mycophenolate Mofetil.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Mycophenolate Sodium.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of mycophenolic acid (MPA), an immunosuppressant drug, in the blood in order to monitor levels in transplant recipients and prevent toxicity
Mycophenolate Sodium.When To Get Tested?: As soon as mycophenolate therapy begins and whenever the dose is changed; may be ordered frequently at first, then at regular intervals; whenever excess or deficient levels of MPA are suspected
Mycophenolate Sodium.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Mycophenolic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of mycophenolic acid (MPA), an immunosuppressant drug, in the blood in order to monitor levels in transplant recipients and prevent toxicity
Mycophenolic Acid.When To Get Tested?: As soon as mycophenolate therapy begins and whenever the dose is changed; may be ordered frequently at first, then at regular intervals; whenever excess or deficient levels of MPA are suspected
Mycophenolic Acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Mycoplasma.Why Get Tested?: To detect an active or recent mycoplasma (type of bacteria) infection
Mycoplasma.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that your respiratory or other symptoms are caused by a mycoplasma infection; when a genital infection may be caused by mycoplasma or ureaplasma (a particular type of mycoplasma)
Mycoplasma.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a throat swab, sputum sample, body fluid or tissue sample; occasionally, genital or urethral swab

Mycoplasma by PCR.Why Get Tested?: To detect an active or recent mycoplasma (type of bacteria) infection
Mycoplasma by PCR.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that your respiratory or other symptoms are caused by a mycoplasma infection; when a genital infection may be caused by mycoplasma or ureaplasma (a particular type of mycoplasma)
Mycoplasma by PCR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a throat swab, sputum sample, body fluid or tissue sample; occasionally, genital or urethral swab

Mycoplasma Culture.Why Get Tested?: To detect an active or recent mycoplasma (type of bacteria) infection
Mycoplasma Culture.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that your respiratory or other symptoms are caused by a mycoplasma infection; when a genital infection may be caused by mycoplasma or ureaplasma (a particular type of mycoplasma)
Mycoplasma Culture.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a throat swab, sputum sample, body fluid or tissue sample; occasionally, genital or urethral swab

Mycoplasma pneumoniae IgG and IgM Antibo.Why Get Tested?: To detect an active or recent mycoplasma (type of bacteria) infection
Mycoplasma pneumoniae IgG and IgM Antibo.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that your respiratory or other symptoms are caused by a mycoplasma infection; when a genital infection may be caused by mycoplasma or ureaplasma (a particular type of mycoplasma)
Mycoplasma pneumoniae IgG and IgM Antibo.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a throat swab, sputum sample, body fluid or tissue sample; occasionally, genital or urethral swab

Myeloperoxidase Antibodies.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
Myeloperoxidase Antibodies.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
Myeloperoxidase Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Myoglobin.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether muscle has been injured; to help diagnose conditions associated with muscle damage; to detect high levels in the urine that can cause kidney damage after extensive muscle damage; sometimes to help determine if you have had a heart attack, although for heart attack detection, this test has been largely replaced by troponin.
Myoglobin.When To Get Tested?: When you have muscle weakness, muscle aches, and/or dark urine and your healthcare provider suspects muscle damage; when there has been severe traumatic injury to skeletal muscle
Myoglobin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random urine sample

N-telopeptide.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
N-telopeptide.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
N-telopeptide.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
N-telopeptide.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Na.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether your sodium level is within normal limits; to help evaluate electrolyte balance and to help determine the cause of and monitor the treatment for illnesses associated with abnormal sodium levels in the body
Na.When To Get Tested?: If you are experiencing dehydration, problems with blood pressure, accumulating excess fluid (edema), or have non-specific symptoms; as part of a routine health examination
Na.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

Native double-stranded DNA Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus, SLE)
Native double-stranded DNA Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have a positive ANA test and signs and symptoms associated with lupus, such as persistent fatigue, pain in your joints and a red rash resembling a butterfly across the nose and cheeks; periodically used to assess disease activity in those who have been diagnosed with lupus
Native double-stranded DNA Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Natriuretic Peptides.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and evaluate the severity of congestive heart failure (CHF)
Natriuretic Peptides.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of heart failure, such as shortness of breath and fatigue, or when you are being treated for CHF
Natriuretic Peptides.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Neisseria gonorrhoeae.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a gonorrhea infection
Neisseria gonorrhoeae.When To Get Tested?:
Screening:
For women, yearly testing recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); if you fall into one of these groups and are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly testing recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
Diagnosis:
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge or vaginal bleeding between menstrual periods (for women), or unusual discharge from the penis, pain during urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
Neisseria gonorrhoeae.Sample Required?: A swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina (for women) or from your penis (for men); for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
Neisseria gonorrhoeae.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow the instructions you are given.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae Nucleic Acid Ampli.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and diagnose a gonorrhea infection
Neisseria gonorrhoeae Nucleic Acid Ampli.When To Get Tested?:
Screening:
For women, yearly testing recommended if you are sexually active and younger than age 25 or 25 or older and at increased risk for this sexually transmitted disease (STD); if you fall into one of these groups and are pregnant or considering pregnancy
For men, yearly testing recommended if you are a man who has sex with men
Diagnosis:
When you have symptoms of this STD, such as pain during urination, vaginal discharge or vaginal bleeding between menstrual periods (for women), or unusual discharge from the penis, pain during urination or painful, swollen testicles (for men)
When a newborn has conjunctivitis
Neisseria gonorrhoeae Nucleic Acid Ampli.Sample Required?: A swab or brush of cells or secretion from your vagina (for women) or from your penis (for men); for men or women, the initial portion of your urine stream (first-catch urine sample); sometimes a swab of cells or secretion from a non-genital area that may be infected
Neisseria gonorrhoeae Nucleic Acid Ampli.Test Preparation Needed?: Tell your healthcare provider about any use of antibiotics or, for women, douches or vaginal creams within 24 hours before testing vaginal samples since they may affect test results. Menstruation will not affect results. For a urine sample, you may be instructed to wait one to two hours after you last urinated before collecting the sample. Follow the instructions you are given.

Neonatal Bilirubin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor liver disorders or hemolytic anemia; to monitor neonatal jaundice
Neonatal Bilirubin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of liver damage, liver disease, bile duct blockage, hemolytic anemia, or a liver-related metabolic problem, or if a newborn has jaundice
Neonatal Bilirubin.Sample Required?: In adults, a blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm; in newborns, a blood sample from a heelstick; non-invasive technology is available in some healthcare facilities that will measure bilirubin by using an instrument placed on the skin (transcutaneous bilirubin meter)
Neonatal Bilirubin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for several hours before the test; fasting requirements vary by laboratory; ask your lab or healthcare provider for instructions.

NH3.Why Get Tested?: To detect an elevated level of ammonia in the blood that may be caused by severe liver disease, kidney failure, or certain rare genetic urea cycle disorders; to help investigate the cause of changes in behavior and consciousness; to support the diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy or Reye syndrome
NH3.When To Get Tested?: When someone with liver disease or kidney failure experiences mental changes or lapses into a coma; when a newborn experiences frequent vomiting and increased lethargy or when a child has continuous vomiting and unusual sleepiness about a week after a viral illness, such as the flu or chickenpox
NH3.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
NH3.Test Preparation Needed?: You should not smoke cigarettes prior to collection of the specimen.

niacin (B3).Why Get Tested?: To screen for and detect moderate to severe vitamin B deficiencies
niacin (B3).When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that may be due to a B vitamin deficiency, are at risk for a deficiency, or have a condition associated with malabsorption
niacin (B3).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a random or 24-hour urine sample may also be collected.
niacin (B3).Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is usually required for blood testing.

Nicotine and Cotinine.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of and/or measure the quantity of nicotine or its metabolite cotinine in blood, urine, saliva, or sometimes hair; to determine whether someone uses products containing tobacco or nicotine or has been exposed to secondhand smoke; sometimes performed to evaluate for acute nicotine poisoning
Nicotine and Cotinine.When To Get Tested?: Whenever someone requires confirmation of tobacco or nicotine usage or exposure to secondhand smoke; occasionally when nicotine overdose is suspected
Nicotine and Cotinine.Sample Required?: A blood sample collected from a vein in your arm or a random urine sample; sometimes a saliva sample or, rarely, a hair sample

NIPS.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of your developing baby (fetus) having certain chromosome disorders
NIPS.When To Get Tested?: During or after the 10th week of pregnancy
NIPS.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the mother's arm

NMR Particle Test.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
NMR Particle Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal and/or family history of CVD at an early age; when the result of your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) test is within a healthy range, but your healthcare provider thinks that you may have an increased risk of developing heart disease; sometimes to help monitor the effectiveness of lipid-lowering treatment and/or lifestyle changes
NMR Particle Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
NMR Particle Test.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast for 9-12 hours before this test; only water is permitted. Follow any instructions you are given.

Non-HDL.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD); to monitor treatment
Non-HDL.When To Get Tested?:
For Screening when no risk factors present: for adults, every four to six years; for youths, once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between ages 17 and 21
For Monitoring: at regular intervals when risk factors are present, when prior results showed high-risk levels, and/or to monitor effectiveness of treatment
Non-HDL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
Non-HDL.Test Preparation Needed?: For a fasting lipid profile, fasting for 9-12 hours (water only) before having your blood drawn is typically required, but some labs offer non-fasting lipid testing. In particular, testing may be done without fasting for youths without risk factors. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

Non-HDL-C.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD); to monitor treatment
Non-HDL-C.When To Get Tested?:
For Screening when no risk factors present: for adults, every four to six years; for youths, once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between ages 17 and 21
For Monitoring: at regular intervals when risk factors are present, when prior results showed high-risk levels, and/or to monitor effectiveness of treatment
Non-HDL-C.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
Non-HDL-C.Test Preparation Needed?: For a fasting lipid profile, fasting for 9-12 hours (water only) before having your blood drawn is typically required, but some labs offer non-fasting lipid testing. In particular, testing may be done without fasting for youths without risk factors. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

Non-High Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD); to monitor treatment
Non-High Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?:
For Screening when no risk factors present: for adults, every four to six years; for youths, once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between ages 17 and 21
For Monitoring: at regular intervals when risk factors are present, when prior results showed high-risk levels, and/or to monitor effectiveness of treatment
Non-High Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
Non-High Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: For a fasting lipid profile, fasting for 9-12 hours (water only) before having your blood drawn is typically required, but some labs offer non-fasting lipid testing. In particular, testing may be done without fasting for youths without risk factors. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

Non-Invasive Prenatal Screening.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of your developing baby (fetus) having certain chromosome disorders
Non-Invasive Prenatal Screening.When To Get Tested?: During or after the 10th week of pregnancy
Non-Invasive Prenatal Screening.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the mother's arm

Norepinephrine.Why Get Tested?: To help confirm or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Norepinephrine.When To Get Tested?: After or in conjunction with plasma free metanephrines and/or urine metanephrines tests and when your healthcare provider needs additional information regarding a possible catecholamine-secreting tumor
Norepinephrine.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Norepinephrine.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection. Although you may be seated for collection of the blood sample, it is recommended that you be lying down. Your healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.

NTx.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
NTx.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
NTx.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
NTx.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

O&P;.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have a parasite infecting your digestive tract
O&P;.When To Get Tested?: When you have diarrhea that lasts more than a few days and/or have blood or mucus in your loose stools, especially if you have drunk unpurified water while camping or have traveled outside of the United States
O&P;.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample transported to the lab within 2 hours or a preserved stool sample; sometimes multiple samples collected on different days

Occult Blood Test, Fecal.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
Occult Blood Test, Fecal.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
Occult Blood Test, Fecal.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
Occult Blood Test, Fecal.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

OGTT.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
OGTT.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
OGTT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
OGTT.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Opioid Testing.Why Get Tested?:
To monitor compliance with prescribed medications
To screen for opioid abuse or drug diversion (when a person gives, trades, or sells the prescription to another individual)
To monitor someone with an opioid addiction
To detect and evaluate opioid overdose
Opioid Testing.When To Get Tested?:
When you are prescribed opioids for long-term (chronic) pain
When required prior to the start of a new job or insurance policy, at various times as part of workplace drug testing, or when it is mandated by a court order
When you are being treated for substance abuse or addiction
When you have signs and symptoms suggesting drug intoxication or overdose

Oral Glucose Tolerance Test.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
Oral Glucose Tolerance Test.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
Oral Glucose Tolerance Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
Oral Glucose Tolerance Test.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Oral Lactose Tolerance.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose lactose intolerance in individuals who have difficulties digesting dairy products, or sometimes as part of an investigation of malabsorption
Oral Lactose Tolerance.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming milk and other dairy products
Oral Lactose Tolerance.Sample Required?: A series of breath samples exhaled into a collector, or a series of blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm
Oral Lactose Tolerance.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting is required; nothing but water is permitted. Two weeks prior to the test, you must be off antibiotics and stomach medications, such as laxatives, antacids and stool softeners. Tell your healthcare practitioner about any other medications you are taking. Avoid strenuous activities. You may be instructed to brush your teeth and/or rinse your mouth with water prior to and during the breath test.

Osmolality.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the body's water and electrolyte balance; to investigate low sodium levels in the blood (hyponatremia) and increased or decreased urine production; to detect alcohol poisoning due to ingestion of toxins such as methanol or ethylene glycol; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for conditions affecting osmolality; to help determine the cause of chronic diarrhea
Osmolality.When To Get Tested?: When someone has a low blood sodium level, is taking mannitol (an osmotic diuretic), may have ingested methanol, ethylene glycol, or isopropyl alcohol, is producing significantly increased or decreased amounts of urine, or has chronic diarrhea
Osmolality.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a random urine sample; sometimes a fresh, liquid stool sample
Osmolality.Test Preparation Needed?: None may be required or you may be instructed to fast for 6 hours before the test; follow any instructions provided. Inform your health care provider of all medications you are taking, especially mannitol.

Osmolality (plasma, urine, stool).Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the body's water and electrolyte balance; to investigate low sodium levels in the blood (hyponatremia) and increased or decreased urine production; to detect alcohol poisoning due to ingestion of toxins such as methanol or ethylene glycol; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for conditions affecting osmolality; to help determine the cause of chronic diarrhea
Osmolality (plasma, urine, stool).When To Get Tested?: When someone has a low blood sodium level, is taking mannitol (an osmotic diuretic), may have ingested methanol, ethylene glycol, or isopropyl alcohol, is producing significantly increased or decreased amounts of urine, or has chronic diarrhea
Osmolality (plasma, urine, stool).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a random urine sample; sometimes a fresh, liquid stool sample
Osmolality (plasma, urine, stool).Test Preparation Needed?: None may be required or you may be instructed to fast for 6 hours before the test; follow any instructions provided. Inform your health care provider of all medications you are taking, especially mannitol.

Osteocalcin.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Osteocalcin.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Osteocalcin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Osteocalcin.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Ova and Parasite Exam.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have a parasite infecting your digestive tract
Ova and Parasite Exam.When To Get Tested?: When you have diarrhea that lasts more than a few days and/or have blood or mucus in your loose stools, especially if you have drunk unpurified water while camping or have traveled outside of the United States
Ova and Parasite Exam.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample transported to the lab within 2 hours or a preserved stool sample; sometimes multiple samples collected on different days

P.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the level of phosphorus in your blood and to aid in the diagnosis of conditions known to cause abnormally high or low levels of phosphorus
P.When To Get Tested?: In follow up to an abnormal calcium level; when you have a kidney disorder or uncontrolled diabetes; when you are taking calcium or phosphate supplements
P.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm. If a timed urine sample is required, you will be asked to save all of your urine over a set time period (usually 24 hours).
P.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting may be required prior to collecting a blood sample; follow any instructions that you are given.

P1NP.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
P1NP.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
P1NP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
P1NP.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

p24 Antigen.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you are infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
p24 Antigen.When To Get Tested?: At least once, when you are 13 to 64 years old; when you think you may have been exposed to the virus; before becoming pregnant or when pregnant; once a year if you are at increased risk of being exposed to the virus
p24 Antigen.Sample Required?: A blood sample collected from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick; there are also HIV antibody tests available that can be performed on oral fluid.

Packed Cell Volume.Why Get Tested?: To determine the proportion of your blood that is made up of red blood cells (RBCs) in order to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect RBCs; as part of a routine health examination or if your healthcare provider suspects that you have anemia or polycythemia
Packed Cell Volume.When To Get Tested?: With a test for hemoglobin or as part of a complete blood count (CBC) during a routine health exam or when you have signs and symptoms of anemia (weakness, fatigue) or polycythemia (dizziness, headache); at regular intervals to monitor a disorder that affects RBCs and to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment
Packed Cell Volume.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

PAF-AH.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD), including your risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) and ischemic stroke
PAF-AH.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider determines that you are at a moderate to high risk of developing CVD or of having an ischemic stroke; when you have a family history of CVD or CHD
PAF-AH.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

pANCA.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
pANCA.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
pANCA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Pancreatic Elastase.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
Pancreatic Elastase.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as stomach cramps, weight loss, malnutrition, malabsorption, delayed growth (in children) and fatty, foul-smelling stools and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
Pancreatic Elastase.Sample Required?: A fresh formed stool sample that is not contaminated with urine
Pancreatic Elastase.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be asked to discontinue them for 5 days prior to stool collection.

pantothenic acid (B5).Why Get Tested?: To screen for and detect moderate to severe vitamin B deficiencies
pantothenic acid (B5).When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that may be due to a B vitamin deficiency, are at risk for a deficiency, or have a condition associated with malabsorption
pantothenic acid (B5).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a random or 24-hour urine sample may also be collected.
pantothenic acid (B5).Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is usually required for blood testing.

Pap Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for cervical cancer and certain vaginal or uterine infections
Pap Test.When To Get Tested?: For women age 21 or older, once every 3 to 5 years depending on your age, risk factors, use of other screening tests, and your healthcare provider's advice
Pap Test.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed not to douche or tub bathe for 24 hours before the Pap test is to be performed. You may also be asked to refrain from sexual intercourse for 24 to 48 hours before the test. Do not use any vaginal creams or foams for 48 hours prior to the exam and do not schedule the test during your menstrual period.

Papanicolaou Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for cervical cancer and certain vaginal or uterine infections
Papanicolaou Test.When To Get Tested?: For women age 21 or older, once every 3 to 5 years depending on your age, risk factors, use of other screening tests, and your healthcare provider's advice
Papanicolaou Test.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed not to douche or tub bathe for 24 hours before the Pap test is to be performed. You may also be asked to refrain from sexual intercourse for 24 to 48 hours before the test. Do not use any vaginal creams or foams for 48 hours prior to the exam and do not schedule the test during your menstrual period.

Paracetamol.Why Get Tested?: To determine if an overdose has occurred; to determine risk of liver damage and to help determine if treatment with an antidote is required
Paracetamol.When To Get Tested?: When it is suspected that a person has ingested an overdose of acetaminophen or has signs and symptoms of toxicity, such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain; when following a patient, every 4 to 6 hours after an overdose of the drug is ingested
Paracetamol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm

Parasitic Examination, stool.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have a parasite infecting your digestive tract
Parasitic Examination, stool.When To Get Tested?: When you have diarrhea that lasts more than a few days and/or have blood or mucus in your loose stools, especially if you have drunk unpurified water while camping or have traveled outside of the United States
Parasitic Examination, stool.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample transported to the lab within 2 hours or a preserved stool sample; sometimes multiple samples collected on different days

Parathormone.Why Get Tested?: To determine the cause of calcium imbalances; to evaluate parathyroid function; to diagnose and differentiate between primary, secondary, and tertiary hyperparathyroidism; to diagnose hypoparathyroidism; during surgery for hyperparathyroidism to confirm removal of the gland(s) causing the problem
Parathormone.When To Get Tested?: When calcium blood levels are higher or lower than normal; when you are having surgery for hyperparathyroidism; when your healthcare practitioner wants to determine how well your parathyroid glands are functioning
Parathormone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Parathormone.Test Preparation Needed?: Current practices do not require fasting. PTH levels peak during sleep hours and are lowest during mid-morning to late afternoon hours, the period when most samples are drawn. There may be seasonal fluctuations in PTH due to its inverse relationship with vitamin D. Talk to your healthcare practitioner about sample timing.

Parathyroid Hormone (PTH).Why Get Tested?: To determine the cause of calcium imbalances; to evaluate parathyroid function; to diagnose and differentiate between primary, secondary, and tertiary hyperparathyroidism; to diagnose hypoparathyroidism; during surgery for hyperparathyroidism to confirm removal of the gland(s) causing the problem
Parathyroid Hormone (PTH).When To Get Tested?: When calcium blood levels are higher or lower than normal; when you are having surgery for hyperparathyroidism; when your healthcare practitioner wants to determine how well your parathyroid glands are functioning
Parathyroid Hormone (PTH).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Parathyroid Hormone (PTH).Test Preparation Needed?: Current practices do not require fasting. PTH levels peak during sleep hours and are lowest during mid-morning to late afternoon hours, the period when most samples are drawn. There may be seasonal fluctuations in PTH due to its inverse relationship with vitamin D. Talk to your healthcare practitioner about sample timing.

Parietal Cell Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose pernicious anemia, the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
Parietal Cell Antibody.When To Get Tested?: As part of an investigation, when you have anemia and/or neuropathy that may be due to a vitamin B12 deficiency; when you have red blood cells that are much larger than normal (macrocytic)
Parietal Cell Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Parotitis.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a measles or mumps infection; to establish whether a person has immunity to measles or mumps due to a previous infection or to vaccination; to confirm a measles or mumps case and investigate its source
Parotitis.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms or complications that a health practitioner suspects are due to a measles or mumps infection; whenever it is necessary or desired to determine measles or mumps immunity; when an outbreak of measles or mumps is occurring in order to track and minimize it
Parotitis.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for measles or mumps antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, sample may be blood, urine, nasopharyngeal (nasal) aspirate/washing, throat swab, swab of the inside of the cheek (buccal swab), cerebrospinal fluid, or other body tissue
Parotitis.Test Preparation Needed?: Prior to collection of a buccal swab for mumps, the salivary gland located in front of and below the ear (parotid gland) is massaged. For other specimens, no test preparation is needed.

Partial Thromboplastin Time.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode); to monitor unfractionated (standard) heparin anticoagulant therapy; as part of screening before surgery or other invasive procedure
Partial Thromboplastin Time.When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained bleeding, inappropriate blood clotting, or recurrent miscarriages; when you are on standard heparin anticoagulant therapy; sometimes as part of a pre-surgical screen
Partial Thromboplastin Time.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

Partial Thromboplastin Time (PTT, aPTT).Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode); to monitor unfractionated (standard) heparin anticoagulant therapy; as part of screening before surgery or other invasive procedure
Partial Thromboplastin Time (PTT, aPTT).When To Get Tested?: When you have unexplained bleeding, inappropriate blood clotting, or recurrent miscarriages; when you are on standard heparin anticoagulant therapy; sometimes as part of a pre-surgical screen
Partial Thromboplastin Time (PTT, aPTT).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

Parvo B19.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have, or recently had, a parvovirus B19 infection if you are at increased risk of complications from this viral infection; if a fetus is at high risk of contracting parvovirus B19 from a mother who is infected or has been exposed
Parvo B19.When To Get Tested?: When a pregnant woman has a parvovirus B19 infection or has been exposed to someone with the virus; when someone, especially an immune-compromised person, has persistent or severe anemia
Parvo B19.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for parvovirus B19 antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, the sample tested may be blood or, rarely, bone marrow; in certain cases, fetal cord blood or amniotic fluid may be collected to test for fetal parvovirus B19 infection.

Parvovirus.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have, or recently had, a parvovirus B19 infection if you are at increased risk of complications from this viral infection; if a fetus is at high risk of contracting parvovirus B19 from a mother who is infected or has been exposed
Parvovirus.When To Get Tested?: When a pregnant woman has a parvovirus B19 infection or has been exposed to someone with the virus; when someone, especially an immune-compromised person, has persistent or severe anemia
Parvovirus.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for parvovirus B19 antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, the sample tested may be blood or, rarely, bone marrow; in certain cases, fetal cord blood or amniotic fluid may be collected to test for fetal parvovirus B19 infection.

Parvovirus B19.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have, or recently had, a parvovirus B19 infection if you are at increased risk of complications from this viral infection; if a fetus is at high risk of contracting parvovirus B19 from a mother who is infected or has been exposed
Parvovirus B19.When To Get Tested?: When a pregnant woman has a parvovirus B19 infection or has been exposed to someone with the virus; when someone, especially an immune-compromised person, has persistent or severe anemia
Parvovirus B19.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for parvovirus B19 antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, the sample tested may be blood or, rarely, bone marrow; in certain cases, fetal cord blood or amniotic fluid may be collected to test for fetal parvovirus B19 infection.

PBG.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
PBG.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
PBG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
PBG.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

PCA3.Why Get Tested?: To help determine if a repeat prostate biopsy is indicated to help detect prostate cancer
PCA3.Sample Required?: The first amount of urine collected after a healthcare practitioner performs a digital rectal exam (DRE)

PCHE.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
PCHE.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
PCHE.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PCT.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose sepsis if you are critically ill and to help determine your risk of progressing to severe sepsis and septic shock; to help identify serious bacterial infections and to distinguish between bacterial and non-bacterial conditions; to help guide antibiotic treatment
PCT.When To Get Tested?: When you are seriously ill and have signs and symptoms of a systemic infection or sepsis; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to a bacterial infection and your healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether antibiotics would be effective; at intervals to monitor effectiveness of antibiotic treatment
PCT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PCV.Why Get Tested?: To determine the proportion of your blood that is made up of red blood cells (RBCs) in order to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect RBCs; as part of a routine health examination or if your healthcare provider suspects that you have anemia or polycythemia
PCV.When To Get Tested?: With a test for hemoglobin or as part of a complete blood count (CBC) during a routine health exam or when you have signs and symptoms of anemia (weakness, fatigue) or polycythemia (dizziness, headache); at regular intervals to monitor a disorder that affects RBCs and to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment
PCV.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)
