PDGFRA-FIP1L1 gene rearrangement.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of hypereosinophilia (HE), a condition with persistent increase in the number of eosinophils, a specific type of white blood cell, or hypereosinophilic syndrome (HES), which is HE with associated tissue or organ damage; to help determine if someone with HE or HES can be treated with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) such as imatinib
PDGFRA-FIP1L1 gene rearrangement.When To Get Tested?: After complete blood counts (CBC) indicate that you have persistently elevated eosinophils and your health practitioner has ruled out other causes such as allergies, parasitic infection, or medication; at regular intervals when you are being treated for HE or HES with imatinib
PDGFRA-FIP1L1 gene rearrangement.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

PDW.Why Get Tested?: To determine the number of platelets in a sample of your blood as part of a health exam; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect the number of platelets, such as a bleeding disorder, a bone marrow disease, or other underlying condition
PDW.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine complete blood count (CBC); when you have episodes of unexplained or prolonged bleeding or other symptoms that may be due to a platelet disorder
PDW.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Pericardial Fluid Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of inflammation of the membrane surrounding the heart (pericardium) and/or fluid accumulation around the heart
Pericardial Fluid Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a condition associated with inflammation of the pericardium and/or fluid accumulation around your heart
Pericardial Fluid Analysis.Sample Required?: A sample of fluid collected from the pericardial sac using a procedure called a pericardiocentesis

Peripheral Blood Smear.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets, to distinguish between the different types of WBCs, and to determine their relative percentages in the blood; to help detect, diagnose, and/or monitor a range of deficiencies, diseases, and disorders involving blood cell production, function, and lifespan
Peripheral Blood Smear.When To Get Tested?: When complete blood count (CBC) and/or automated WBC differential results are abnormal or when you have signs and symptoms that a healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a condition affecting your blood cells
Peripheral Blood Smear.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by pricking a finger or, in the case of an infant, a heelstick

Peripheral Differential.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of abnormal results on a white blood cell (WBC) count; to help diagnose and/or monitor an illness affecting your immune system, such as an infection or inflammatory condition, or cancers that affect your white blood cells, such as leukemia
Peripheral Differential.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when results of a CBC fall outside the reference range; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting white blood cells, such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs, such as chemotherapy
Peripheral Differential.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (infants)

Peripheral Smear.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets, to distinguish between the different types of WBCs, and to determine their relative percentages in the blood; to help detect, diagnose, and/or monitor a range of deficiencies, diseases, and disorders involving blood cell production, function, and lifespan
Peripheral Smear.When To Get Tested?: When complete blood count (CBC) and/or automated WBC differential results are abnormal or when you have signs and symptoms that a healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a condition affecting your blood cells
Peripheral Smear.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by pricking a finger or, in the case of an infant, a heelstick

Peritoneal Fluid Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of peritonitis, an inflammation of the membrane lining the abdomen, and/or peritoneal fluid accumulation, where fluid builds up in the abdomen or around internal organs (called ascites)
Peritoneal Fluid Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When you have abdominal pain and swelling, nausea, and/or fever and your healthcare practitioner suspects you have peritonitis or ascites
Peritoneal Fluid Analysis.Sample Required?: A peritoneal fluid sample obtained by inserting a needle into the abdominal cavity
Peritoneal Fluid Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: You will be asked to empty your bladder prior to sample collection.

Pertussis Tests.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose a Bordetella pertussis infection, commonly known as whooping cough
Pertussis Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have persistent spasms or fits of coughing (paroxysms) that the healthcare practitioner suspects is due to pertussis (whooping cough); when you have symptoms of a cold and have been exposed to someone with pertussis
Pertussis Tests.Sample Required?: A nasopharyngeal (NP) swab or a nasal aspirate; occasionally, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PFA.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of or potential for excessive bleeding and/or to diagnose a platelet function disorder; to monitor and evaluate platelet function; to monitor the presence and effectiveness of anti-platelet medications
PFA.When To Get Tested?: When you bruise easily or experience excessive or prolonged bleeding from minor cuts, nose or gums, or excessive menstrual bleeding; when you are taking medications that can alter platelet function; prior to or during certain surgeries; if you have a family member with a history of excessive bleeding
PFA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
PFA.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to refrain from taking drugs that can affect the results of these tests, such as aspirin, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), or any over-the-counter medications that contain drugs such as these, anti-histamines, and certain antibiotics. The most common NSAIDs include ibuprofen, naproxen and COX-2 inhibitors. However, do not stop taking your medications unless instructed to do so by your healthcare practitioner.

PFT.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of or potential for excessive bleeding and/or to diagnose a platelet function disorder; to monitor and evaluate platelet function; to monitor the presence and effectiveness of anti-platelet medications
PFT.When To Get Tested?: When you bruise easily or experience excessive or prolonged bleeding from minor cuts, nose or gums, or excessive menstrual bleeding; when you are taking medications that can alter platelet function; prior to or during certain surgeries; if you have a family member with a history of excessive bleeding
PFT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
PFT.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to refrain from taking drugs that can affect the results of these tests, such as aspirin, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), or any over-the-counter medications that contain drugs such as these, anti-histamines, and certain antibiotics. The most common NSAIDs include ibuprofen, naproxen and COX-2 inhibitors. However, do not stop taking your medications unless instructed to do so by your healthcare practitioner.

PGSN.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of infertility, track ovulation, help diagnose an ectopic or failing pregnancy, monitor the health of a pregnancy, monitor progesterone replacement therapy, or help diagnose the cause of abnormal uterine bleeding
PGSN.When To Get Tested?: At specific times during a woman's menstrual cycle to determine whether/when she is ovulating (releasing an egg from an ovary); during early pregnancy when symptoms suggest an ectopic or failing pregnancy; throughout a high-risk pregnancy to help determine placenta and fetal health; periodically when a person is receiving progesterone replacement therapy; when a woman has abnormal uterine bleeding
PGSN.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
PGSN.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but for women, the date of your last menstrual period or trimester of pregnancy should be noted.

Phenobarbital.Why Get Tested?: To monitor the phenobarbital level in your blood to ensure a therapeutic level while avoiding toxic side effects
Phenobarbital.When To Get Tested?: At the start of therapy and at a regular intervals during treatment; when someone has signs and symptoms of toxicity or is experiencing seizures
Phenobarbital.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Phenytoin.Why Get Tested?: To determine the level of the drug phenytoin in your blood in order to maintain a therapeutic level and to detect potential for toxicity
Phenytoin.When To Get Tested?: At regular intervals to monitor; as needed to detect low or toxic concentrations
Phenytoin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
Phenytoin.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, be sure your healthcare practitioner knows about all medications (prescribed and over-the-counter), herbs, and supplements you are taking.

Phenytoin, total and free.Why Get Tested?: To determine the level of the drug phenytoin in your blood in order to maintain a therapeutic level and to detect potential for toxicity
Phenytoin, total and free.When To Get Tested?: At regular intervals to monitor; as needed to detect low or toxic concentrations
Phenytoin, total and free.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
Phenytoin, total and free.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, be sure your healthcare practitioner knows about all medications (prescribed and over-the-counter), herbs, and supplements you are taking.

Philadelphia Chromosome.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and a type of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
Philadelphia Chromosome.When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for CML or BCR-ABL1-positive ALL
Philadelphia Chromosome.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration and/or biopsy procedure

Phosphate.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the level of phosphorus in your blood and to aid in the diagnosis of conditions known to cause abnormally high or low levels of phosphorus
Phosphate.When To Get Tested?: In follow up to an abnormal calcium level; when you have a kidney disorder or uncontrolled diabetes; when you are taking calcium or phosphate supplements
Phosphate.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm. If a timed urine sample is required, you will be asked to save all of your urine over a set time period (usually 24 hours).
Phosphate.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting may be required prior to collecting a blood sample; follow any instructions that you are given.

Phospholipid Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the presence of blood clots or an unexpectedly prolonged PTT (partial thromboplastin time), especially if you have had recurrent miscarriages; as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS); sometimes to help diagnose or evaluate an autoimmune disorder
Phospholipid Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have an unexplained prolonged PTT test; when you have had recurrent unexplained blood clots; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters
Phospholipid Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Phosphorus.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the level of phosphorus in your blood and to aid in the diagnosis of conditions known to cause abnormally high or low levels of phosphorus
Phosphorus.When To Get Tested?: In follow up to an abnormal calcium level; when you have a kidney disorder or uncontrolled diabetes; when you are taking calcium or phosphate supplements
Phosphorus.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm. If a timed urine sample is required, you will be asked to save all of your urine over a set time period (usually 24 hours).
Phosphorus.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting may be required prior to collecting a blood sample; follow any instructions that you are given.

PIVKA II (protein induced by vitamin K a.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate effectiveness of treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), a type of liver cancer, if the level of des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin is elevated prior to treatment; to monitor for recurrence of HCC
PIVKA II (protein induced by vitamin K a.When To Get Tested?: Periodically when you have been treated for HCC
PIVKA II (protein induced by vitamin K a.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PLAC.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD), including your risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) and ischemic stroke
PLAC.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider determines that you are at a moderate to high risk of developing CVD or of having an ischemic stroke; when you have a family history of CVD or CHD
PLAC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Plasma Cholinesterase.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
Plasma Cholinesterase.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
Plasma Cholinesterase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Plasma Fibrinogen.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of a possible bleeding disorder or blood clot (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; sometimes used to help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Plasma Fibrinogen.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged; when you have a relative with a hereditary fibrinogen deficiency or abnormality; when your health care provider wants additional information to help evaluate your risk of developing heart disease
Plasma Fibrinogen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Plasma Free Metanephrines.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Plasma Free Metanephrines.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of increased catecholamines release such as sudden bursts (paroxysms) of high blood pressure (hypertension), severe headaches, rapid heart rate (palpitations), sweating, and tremors; when hypertension does not respond to standard treatment; when the signs and symptoms occur in a relatively young person (younger than age 40) and when there is a family history of hypertension; when a health practitioner suspects you may have a tumor that is releasing or may release excess catecholamines
Plasma Free Metanephrines.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Plasma Free Metanephrines.Test Preparation Needed?:
Blood for plasma metanephrine testing is collected by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm. Although you may be seated for the collection, it is recommended that you be lying down. The healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.
These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection.

Plasma Ketones.Why Get Tested?: To determine the amount of ketones (ketone bodies, acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood to help diagnose a life-threatening problem called diabetic ketoacidosis
Plasma Ketones.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with ketoacidosis, such as increased urination, excessive thirst, dehydration, rapid breathing, and shortness of breath
Plasma Ketones.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

Plasma Metanephrines.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Plasma Metanephrines.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of increased catecholamines release such as sudden bursts (paroxysms) of high blood pressure (hypertension), severe headaches, rapid heart rate (palpitations), sweating, and tremors; when hypertension does not respond to standard treatment; when the signs and symptoms occur in a relatively young person (younger than age 40) and when there is a family history of hypertension; when a health practitioner suspects you may have a tumor that is releasing or may release excess catecholamines
Plasma Metanephrines.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Plasma Metanephrines.Test Preparation Needed?:
Blood for plasma metanephrine testing is collected by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm. Although you may be seated for the collection, it is recommended that you be lying down. The healthcare provider or the collection site will instruct you as to their specific requirements.
These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection.

Plasma Total Homocysteine.Why Get Tested?: To help determine if you are deficient in vitamins B6, B9 (folate) or B12; to determine if you are at increased risk of heart attack or stroke; to monitor those who have heart disease; sometimes to help diagnose a rare inherited disorder called homocystinuria in newborns
Plasma Total Homocysteine.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that you have a vitamin B6, B12 or folate deficiency; when you have had a heart attack or stroke and do not have traditional risk factors, such as unhealthy lipid levels
Plasma Total Homocysteine.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken by needle from a vein
Plasma Total Homocysteine.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 10 to 12 hours prior to this test; only water is permitted.

Platelet Aggregation Studies.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of or potential for excessive bleeding and/or to diagnose a platelet function disorder; to monitor and evaluate platelet function; to monitor the presence and effectiveness of anti-platelet medications
Platelet Aggregation Studies.When To Get Tested?: When you bruise easily or experience excessive or prolonged bleeding from minor cuts, nose or gums, or excessive menstrual bleeding; when you are taking medications that can alter platelet function; prior to or during certain surgeries; if you have a family member with a history of excessive bleeding
Platelet Aggregation Studies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Platelet Aggregation Studies.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to refrain from taking drugs that can affect the results of these tests, such as aspirin, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), or any over-the-counter medications that contain drugs such as these, anti-histamines, and certain antibiotics. The most common NSAIDs include ibuprofen, naproxen and COX-2 inhibitors. However, do not stop taking your medications unless instructed to do so by your healthcare practitioner.

Platelet Count.Why Get Tested?: To determine the number of platelets in a sample of your blood as part of a health exam; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect the number of platelets, such as a bleeding disorder, a bone marrow disease, or other underlying condition
Platelet Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine complete blood count (CBC); when you have episodes of unexplained or prolonged bleeding or other symptoms that may be due to a platelet disorder
Platelet Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Platelet Distribution Width.Why Get Tested?: To determine the number of platelets in a sample of your blood as part of a health exam; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect the number of platelets, such as a bleeding disorder, a bone marrow disease, or other underlying condition
Platelet Distribution Width.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine complete blood count (CBC); when you have episodes of unexplained or prolonged bleeding or other symptoms that may be due to a platelet disorder
Platelet Distribution Width.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Platelet Function Assay.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of or potential for excessive bleeding and/or to diagnose a platelet function disorder; to monitor and evaluate platelet function; to monitor the presence and effectiveness of anti-platelet medications
Platelet Function Assay.When To Get Tested?: When you bruise easily or experience excessive or prolonged bleeding from minor cuts, nose or gums, or excessive menstrual bleeding; when you are taking medications that can alter platelet function; prior to or during certain surgeries; if you have a family member with a history of excessive bleeding
Platelet Function Assay.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Platelet Function Assay.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to refrain from taking drugs that can affect the results of these tests, such as aspirin, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), or any over-the-counter medications that contain drugs such as these, anti-histamines, and certain antibiotics. The most common NSAIDs include ibuprofen, naproxen and COX-2 inhibitors. However, do not stop taking your medications unless instructed to do so by your healthcare practitioner.

Platelet Function Tests.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of or potential for excessive bleeding and/or to diagnose a platelet function disorder; to monitor and evaluate platelet function; to monitor the presence and effectiveness of anti-platelet medications
Platelet Function Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you bruise easily or experience excessive or prolonged bleeding from minor cuts, nose or gums, or excessive menstrual bleeding; when you are taking medications that can alter platelet function; prior to or during certain surgeries; if you have a family member with a history of excessive bleeding
Platelet Function Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Platelet Function Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to refrain from taking drugs that can affect the results of these tests, such as aspirin, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), or any over-the-counter medications that contain drugs such as these, anti-histamines, and certain antibiotics. The most common NSAIDs include ibuprofen, naproxen and COX-2 inhibitors. However, do not stop taking your medications unless instructed to do so by your healthcare practitioner.

Platelet-activating Factor Acetylhydrola.Why Get Tested?: To help determine your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD), including your risk of coronary heart disease (CHD) and ischemic stroke
Platelet-activating Factor Acetylhydrola.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider determines that you are at a moderate to high risk of developing CVD or of having an ischemic stroke; when you have a family history of CVD or CHD
Platelet-activating Factor Acetylhydrola.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Pleural Fluid Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of accumulation of fluid in the chest cavity (pleural effusion)
Pleural Fluid Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that someone with chest pain, coughing, and/or difficulty breathing has a condition that is causing an accumulation of fluid in the chest cavity
Pleural Fluid Analysis.Sample Required?: A volume of pleural fluid collected using a procedure called thoracentesis

PLT.Why Get Tested?: To determine the number of platelets in a sample of your blood as part of a health exam; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect the number of platelets, such as a bleeding disorder, a bone marrow disease, or other underlying condition
PLT.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine complete blood count (CBC); when you have episodes of unexplained or prolonged bleeding or other symptoms that may be due to a platelet disorder
PLT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

PML-RARA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML); to help guide and/or monitor treatment of APL or to monitor for leukemia cells that remain after treatment (minimal residual disease) or for disease recurrence
PML-RARA.When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for APL and/or when you are in remission but need follow up
PML-RARA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration procedure

PML-RARA t(15;17)(q22;q12).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML); to help guide and/or monitor treatment of APL or to monitor for leukemia cells that remain after treatment (minimal residual disease) or for disease recurrence
PML-RARA t(15;17)(q22;q12).When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for APL and/or when you are in remission but need follow up
PML-RARA t(15;17)(q22;q12).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration procedure

PO4.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the level of phosphorus in your blood and to aid in the diagnosis of conditions known to cause abnormally high or low levels of phosphorus
PO4.When To Get Tested?: In follow up to an abnormal calcium level; when you have a kidney disorder or uncontrolled diabetes; when you are taking calcium or phosphate supplements
PO4.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm. If a timed urine sample is required, you will be asked to save all of your urine over a set time period (usually 24 hours).
PO4.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting may be required prior to collecting a blood sample; follow any instructions that you are given.

Poison Testing.Why Get Tested?: To detect, quantify, and occasionally monitor drugs that are causing acute overdose symptoms; results from emergency and overdose testing are used primarily for treatment purposes; if results are needed for legal proceedings, then specific legal (forensic) procedures must be followed for sample collection, storage, and testing.
Poison Testing.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms such as delirium, difficulty breathing, nausea, agitation, seizures, changes in heart rhythm, characteristic odors, or increased temperature that an emergency room health practitioner thinks may be drug-related; at intervals to monitor a drug overdose
Poison Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva or another body fluid

Porphobilinogen.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
Porphobilinogen.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
Porphobilinogen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
Porphobilinogen.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

Porphyrin Tests.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
Porphyrin Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
Porphyrin Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
Porphyrin Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

Porphyrins.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
Porphyrins.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
Porphyrins.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
Porphyrins.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

Potassium.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether your potassium level is within normal limits; to help evaluate electrolyte balance; to help determine the cause of and monitor treatment for illnesses associated with abnormal potassium levels in the body
Potassium.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as muscle weakness and/or irregular heart beat (cardiac arrhythmia) or when an electrolyte imbalance is suspected; at regular intervals when you are taking a medication and/or have a disease or condition, such as high blood pressure (hypertension) or kidney disease, that can affect your potassium level; as part of a routine medical exam
Potassium.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

Potassium Hydroxide Preparation.Why Get Tested?: To detect a fungal infection, to determine which specific fungus or fungi are present, and to help guide treatment
Potassium Hydroxide Preparation.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have a skin, lung, or systemic fungal infection; sometimes after treatment to monitor its effectiveness
Potassium Hydroxide Preparation.Sample Required?: The sample collected depends upon the suspected location(s) of the infection. Some examples include: scrapings of the skin, nail and hair samples, body fluids, blood, and/or a tissue biopsy.

Potassium, blood or urine.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether your potassium level is within normal limits; to help evaluate electrolyte balance; to help determine the cause of and monitor treatment for illnesses associated with abnormal potassium levels in the body
Potassium, blood or urine.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as muscle weakness and/or irregular heart beat (cardiac arrhythmia) or when an electrolyte imbalance is suspected; at regular intervals when you are taking a medication and/or have a disease or condition, such as high blood pressure (hypertension) or kidney disease, that can affect your potassium level; as part of a routine medical exam
Potassium, blood or urine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

PPD.Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
PPD.When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
PPD.Sample Required?: No sample is required. A small amount of purified protein derivative (PPD) solution is injected with a tuberculin syringe just under the first layer of skin of your inner forearm.

PR3.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
PR3.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
PR3.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PR3-ANCA.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
PR3-ANCA.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
PR3-ANCA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PRA.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your aldosterone and renin levels are abnormal, to help diagnose a hormonal (endocrine) disorder such as primary aldosteronism (PA, Conn syndrome)
PRA.When To Get Tested?: When you develop symptoms or signs associated with increased aldosterone production, such as elevated blood pressure, muscle weakness, and low potassium, or low aldosterone production, such as low blood pressure, high potassium, and low sodium
PRA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes at specialized medical centers, blood from the kidney (renal) or adrenal veins is also collected.
PRA.Test Preparation Needed?: For a blood aldosterone and renin measurement, the healthcare practitioner may ask you to be upright or lying down (e.g., for 15-30 minutes) prior to drawing blood. You may also be instructed to avoid certain foods, beverages, or medications before the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

Prealbumin.Why Get Tested?: Reasons for ordering the prealbumin test are undergoing reassessment as understanding of prealbumin is evolving. Historically, prealbumin has been ordered to help detect protein-calorie malnutrition and to monitor the effectiveness of parenteral (for example, intravenous) nutrition. Newer evidence suggests that the reasons for changes in prealbumin levels may be more complex and the test should not be interpreted as a simple indicator of nutritional status.
Prealbumin.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested, although prealbumin may be ordered, along with assessments of nutritional intake, when a healthcare practitioner suspects that someone is malnourished or is at risk of malnutrition.
Prealbumin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Pregnancy Test.Why Get Tested?: To confirm a pregnancy; to help identify an ectopic pregnancy; to monitor a pregnancy that may be at risk of failing; occasionally to screen a woman for pregnancy prior to some medical treatments; as part of a panel of tests used to screen for fetal abnormalities (see First Trimester Down Syndrome Screen and Second Trimester Maternal Serum Screening)
Pregnancy Test.When To Get Tested?: When you suspect that you are pregnant (testing can be done reliably by 10 days after you miss your menstrual period and some methods can detect hCG even earlier); when you have signs and symptoms that suggest you may have an ectopic pregnancy or a pregnancy that is failing; prior to some medical treatments
Pregnancy Test.Sample Required?: A urine sample collected first thing in the morning or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Pregnancy Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Do not drink large amounts of fluid before collecting a urine sample for a pregnancy test because overly diluted urine may result in a false negative; no preparation is needed for a blood sample.

Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (P.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of your baby having a chromosome disorder, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18)
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (P.When To Get Tested?: Usually between 11 and 14 weeks of pregnancy
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (P.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a blood spot collected on special paper from a finger stick; a nuchal translucency requires a special ultrasound exam.
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (P.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have a full bladder when having the nuchal translucency ultrasound performed.

Pregnenolone.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and monitor treatment for rare types of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH); sometimes to help rule out other conditions
Pregnenolone.When To Get Tested?: When an infant has external sex organs that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) and/or has high blood pressure (hypertension), low blood potassium (hypokalemia), or signs of excess loss of salt (salt wasting); when the most common cause for CAH, a 21-hydroxylase deficiency, has been ruled out; when a teen fails to develop secondary sexual characteristics and/or has delayed puberty
Pregnenolone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Prenatal Group B Strep (GBS) Screening.Why Get Tested?: To screen a pregnant woman for the presence of group B streptococcus (GBS) in her vagina or rectum to determine the risk that she will pass the bacteria on to her newborn during labor and delivery, possibly resulting in a serious infection in her newborn called early-onset GBS
Prenatal Group B Strep (GBS) Screening.When To Get Tested?: When a woman is between 35 and 37 weeks of pregnancy or has preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes
Prenatal Group B Strep (GBS) Screening.Sample Required?: A swab obtained from the vagina and rectum of a pregnant woman; a urine sample collected anytime during pregnancy may be used to detect significant numbers of GBS.

Prenatal Group B Streptococcus Screening.Why Get Tested?: To screen a pregnant woman for the presence of group B streptococcus (GBS) in her vagina or rectum to determine the risk that she will pass the bacteria on to her newborn during labor and delivery, possibly resulting in a serious infection in her newborn called early-onset GBS
Prenatal Group B Streptococcus Screening.When To Get Tested?: When a woman is between 35 and 37 weeks of pregnancy or has preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes
Prenatal Group B Streptococcus Screening.Sample Required?: A swab obtained from the vagina and rectum of a pregnant woman; a urine sample collected anytime during pregnancy may be used to detect significant numbers of GBS.

Presenilin 1 Gene.Why Get Tested?: To screen for a rare mutation in the PSEN1 gene known to be associated with early onset familial Alzheimer disease (EOFAD, also called Alzheimer disease type 3 or AD3)
Presenilin 1 Gene.When To Get Tested?: When you are an adult who has symptoms of dementia and a strong family history of Alzheimer disease that begins before age 60-65 or if you are an asymptomatic adult with a family member who has early onset Alzheimer disease and an identified PSEN1 genetic mutation
Presenilin 1 Gene.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PRL.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate unexplained flow of breast milk (galactorrhea), abnormal nipple discharge, absence of menstrual periods, and/or infertility in women; in men, to help diagnose the cause of decreased libido and/or erectile dysfunction; to detect and monitor a prolactin-producing pituitary tumor (prolactinoma)
PRL.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of elevated prolactin, such as galactorrhea and/or visual disturbances and headaches; during a workup for infertility; for follow-up of low testosterone in men; periodically to monitor for recurrence of a prolactinoma
PRL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
PRL.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, the sample should be collected 3 to 4 hours after waking.

Pro Time.Why Get Tested?: A prothrombin time (PT) is a test used to help detect and diagnose a bleeding disorder or excessive clotting disorder; the international normalized ratio (INR) is calculated from a PT result and is used to monitor how well the blood-thinning medication (anticoagulant) warfarin (Coumadin®) is working to prevent blood clots.
Pro Time.When To Get Tested?: When you are taking warfarin or when you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding or inappropriate blood clotting
Pro Time.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes blood from a fingerstick
Pro Time.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed, although if you are receiving anticoagulant therapy, the specimen should be collected before taking your daily dose.

proBNP.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and evaluate the severity of congestive heart failure (CHF)
proBNP.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of heart failure, such as shortness of breath and fatigue, or when you are being treated for CHF
proBNP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Procalcitonin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose sepsis if you are critically ill and to help determine your risk of progressing to severe sepsis and septic shock; to help identify serious bacterial infections and to distinguish between bacterial and non-bacterial conditions; to help guide antibiotic treatment
Procalcitonin.When To Get Tested?: When you are seriously ill and have signs and symptoms of a systemic infection or sepsis; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to a bacterial infection and your healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether antibiotics would be effective; at intervals to monitor effectiveness of antibiotic treatment
Procalcitonin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Procollagen Type 1 N-Terminal Propeptide.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Procollagen Type 1 N-Terminal Propeptide.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Procollagen Type 1 N-Terminal Propeptide.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Procollagen Type 1 N-Terminal Propeptide.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Progesterone.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of infertility, track ovulation, help diagnose an ectopic or failing pregnancy, monitor the health of a pregnancy, monitor progesterone replacement therapy, or help diagnose the cause of abnormal uterine bleeding
Progesterone.When To Get Tested?: At specific times during a woman's menstrual cycle to determine whether/when she is ovulating (releasing an egg from an ovary); during early pregnancy when symptoms suggest an ectopic or failing pregnancy; throughout a high-risk pregnancy to help determine placenta and fetal health; periodically when a person is receiving progesterone replacement therapy; when a woman has abnormal uterine bleeding
Progesterone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Progesterone.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but for women, the date of your last menstrual period or trimester of pregnancy should be noted.

Progesterone Receptors.Why Get Tested?: The hormone receptor test determines if a breast cancer tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, helping to guide treatment and determine prognosis
Progesterone Receptors.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with invasive breast cancer or when your cancer has recurred
Progesterone Receptors.Sample Required?: A sample of breast cancer tissue obtained during a biopsy or a tumor removed surgically during a lumpectomy or mastectomy
Progesterone Receptors.Test Preparation Needed?: Your health practitioner may have you discontinue taking hormones for a time period before your sample is collected.

Proinsulin C-peptide.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate insulin production by the beta cells in the pancreas or to help determine the cause of low blood glucose (hypoglycemia)
Proinsulin C-peptide.When To Get Tested?: When you have diabetes and your health practitioner wants to determine if you are producing enough of your own insulin or if it is time to supplement oral medication with insulin injections or an insulin pump; when your health practitioner suspects that you have insulin resistance; when you have documented hypoglycemia
Proinsulin C-peptide.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and sometimes a 24-hour urine sample
Proinsulin C-peptide.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting for 8 to 10 hours before blood testing is usually required.

Prolactin.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate unexplained flow of breast milk (galactorrhea), abnormal nipple discharge, absence of menstrual periods, and/or infertility in women; in men, to help diagnose the cause of decreased libido and/or erectile dysfunction; to detect and monitor a prolactin-producing pituitary tumor (prolactinoma)
Prolactin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of elevated prolactin, such as galactorrhea and/or visual disturbances and headaches; during a workup for infertility; for follow-up of low testosterone in men; periodically to monitor for recurrence of a prolactinoma
Prolactin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Prolactin.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, the sample should be collected 3 to 4 hours after waking.

Promyelocytic Leukemia/Retinoic Acid Rec.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML); to help guide and/or monitor treatment of APL or to monitor for leukemia cells that remain after treatment (minimal residual disease) or for disease recurrence
Promyelocytic Leukemia/Retinoic Acid Rec.When To Get Tested?: When you have results of a complete blood count (CBC) and/or signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have leukemia; periodically when you are being treated for APL and/or when you are in remission but need follow up
Promyelocytic Leukemia/Retinoic Acid Rec.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a bone marrow sample collected using a bone marrow aspiration procedure

Prostate Cancer Antigen 3.Why Get Tested?: To help determine if a repeat prostate biopsy is indicated to help detect prostate cancer
Prostate Cancer Antigen 3.Sample Required?: The first amount of urine collected after a healthcare practitioner performs a digital rectal exam (DRE)

Prostate Specific Antigen.Why Get Tested?: To screen men for prostate cancer, to help determine the necessity for a biopsy of the prostate, to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for prostate cancer, and/or to detect recurrence of prostate cancer
Prostate Specific Antigen.When To Get Tested?: When a man has symptoms suggestive of prostate cancer such as difficult, painful, and/or frequent urination; may also be ordered during and at regular intervals after prostate cancer treatment; in asymptomatic men, after a discussion with your healthcare provider about the benefits and harms of screening and you make an informed decision to undergo screening (For specific details, see prostate cancer screening for Adults and Adults 50 and Up).
Prostate Specific Antigen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Prostate Specific Antigen.Test Preparation Needed?: Avoid ejaculation for 24 hours before sample collection as it has been associated with elevated PSA levels; the sample should also be collected prior to your health practitioner performing a digital rectal exam (DRE) and prior to (or several weeks after) a prostate biopsy.

Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA).Why Get Tested?: To screen men for prostate cancer, to help determine the necessity for a biopsy of the prostate, to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for prostate cancer, and/or to detect recurrence of prostate cancer
Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA).When To Get Tested?: When a man has symptoms suggestive of prostate cancer such as difficult, painful, and/or frequent urination; may also be ordered during and at regular intervals after prostate cancer treatment; in asymptomatic men, after a discussion with your healthcare provider about the benefits and harms of screening and you make an informed decision to undergo screening (For specific details, see prostate cancer screening for Adults and Adults 50 and Up).
Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA).Test Preparation Needed?: Avoid ejaculation for 24 hours before sample collection as it has been associated with elevated PSA levels; the sample should also be collected prior to your health practitioner performing a digital rectal exam (DRE) and prior to (or several weeks after) a prostate biopsy.

Protein C Activity.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or thromboembolism); to determine whether you may have a protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein C Activity.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot; when your newborn has a severe clotting disorder; sometimes when a close relative has an inherited protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein C Activity.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Protein C Activity.Test Preparation Needed?: You must wait at least 10 days after a thrombotic episode and be off oral warfarin (Coumadin®) anticoagulant therapy for 2 weeks before having this test done. (See also Common Questions #1.)

Protein C and Protein S.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or thromboembolism); to determine whether you may have a protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein C and Protein S.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot; when your newborn has a severe clotting disorder; sometimes when a close relative has an inherited protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein C and Protein S.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Protein C and Protein S.Test Preparation Needed?: You must wait at least 10 days after a thrombotic episode and be off oral warfarin (Coumadin®) anticoagulant therapy for 2 weeks before having this test done. (See also Common Questions #1.)

Protein C Level.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or thromboembolism); to determine whether you may have a protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein C Level.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot; when your newborn has a severe clotting disorder; sometimes when a close relative has an inherited protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein C Level.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Protein C Level.Test Preparation Needed?: You must wait at least 10 days after a thrombotic episode and be off oral warfarin (Coumadin®) anticoagulant therapy for 2 weeks before having this test done. (See also Common Questions #1.)

Protein C, Functional or Antigen; Protei.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or thromboembolism); to determine whether you may have a protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein C, Functional or Antigen; Protei.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot; when your newborn has a severe clotting disorder; sometimes when a close relative has an inherited protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein C, Functional or Antigen; Protei.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Protein C, Functional or Antigen; Protei.Test Preparation Needed?: You must wait at least 10 days after a thrombotic episode and be off oral warfarin (Coumadin®) anticoagulant therapy for 2 weeks before having this test done. (See also Common Questions #1.)

Protein Electrophoresis Immunofixation E.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
Protein Electrophoresis Immunofixation E.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
Protein Electrophoresis Immunofixation E.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Protein Electrophoresis; Immunofixation.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
Protein Electrophoresis; Immunofixation.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
Protein Electrophoresis; Immunofixation.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Protein ELP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
Protein ELP.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
Protein ELP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Protein S Activity.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or thromboembolism); to determine whether you may have a protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein S Activity.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot; when your newborn has a severe clotting disorder; sometimes when a close relative has an inherited protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein S Activity.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Protein S Activity.Test Preparation Needed?: You must wait at least 10 days after a thrombotic episode and be off oral warfarin (Coumadin®) anticoagulant therapy for 2 weeks before having this test done. (See also Common Questions #1.)

Protein S Level.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or thromboembolism); to determine whether you may have a protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein S Level.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot; when your newborn has a severe clotting disorder; sometimes when a close relative has an inherited protein C or protein S deficiency
Protein S Level.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Protein S Level.Test Preparation Needed?: You must wait at least 10 days after a thrombotic episode and be off oral warfarin (Coumadin®) anticoagulant therapy for 2 weeks before having this test done. (See also Common Questions #1.)

Proteinase 3 Antibodies.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
Proteinase 3 Antibodies.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
Proteinase 3 Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Prothrombin Time and International Norma.Why Get Tested?: A prothrombin time (PT) is a test used to help detect and diagnose a bleeding disorder or excessive clotting disorder; the international normalized ratio (INR) is calculated from a PT result and is used to monitor how well the blood-thinning medication (anticoagulant) warfarin (Coumadin®) is working to prevent blood clots.
Prothrombin Time and International Norma.When To Get Tested?: When you are taking warfarin or when you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding or inappropriate blood clotting
Prothrombin Time and International Norma.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes blood from a fingerstick
Prothrombin Time and International Norma.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed, although if you are receiving anticoagulant therapy, the specimen should be collected before taking your daily dose.

Prothrombin Time and International Norma.Why Get Tested?: A prothrombin time (PT) is a test used to help detect and diagnose a bleeding disorder or excessive clotting disorder; the international normalized ratio (INR) is calculated from a PT result and is used to monitor how well the blood-thinning medication (anticoagulant) warfarin (Coumadin®) is working to prevent blood clots.
Prothrombin Time and International Norma.When To Get Tested?: When you are taking warfarin or when you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding or inappropriate blood clotting
Prothrombin Time and International Norma.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes blood from a fingerstick
Prothrombin Time and International Norma.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed, although if you are receiving anticoagulant therapy, the specimen should be collected before taking your daily dose.

Protime.Why Get Tested?: A prothrombin time (PT) is a test used to help detect and diagnose a bleeding disorder or excessive clotting disorder; the international normalized ratio (INR) is calculated from a PT result and is used to monitor how well the blood-thinning medication (anticoagulant) warfarin (Coumadin®) is working to prevent blood clots.
Protime.When To Get Tested?: When you are taking warfarin or when you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding or inappropriate blood clotting
Protime.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes blood from a fingerstick
Protime.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed, although if you are receiving anticoagulant therapy, the specimen should be collected before taking your daily dose.

Protoporphyrin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
Protoporphyrin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
Protoporphyrin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
Protoporphyrin.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

PS1.Why Get Tested?: To screen for a rare mutation in the PSEN1 gene known to be associated with early onset familial Alzheimer disease (EOFAD, also called Alzheimer disease type 3 or AD3)
PS1.When To Get Tested?: When you are an adult who has symptoms of dementia and a strong family history of Alzheimer disease that begins before age 60-65 or if you are an asymptomatic adult with a family member who has early onset Alzheimer disease and an identified PSEN1 genetic mutation
PS1.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PS1 or PSEN1 Genetic Mutation Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To screen for a rare mutation in the PSEN1 gene known to be associated with early onset familial Alzheimer disease (EOFAD, also called Alzheimer disease type 3 or AD3)
PS1 or PSEN1 Genetic Mutation Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When you are an adult who has symptoms of dementia and a strong family history of Alzheimer disease that begins before age 60-65 or if you are an asymptomatic adult with a family member who has early onset Alzheimer disease and an identified PSEN1 genetic mutation
PS1 or PSEN1 Genetic Mutation Analysis.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PSEN1.Why Get Tested?: To screen for a rare mutation in the PSEN1 gene known to be associated with early onset familial Alzheimer disease (EOFAD, also called Alzheimer disease type 3 or AD3)
PSEN1.When To Get Tested?: When you are an adult who has symptoms of dementia and a strong family history of Alzheimer disease that begins before age 60-65 or if you are an asymptomatic adult with a family member who has early onset Alzheimer disease and an identified PSEN1 genetic mutation
PSEN1.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Pseudocholinesterase.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
Pseudocholinesterase.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
Pseudocholinesterase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PT.Why Get Tested?: A prothrombin time (PT) is a test used to help detect and diagnose a bleeding disorder or excessive clotting disorder; the international normalized ratio (INR) is calculated from a PT result and is used to monitor how well the blood-thinning medication (anticoagulant) warfarin (Coumadin®) is working to prevent blood clots.
PT.When To Get Tested?: When you are taking warfarin or when you have unexplained or prolonged bleeding or inappropriate blood clotting
PT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes blood from a fingerstick
PT.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed, although if you are receiving anticoagulant therapy, the specimen should be collected before taking your daily dose.

PT G20210A.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an inherited gene mutation that increases your risk of developing a blood clot, including a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and/or venous thromboembolism (VTE)
PT G20210A.When To Get Tested?: When you have had an unexplained blood clot (thrombotic episode), especially when you are less than 50 years old, have recurrent DVT or VTE episodes, experienced DVT or VTE during pregnancy, had DVT at unusual sites, or have a strong family history of thrombosis
PT G20210A.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

PTT-LA.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate the cause of a blood clot (thrombotic episode); to evaluate a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriages, or as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome; the tests are not used to diagnose the chronic autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), commonly known as lupus.
PTT-LA.When To Get Tested?: When you have had signs and symptoms of a blood clot in a vein or artery (known as thrombosis or thromboembolism); when you have a prolonged PTT test of unknown cause; when you have had recurrent miscarriages
PTT-LA.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm

Purified Protein Derivative.Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
Purified Protein Derivative.When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
Purified Protein Derivative.Sample Required?: No sample is required. A small amount of purified protein derivative (PPD) solution is injected with a tuberculin syringe just under the first layer of skin of your inner forearm.

Pyridinium Crosslinks.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Pyridinium Crosslinks.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Pyridinium Crosslinks.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Pyridinium Crosslinks.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

pyridoxal phosphate (B6).Why Get Tested?: To screen for and detect moderate to severe vitamin B deficiencies
pyridoxal phosphate (B6).When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that may be due to a B vitamin deficiency, are at risk for a deficiency, or have a condition associated with malabsorption
pyridoxal phosphate (B6).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a random or 24-hour urine sample may also be collected.
pyridoxal phosphate (B6).Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is usually required for blood testing.

Quad Screen.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
Quad Screen.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
Quad Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Quadruple Marker Test.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
Quadruple Marker Test.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
Quadruple Marker Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Qualitative hCG.Why Get Tested?: To confirm a pregnancy; to help identify an ectopic pregnancy; to monitor a pregnancy that may be at risk of failing; occasionally to screen a woman for pregnancy prior to some medical treatments; as part of a panel of tests used to screen for fetal abnormalities (see First Trimester Down Syndrome Screen and Second Trimester Maternal Serum Screening)
Qualitative hCG.When To Get Tested?: When you suspect that you are pregnant (testing can be done reliably by 10 days after you miss your menstrual period and some methods can detect hCG even earlier); when you have signs and symptoms that suggest you may have an ectopic pregnancy or a pregnancy that is failing; prior to some medical treatments
Qualitative hCG.Sample Required?: A urine sample collected first thing in the morning or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Qualitative hCG.Test Preparation Needed?: Do not drink large amounts of fluid before collecting a urine sample for a pregnancy test because overly diluted urine may result in a false negative; no preparation is needed for a blood sample.

Qualitative or Quantitative Stool Fat.Why Get Tested?: To detect and measure excess fat in the stool; to help diagnose conditions causing malabsorption
Qualitative or Quantitative Stool Fat.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
Qualitative or Quantitative Stool Fat.Sample Required?: A random stool collection; sometimes a 72-hour stool collection
Qualitative or Quantitative Stool Fat.Test Preparation Needed?: For a 72-hour stool collection, follow your healthcare practitioner's instructions; this may include consuming 50-150 grams of fat a day in your diet for 2-3 days prior to and during the stool collection period.

QuantiFERON®-TB Gold In-Tube (QFT-GIT).Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
QuantiFERON®-TB Gold In-Tube (QFT-GIT).When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
QuantiFERON®-TB Gold In-Tube (QFT-GIT).Sample Required?: A blood sample is drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

QuantiFERON®-TB Gold Plus (QFT-Plus).Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
QuantiFERON®-TB Gold Plus (QFT-Plus).When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
QuantiFERON®-TB Gold Plus (QFT-Plus).Sample Required?: A blood sample is drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

Quantitative hCG.Why Get Tested?: To confirm a pregnancy; to help identify an ectopic pregnancy; to monitor a pregnancy that may be at risk of failing; occasionally to screen a woman for pregnancy prior to some medical treatments; as part of a panel of tests used to screen for fetal abnormalities (see First Trimester Down Syndrome Screen and Second Trimester Maternal Serum Screening)
Quantitative hCG.When To Get Tested?: When you suspect that you are pregnant (testing can be done reliably by 10 days after you miss your menstrual period and some methods can detect hCG even earlier); when you have signs and symptoms that suggest you may have an ectopic pregnancy or a pregnancy that is failing; prior to some medical treatments
Quantitative hCG.Sample Required?: A urine sample collected first thing in the morning or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Quantitative hCG.Test Preparation Needed?: Do not drink large amounts of fluid before collecting a urine sample for a pregnancy test because overly diluted urine may result in a false negative; no preparation is needed for a blood sample.

Quantitative IgE.Why Get Tested?: To screen for an allergic disease; sometimes to screen for a parasitic infection
Quantitative IgE.When To Get Tested?: When you have periodic or persistent skin, lung, or digestive symptoms that suggest allergies; when a healthcare practitioner suspects a parasitic infection
Quantitative IgE.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Quantitative Serum Free Light Chains wit.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and monitor plasma cell disorders (dyscrasias) such as multiple myeloma, primary amyloidosis, and related diseases or to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Quantitative Serum Free Light Chains wit.When To Get Tested?: When you have bone pain, fractures, anemia (with normal size and shape red blood cells (normocytic)), kidney disease, and recurrent infections that your healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a plasma cell disorder; when you are being treated for a plasma cell disorder
Quantitative Serum Free Light Chains wit.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Rapamycin.Why Get Tested?: To determine the level of sirolimus in the blood in order to establish a dosing regimen, maintain therapeutic levels, and detect toxic levels
Rapamycin.When To Get Tested?: As soon as sirolimus therapy begins and whenever dose is changed; frequently at first, then at regular intervals to monitor concentrations over time; whenever excess or deficient levels are suspected
Rapamycin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Rapamycin.Test Preparation Needed?: None; the sample is typically collected 12 hours after the last dose and immediately prior to the next dose, or as directed by your healthcare provider

Rapid Antigen Detection Test (RADT).Why Get Tested?: To determine if your sore throat is "strep throat" that is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) bacteria
Rapid Antigen Detection Test (RADT).When To Get Tested?: When you have a sore throat that starts quickly and lasts more than a week and/or other symptoms such as a fever of 101° F or higher, or reddened throat and/or tonsils with white or yellow patches or streaks
Rapid Antigen Detection Test (RADT).Sample Required?: A swab rubbed against the back of your throat and tonsils

Rapid Flu Test.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an influenza infection (flu), especially if you are hospitalized, have a weakened immune system, or are otherwise at an increased risk of serious complications from influenza; to help your healthcare practitioner make treatment decisions; to help determine whether or not the flu has spread to your community
Rapid Flu Test.When To Get Tested?: When it is flu season and a healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether your symptoms are due to seasonal influenza A or B or to another cause; within 3 to 4 days of the onset of signs and symptoms, such as fever, headache, muscle aches, sore throat, weakness, fatigue, cough, sore throat, stuffy nose and sometimes runny nose
Rapid Flu Test.Sample Required?: Depending on the test used, a respiratory sample collected on a swab from the nasopharynx or a nasal aspirate; sometimes, a nasal or throat swab

Rapid Influenza Diagnostic Test.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether or not you have an influenza infection (flu), especially if you are hospitalized, have a weakened immune system, or are otherwise at an increased risk of serious complications from influenza; to help your healthcare practitioner make treatment decisions; to help determine whether or not the flu has spread to your community
Rapid Influenza Diagnostic Test.When To Get Tested?: When it is flu season and a healthcare practitioner wants to determine whether your symptoms are due to seasonal influenza A or B or to another cause; within 3 to 4 days of the onset of signs and symptoms, such as fever, headache, muscle aches, sore throat, weakness, fatigue, cough, sore throat, stuffy nose and sometimes runny nose
Rapid Influenza Diagnostic Test.Sample Required?: Depending on the test used, a respiratory sample collected on a swab from the nasopharynx or a nasal aspirate; sometimes, a nasal or throat swab

Rapid Plasma Reagin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Rapid Plasma Reagin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Rapid Plasma Reagin.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Rapid Strep Test.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your sore throat is "strep throat" that is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) bacteria
Rapid Strep Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have a sore throat that starts quickly and lasts more than a week and/or other symptoms such as a fever of 101° F or higher, or reddened throat and/or tonsils with white or yellow patches or streaks
Rapid Strep Test.Sample Required?: A swab rubbed against the back of your throat and tonsils

Rapid urease test (RUT) for H. pylori.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with Helicobacter pylori, bacteria that can cause peptic ulcers
Rapid urease test (RUT) for H. pylori.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an ulcer, such as gastrointestinal pain that comes and goes, unexplained weight loss, nausea and/or vomiting
Rapid urease test (RUT) for H. pylori.Sample Required?: A stool sample, a breath sample, or a tissue biopsy of the stomach lining
Rapid urease test (RUT) for H. pylori.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to avoid certain medications; follow any instructions you are given.

RBC Ab ID.Why Get Tested?: To identify the specific antibody detected by a direct antiglobulin test (DAT) or RBC antibody screen; to help identify the cause of a transfusion reaction, hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), or hemolytic anemia
