RBC Ab ID.When To Get Tested?: When a DAT or RBC antibody screen is positive; when a transfusion reaction is suspected or when a newborn has HDN
RBC Ab ID.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

RBC Cholinesterase.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
RBC Cholinesterase.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
RBC Cholinesterase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

RBC Count.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the number of red blood cells (RBCs); used to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions affecting red blood cells
RBC Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), during a health examination, or when you have signs and symptoms of a condition such as anemia or polycythemia
RBC Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

RBC Folate.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose one cause of anemia or neuropathy; to evaluate nutritional status in some people; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
RBC Folate.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal complete blood count (CBC) with a blood smear showing large red blood cells (macrocytosis) or abnormal (hypersegmented) neutrophils; when you have symptoms of anemia (weakness, tiredness, pale skin) and/or of neuropathy (tingling or itching sensations, eye twitching, memory loss, altered mental status); when you are being treated for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
RBC Folate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
RBC Folate.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting for 6-8 hours before sample collection may be required. Certain medicines may affect the test results; your healthcare provider will advise you on which ones to stop taking.

RBC G6PD test.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an inherited G6PD deficiency
RBC G6PD test.When To Get Tested?: When a child experienced persistent jaundice as a newborn for unknown reasons; when you have had one or more intermittent bouts of hemolytic anemia that may be triggered by an infection or certain medications
RBC G6PD test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, by fingerstick, or by heelstick (newborns)
RBC G6PD test.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally, none; however, if symptoms are acute, it is advised that you wait to be tested for at least several weeks after the episode has resolved.

Red Blood Cell (RBC) Antibody Identifica.Why Get Tested?: To identify the specific antibody detected by a direct antiglobulin test (DAT) or RBC antibody screen; to help identify the cause of a transfusion reaction, hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), or hemolytic anemia
Red Blood Cell (RBC) Antibody Identifica.When To Get Tested?: When a DAT or RBC antibody screen is positive; when a transfusion reaction is suspected or when a newborn has HDN
Red Blood Cell (RBC) Antibody Identifica.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Red Blood Cell (RBC) Antibody Screen.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies directed against red blood cell antigens
Red Blood Cell (RBC) Antibody Screen.When To Get Tested?: When preparing for a blood transfusion; during pregnancy and at delivery
Red Blood Cell (RBC) Antibody Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Red Blood Cell Antibody Identification.Why Get Tested?: To identify the specific antibody detected by a direct antiglobulin test (DAT) or RBC antibody screen; to help identify the cause of a transfusion reaction, hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN), or hemolytic anemia
Red Blood Cell Antibody Identification.When To Get Tested?: When a DAT or RBC antibody screen is positive; when a transfusion reaction is suspected or when a newborn has HDN
Red Blood Cell Antibody Identification.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Red Blood Cell Antibody Screen.Why Get Tested?: To detect antibodies directed against red blood cell antigens
Red Blood Cell Antibody Screen.When To Get Tested?: When preparing for a blood transfusion; during pregnancy and at delivery
Red Blood Cell Antibody Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Red Blood Cell Count.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the number of red blood cells (RBCs); used to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions affecting red blood cells
Red Blood Cell Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), during a health examination, or when you have signs and symptoms of a condition such as anemia or polycythemia
Red Blood Cell Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Red Blood Cell Count (RBC).Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the number of red blood cells (RBCs); used to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions affecting red blood cells
Red Blood Cell Count (RBC).When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), during a health examination, or when you have signs and symptoms of a condition such as anemia or polycythemia
Red Blood Cell Count (RBC).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Red Blood Cell Morphology.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate your red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets, to distinguish between the different types of WBCs, and to determine their relative percentages in the blood; to help detect, diagnose, and/or monitor a range of deficiencies, diseases, and disorders involving blood cell production, function, and lifespan
Red Blood Cell Morphology.When To Get Tested?: When complete blood count (CBC) and/or automated WBC differential results are abnormal or when you have signs and symptoms that a healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a condition affecting your blood cells
Red Blood Cell Morphology.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by pricking a finger or, in the case of an infant, a heelstick

Red Cell Cholinesterase.Why Get Tested?:
To determine if you have been exposed to and/or poisoned by certain organophosphate chemicals found in pesticides; to monitor cholinesterase levels if you work with pesticides
Sometimes to identify individuals with inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency before they are given anesthesia with the muscle relaxant succinylcholine or to help determine the cause of prolonged apnea after surgical anesthesia
Red Cell Cholinesterase.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms of pesticide poisoning or on a regular basis when you are at risk of exposure to organophosphates, such as through work in the agriculture industry and/or frequent use of organophosphate insecticides
When you or a close relative have experienced prolonged apnea and muscle paralysis after use of the drug succinylcholine for a surgical operation
Red Cell Cholinesterase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Red Count.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the number of red blood cells (RBCs); used to screen for, help diagnose, or monitor conditions affecting red blood cells
Red Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), during a health examination, or when you have signs and symptoms of a condition such as anemia or polycythemia
Red Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Renal Calculus Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the composition of a kidney stone, to help determine the cause of its formation and to guide treatment
Renal Calculus Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When a stone has passed through or been removed from your urinary tract
Renal Calculus Analysis.Sample Required?: A stone or stones filtered from your urine or surgically removed from your urinary tract by a health practitioner

Renal Function Panel.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and manage conditions affecting kidney function; may be used as part of general health screening or to screen someone who is at risk of developing kidney disease, or to follow someone with known kidney disease
Renal Function Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have a condition affecting the function of your kidneys; when you are being treated for kidney disease; when you have certain risk factors for kidney disease, such as high blood pressure or diabetes
Renal Function Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Renal Function Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 8-12 hours (no food, only water) prior to the test.

Renal Panel.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and manage conditions affecting kidney function; may be used as part of general health screening or to screen someone who is at risk of developing kidney disease, or to follow someone with known kidney disease
Renal Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms that suggest that you may have a condition affecting the function of your kidneys; when you are being treated for kidney disease; when you have certain risk factors for kidney disease, such as high blood pressure or diabetes
Renal Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Renal Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 8-12 hours (no food, only water) prior to the test.

Renal Stone Risk Panel.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's risk of recurring kidney stone formation; to help determine the underlying reason for developing a kidney stone; to determine if there is a family history of kidney stone disease; to help guide and monitor treatment
Renal Stone Risk Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have had kidney stones and a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your risk of developing additional kidney stones; when you have risk factors such as a family history of kidney stones, a single functional kidney, or a transplanted kidney
Renal Stone Risk Panel.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine collection is required for this test. Frequently, two different 24-hour urine samples are collected and tested to determine whether elevated or decreased levels of a substance eliminated in the urine are temporary or persistent. Collection containers with preservative will be provided by your healthcare practitioner or the lab performing the testing.

Respiratory Culture.Why Get Tested?: To detect and identify the cause of bacterial pneumonia or some other lower respiratory tract infections; to monitor the efficacy of treatment
Respiratory Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with a lower respiratory tract infection; when you have been treated for bacterial pneumonia or any other lower respiratory tract infection
Respiratory Culture.Sample Required?: A sputum sample (deep respiratory secretions, not saliva), usually collected first thing in the morning; sometimes, depending on the infection, up to 3 sputum samples might be collected over consecutive days.
Respiratory Culture.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to rinse your mouth out with water prior to collection and to avoid food for 1-2 hours before the sample is collected.

Respiratory Syncytial Virus.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection; to help determine whether or not RSV is circulating in your community
Respiratory Syncytial Virus.When To Get Tested?: When it is RSV season (late fall through early spring in the U.S.) and an infant, an elderly person, or a person with a weakened immune system has a moderate to severe respiratory infection and symptoms such as runny nose, congestion, coughing and/or difficulty breathing
Respiratory Syncytial Virus.Sample Required?: Usually a nasal aspirate or nasal wash; occasionally a nasopharyngeal (NP) swab

Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) Testin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection; to help determine whether or not RSV is circulating in your community
Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) Testin.When To Get Tested?: When it is RSV season (late fall through early spring in the U.S.) and an infant, an elderly person, or a person with a weakened immune system has a moderate to severe respiratory infection and symptoms such as runny nose, congestion, coughing and/or difficulty breathing
Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) Testin.Sample Required?: Usually a nasal aspirate or nasal wash; occasionally a nasopharyngeal (NP) swab

Retic Count.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the bone marrow's ability to produce red blood cells (RBCs); to help distinguish between various causes of anemia; to help monitor bone marrow response and the return of normal marrow function following chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant, or post-treatment follow-up for iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia, or renal failure
Retic Count.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit and/or symptoms of anemia; when a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your bone marrow function; sometimes as part of a complete blood count (CBC)
Retic Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick or heelstick (infant)

Reticulocyte Count.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the bone marrow's ability to produce red blood cells (RBCs); to help distinguish between various causes of anemia; to help monitor bone marrow response and the return of normal marrow function following chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant, or post-treatment follow-up for iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia, or renal failure
Reticulocyte Count.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit and/or symptoms of anemia; when a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your bone marrow function; sometimes as part of a complete blood count (CBC)
Reticulocyte Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick or heelstick (infant)

Reticulocyte Index.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the bone marrow's ability to produce red blood cells (RBCs); to help distinguish between various causes of anemia; to help monitor bone marrow response and the return of normal marrow function following chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant, or post-treatment follow-up for iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia, or renal failure
Reticulocyte Index.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit and/or symptoms of anemia; when a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your bone marrow function; sometimes as part of a complete blood count (CBC)
Reticulocyte Index.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick or heelstick (infant)

Reticulocyte Percent.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the bone marrow's ability to produce red blood cells (RBCs); to help distinguish between various causes of anemia; to help monitor bone marrow response and the return of normal marrow function following chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant, or post-treatment follow-up for iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia, or renal failure
Reticulocyte Percent.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit and/or symptoms of anemia; when a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your bone marrow function; sometimes as part of a complete blood count (CBC)
Reticulocyte Percent.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick or heelstick (infant)

Reticulocyte Production Index.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the bone marrow's ability to produce red blood cells (RBCs); to help distinguish between various causes of anemia; to help monitor bone marrow response and the return of normal marrow function following chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant, or post-treatment follow-up for iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia, or renal failure
Reticulocyte Production Index.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit and/or symptoms of anemia; when a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your bone marrow function; sometimes as part of a complete blood count (CBC)
Reticulocyte Production Index.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick or heelstick (infant)

Reticulocytes.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the bone marrow's ability to produce red blood cells (RBCs); to help distinguish between various causes of anemia; to help monitor bone marrow response and the return of normal marrow function following chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant, or post-treatment follow-up for iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia, or renal failure
Reticulocytes.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit and/or symptoms of anemia; when a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your bone marrow function; sometimes as part of a complete blood count (CBC)
Reticulocytes.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick or heelstick (infant)

Retinol.Why Get Tested?: To detect vitamin A deficiency or toxicity
Retinol.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting a vitamin A deficiency or excess, or are at risk for a deficiency
Retinol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Retinol.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is required and no alcohol should be consumed for 24 hours before sample collection.

RF.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the presence of an autoimmune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
RF.When To Get Tested?: When you have joint pain and fatigue that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to RA
RF.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Rh Factor.Why Get Tested?: To determine your ABO blood group and Rh type
Rh Factor.When To Get Tested?: When you need a transfusion of blood or blood components; when you donate blood at a collection facility or donate an organ, tissue, or bone marrow for transplantation; before or during a woman's pregnancy to determine the risk of Rh incompatibility with the fetus
Rh Factor.Sample Required?: A sample of blood is drawn from a vein or from the tip of the finger (fingerstick). In newborns, blood from the umbilical cord or a small amount of blood from a heelstick may be used for testing.

Rheumatoid Factor (RF).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the presence of an autoimmune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
Rheumatoid Factor (RF).When To Get Tested?: When you have joint pain and fatigue that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to RA
Rheumatoid Factor (RF).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

riboflavin (B2).Why Get Tested?: To screen for and detect moderate to severe vitamin B deficiencies
riboflavin (B2).When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that may be due to a B vitamin deficiency, are at risk for a deficiency, or have a condition associated with malabsorption
riboflavin (B2).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a random or 24-hour urine sample may also be collected.
riboflavin (B2).Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is usually required for blood testing.

Ristocetin Cofactor.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of unexplained excessive or repeated episodes of bleeding, to diagnose von Willebrand disease (VWD), and to distinguish between different types of VWD
Ristocetin Cofactor.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal or family history of heavy, prolonged, and/or spontaneous bleeding; when your healthcare provider suspects that you may have a bleeding disorder
Ristocetin Cofactor.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

RPI.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the bone marrow's ability to produce red blood cells (RBCs); to help distinguish between various causes of anemia; to help monitor bone marrow response and the return of normal marrow function following chemotherapy, bone marrow transplant, or post-treatment follow-up for iron deficiency anemia, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia, or renal failure
RPI.When To Get Tested?: When you have a low RBC count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit and/or symptoms of anemia; when a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your bone marrow function; sometimes as part of a complete blood count (CBC)
RPI.Sample Required?: A blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in your arm or sometimes from a fingerstick or heelstick (infant)

RPR.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
RPR.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
RPR.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Rubella Antibodies, IgM and IgG.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sufficient rubella antibodies to protect you from the rubella virus; to verify a past infection or detect a recent infection
Rubella Antibodies, IgM and IgG.When To Get Tested?: Prior to or at the beginning of a pregnancy to verify immunity; when a pregnant woman has symptoms of rubella, such as fever and rash; when a newborn shows signs of abnormal development or birth defects that may be caused by an in utero infection; whenever there is need to verify a recent rubella infection or to verify immunity
Rubella Antibodies, IgM and IgG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm of an adult or blood drawn from a heelprick or from the umbilical cord of a newborn

Rubella Test.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sufficient rubella antibodies to protect you from the rubella virus; to verify a past infection or detect a recent infection
Rubella Test.When To Get Tested?: Prior to or at the beginning of a pregnancy to verify immunity; when a pregnant woman has symptoms of rubella, such as fever and rash; when a newborn shows signs of abnormal development or birth defects that may be caused by an in utero infection; whenever there is need to verify a recent rubella infection or to verify immunity
Rubella Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm of an adult or blood drawn from a heelprick or from the umbilical cord of a newborn

Rubeola.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a measles or mumps infection; to establish whether a person has immunity to measles or mumps due to a previous infection or to vaccination; to confirm a measles or mumps case and investigate its source
Rubeola.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms or complications that a health practitioner suspects are due to a measles or mumps infection; whenever it is necessary or desired to determine measles or mumps immunity; when an outbreak of measles or mumps is occurring in order to track and minimize it
Rubeola.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for measles or mumps antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, sample may be blood, urine, nasopharyngeal (nasal) aspirate/washing, throat swab, swab of the inside of the cheek (buccal swab), cerebrospinal fluid, or other body tissue
Rubeola.Test Preparation Needed?: Prior to collection of a buccal swab for mumps, the salivary gland located in front of and below the ear (parotid gland) is massaged. For other specimens, no test preparation is needed.

S182.Why Get Tested?: To screen for a rare mutation in the PSEN1 gene known to be associated with early onset familial Alzheimer disease (EOFAD, also called Alzheimer disease type 3 or AD3)
S182.When To Get Tested?: When you are an adult who has symptoms of dementia and a strong family history of Alzheimer disease that begins before age 60-65 or if you are an asymptomatic adult with a family member who has early onset Alzheimer disease and an identified PSEN1 genetic mutation
S182.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Saccharomyces cerevisiae Antibodies, IgG.Why Get Tested?: To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
Saccharomyces cerevisiae Antibodies, IgG.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your healthcare practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
Saccharomyces cerevisiae Antibodies, IgG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

SACE.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor sarcoidosis; to help differentiate this systemic condition from other disorders causing similar symptoms
SACE.When To Get Tested?: When you have granulomas that produce small bumps under the skin, a lingering cough, red watery eyes, and/or other symptoms suggestive of sarcoidosis; regularly when you have active sarcoidosis to monitor its course
SACE.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Salicylates.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
Salicylates.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
Salicylates.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
Salicylates.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

Salicylates, blood, urine.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
Salicylates, blood, urine.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
Salicylates, blood, urine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
Salicylates, blood, urine.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

Salivary Cortisol.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose Cushing syndrome or primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease); to detect conditions affecting the pituitary or adrenal glands
Salivary Cortisol.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects excess or deficient cortisol production
Salivary Cortisol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a saliva sample may be used
Salivary Cortisol.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be required to rest before sample collection. For a salivary cortisol test, you may be instructed to refrain from eating, drinking, or brushing your teeth for a period of time (may be some time between 15 to 30 minutes) prior to the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

Salsalate.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
Salsalate.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
Salsalate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
Salsalate.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

Scl-70.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Scl-70.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Scl-70.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Scleroderma Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Scleroderma Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Scleroderma Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

sdLDL.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your risk of developing cardiovascular disease (CVD)
sdLDL.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal and/or family history of CVD at an early age; when the result of your low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) test is within a healthy range, but your healthcare provider thinks that you may have an increased risk of developing heart disease; sometimes to help monitor the effectiveness of lipid-lowering treatment and/or lifestyle changes
sdLDL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
sdLDL.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast for 9-12 hours before this test; only water is permitted. Follow any instructions you are given.

Sed Rate.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of inflammation caused by one or more conditions such as infections, tumors or autoimmune diseases; to help diagnose and monitor specific conditions such as temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis
Sed Rate.When To Get Tested?: When your health practitioner thinks that you might have a condition causing inflammation; when you have signs and symptoms associated with temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis such as headaches, neck or shoulder pain, pelvic pain, anemia, poor appetite, unexplained weight loss, and joint stiffness
Sed Rate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Sedimentation Rate.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of inflammation caused by one or more conditions such as infections, tumors or autoimmune diseases; to help diagnose and monitor specific conditions such as temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis
Sedimentation Rate.When To Get Tested?: When your health practitioner thinks that you might have a condition causing inflammation; when you have signs and symptoms associated with temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis such as headaches, neck or shoulder pain, pelvic pain, anemia, poor appetite, unexplained weight loss, and joint stiffness
Sedimentation Rate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Semen Analysis.Why Get Tested?: As part of infertility testing if your partner is having trouble becoming pregnant or after a vasectomy to determine if the operation was successful
Semen Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When you think you might have a fertility problem or about three months after you have had a vasectomy
Semen Analysis.Sample Required?: A semen sample collected in a sterile, wide-mouth container provided by the lab; often collected on-site, but sometimes it may be collected at home using a special condom obtained from a healthcare practitioner. For infertility testing, the sample must be analyzed within one hour of collection. Two separate collections on two separate days may be required.
Semen Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: For infertility testing, refrain from having sex or masturbation for 2-5 days before sample collection; carefully follow instructions provided.

Seminal Fluid Analysis.Why Get Tested?: As part of infertility testing if your partner is having trouble becoming pregnant or after a vasectomy to determine if the operation was successful
Seminal Fluid Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When you think you might have a fertility problem or about three months after you have had a vasectomy
Seminal Fluid Analysis.Sample Required?: A semen sample collected in a sterile, wide-mouth container provided by the lab; often collected on-site, but sometimes it may be collected at home using a special condom obtained from a healthcare practitioner. For infertility testing, the sample must be analyzed within one hour of collection. Two separate collections on two separate days may be required.
Seminal Fluid Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: For infertility testing, refrain from having sex or masturbation for 2-5 days before sample collection; carefully follow instructions provided.

Sensitivity Testing.Why Get Tested?: To determine the likelihood that a particular antibiotic or antifungal drug will be effective in stopping the growth of the bacteria or fungi causing your infection
Sensitivity Testing.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to a positive bacterial or fungal culture; when selecting the best treatment for a bacterial or fungal infection requires laboratory testing; when your infection is not responding to treatment
Sensitivity Testing.Sample Required?: A sample from an infected site is cultured on specialized media to recover the bacteria or fungus that is causing the infection. The method used to collect a sample from an individual depends on the type of culture performed (e.g., urine culture, blood culture, sputum culture, etc.).

Serine Protease 3.Why Get Tested?:
To help detect, aid in the diagnosis of, and sometimes monitor certain forms of the autoimmune disorder systemic vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels)
To help distinguish between Crohn disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC), the two most common types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); as an adjunct to other IBD testing
Serine Protease 3.When To Get Tested?:
When you have symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and weight loss that your health practitioner thinks may be due to a vascular autoimmune disorder; sometimes to monitor response to therapy
When you have symptoms such as persistent or intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain that your health practitioner suspects may be due to an IBD; when your health practitioner wants to distinguish between CD and UC
Serine Protease 3.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Serotonin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a carcinoid tumor that produces serotonin
Serotonin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggestive of a carcinoid tumor, such as flushing, diarrhea, and/or wheezing
Serotonin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Serotonin Metabolite.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor treatment for a carcinoid tumor that produces serotonin
Serotonin Metabolite.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggestive of a carcinoid tumor, such as flushing, diarrhea, and/or wheezing; at intervals following treatment
Serotonin Metabolite.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample; rarely, a random urine sample
Serotonin Metabolite.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to avoid certain foods and medications prior to this test.

Serum Angiotensin Converting Enzyme.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor sarcoidosis; to help differentiate this systemic condition from other disorders causing similar symptoms
Serum Angiotensin Converting Enzyme.When To Get Tested?: When you have granulomas that produce small bumps under the skin, a lingering cough, red watery eyes, and/or other symptoms suggestive of sarcoidosis; regularly when you have active sarcoidosis to monitor its course
Serum Angiotensin Converting Enzyme.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Serum Creatinine.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor treatment for kidney disease
Serum Creatinine.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of a comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when your have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or damage or when you have a condition that may affect your kidneys and/or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at intervals to monitor treatment for kidney disease or kidney function while on certain medications
Serum Creatinine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample
Serum Creatinine.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Serum Fe.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to determine your blood iron level; along with other tests, to help diagnose iron-deficiency anemia or iron overload
Serum Fe.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (deficiency) or too much iron (overload) in your body
Serum Fe.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Serum Fe.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before sample collection; in this case, only water is permitted. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Serum Ferritin.Why Get Tested?: To determine your body's total iron storage capacity; to help diagnose iron deficiency or iron overload
Serum Ferritin.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (iron deficiency) or too much iron (iron overload) in the body
Serum Ferritin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Serum Ferritin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is permitted. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Serum Free Light Chains.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and monitor plasma cell disorders (dyscrasias) such as multiple myeloma, primary amyloidosis, and related diseases or to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Serum Free Light Chains.When To Get Tested?: When you have bone pain, fractures, anemia (with normal size and shape red blood cells (normocytic)), kidney disease, and recurrent infections that your healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a plasma cell disorder; when you are being treated for a plasma cell disorder
Serum Free Light Chains.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Serum Glutamic-Oxaloacetic Transaminase.Why Get Tested?: To detect liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
Serum Glutamic-Oxaloacetic Transaminase.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to a hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel when you have a routine health exam
Serum Glutamic-Oxaloacetic Transaminase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Serum Glutamic-Pyruvic Transaminase.Why Get Tested?: To screen for liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
Serum Glutamic-Pyruvic Transaminase.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) when you have a routine health exam
Serum Glutamic-Pyruvic Transaminase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Serum Iron.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to determine your blood iron level; along with other tests, to help diagnose iron-deficiency anemia or iron overload
Serum Iron.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have too little iron (deficiency) or too much iron (overload) in your body
Serum Iron.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Serum Iron.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before sample collection; in this case, only water is permitted. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Serum Iron-Binding Capacity.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to assess your body's ability to transport iron in the blood; to help diagnose iron-deficiency or iron overload
Serum Iron-Binding Capacity.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects you may have too much iron (overload) or too little iron (deficiency) in the body
Serum Iron-Binding Capacity.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Serum Iron-Binding Capacity.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Serum Ketones.Why Get Tested?: To determine the amount of ketones (ketone bodies, acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood to help diagnose a life-threatening problem called diabetic ketoacidosis
Serum Ketones.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with ketoacidosis, such as increased urination, excessive thirst, dehydration, rapid breathing, and shortness of breath
Serum Ketones.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

Serum Myoglobin.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether muscle has been injured; to help diagnose conditions associated with muscle damage; to detect high levels in the urine that can cause kidney damage after extensive muscle damage; sometimes to help determine if you have had a heart attack, although for heart attack detection, this test has been largely replaced by troponin.
Serum Myoglobin.When To Get Tested?: When you have muscle weakness, muscle aches, and/or dark urine and your healthcare provider suspects muscle damage; when there has been severe traumatic injury to skeletal muscle
Serum Myoglobin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random urine sample

Serum Protein Electrophoresis.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
Serum Protein Electrophoresis.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
Serum Protein Electrophoresis.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Serum Transferrin Receptors.Why Get Tested?: To detect iron deficiency anemia and distinguish it from anemia caused by chronic illness or inflammation
Serum Transferrin Receptors.When To Get Tested?: When iron deficiency anemia is suspected
Serum Transferrin Receptors.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Serum Trypsinogen.Why Get Tested?: To screen for cystic fibrosis (CF); sometimes to detect pancreatitis
Serum Trypsinogen.When To Get Tested?: As part of a newborn screening test; sometimes when you have symptoms of pancreatitis, such as severe abdominal pain that may be persistent or intermittent, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and jaundice
Serum Trypsinogen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel, a spot of blood that is put onto filter paper, or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Serum Urate.Why Get Tested?: To detect high levels of uric acid in the blood, which could be a sign of the condition gout, or to monitor uric acid levels when undergoing chemotherapy or radiation treatment; to detect high levels of uric acid in the urine in order to diagnose the cause of kidney stones and to monitor those with gout who are at risk of developing such stones
Serum Urate.When To Get Tested?: When you have joint pain or other symptoms that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to gout; when you have had or are going to have certain chemotherapy or radiation therapies for cancer; when you have recurrent kidney stones; when you have gout or are otherwise at risk for kidney stone formation
Serum Urate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm or a 24-hour urine sample
Serum Urate.Test Preparation Needed?: None may be needed; however, some institutions recommend fasting. Follow any instructions you are given.

Sex Hormone Binding Globulin.Why Get Tested?: Most commonly measured in the evaluation of low testosterone (androgen deficiency) in men; also commonly used in the evaluation of women with signs and symptoms of excess male hormones (androgens)
Sex Hormone Binding Globulin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of increased or decreased testosterone and a total testosterone measurement is inconsistent with your symptoms
Sex Hormone Binding Globulin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG).Why Get Tested?: Most commonly measured in the evaluation of low testosterone (androgen deficiency) in men; also commonly used in the evaluation of women with signs and symptoms of excess male hormones (androgens)
Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG).When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of increased or decreased testosterone and a total testosterone measurement is inconsistent with your symptoms
Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

SFLC.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and monitor plasma cell disorders (dyscrasias) such as multiple myeloma, primary amyloidosis, and related diseases or to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
SFLC.When To Get Tested?: When you have bone pain, fractures, anemia (with normal size and shape red blood cells (normocytic)), kidney disease, and recurrent infections that your healthcare practitioner suspects are due to a plasma cell disorder; when you are being treated for a plasma cell disorder
SFLC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

SGOT.Why Get Tested?: To detect liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
SGOT.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to a hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel when you have a routine health exam
SGOT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

SGPT.Why Get Tested?: To screen for liver damage and/or to help diagnose liver disease
SGPT.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver disorder, such as abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, jaundice (yellow skin), or potential exposure to hepatitis virus; as part of a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) when you have a routine health exam
SGPT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your gastrointestinal symptoms are due to an infection caused by Escherichia coli bacteria that produce Shiga toxin
Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli.When To Get Tested?: When you have acute diarrhea that is persistent, severe and/or bloody
Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli.Sample Required?: A fresh liquid or unformed stool sample that does not contain urine or water, collected in a clean dry container; a rectal swab may be collected from infants. The stool or rectal swab may be placed in transport media for delivery to the laboratory.

Sickle Cell Screen.Why Get Tested?: To investigate hemoglobinopathy as the cause of signs and symptoms; to screen for a hemoglobin disorder
Sickle Cell Screen.When To Get Tested?: As follow up to abnormal results on a complete blood count (CBC) and/or blood smear; when you have symptoms of hemolytic anemia such as weakness and fatigue and your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have an abnormal form of hemoglobin (hemoglobinopathy); when you have a family history of hemoglobinopathy; as part of newborn screening
Sickle Cell Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or obtained from the heel or finger of an infant

Sickle Cell Tests.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sickle cell trait or sickle cell disease
Sickle Cell Tests.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of newborn screening; if you are in a high risk group and were born before newborn screening was mandated and want to know if you have sickle cell disease or are carrying the sickle cell trait; when you have signs and symptoms of anemia or abnormal results from a complete blood count (CBC) and your healthcare practitioner suspects sickle cell disease or trait
Sickle Cell Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or, for infants, by pricking a heel or finger
Sickle Cell Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, if this test is used for diagnosis, the sample should not be drawn after a recent blood transfusion.

Siderophilin.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to assess your body's ability to transport iron in the blood; to help diagnose iron-deficiency or iron overload
Siderophilin.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects you may have too much iron (overload) or too little iron (deficiency) in the body
Siderophilin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Siderophilin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Sirolimus.Why Get Tested?: To determine the level of sirolimus in the blood in order to establish a dosing regimen, maintain therapeutic levels, and detect toxic levels
Sirolimus.When To Get Tested?: As soon as sirolimus therapy begins and whenever dose is changed; frequently at first, then at regular intervals to monitor concentrations over time; whenever excess or deficient levels are suspected
Sirolimus.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Sirolimus.Test Preparation Needed?: None; the sample is typically collected 12 hours after the last dose and immediately prior to the next dose, or as directed by your healthcare provider

SMA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
SMA.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
SMA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

SMA 12.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about the current status of your metabolism, including the health of your kidneys and liver as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and levels of blood glucose and blood proteins; to monitor known conditions, such as hypertension, and to monitor the use of medications to check for any kidney- or liver-related side effects
SMA 12.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are being monitored for a specific condition or are taking medications that may impact your kidney or liver
SMA 12.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
SMA 12.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the CMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

SMA 20.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about the current status of your metabolism, including the health of your kidneys and liver as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and levels of blood glucose and blood proteins; to monitor known conditions, such as hypertension, and to monitor the use of medications to check for any kidney- or liver-related side effects
SMA 20.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are being monitored for a specific condition or are taking medications that may impact your kidney or liver
SMA 20.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
SMA 20.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the CMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

SMA 7.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about your body's metabolism, including the current status of your kidneys as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and level of blood glucose
SMA 7.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are hospitalized, in the emergency room
SMA 7.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
SMA 7.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the BMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

SMAC (somewhat outdated terms).Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about the current status of your metabolism, including the health of your kidneys and liver as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and levels of blood glucose and blood proteins; to monitor known conditions, such as hypertension, and to monitor the use of medications to check for any kidney- or liver-related side effects
SMAC (somewhat outdated terms).When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are being monitored for a specific condition or are taking medications that may impact your kidney or liver
SMAC (somewhat outdated terms).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
SMAC (somewhat outdated terms).Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the CMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

SMAC7.Why Get Tested?: To give your healthcare provider important information about your body's metabolism, including the current status of your kidneys as well as electrolyte and acid/base balance and level of blood glucose
SMAC7.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine health exam; when you are hospitalized, in the emergency room
SMAC7.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
SMAC7.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast (nothing but water) for 10 to 12 hours prior to the blood draw. Depending on the reason for ordering the BMP, it may be drawn after fasting or on a random basis. Follow any instructions you are given.

Smith Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
Smith Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
Smith Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Smooth Muscle Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Smooth Muscle Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Smooth Muscle Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Smooth Muscle Antibody (SMA) and F-actin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose autoimmune hepatitis and distinguish it from other causes of liver injury
Smooth Muscle Antibody (SMA) and F-actin.When To Get Tested?: When you have hepatitis that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to an autoimmune-related process
Smooth Muscle Antibody (SMA) and F-actin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

SMRP.Why Get Tested?: To monitor progression or recurrence of a rare cancer called mesothelioma that affects the membranes that surround the lungs, heart, and abdominal cavity; most cases of mesothelioma are associated with asbestos exposure.
SMRP.When To Get Tested?: After you have been diagnosed with mesothelioma, this test may be ordered anytime during or after treatment to follow response to treatment.
SMRP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Sodium.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether your sodium level is within normal limits; to help evaluate electrolyte balance and to help determine the cause of and monitor the treatment for illnesses associated with abnormal sodium levels in the body
Sodium.When To Get Tested?: If you are experiencing dehydration, problems with blood pressure, accumulating excess fluid (edema), or have non-specific symptoms; as part of a routine health examination
Sodium.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

Sodium salicylate.Why Get Tested?: To detect salicylate overdose, to help evaluate its severity and monitor its resolution; sometimes to monitor for an overdose if you regularly use prescription-strength salicylates
Sodium salicylate.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as nausea, hyperventilation, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), or confusion that may be from taking too much aspirin or medications with salicylate ingredients; when it is suspected that an unconscious person or a child may have ingested a significant quantity of a salicylate, often as part of emergency and overdose testing; at regular intervals when monitoring an overdose; sometimes on a regular basis if you take a prescription salicylate for rheumatoid arthritis or other autoimmune disorder
Sodium salicylate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container
Sodium salicylate.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but a healthcare practitioner may ask when you last took a salicylate and the amount taken. If you regularly take a prescription salicylate, the healthcare practitioner may want to collect blood just prior to your next dose (trough level). Tell your healthcare provider about any other medications you are taking.

Soluble Mesothelin-Related Peptides.Why Get Tested?: To monitor progression or recurrence of a rare cancer called mesothelioma that affects the membranes that surround the lungs, heart, and abdominal cavity; most cases of mesothelioma are associated with asbestos exposure.
Soluble Mesothelin-Related Peptides.When To Get Tested?: After you have been diagnosed with mesothelioma, this test may be ordered anytime during or after treatment to follow response to treatment.
Soluble Mesothelin-Related Peptides.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Soluble Transferrin Receptor.Why Get Tested?: To detect iron deficiency anemia and distinguish it from anemia caused by chronic illness or inflammation
Soluble Transferrin Receptor.When To Get Tested?: When iron deficiency anemia is suspected
Soluble Transferrin Receptor.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Somatomedin C.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of GH treatment
Somatomedin C.When To Get Tested?: When a child has signs and symptoms of slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or an adult has decreased bone density, reduced muscle strength, and increased lipids that suggest insufficient GH and IGF-1 production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms of gigantism or acromegaly, respectively, that suggest excess GH and IGF-1 production; during and after treatment for GH abnormalities; when a pituitary disorder is suspected
Somatomedin C.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Somatomedin C.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally none, unless instructed to fast

Somatotropin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose growth hormone (GH) deficiency or, less commonly, growth hormone excess; to evaluate pituitary function; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for excess production of GH
Somatotropin.When To Get Tested?: When a child has slow growth, short stature, and delayed development or sometimes when an adult has decreased bone density and/or muscle strength and elevated blood lipid levels that could be related to insufficient GH production; when a child or adult has signs and symptoms suggestive of GH excess, which can cause two rare conditions, gigantism and acromegaly, respectively; when a pituitary disorder is suspected and other pituitary hormone levels are abnormal
Somatotropin.Sample Required?: Usually several blood samples, drawn at timed intervals from veins in your arms; sometimes a single sample of blood, drawn following a fast and rest, after a period of strenuous exercise, or after ingesting a glucose (sugar) solution
Somatotropin.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow any instructions you are given, such as to fast, in order to prepare for this test.

SPE.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
SPE.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
SPE.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

SPEP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
SPEP.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
SPEP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Sperm Analysis.Why Get Tested?: As part of infertility testing if your partner is having trouble becoming pregnant or after a vasectomy to determine if the operation was successful
Sperm Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When you think you might have a fertility problem or about three months after you have had a vasectomy
Sperm Analysis.Sample Required?: A semen sample collected in a sterile, wide-mouth container provided by the lab; often collected on-site, but sometimes it may be collected at home using a special condom obtained from a healthcare practitioner. For infertility testing, the sample must be analyzed within one hour of collection. Two separate collections on two separate days may be required.
Sperm Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: For infertility testing, refrain from having sex or masturbation for 2-5 days before sample collection; carefully follow instructions provided.

Sperm Count.Why Get Tested?: As part of infertility testing if your partner is having trouble becoming pregnant or after a vasectomy to determine if the operation was successful
Sperm Count.When To Get Tested?: When you think you might have a fertility problem or about three months after you have had a vasectomy
Sperm Count.Sample Required?: A semen sample collected in a sterile, wide-mouth container provided by the lab; often collected on-site, but sometimes it may be collected at home using a special condom obtained from a healthcare practitioner. For infertility testing, the sample must be analyzed within one hour of collection. Two separate collections on two separate days may be required.
Sperm Count.Test Preparation Needed?: For infertility testing, refrain from having sex or masturbation for 2-5 days before sample collection; carefully follow instructions provided.

Spinal Fluid Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a disease or condition affecting the central nervous system such as infection, bleeding within the brain or skull, cancer, or autoimmune disorder
Spinal Fluid Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that your symptoms are due to a condition or disease involving your central nervous system
Spinal Fluid Analysis.Sample Required?: A sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected by a health practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap
Spinal Fluid Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: You will be instructed to empty your bladder and bowels prior to sample collection. It will be necessary to lie still in a curled-up fetal position during the collection and to lie flat and still for a time period after the collection.

Sports Doping Tests.Why Get Tested?: To screen for drug abuse, to monitor someone with a substance abuse problem, to monitor compliance with prescribed medications, or to detect and evaluate drug intoxication or overdose
Sports Doping Tests.When To Get Tested?: Sometimes required prior to the start of a new job or insurance policy; randomly for workplace drug testing or athletic drug testing programs; as mandated when court-ordered; as indicated when ordered by a health practitioner to monitor a known or suspected substance abuse patient; sometimes when you are pregnant, will be receiving an organ transplant, when you are prescribed pain medication, or when you have symptoms suggesting drug intoxication or overdose
Sports Doping Tests.Sample Required?: A random urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; hair, saliva, or sweat
Sports Doping Tests.Test Preparation Needed?: Some prescription and over-the-counter drugs may give a positive screening result; prior to testing, indicate any medications that you have taken and/or for which you have prescriptions.

Sputum Culture, Bacterial.Why Get Tested?: To detect and identify the cause of bacterial pneumonia or some other lower respiratory tract infections; to monitor the efficacy of treatment
Sputum Culture, Bacterial.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms associated with a lower respiratory tract infection; when you have been treated for bacterial pneumonia or any other lower respiratory tract infection
Sputum Culture, Bacterial.Sample Required?: A sputum sample (deep respiratory secretions, not saliva), usually collected first thing in the morning; sometimes, depending on the infection, up to 3 sputum samples might be collected over consecutive days.
Sputum Culture, Bacterial.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to rinse your mouth out with water prior to collection and to avoid food for 1-2 hours before the sample is collected.

SSA (Ro).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
SSA (Ro).When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
SSA (Ro).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

SSB (La).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and distinguish between autoimmune disorders as well as to monitor autoimmune disease progression
SSB (La).When To Get Tested?: When your antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive and you have symptoms that suggest an autoimmune disorder; when monitoring the activity of an autoimmune disorder
SSB (La).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

STEC.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your gastrointestinal symptoms are due to an infection caused by Escherichia coli bacteria that produce Shiga toxin
STEC.When To Get Tested?: When you have acute diarrhea that is persistent, severe and/or bloody
STEC.Sample Required?: A fresh liquid or unformed stool sample that does not contain urine or water, collected in a clean dry container; a rectal swab may be collected from infants. The stool or rectal swab may be placed in transport media for delivery to the laboratory.

sTfR.Why Get Tested?: To detect iron deficiency anemia and distinguish it from anemia caused by chronic illness or inflammation
sTfR.When To Get Tested?: When iron deficiency anemia is suspected
sTfR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Stool Calprotectin.Why Get Tested?: To detect inflammation in the intestines; to distinguish between inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and non-inflammatory bowel conditions; to monitor IBD activity
Stool Calprotectin.When To Get Tested?: When you have bloody or watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, with or without fever, lasting more than a few days
Stool Calprotectin.Sample Required?: A stool sample collected in a clean container

Stool Chymotrypsin.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
Stool Chymotrypsin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as persistent diarrhea; foul-smelling, bulky, greasy stools; malnutrition; malabsorption; and vitamin deficiency and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
Stool Chymotrypsin.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample, uncontaminated with urine
Stool Chymotrypsin.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be instructed to discontinue taking the enzymes 5 days before providing the stool sample.

Stool Culture.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have an infection of your digestive tract due to the presence of disease-causing (pathogenic) bacteria
Stool Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea and/or vomiting that is severe or lasts more than a few days
Stool Culture.Sample Required?: A fresh stool sample transported to the laboratory within 2 hours or one that has been placed in a transport medium (a collection vial containing a preservative)

Stool Elastase.Why Get Tested?: To help detect and evaluate pancreatic insufficiency
Stool Elastase.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms such as stomach cramps, weight loss, malnutrition, malabsorption, delayed growth (in children) and fatty, foul-smelling stools and pancreatic insufficiency is suspected
Stool Elastase.Sample Required?: A fresh formed stool sample that is not contaminated with urine
Stool Elastase.Test Preparation Needed?: If you are taking pancreatic enzymes, you may be asked to discontinue them for 5 days prior to stool collection.

Stool Lactoferrin.Why Get Tested?: To detect inflammation in the intestines; to help identify active inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); to distinguish between IBD and non-inflammatory bowel conditions; to monitor IBD activity
Stool Lactoferrin.When To Get Tested?: When you have bloody or watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, with or without fever, lasting more than a few days
Stool Lactoferrin.Sample Required?: A stool sample collected in a clean container

Stool Lipids.Why Get Tested?: To detect and measure excess fat in the stool; to help diagnose conditions causing malabsorption
Stool Lipids.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
Stool Lipids.Sample Required?: A random stool collection; sometimes a 72-hour stool collection
Stool Lipids.Test Preparation Needed?: For a 72-hour stool collection, follow your healthcare practitioner's instructions; this may include consuming 50-150 grams of fat a day in your diet for 2-3 days prior to and during the stool collection period.

Stool Occult Blood.Why Get Tested?: To screen for digestive tract bleeding, which may be an indicator of colon cancer
Stool Occult Blood.When To Get Tested?:
The American Cancer Society recommends screening for colon cancer between the ages of 45 and 75, while the U.S. Multi-Society Task Force (MSTF) on Colorectal Cancer and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommend screening starting at age 50. Screening annually is usually recommended if an occult blood test is used.
When there is a suspicion that you have gastrointestinal bleeding
Stool Occult Blood.Sample Required?: Stool samples are required. The sampling procedure depends on the choice of test, and the samples may be collected in the privacy of your home. (See the section "What is being tested?" below for more details.)
Stool Occult Blood.Test Preparation Needed?: For the fecal immunochemical test (FIT), which is the preferred test, no preparation is necessary. For the guaiac-based FOBT (gFOBT, FOBT), you will be instructed to avoid certain medications and follow certain dietary restrictions for several days before collecting the stool samples.

Strep Group B.Why Get Tested?: To screen a pregnant woman for the presence of group B streptococcus (GBS) in her vagina or rectum to determine the risk that she will pass the bacteria on to her newborn during labor and delivery, possibly resulting in a serious infection in her newborn called early-onset GBS
Strep Group B.When To Get Tested?: When a woman is between 35 and 37 weeks of pregnancy or has preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes
Strep Group B.Sample Required?: A swab obtained from the vagina and rectum of a pregnant woman; a urine sample collected anytime during pregnancy may be used to detect significant numbers of GBS.

Strep Throat Test.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your sore throat is "strep throat" that is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) bacteria
Strep Throat Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have a sore throat that starts quickly and lasts more than a week and/or other symptoms such as a fever of 101° F or higher, or reddened throat and/or tonsils with white or yellow patches or streaks
Strep Throat Test.Sample Required?: A swab rubbed against the back of your throat and tonsils

Streptococcal Screen.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your sore throat is "strep throat" that is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) bacteria
Streptococcal Screen.When To Get Tested?: When you have a sore throat that starts quickly and lasts more than a week and/or other symptoms such as a fever of 101° F or higher, or reddened throat and/or tonsils with white or yellow patches or streaks
Streptococcal Screen.Sample Required?: A swab rubbed against the back of your throat and tonsils

Streptococcus agalactiae.Why Get Tested?: To screen a pregnant woman for the presence of group B streptococcus (GBS) in her vagina or rectum to determine the risk that she will pass the bacteria on to her newborn during labor and delivery, possibly resulting in a serious infection in her newborn called early-onset GBS
Streptococcus agalactiae.When To Get Tested?: When a woman is between 35 and 37 weeks of pregnancy or has preterm labor or preterm premature rupture of membranes
Streptococcus agalactiae.Sample Required?: A swab obtained from the vagina and rectum of a pregnant woman; a urine sample collected anytime during pregnancy may be used to detect significant numbers of GBS.

Substance Abuse Testing.Why Get Tested?: To screen for drug abuse, to monitor someone with a substance abuse problem, to monitor compliance with prescribed medications, or to detect and evaluate drug intoxication or overdose
