Substance Abuse Testing.When To Get Tested?: Sometimes required prior to the start of a new job or insurance policy; randomly for workplace drug testing or athletic drug testing programs; as mandated when court-ordered; as indicated when ordered by a health practitioner to monitor a known or suspected substance abuse patient; sometimes when you are pregnant, will be receiving an organ transplant, when you are prescribed pain medication, or when you have symptoms suggesting drug intoxication or overdose
Substance Abuse Testing.Sample Required?: A random urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; hair, saliva, or sweat
Substance Abuse Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: Some prescription and over-the-counter drugs may give a positive screening result; prior to testing, indicate any medications that you have taken and/or for which you have prescriptions.

Sweat Chloride.When To Get Tested?: When an infant has a positive newborn screening test for CF; when you or your child has signs and symptoms that suggest CF or tested positive or indeterminate for CF with other tests
Sweat Chloride.Sample Required?: A sweat sample collected using a special sweat stimulation procedure (see below)
Sweat Chloride.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, you may be instructed to avoid applying creams or lotions to your skin 24 hours before the test. Also, it is important to be well-hydrated before undergoing the procedure.

Sweat Chloride Test.When To Get Tested?: When an infant has a positive newborn screening test for CF; when you or your child has signs and symptoms that suggest CF or tested positive or indeterminate for CF with other tests
Sweat Chloride Test.Sample Required?: A sweat sample collected using a special sweat stimulation procedure (see below)
Sweat Chloride Test.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, you may be instructed to avoid applying creams or lotions to your skin 24 hours before the test. Also, it is important to be well-hydrated before undergoing the procedure.

Sweat Electrolytes.When To Get Tested?: When an infant has a positive newborn screening test for CF; when you or your child has signs and symptoms that suggest CF or tested positive or indeterminate for CF with other tests
Sweat Electrolytes.Sample Required?: A sweat sample collected using a special sweat stimulation procedure (see below)
Sweat Electrolytes.Test Preparation Needed?: None; however, you may be instructed to avoid applying creams or lotions to your skin 24 hours before the test. Also, it is important to be well-hydrated before undergoing the procedure.

Synovial Fluid Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of joint inflammation, pain, and/or swelling
Synovial Fluid Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When one or more of your joints are swollen, red, and/or painful
Synovial Fluid Analysis.Sample Required?: A synovial fluid sample is obtained by inserting a needle into the space between the bones at a joint
Synovial Fluid Analysis.Test Preparation Needed?: Consult with your healthcare provider; synovial fluid collection and analysis may be performed after fasting or at random.

Syphilis Detection Tests.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Syphilis Detection Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Syphilis Detection Tests.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Syphilis Tests.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Syphilis Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Syphilis Tests.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

T-cell Gene Clonality.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a T-cell lymphoma; sometimes to detect and evaluate residual lymphoma cells
T-cell Gene Clonality.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have a T-cell lymphoma; when a healthcare practitioner would like to assess whether treatment has been effective and/or whether lymphoma has recurred
T-cell Gene Clonality.Sample Required?: A bone marrow, tissue such as a lymph node (biopsy), or body fluid sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

T-Cell Receptor Gene Rearrangement.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a T-cell lymphoma; sometimes to detect and evaluate residual lymphoma cells
T-Cell Receptor Gene Rearrangement.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have a T-cell lymphoma; when a healthcare practitioner would like to assess whether treatment has been effective and/or whether lymphoma has recurred
T-Cell Receptor Gene Rearrangement.Sample Required?: A bone marrow, tissue such as a lymph node (biopsy), or body fluid sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

T-helper Cells.Why Get Tested?: Most often, this test is done to measure the strength of your immune system if you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and to monitor treatment; occasionally, it may be used with other conditions (see Common Questions below).
T-helper Cells.When To Get Tested?: When you are first diagnosed with HIV infection to get a baseline assessment of your immune system; about every 3 to 6 months after starting antiretroviral therapy (ART) to check whether you are responding to treatment; if you have responded well to treatment, you may then be tested every 6 to 12 months.
T-helper Cells.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

T-Spot®.Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
T-Spot®.When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
T-Spot®.Sample Required?: A blood sample is drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

T. vaginalis.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, which causes the sexually transmitted disease trichomoniasis
T. vaginalis.When To Get Tested?: When a woman has symptoms of infection, such as a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, genital itching, and/or pain during urination, or when a man has genital itching or irritation, burning after urination or ejaculation, and/or a discharge from the penis
T. vaginalis.Sample Required?: For men or women, the initial portion of urine stream (first-catch urine sample); or in women, a swab of fluid and cells from the vagina or cervix; or in men, a swab from the tube that carries urine from the bladder to outside the body (urethra).

T3 (Free and Total).Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate thyroid gland function; to diagnose thyroid disease, including hyperthyroidism, and determine the cause; to monitor effectiveness of treatment of a thyroid disorder
T3 (Free and Total).When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), particularly with a normal free thyroxine (T4) result, and/or signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism
T3 (Free and Total).Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm
T3 (Free and Total).Test Preparation Needed?: None needed; however, certain medications, multivitamins and supplements can interfere with the free T3 and total T3 tests, so tell your healthcare practitioner about any prescribed or over-the-counter drugs and/or supplements that you are taking. Acute illness may affect thyroid testing test results. It is generally recommended that thyroid testing be avoided in hospitalized patients or deferred until after a person has recovered from an acute illness.

T4 Count.Why Get Tested?: Most often, this test is done to measure the strength of your immune system if you have been diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and to monitor treatment; occasionally, it may be used with other conditions (see Common Questions below).
T4 Count.When To Get Tested?: When you are first diagnosed with HIV infection to get a baseline assessment of your immune system; about every 3 to 6 months after starting antiretroviral therapy (ART) to check whether you are responding to treatment; if you have responded well to treatment, you may then be tested every 6 to 12 months.
T4 Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

T4, Free.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate thyroid gland function; to help diagnose thyroid disease; to monitor effectiveness of thyroid treatment; sometimes a free T4 is used to help diagnose congenital hypothyroidism in newborns
T4, Free.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of thyroid disease and/or an enlarged thyroid (goiter) or when you have a thyroid nodule (a small lump on the thyroid gland that may be solid or fluid-filled cyst), usually after an abnormal result on a TSH test; when you are being treated for a thyroid disorder
T4, Free.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from pricking the heel of an infant
T4, Free.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed; however, certain medications, multivitamins and supplements can interfere with the free T4 test, so tell your healthcare provider about any prescribed or over-the-counter drugs and/or supplements that you are taking. If you take thyroid hormone as treatment for thyroid disease, it is recommended that your blood sample be drawn before you take your dose for that day. Acute illness may affect thyroid testing results. It is generally recommended that thyroid testing be avoided in hospitalized patients or deferred until after a person has recovered from an acute illness.

TAC.Why Get Tested?: To determine the level of the drug tacrolimus in your blood in order to establish a dosing regimen, maintain therapeutic levels, and detect toxic levels
TAC.When To Get Tested?: As soon as tacrolimus therapy begins, frequently at first, then at regular intervals to monitor concentrations over time
TAC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
TAC.Test Preparation Needed?: The sample should be collected 12 hours after your last dose and immediately prior to your next dose or as directed by your healthcare practitioner.

Tacrolimus.Why Get Tested?: To determine the level of the drug tacrolimus in your blood in order to establish a dosing regimen, maintain therapeutic levels, and detect toxic levels
Tacrolimus.When To Get Tested?: As soon as tacrolimus therapy begins, frequently at first, then at regular intervals to monitor concentrations over time
Tacrolimus.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Tacrolimus.Test Preparation Needed?: The sample should be collected 12 hours after your last dose and immediately prior to your next dose or as directed by your healthcare practitioner.

Tartrate-resistant Acid Phosphatase.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
Tartrate-resistant Acid Phosphatase.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
Tartrate-resistant Acid Phosphatase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
Tartrate-resistant Acid Phosphatase.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Tau Protein and Amyloid Beta 42 Peptide.Why Get Tested?: To help distinguish between Alzheimer disease and other forms of dementia
Tau Protein and Amyloid Beta 42 Peptide.When To Get Tested?: These tests may be ordered along with cognitive and brain-imaging tests in people who demonstrate some form of dementia. These tests are not routine laboratory tests and are typically available only in research settings or memory clinics.
Tau Protein and Amyloid Beta 42 Peptide.Sample Required?: A sample of cerebrospinal fluid collected using a spinal tap
Tau Protein and Amyloid Beta 42 Peptide.Test Preparation Needed?: Your healthcare practitioner will advise you of any preparatory requirements.

Tau/Aß42.Why Get Tested?: To help distinguish between Alzheimer disease and other forms of dementia
Tau/Aß42.When To Get Tested?: These tests may be ordered along with cognitive and brain-imaging tests in people who demonstrate some form of dementia. These tests are not routine laboratory tests and are typically available only in research settings or memory clinics.
Tau/Aß42.Sample Required?: A sample of cerebrospinal fluid collected using a spinal tap
Tau/Aß42.Test Preparation Needed?: Your healthcare practitioner will advise you of any preparatory requirements.

TB Culture and Sensitivity.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose tuberculosis (TB) and infections caused by other Mycobacterium species, which are known as acid-fast bacilli (AFB), in people at risk of developing mycobacterial infections; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
TB Culture and Sensitivity.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a lung infection, such as a chronic cough, weight loss, fever, chills, and weakness, that may be due to TB or a nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection; when you have a positive IGRA blood test or Tuberculin skin test (TST) and you are in a high-risk group for progressing to active TB; when you have a skin or other body site infection that may be due to mycobacteria; when you are undergoing treatment for TB
TB Culture and Sensitivity.Sample Required?: For suspected cases of tuberculosis lung infections, usually three sputum samples are collected early in the morning on different days. If you are unable to produce sputum, a bronchoscope may be used to collect fluid during a procedure called a bronchoscopy. In children, gastric washings/aspirates may be collected. Depending on symptoms, urine, an aspirate from the site of suspected infection, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), other body fluids, or biopsied tissue samples may be collected for AFB testing.

TB NAAT.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose tuberculosis (TB) and infections caused by other Mycobacterium species, which are known as acid-fast bacilli (AFB), in people at risk of developing mycobacterial infections; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
TB NAAT.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of a lung infection, such as a chronic cough, weight loss, fever, chills, and weakness, that may be due to TB or a nontuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection; when you have a positive IGRA blood test or Tuberculin skin test (TST) and you are in a high-risk group for progressing to active TB; when you have a skin or other body site infection that may be due to mycobacteria; when you are undergoing treatment for TB
TB NAAT.Sample Required?: For suspected cases of tuberculosis lung infections, usually three sputum samples are collected early in the morning on different days. If you are unable to produce sputum, a bronchoscope may be used to collect fluid during a procedure called a bronchoscopy. In children, gastric washings/aspirates may be collected. Depending on symptoms, urine, an aspirate from the site of suspected infection, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), other body fluids, or biopsied tissue samples may be collected for AFB testing.

TB QuantiFERON®-TB Gold (QFT-G).Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
TB QuantiFERON®-TB Gold (QFT-G).When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
TB QuantiFERON®-TB Gold (QFT-G).Sample Required?: A blood sample is drawn by needle from a vein in your arm

TB Skin Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
TB Skin Test.When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
TB Skin Test.Sample Required?: No sample is required. A small amount of purified protein derivative (PPD) solution is injected with a tuberculin syringe just under the first layer of skin of your inner forearm.

TBII.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
TBII.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
TBII.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TBIL.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor liver disorders or hemolytic anemia; to monitor neonatal jaundice
TBIL.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of liver damage, liver disease, bile duct blockage, hemolytic anemia, or a liver-related metabolic problem, or if a newborn has jaundice
TBIL.Sample Required?: In adults, a blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm; in newborns, a blood sample from a heelstick; non-invasive technology is available in some healthcare facilities that will measure bilirubin by using an instrument placed on the skin (transcutaneous bilirubin meter)
TBIL.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for several hours before the test; fasting requirements vary by laboratory; ask your lab or healthcare provider for instructions.

TCGR.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a T-cell lymphoma; sometimes to detect and evaluate residual lymphoma cells
TCGR.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have a T-cell lymphoma; when a healthcare practitioner would like to assess whether treatment has been effective and/or whether lymphoma has recurred
TCGR.Sample Required?: A bone marrow, tissue such as a lymph node (biopsy), or body fluid sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TCO2.Why Get Tested?: As part of an electrolyte panel to identify or monitor an electrolyte imbalance or acid-base (pH) imbalance
TCO2.When To Get Tested?: During a routine physical or as recommended by your healthcare practitioner if you are experiencing symptoms such as weakness, confusion, prolonged vomiting, or breathing problems that could indicate an electrolyte imbalance or an acid-base imbalance (commonly described as acidosis or alkalosis)
TCO2.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TCR Gene Rearrangement.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose a T-cell lymphoma; sometimes to detect and evaluate residual lymphoma cells
TCR Gene Rearrangement.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have a T-cell lymphoma; when a healthcare practitioner would like to assess whether treatment has been effective and/or whether lymphoma has recurred
TCR Gene Rearrangement.Sample Required?: A bone marrow, tissue such as a lymph node (biopsy), or body fluid sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TeBG.Why Get Tested?: Most commonly measured in the evaluation of low testosterone (androgen deficiency) in men; also commonly used in the evaluation of women with signs and symptoms of excess male hormones (androgens)
TeBG.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of increased or decreased testosterone and a total testosterone measurement is inconsistent with your symptoms
TeBG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Testosterone.Why Get Tested?: To detect an abnormal testosterone level in males and females; in males, to help diagnose the cause of erectile dysfunction or the inability of your partner to get pregnant (infertility); in females, to help diagnose the cause of masculine physical features (virilization), infertility, or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS); in children, to help determine the cause of genitals that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) or delayed or early puberty
Testosterone.When To Get Tested?:
For males, when you may be infertile or are unable to get or maintain an erection; when you are a boy with either early or delayed sexual maturity (puberty) 
For females, when you have male traits, such as a low voice or excessive body hair (hirsutism), when you have abnormal uterine bleeding, do not menstruate (amenorrhea), or are infertile
Testosterone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a morning sample is preferred.

Testosterone-estrogen Binding Globulin.Why Get Tested?: Most commonly measured in the evaluation of low testosterone (androgen deficiency) in men; also commonly used in the evaluation of women with signs and symptoms of excess male hormones (androgens)
Testosterone-estrogen Binding Globulin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of increased or decreased testosterone and a total testosterone measurement is inconsistent with your symptoms
Testosterone-estrogen Binding Globulin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) testing.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and/or confirm marijuana use
As part of a panel of tests to help detect drug use, impairment, intoxication and/or overdose
To monitor for drug abuse
To monitor compliance with prescription drugs
Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) testing.When To Get Tested?:
During medical screening, such as upon admission to the emergency room or when pregnant or after giving birth
When being treated for chronic pain or for cancer
During random drug screening in the workplace or during the hiring process
As part of a drug rehabilitation program or upon court order
To test for impairment, such as during a traffic stop, or after an accident
Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) testing.Sample Required?:
A random urine specimen is the most commonly tested sample for marijuana. Urine is collected in a clean, sterile container.
Sometimes, saliva is collected in an absorbent pad or swab placed between the lower cheek and gums. This technique is increasingly used in workplace marijuana testing.
Other types of samples that are used less frequently include blood and hair. For newborns, samples may include the umbilical cord or meconium, a newborn's first bowel movement. For more information on these, see Common Questions below.
Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) testing.Test Preparation Needed?:
Prior to testing, declare any prescriptions you are currently taking, including those for medical marijuana.
If saliva is to be collected for testing, you typically should not put anything in your mouth for the 10 minutes prior to the collection of the sample. Follow the directions provided with the sample container.

TfR.Why Get Tested?: To detect iron deficiency anemia and distinguish it from anemia caused by chronic illness or inflammation
TfR.When To Get Tested?: When iron deficiency anemia is suspected
TfR.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Tg.Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment of thyroid cancer and to detect recurrence; less commonly, to help determine the cause of hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism
Tg.When To Get Tested?: Prior to and after the completion of treatment for thyroid cancer, before and after radioactive iodine therapy, and at regular intervals to monitor for recurrence; it may be ordered in conjunction with other thyroid tests for certain thyroid disorders.
Tg.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Tg.Test Preparation Needed?:
Usually none; however, depending on the laboratory method used for measurement of thyroglobulin, some dietary supplements such as multivitamins or supplements rich in vitamin B7 (Biotin) should not be taken at least 12 hours before the test is performed in order to avoid any test interference that may lead to false results.
Based on information provided by the lab, your healthcare practitioner should inform you if this or any other preparation is necessary.

TG.Why Get Tested?: To assess your risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
TG.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a lipid profile during a regular medical exam at least once every four to six years for adults; for children, at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between the ages of 17 and 21
Monitoring: may be done more frequently if you have risk factors for heart disease and/or if you are being treated for unhealthy lipid levels
TG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
TG.Test Preparation Needed?: Current standards recommend that testing be done when you are fasting. For 9 to 12 hours before the test, only water is permitted. In addition, alcohol should not be consumed for 24 hours just before the test. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

TgAb.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
TgAb.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
TgAb.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TGB.Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment of thyroid cancer and to detect recurrence; less commonly, to help determine the cause of hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism
TGB.When To Get Tested?: Prior to and after the completion of treatment for thyroid cancer, before and after radioactive iodine therapy, and at regular intervals to monitor for recurrence; it may be ordered in conjunction with other thyroid tests for certain thyroid disorders.
TGB.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
TGB.Test Preparation Needed?:
Usually none; however, depending on the laboratory method used for measurement of thyroglobulin, some dietary supplements such as multivitamins or supplements rich in vitamin B7 (Biotin) should not be taken at least 12 hours before the test is performed in order to avoid any test interference that may lead to false results.
Based on information provided by the lab, your healthcare practitioner should inform you if this or any other preparation is necessary.

Theophylline and Caffeine.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of theophylline or caffeine in the blood to establish an appropriate dose and to maintain a therapeutic level
Theophylline and Caffeine.When To Get Tested?: At the start of drug therapy and at regular intervals to monitor the drug's concentration; when indicated, to detect low or excessive (potentially toxic) concentrations
Theophylline and Caffeine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from pricking an infant's heel

Theophylline; Caffeine.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of theophylline or caffeine in the blood to establish an appropriate dose and to maintain a therapeutic level
Theophylline; Caffeine.When To Get Tested?: At the start of drug therapy and at regular intervals to monitor the drug's concentration; when indicated, to detect low or excessive (potentially toxic) concentrations
Theophylline; Caffeine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from pricking an infant's heel

thiamine or thiamin (B1).Why Get Tested?: To screen for and detect moderate to severe vitamin B deficiencies
thiamine or thiamin (B1).When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that may be due to a B vitamin deficiency, are at risk for a deficiency, or have a condition associated with malabsorption
thiamine or thiamin (B1).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a random or 24-hour urine sample may also be collected.
thiamine or thiamin (B1).Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is usually required for blood testing.

Thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT).Why Get Tested?: To detect a thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT) deficiency and determine your risk of developing severe side effects if treated with the class of immune-suppressing thiopurine drugs that includes azathioprine, mercaptopurine, and thioguanine
Thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT).When To Get Tested?: Typically, prior to thiopurine drug treatment; this is a specialized test and is not routinely ordered.
Thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a swab from inside your cheek (i.e., buccal swab)
Thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT).Test Preparation Needed?: For measuring TPMT enzyme activity (TPMT phenotyping), the test must be performed prior to taking a thiopurine drug since it may affect results; for the genetic test (TPMT genotyping), no specific test preparation is needed.

Thiopurine S-methyltransferase Phenotype.Why Get Tested?: To detect a thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT) deficiency and determine your risk of developing severe side effects if treated with the class of immune-suppressing thiopurine drugs that includes azathioprine, mercaptopurine, and thioguanine
Thiopurine S-methyltransferase Phenotype.When To Get Tested?: Typically, prior to thiopurine drug treatment; this is a specialized test and is not routinely ordered.
Thiopurine S-methyltransferase Phenotype.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a swab from inside your cheek (i.e., buccal swab)
Thiopurine S-methyltransferase Phenotype.Test Preparation Needed?: For measuring TPMT enzyme activity (TPMT phenotyping), the test must be performed prior to taking a thiopurine drug since it may affect results; for the genetic test (TPMT genotyping), no specific test preparation is needed.

Three-day Measles.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have sufficient rubella antibodies to protect you from the rubella virus; to verify a past infection or detect a recent infection
Three-day Measles.When To Get Tested?: Prior to or at the beginning of a pregnancy to verify immunity; when a pregnant woman has symptoms of rubella, such as fever and rash; when a newborn shows signs of abnormal development or birth defects that may be caused by an in utero infection; whenever there is need to verify a recent rubella infection or to verify immunity
Three-day Measles.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm of an adult or blood drawn from a heelprick or from the umbilical cord of a newborn

Throat Culture.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your sore throat is "strep throat" that is caused by group A streptococcus (GAS) bacteria
Throat Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you have a sore throat that starts quickly and lasts more than a week and/or other symptoms such as a fever of 101° F or higher, or reddened throat and/or tonsils with white or yellow patches or streaks
Throat Culture.Sample Required?: A swab rubbed against the back of your throat and tonsils

Thrombin Clotting Time.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of excessive bleeding or inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; to detect heparin contamination
Thrombin Clotting Time.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes, or recurrent miscarriages; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged, particularly if abnormal fibrinogen level or function is considered; when heparin contamination of a blood sample is suspected
Thrombin Clotting Time.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thrombin Time.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of excessive bleeding or inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; to detect heparin contamination
Thrombin Time.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes, or recurrent miscarriages; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged, particularly if abnormal fibrinogen level or function is considered; when heparin contamination of a blood sample is suspected
Thrombin Time.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thrombocyte Count.Why Get Tested?: To determine the number of platelets in a sample of your blood as part of a health exam; to screen for, diagnose, or monitor conditions that affect the number of platelets, such as a bleeding disorder, a bone marrow disease, or other underlying condition
Thrombocyte Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine complete blood count (CBC); when you have episodes of unexplained or prolonged bleeding or other symptoms that may be due to a platelet disorder
Thrombocyte Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Thymotaxin.Why Get Tested?: To help detect kidney damage and follow kidney disorders; sometimes to monitor people who are exposed to cadmium
Thymotaxin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms and signs associated with kidney dysfunction; periodically if you work with cadmium
Thymotaxin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample

Thyrocalcitonin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor C-cell hyperplasia and medullary thyroid cancer; to screen those at risk for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2)
Thyrocalcitonin.When To Get Tested?: When a healthcare practitioner suspects that you have or when you are being treated for medullary thyroid cancer, or when a family member has medullary thyroid cancer or MEN 2
Thyrocalcitonin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Thyrocalcitonin.Test Preparation Needed?: Overnight fasting may be required; follow instructions provided by your healthcare practitioner or the laboratory.

Thyroglobulin.Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment of thyroid cancer and to detect recurrence; less commonly, to help determine the cause of hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism
Thyroglobulin.When To Get Tested?: Prior to and after the completion of treatment for thyroid cancer, before and after radioactive iodine therapy, and at regular intervals to monitor for recurrence; it may be ordered in conjunction with other thyroid tests for certain thyroid disorders.
Thyroglobulin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Thyroglobulin.Test Preparation Needed?:
Usually none; however, depending on the laboratory method used for measurement of thyroglobulin, some dietary supplements such as multivitamins or supplements rich in vitamin B7 (Biotin) should not be taken at least 12 hours before the test is performed in order to avoid any test interference that may lead to false results.
Based on information provided by the lab, your healthcare practitioner should inform you if this or any other preparation is necessary.

Thyroglobulin, Serum or Plasma.Why Get Tested?: To monitor treatment of thyroid cancer and to detect recurrence; less commonly, to help determine the cause of hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism
Thyroglobulin, Serum or Plasma.When To Get Tested?: Prior to and after the completion of treatment for thyroid cancer, before and after radioactive iodine therapy, and at regular intervals to monitor for recurrence; it may be ordered in conjunction with other thyroid tests for certain thyroid disorders.
Thyroglobulin, Serum or Plasma.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Thyroglobulin, Serum or Plasma.Test Preparation Needed?:
Usually none; however, depending on the laboratory method used for measurement of thyroglobulin, some dietary supplements such as multivitamins or supplements rich in vitamin B7 (Biotin) should not be taken at least 12 hours before the test is performed in order to avoid any test interference that may lead to false results.
Based on information provided by the lab, your healthcare practitioner should inform you if this or any other preparation is necessary.

Thyroid Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Thyroid Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Thyroid Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thyroid Autoantibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Thyroid Autoantibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Thyroid Autoantibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thyroid Function Panel.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate thyroid gland function and to help diagnose thyroid disorders
Thyroid Function Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms suggesting hypo- or hyperthyroidism due to a condition affecting the thyroid
Thyroid Function Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Thyroid Function Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed; however, certain medications can interfere with the tests included in the panel, so tell your health practitioner about any drugs that you are taking.

Thyroid Microsomal Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Thyroid Microsomal Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Thyroid Microsomal Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thyroid Panel.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate thyroid gland function and to help diagnose thyroid disorders
Thyroid Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms suggesting hypo- or hyperthyroidism due to a condition affecting the thyroid
Thyroid Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Thyroid Panel.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed; however, certain medications can interfere with the tests included in the panel, so tell your health practitioner about any drugs that you are taking.

Thyroid Peroxidase Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Thyroid Peroxidase Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Thyroid Peroxidase Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thyroid Peroxidase Antibody; Thyroglobul.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Thyroid Peroxidase Antibody; Thyroglobul.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Thyroid Peroxidase Antibody; Thyroglobul.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thyroid-stimulating Hormone (TSH).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose thyroid disorders and to monitor treatment of hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism; sometimes a TSH test is used to screen newborns for congenital hypothyroidism; there is no consensus within the medical community as to whether screening of adults should be done.
Thyroid-stimulating Hormone (TSH).When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism and/or an enlarged thyroid (goiter) or when you have a thyroid nodule (a small lump on the thyroid gland that may be solid or a fluid-filled cyst); when you are being treated for a thyroid disorder
Thyroid-stimulating Hormone (TSH).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from pricking the heel of an infant
Thyroid-stimulating Hormone (TSH).Test Preparation Needed?: No test preparation is needed. However, certain medications, multivitamins and supplements can interfere with the TSH test, so tell your healthcare practitioner about any prescribed or over-the-counter drugs and/or supplements that you are taking. If you take thyroid hormone as treatment for thyroid disease, it is recommended that your blood sample be drawn before you take your dose for that day. Acute illness may affect TSH test results. It is generally recommended that thyroid testing be avoided in hospitalized patients or deferred until after a person has recovered from an acute illness.

Thyroperoxidase Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Thyroperoxidase Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Thyroperoxidase Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thyrotropin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose thyroid disorders and to monitor treatment of hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism; sometimes a TSH test is used to screen newborns for congenital hypothyroidism; there is no consensus within the medical community as to whether screening of adults should be done.
Thyrotropin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism and/or an enlarged thyroid (goiter) or when you have a thyroid nodule (a small lump on the thyroid gland that may be solid or a fluid-filled cyst); when you are being treated for a thyroid disorder
Thyrotropin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from pricking the heel of an infant
Thyrotropin.Test Preparation Needed?: No test preparation is needed. However, certain medications, multivitamins and supplements can interfere with the TSH test, so tell your healthcare practitioner about any prescribed or over-the-counter drugs and/or supplements that you are taking. If you take thyroid hormone as treatment for thyroid disease, it is recommended that your blood sample be drawn before you take your dose for that day. Acute illness may affect TSH test results. It is generally recommended that thyroid testing be avoided in hospitalized patients or deferred until after a person has recovered from an acute illness.

Thyrotropin Receptor Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
Thyrotropin Receptor Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
Thyrotropin Receptor Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Thyroxine.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate thyroid gland function; to help diagnose thyroid disease; to monitor effectiveness of thyroid treatment; sometimes a free T4 is used to help diagnose congenital hypothyroidism in newborns
Thyroxine.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of thyroid disease and/or an enlarged thyroid (goiter) or when you have a thyroid nodule (a small lump on the thyroid gland that may be solid or fluid-filled cyst), usually after an abnormal result on a TSH test; when you are being treated for a thyroid disorder
Thyroxine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from pricking the heel of an infant
Thyroxine.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed; however, certain medications, multivitamins and supplements can interfere with the free T4 test, so tell your healthcare provider about any prescribed or over-the-counter drugs and/or supplements that you are taking. If you take thyroid hormone as treatment for thyroid disease, it is recommended that your blood sample be drawn before you take your dose for that day. Acute illness may affect thyroid testing results. It is generally recommended that thyroid testing be avoided in hospitalized patients or deferred until after a person has recovered from an acute illness.

Thyroxine-binding Prealbumin.Why Get Tested?: Reasons for ordering the prealbumin test are undergoing reassessment as understanding of prealbumin is evolving. Historically, prealbumin has been ordered to help detect protein-calorie malnutrition and to monitor the effectiveness of parenteral (for example, intravenous) nutrition. Newer evidence suggests that the reasons for changes in prealbumin levels may be more complex and the test should not be interpreted as a simple indicator of nutritional status.
Thyroxine-binding Prealbumin.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested, although prealbumin may be ordered, along with assessments of nutritional intake, when a healthcare practitioner suspects that someone is malnourished or is at risk of malnutrition.
Thyroxine-binding Prealbumin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TIBC.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to assess your body's ability to transport iron in the blood; to help diagnose iron-deficiency or iron overload
TIBC.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects you may have too much iron (overload) or too little iron (deficiency) in the body
TIBC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
TIBC.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Tissue Transglutaminase Antibody; Deamin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
Tissue Transglutaminase Antibody; Deamin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
Tissue Transglutaminase Antibody; Deamin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Tissue Transglutaminase Antibody; Deamin.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

TnI.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have had a heart attack or injury to heart muscle; to determine if your angina (chest pain related to heart trouble) is worsening
TnI.When To Get Tested?: Immediately, then followed by a series of troponin tests over several hours when you are having signs and symptoms that may be due to a heart attack, such as pain in your chest, shoulders, neck, jaw and/or shortness of breath; when your angina worsens, especially if it does not resolve with rest
TnI.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
TnI.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but tell your healthcare practitioner or emergency department personnel about any over-the-counter or prescription medications and/or supplements you take.

TnT.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have had a heart attack or injury to heart muscle; to determine if your angina (chest pain related to heart trouble) is worsening
TnT.When To Get Tested?: Immediately, then followed by a series of troponin tests over several hours when you are having signs and symptoms that may be due to a heart attack, such as pain in your chest, shoulders, neck, jaw and/or shortness of breath; when your angina worsens, especially if it does not resolve with rest
TnT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
TnT.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but tell your healthcare practitioner or emergency department personnel about any over-the-counter or prescription medications and/or supplements you take.

TORCH.Why Get Tested?: To detect certain infectious diseases that can cause birth defects in a newborn; sometimes to screen pregnant women for these infections
TORCH.When To Get Tested?: When a baby is born with congenital abnormalities that may be caused by an infection with one of the diseases included in the panel; sometimes if a woman is exposed to certain infections or becomes ill while pregnant
TORCH.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the woman's arm by needle or by heelstick for infants

TORCH Panel.Why Get Tested?: To detect certain infectious diseases that can cause birth defects in a newborn; sometimes to screen pregnant women for these infections
TORCH Panel.When To Get Tested?: When a baby is born with congenital abnormalities that may be caused by an infection with one of the diseases included in the panel; sometimes if a woman is exposed to certain infections or becomes ill while pregnant
TORCH Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the woman's arm by needle or by heelstick for infants

TORCH Test.Why Get Tested?: To detect certain infectious diseases that can cause birth defects in a newborn; sometimes to screen pregnant women for these infections
TORCH Test.When To Get Tested?: When a baby is born with congenital abnormalities that may be caused by an infection with one of the diseases included in the panel; sometimes if a woman is exposed to certain infections or becomes ill while pregnant
TORCH Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the woman's arm by needle or by heelstick for infants

Total AFP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor therapy for certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries
Total AFP.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that you have certain cancers of the liver, testicles, or ovaries; at intervals during and after treatment for one of these cancers; sometimes when you have cancer-predisposing diseases such as chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis
Total AFP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Total beta hCG.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors
Total beta hCG.When To Get Tested?: When your symptoms suggest gestational trophoblastic disease or germ cell tumors; to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment for these conditions; to monitor for recurrence
Total beta hCG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein

Total Bilirubin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor liver disorders or hemolytic anemia; to monitor neonatal jaundice
Total Bilirubin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of liver damage, liver disease, bile duct blockage, hemolytic anemia, or a liver-related metabolic problem, or if a newborn has jaundice
Total Bilirubin.Sample Required?: In adults, a blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm; in newborns, a blood sample from a heelstick; non-invasive technology is available in some healthcare facilities that will measure bilirubin by using an instrument placed on the skin (transcutaneous bilirubin meter)
Total Bilirubin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for several hours before the test; fasting requirements vary by laboratory; ask your lab or healthcare provider for instructions.

Total Calcium.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, diagnose, and monitor a range of medical conditions
Total Calcium.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine metabolic panel; when you have symptoms of a disorder, or known presence of one, affecting your kidneys, bones, thyroid, parathyroid, or nerves or when symptoms of significantly increased or decreased calcium concentrations are present; when someone is critically ill, to monitor ionized calcium levels; when someone has certain types of cancer; when someone is being treated for abnormal calcium levels, to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment
Total Calcium.Sample Required?: A blood sample is taken by needle from a vein in the arm. If a urine collection is required, a 24-hour urine sample or a timed collection of a shorter duration is obtained. Sometimes a random urine collection may be used, although a timed collection is preferred.
Total Calcium.Test Preparation Needed?: Current practices do not require fasting. You may be instructed to stop taking certain medications, such as lithium, antacids, diuretics, and vitamin D supplements, among others, to ensure the most accurate test results.

Total Carbamazepine.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of carbamazepine in the blood to establish an appropriate dose and maintain a therapeutic level
Total Carbamazepine.When To Get Tested?: At regular intervals to monitor the drug's level; when indicated to detect low or excessive (potentially toxic) concentrations
Total Carbamazepine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Total Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To screen for risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
Total Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a regular health exam with a lipid profile when no risk factors for heart disease are present; adults should be tested once every four to six years; children, teens, and young adults should be tested once between the ages of 9 and 11 and then again between the ages of 17 and 21.
Monitoring: may be done more frequently and at regular intervals when risk factors for heart disease are present, when prior results showed high risk levels, and/or when undergoing treatment for unhealthy lipid levels
Total Cholesterol.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample is collected from a vein in the arm. Sometimes cholesterol is measured using a drop of blood collected by puncturing the skin on a finger. A fingerstick sample is typically used when cholesterol is being measured on a portable testing device, for example, at a health fair.
Total Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: Cholesterol tests typically require fasting for 9-12 hours before the test; only water is permitted. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted. For youths without risk factors, testing may be done without fasting.

Total CK.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor muscle damage; to help diagnose conditions associated with muscle damage; for heart attack detection, this test has been largely replaced by troponin T and I – markers more specific to cardiac tissue; however, it may sometimes be used to help detect a second or subsequent heart attack (see Common Questions #4).
Total CK.When To Get Tested?: When you have muscle weakness, muscle aches, and/or dark urine and your healthcare practitioner suspects muscle damage; sometimes to monitor for muscle injury resolution or persistence
Total CK.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Total CO2.Why Get Tested?: As part of an electrolyte panel to identify or monitor an electrolyte imbalance or acid-base (pH) imbalance
Total CO2.When To Get Tested?: During a routine physical or as recommended by your healthcare practitioner if you are experiencing symptoms such as weakness, confusion, prolonged vomiting, or breathing problems that could indicate an electrolyte imbalance or an acid-base imbalance (commonly described as acidosis or alkalosis)
Total CO2.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Total Complement.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether deficiencies or abnormalities in complement system proteins are contributing to increased infections or increased autoimmune activity; to help monitor the activity and treatment of autoimmune diseases and immune complex-related diseases (Complement deficiencies may comprise between 1 and 10% of all primary immunodeficiencies.)
Total Complement.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent microbial (usually bacterial) infections, unexplained inflammation or edema, or symptoms related to an autoimmune disorder; periodically to help monitor a known acute or chronic condition that affects the complement system
Total Complement.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Total hCG.Why Get Tested?: To confirm a pregnancy; to help identify an ectopic pregnancy; to monitor a pregnancy that may be at risk of failing; occasionally to screen a woman for pregnancy prior to some medical treatments; as part of a panel of tests used to screen for fetal abnormalities (see First Trimester Down Syndrome Screen and Second Trimester Maternal Serum Screening)
Total hCG.When To Get Tested?: When you suspect that you are pregnant (testing can be done reliably by 10 days after you miss your menstrual period and some methods can detect hCG even earlier); when you have signs and symptoms that suggest you may have an ectopic pregnancy or a pregnancy that is failing; prior to some medical treatments
Total hCG.Sample Required?: A urine sample collected first thing in the morning or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Total hCG.Test Preparation Needed?: Do not drink large amounts of fluid before collecting a urine sample for a pregnancy test because overly diluted urine may result in a false negative; no preparation is needed for a blood sample.

Total IgA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
Total IgA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
Total IgA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Total IgA.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

Total IgE.Why Get Tested?: To screen for an allergic disease; sometimes to screen for a parasitic infection
Total IgE.When To Get Tested?: When you have periodic or persistent skin, lung, or digestive symptoms that suggest allergies; when a healthcare practitioner suspects a parasitic infection
Total IgE.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Total Immunoglobulins.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's immune system status; to detect and monitor an excess or deficiency in one or more of the immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM)
Total Immunoglobulins.When To Get Tested?: When you have recurrent infections and/or chronic diarrhea; when your healthcare practitioner suspects an immunoglobulin deficiency or excess of a particular immunoglobulin; periodically to monitor a condition that affects immunoglobulin levels that may be genetic (selective IgA deficiency) or acquired (HIV/AIDS, multiple myeloma)
Total Immunoglobulins.Sample Required?: A blood sample is obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. When required, a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected by a healthcare practitioner from the lower back using a procedure called a lumbar puncture or spinal tap. Saliva or other fluids are collected in a container provided by the laboratory.

Total Protein and Albumin/Globulin (A/G).Why Get Tested?: As part of a general health checkup, to determine your nutritional status or to screen for and help diagnose certain liver and kidney disorders as well as other diseases
Total Protein and Albumin/Globulin (A/G).When To Get Tested?: When you have a routine physical exam or when you experience unexpected weight loss or fatigue, or when a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver or kidney disorder
Total Protein and Albumin/Globulin (A/G).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick (adults and children) or heelstick (newborns)

Total Protein; Albumin to Globulin Ratio.Why Get Tested?: As part of a general health checkup, to determine your nutritional status or to screen for and help diagnose certain liver and kidney disorders as well as other diseases
Total Protein; Albumin to Globulin Ratio.When To Get Tested?: When you have a routine physical exam or when you experience unexpected weight loss or fatigue, or when a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver or kidney disorder
Total Protein; Albumin to Globulin Ratio.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick (adults and children) or heelstick (newborns)

Total PSA.Why Get Tested?: To screen men for prostate cancer, to help determine the necessity for a biopsy of the prostate, to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for prostate cancer, and/or to detect recurrence of prostate cancer
Total PSA.When To Get Tested?: When a man has symptoms suggestive of prostate cancer such as difficult, painful, and/or frequent urination; may also be ordered during and at regular intervals after prostate cancer treatment; in asymptomatic men, after a discussion with your healthcare provider about the benefits and harms of screening and you make an informed decision to undergo screening (For specific details, see prostate cancer screening for Adults and Adults 50 and Up).
Total PSA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Total PSA.Test Preparation Needed?: Avoid ejaculation for 24 hours before sample collection as it has been associated with elevated PSA levels; the sample should also be collected prior to your health practitioner performing a digital rectal exam (DRE) and prior to (or several weeks after) a prostate biopsy.

Total Testosterone.Why Get Tested?: To detect an abnormal testosterone level in males and females; in males, to help diagnose the cause of erectile dysfunction or the inability of your partner to get pregnant (infertility); in females, to help diagnose the cause of masculine physical features (virilization), infertility, or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS); in children, to help determine the cause of genitals that are not clearly male or female (ambiguous genitalia) or delayed or early puberty
Total Testosterone.When To Get Tested?:
For males, when you may be infertile or are unable to get or maintain an erection; when you are a boy with either early or delayed sexual maturity (puberty) 
For females, when you have male traits, such as a low voice or excessive body hair (hirsutism), when you have abnormal uterine bleeding, do not menstruate (amenorrhea), or are infertile
Total Testosterone.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a morning sample is preferred.

Total Tryptase.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose anaphylaxis, mastocytosis (too many mast cells), or mast cell activation
Total Tryptase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as flushing, nausea, throat swelling, or low blood pressure that may be due to a life-threatening allergic reaction; when your healthcare provider suspects that you have mastocytosis or mast cell activation
Total Tryptase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Total Tryptase.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample soon after the beginning of symptoms can be important.

Tox Screen.Why Get Tested?: To screen for drug abuse, to monitor someone with a substance abuse problem, to monitor compliance with prescribed medications, or to detect and evaluate drug intoxication or overdose
Tox Screen.When To Get Tested?: Sometimes required prior to the start of a new job or insurance policy; randomly for workplace drug testing or athletic drug testing programs; as mandated when court-ordered; as indicated when ordered by a health practitioner to monitor a known or suspected substance abuse patient; sometimes when you are pregnant, will be receiving an organ transplant, when you are prescribed pain medication, or when you have symptoms suggesting drug intoxication or overdose
Tox Screen.Sample Required?: A random urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; hair, saliva, or sweat
Tox Screen.Test Preparation Needed?: Some prescription and over-the-counter drugs may give a positive screening result; prior to testing, indicate any medications that you have taken and/or for which you have prescriptions.

Toxic Metals.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, detect, and monitor excessive exposure to specific heavy metals
Toxic Metals.When To Get Tested?: Periodically when you work with heavy metals, or when a healthcare practitioner suspects that you may have been exposed
Toxic Metals.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a 24-hour urine sample; rarely, a hair or nail sample, tissue sample, or other body fluid sample
Toxic Metals.Test Preparation Needed?: 48 hours before collection, you should not eat seafood. If you have had a procedure in which either gadolinium- or iodine-containing contrast media has been administered, wait 96 hours before sample collection.

Toxicology Assays.Why Get Tested?: To detect, quantify, and occasionally monitor drugs that are causing acute overdose symptoms; results from emergency and overdose testing are used primarily for treatment purposes; if results are needed for legal proceedings, then specific legal (forensic) procedures must be followed for sample collection, storage, and testing.
Toxicology Assays.When To Get Tested?: When a person has symptoms such as delirium, difficulty breathing, nausea, agitation, seizures, changes in heart rhythm, characteristic odors, or increased temperature that an emergency room health practitioner thinks may be drug-related; at intervals to monitor a drug overdose
Toxicology Assays.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a urine sample, or sometimes a breath sample; rarely, saliva or another body fluid

Toxicology Screen.Why Get Tested?: To screen for drug abuse, to monitor someone with a substance abuse problem, to monitor compliance with prescribed medications, or to detect and evaluate drug intoxication or overdose
Toxicology Screen.When To Get Tested?: Sometimes required prior to the start of a new job or insurance policy; randomly for workplace drug testing or athletic drug testing programs; as mandated when court-ordered; as indicated when ordered by a health practitioner to monitor a known or suspected substance abuse patient; sometimes when you are pregnant, will be receiving an organ transplant, when you are prescribed pain medication, or when you have symptoms suggesting drug intoxication or overdose
Toxicology Screen.Sample Required?: A random urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; hair, saliva, or sweat
Toxicology Screen.Test Preparation Needed?: Some prescription and over-the-counter drugs may give a positive screening result; prior to testing, indicate any medications that you have taken and/or for which you have prescriptions.

Toxoplasma gondii Antibodies, IgG, IgM;.Why Get Tested?: To detect a Toxoplasma gondii infection in a pregnant woman, unborn baby, or in a person with a weakened immune system (immunocompromised) who has flu-like symptoms; sometimes to determine if a person has been previously infected or to help determine if complications are due to an active Toxoplasma infection
Toxoplasma gondii Antibodies, IgG, IgM;.When To Get Tested?: When a pregnant woman or a person with a weakened immune system has been exposed to T. gondii and/or has flu-like symptoms or a severe eye or brain infection that a health practitioner suspects are due to toxoplasmosis
Toxoplasma gondii Antibodies, IgG, IgM;.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or amniotic fluid sample

Toxoplasma gondii, T. gondii.Why Get Tested?: To detect a Toxoplasma gondii infection in a pregnant woman, unborn baby, or in a person with a weakened immune system (immunocompromised) who has flu-like symptoms; sometimes to determine if a person has been previously infected or to help determine if complications are due to an active Toxoplasma infection
Toxoplasma gondii, T. gondii.When To Get Tested?: When a pregnant woman or a person with a weakened immune system has been exposed to T. gondii and/or has flu-like symptoms or a severe eye or brain infection that a health practitioner suspects are due to toxoplasmosis
Toxoplasma gondii, T. gondii.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or amniotic fluid sample

Toxoplasmosis Testing.Why Get Tested?: To detect a Toxoplasma gondii infection in a pregnant woman, unborn baby, or in a person with a weakened immune system (immunocompromised) who has flu-like symptoms; sometimes to determine if a person has been previously infected or to help determine if complications are due to an active Toxoplasma infection
Toxoplasmosis Testing.When To Get Tested?: When a pregnant woman or a person with a weakened immune system has been exposed to T. gondii and/or has flu-like symptoms or a severe eye or brain infection that a health practitioner suspects are due to toxoplasmosis
Toxoplasmosis Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or amniotic fluid sample

TP.Why Get Tested?: As part of a general health checkup, to determine your nutritional status or to screen for and help diagnose certain liver and kidney disorders as well as other diseases
TP.When To Get Tested?: When you have a routine physical exam or when you experience unexpected weight loss or fatigue, or when a healthcare practitioner thinks that you have symptoms of a liver or kidney disorder
TP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by fingerstick (adults and children) or heelstick (newborns)

TPMT Genotype.Why Get Tested?: To detect a thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT) deficiency and determine your risk of developing severe side effects if treated with the class of immune-suppressing thiopurine drugs that includes azathioprine, mercaptopurine, and thioguanine
TPMT Genotype.When To Get Tested?: Typically, prior to thiopurine drug treatment; this is a specialized test and is not routinely ordered.
TPMT Genotype.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a swab from inside your cheek (i.e., buccal swab)
TPMT Genotype.Test Preparation Needed?: For measuring TPMT enzyme activity (TPMT phenotyping), the test must be performed prior to taking a thiopurine drug since it may affect results; for the genetic test (TPMT genotyping), no specific test preparation is needed.

TPMT Phenotype.Why Get Tested?: To detect a thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT) deficiency and determine your risk of developing severe side effects if treated with the class of immune-suppressing thiopurine drugs that includes azathioprine, mercaptopurine, and thioguanine
TPMT Phenotype.When To Get Tested?: Typically, prior to thiopurine drug treatment; this is a specialized test and is not routinely ordered.
TPMT Phenotype.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a swab from inside your cheek (i.e., buccal swab)
TPMT Phenotype.Test Preparation Needed?: For measuring TPMT enzyme activity (TPMT phenotyping), the test must be performed prior to taking a thiopurine drug since it may affect results; for the genetic test (TPMT genotyping), no specific test preparation is needed.

TPMT RBC.Why Get Tested?: To detect a thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT) deficiency and determine your risk of developing severe side effects if treated with the class of immune-suppressing thiopurine drugs that includes azathioprine, mercaptopurine, and thioguanine
TPMT RBC.When To Get Tested?: Typically, prior to thiopurine drug treatment; this is a specialized test and is not routinely ordered.
TPMT RBC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a swab from inside your cheek (i.e., buccal swab)
TPMT RBC.Test Preparation Needed?: For measuring TPMT enzyme activity (TPMT phenotyping), the test must be performed prior to taking a thiopurine drug since it may affect results; for the genetic test (TPMT genotyping), no specific test preparation is needed.

TPO.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
TPO.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
TPO.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TPPA.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
TPPA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
TPPA.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

TRAb.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
TRAb.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
TRAb.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Trace Elements.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor a mineral deficiency or excess; sometimes to evaluate your nutritional status
Trace Elements.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms or signs of a mineral deficiency or excess; as indicated by your healthcare provider when you have a condition that affects mineral absorption, use, or storage
Trace Elements.Sample Required?: Trace mineral testing is usually performed on a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes a 24-hour urine collection is obtained. Special metal-free blood or acid-washed urine containers are used to minimize the potential for sample contamination by any outside sources of minerals. Rarely, hair may be collected or a biopsy may be performed to obtain a tissue sample to evaluate mineral deficiencies, excesses, and storage that have occurred over time.
Trace Elements.Test Preparation Needed?: Check with your healthcare practitioner to find out if fasting is needed before your test.

Trace Minerals.Why Get Tested?: To detect and monitor a mineral deficiency or excess; sometimes to evaluate your nutritional status
