Trace Minerals.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms or signs of a mineral deficiency or excess; as indicated by your healthcare provider when you have a condition that affects mineral absorption, use, or storage
Trace Minerals.Sample Required?: Trace mineral testing is usually performed on a blood sample obtained by inserting a needle into a vein in the arm. Sometimes a 24-hour urine collection is obtained. Special metal-free blood or acid-washed urine containers are used to minimize the potential for sample contamination by any outside sources of minerals. Rarely, hair may be collected or a biopsy may be performed to obtain a tissue sample to evaluate mineral deficiencies, excesses, and storage that have occurred over time.
Trace Minerals.Test Preparation Needed?: Check with your healthcare practitioner to find out if fasting is needed before your test.

Transferrin and Iron-binding Capacity (T.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to assess your body's ability to transport iron in the blood; to help diagnose iron-deficiency or iron overload
Transferrin and Iron-binding Capacity (T.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects you may have too much iron (overload) or too little iron (deficiency) in the body
Transferrin and Iron-binding Capacity (T.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Transferrin and Iron-binding Capacity (T.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Transferrin Receptor.Why Get Tested?: To detect iron deficiency anemia and distinguish it from anemia caused by chronic illness or inflammation
Transferrin Receptor.When To Get Tested?: When iron deficiency anemia is suspected
Transferrin Receptor.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Transferrin, Total Iron Binding Capacity.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to assess your body's ability to transport iron in the blood; to help diagnose iron-deficiency or iron overload
Transferrin, Total Iron Binding Capacity.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects you may have too much iron (overload) or too little iron (deficiency) in the body
Transferrin, Total Iron Binding Capacity.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Transferrin, Total Iron Binding Capacity.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Transthyretin.Why Get Tested?: Reasons for ordering the prealbumin test are undergoing reassessment as understanding of prealbumin is evolving. Historically, prealbumin has been ordered to help detect protein-calorie malnutrition and to monitor the effectiveness of parenteral (for example, intravenous) nutrition. Newer evidence suggests that the reasons for changes in prealbumin levels may be more complex and the test should not be interpreted as a simple indicator of nutritional status.
Transthyretin.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested, although prealbumin may be ordered, along with assessments of nutritional intake, when a healthcare practitioner suspects that someone is malnourished or is at risk of malnutrition.
Transthyretin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TRAP.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate and monitor the rate of bone resorption and formation; to monitor some metabolic bone diseases such as osteoporosis; to help detect metabolic bone disorders such as Paget disease
TRAP.When To Get Tested?: When a bone mineral density scan indicates reduced bone density; before and periodically during treatment for bone loss to evaluate effectiveness, to determine if the rate of loss has decreased or the rate of bone formation has increased
TRAP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or sometimes a urine sample
TRAP.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting may be required before testing; samples are typically collected in the morning.

Treponema pallidum by PCR.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Treponema pallidum by PCR.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Treponema pallidum by PCR.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Treponema pallidum Particle Agglutinatio.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Treponema pallidum Particle Agglutinatio.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Treponema pallidum Particle Agglutinatio.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Trichomonas Testing.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, which causes the sexually transmitted disease trichomoniasis
Trichomonas Testing.When To Get Tested?: When a woman has symptoms of infection, such as a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, genital itching, and/or pain during urination, or when a man has genital itching or irritation, burning after urination or ejaculation, and/or a discharge from the penis
Trichomonas Testing.Sample Required?: For men or women, the initial portion of urine stream (first-catch urine sample); or in women, a swab of fluid and cells from the vagina or cervix; or in men, a swab from the tube that carries urine from the bladder to outside the body (urethra).

Trichomonas vaginalis testing.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, which causes the sexually transmitted disease trichomoniasis
Trichomonas vaginalis testing.When To Get Tested?: When a woman has symptoms of infection, such as a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, genital itching, and/or pain during urination, or when a man has genital itching or irritation, burning after urination or ejaculation, and/or a discharge from the penis
Trichomonas vaginalis testing.Sample Required?: For men or women, the initial portion of urine stream (first-catch urine sample); or in women, a swab of fluid and cells from the vagina or cervix; or in men, a swab from the tube that carries urine from the bladder to outside the body (urethra).

TRIG.Why Get Tested?: To assess your risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
TRIG.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a lipid profile during a regular medical exam at least once every four to six years for adults; for children, at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between the ages of 17 and 21
Monitoring: may be done more frequently if you have risk factors for heart disease and/or if you are being treated for unhealthy lipid levels
TRIG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
TRIG.Test Preparation Needed?: Current standards recommend that testing be done when you are fasting. For 9 to 12 hours before the test, only water is permitted. In addition, alcohol should not be consumed for 24 hours just before the test. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

Triglycerides.Why Get Tested?: To assess your risk of developing heart disease; to monitor effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapy
Triglycerides.When To Get Tested?:
Screening: as part of a lipid profile during a regular medical exam at least once every four to six years for adults; for children, at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between the ages of 17 and 21
Monitoring: may be done more frequently if you have risk factors for heart disease and/or if you are being treated for unhealthy lipid levels
Triglycerides.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick
Triglycerides.Test Preparation Needed?: Current standards recommend that testing be done when you are fasting. For 9 to 12 hours before the test, only water is permitted. In addition, alcohol should not be consumed for 24 hours just before the test. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

Triiodothyronine.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate thyroid gland function; to diagnose thyroid disease, including hyperthyroidism, and determine the cause; to monitor effectiveness of treatment of a thyroid disorder
Triiodothyronine.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), particularly with a normal free thyroxine (T4) result, and/or signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism
Triiodothyronine.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken from a vein in your arm
Triiodothyronine.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed; however, certain medications, multivitamins and supplements can interfere with the free T3 and total T3 tests, so tell your healthcare practitioner about any prescribed or over-the-counter drugs and/or supplements that you are taking. Acute illness may affect thyroid testing test results. It is generally recommended that thyroid testing be avoided in hospitalized patients or deferred until after a person has recovered from an acute illness.

Triple Screen.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
Triple Screen.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
Triple Screen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Triple Test.Why Get Tested?: For pregnant women, to assess the risk of having a baby with certain chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), or open neural tube defects, such as spina bifida
Triple Test.When To Get Tested?: Usually between the 15th and 20th weeks of pregnancy
Triple Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Troponin.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have had a heart attack or injury to heart muscle; to determine if your angina (chest pain related to heart trouble) is worsening
Troponin.When To Get Tested?: Immediately, then followed by a series of troponin tests over several hours when you are having signs and symptoms that may be due to a heart attack, such as pain in your chest, shoulders, neck, jaw and/or shortness of breath; when your angina worsens, especially if it does not resolve with rest
Troponin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
Troponin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but tell your healthcare practitioner or emergency department personnel about any over-the-counter or prescription medications and/or supplements you take.

Trypsin-like Immunoreactivity.Why Get Tested?: To screen for cystic fibrosis (CF); sometimes to detect pancreatitis
Trypsin-like Immunoreactivity.When To Get Tested?: As part of a newborn screening test; sometimes when you have symptoms of pancreatitis, such as severe abdominal pain that may be persistent or intermittent, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and jaundice
Trypsin-like Immunoreactivity.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from an infant's heel, a spot of blood that is put onto filter paper, or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Tryptase.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose anaphylaxis, mastocytosis (too many mast cells), or mast cell activation
Tryptase.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms such as flushing, nausea, throat swelling, or low blood pressure that may be due to a life-threatening allergic reaction; when your healthcare provider suspects that you have mastocytosis or mast cell activation
Tryptase.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Tryptase.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample soon after the beginning of symptoms can be important.

TSH Receptor Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
TSH Receptor Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
TSH Receptor Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TSI.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and monitor autoimmune thyroid diseases and to distinguish these from other forms of thyroid disease; to help guide treatment decisions
TSI.When To Get Tested?: When you have an enlarged thyroid (goiter) and/or when your other thyroid tests, such as total or free T3, free T4, and TSH, indicate thyroid dysfunction; along with a thyroglobulin test when your healthcare provider is using it as a monitoring tool; at intervals recommended by your healthcare provider when you have a known autoimmune thyroid disorder
TSI.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

TT.Why Get Tested?: As part of an investigation of excessive bleeding or inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode), particularly to evaluate the level and function of fibrinogen; to detect heparin contamination
TT.When To Get Tested?: When you have bleeding or thrombotic episodes, or recurrent miscarriages; when a PT and/or PTT test is prolonged, particularly if abnormal fibrinogen level or function is considered; when heparin contamination of a blood sample is suspected
TT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

tTG.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
tTG.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
tTG.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
tTG.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

tTGA.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose celiac disease and to evaluate the effectiveness of a gluten-free diet
tTGA.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting celiac disease, such as chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, anemia, and weight loss; when an infant is chronically irritable or fails to grow at a normal rate; when a close family member has celiac disease; when you are being treated for celiac disease
tTGA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
tTGA.Test Preparation Needed?: Follow your health practitioner's instructions; for diagnosis, you should continue to eat foods that contain gluten for a time period, such as several weeks, prior to testing; for monitoring, no preparation is necessary.

Tuberculin Skin Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for tuberculosis (TB) active or latent infection
Tuberculin Skin Test.When To Get Tested?: If you have been exposed to a person with TB; if you have a clinical condition or risk factor that makes progression to active TB more likely
Tuberculin Skin Test.Sample Required?: No sample is required. A small amount of purified protein derivative (PPD) solution is injected with a tuberculin syringe just under the first layer of skin of your inner forearm.

type 1 diabetes.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
type 1 diabetes.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
type 1 diabetes.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
type 1 diabetes.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

type 2 diabetes.Why Get Tested?: To assess kidney function and diagnose, stage, and monitor chronic kidney disease (CKD)
type 2 diabetes.When To Get Tested?: With a blood creatinine test as part of a routine health exam or when your healthcare practitioner thinks that you may have kidney damage or that you may be at risk for developing kidney disease
type 2 diabetes.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; the eGFR is a calculated estimate of the actual glomerular filtration rate and is based on your blood creatinine level along with other variables such as your age, sex, and race, depending on the equation used.
type 2 diabetes.Test Preparation Needed?: This test uses a blood creatinine level to calculate a result. You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

UA.Why Get Tested?: To detect high levels of uric acid in the blood, which could be a sign of the condition gout, or to monitor uric acid levels when undergoing chemotherapy or radiation treatment; to detect high levels of uric acid in the urine in order to diagnose the cause of kidney stones and to monitor those with gout who are at risk of developing such stones
UA.When To Get Tested?: When you have joint pain or other symptoms that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to gout; when you have had or are going to have certain chemotherapy or radiation therapies for cancer; when you have recurrent kidney stones; when you have gout or are otherwise at risk for kidney stone formation
UA.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm or a 24-hour urine sample
UA.Test Preparation Needed?: None may be needed; however, some institutions recommend fasting. Follow any instructions you are given.

UACR.Why Get Tested?: To detect early kidney disease in those with diabetes or other risk factors, such as high blood pressure (hypertension)
UACR.When To Get Tested?: Annually after a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes; annually 5 years after diagnosis of type 1 diabetes
UACR.Sample Required?: A random, timed, overnight, or 24-hour urine sample

UIBC.Why Get Tested?: Along with other iron tests, to assess your body's ability to transport iron in the blood; to help diagnose iron-deficiency or iron overload
UIBC.When To Get Tested?: When you have low hemoglobin and hematocrit on a complete blood count (CBC); when your healthcare practitioner suspects you may have too much iron (overload) or too little iron (deficiency) in the body
UIBC.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
UIBC.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to have your blood drawn in the morning and/or fast for 12 hours before the test; in this case, only water is allowed. Follow any instructions from your healthcare practitioner and/or from the laboratory performing the test.

Ultra-sensitive CRP.Why Get Tested?: To help assess your risk of developing cardiovascular disease
Ultra-sensitive CRP.When To Get Tested?: No current consensus exists on when to get tested; hs-CRP is often ordered in conjunction with other tests that are performed to assess risk of heart disease, such as a lipid profile (cholesterol, triglycerides, HDL-C, LDL-C) when your healthcare provider would like additional information on your risk.
Ultra-sensitive CRP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Ultra-sensitive CRP.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 9-12 hours before the blood sample is taken if a lipid profile also is going to be done at the same time. You should be healthy at the time of the sample collection, without any recent illnesses, infections, inflammation, or injuries.

Unconjugated Bilirubin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or monitor liver disorders or hemolytic anemia; to monitor neonatal jaundice
Unconjugated Bilirubin.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs or symptoms of liver damage, liver disease, bile duct blockage, hemolytic anemia, or a liver-related metabolic problem, or if a newborn has jaundice
Unconjugated Bilirubin.Sample Required?: In adults, a blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm; in newborns, a blood sample from a heelstick; non-invasive technology is available in some healthcare facilities that will measure bilirubin by using an instrument placed on the skin (transcutaneous bilirubin meter)
Unconjugated Bilirubin.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to fast (nothing but water) for several hours before the test; fasting requirements vary by laboratory; ask your lab or healthcare provider for instructions.

UPCR.Why Get Tested?: To screen for excess protein in the urine, to help evaluate and monitor kidney function, and to detect kidney damage
UPCR.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine physical, as a follow-up to a previous positive urine protein test, or when you have a disorder or disease that affects the kidney
UPCR.Sample Required?: A single urine sample collected at any time (random) or 24-hour urine sample; occasionally, a split 24-hour sample, with the night collection (11pm to 7am) separated from the day collection (7am to 11pm). Often, a blood sample may also be taken to measure your creatinine and serum protein levels, especially when a 24-hour urine has been ordered.

UPE.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
UPE.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
UPE.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

UPEP.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
UPEP.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
UPEP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Urea.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor the effectiveness of dialysis and other treatments related to kidney disease or damage
Urea.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or you have a condition that may cause or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at regular intervals when you are being treated for kidney disease or damage
Urea.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Urea breath test.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with Helicobacter pylori, bacteria that can cause peptic ulcers
Urea breath test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an ulcer, such as gastrointestinal pain that comes and goes, unexplained weight loss, nausea and/or vomiting
Urea breath test.Sample Required?: A stool sample, a breath sample, or a tissue biopsy of the stomach lining
Urea breath test.Test Preparation Needed?: You may need to avoid certain medications; follow any instructions you are given.

Urea Nitrogen.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor the effectiveness of dialysis and other treatments related to kidney disease or damage
Urea Nitrogen.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when you have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or you have a condition that may cause or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at regular intervals when you are being treated for kidney disease or damage
Urea Nitrogen.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Ureaplasma Culture.Why Get Tested?: To detect an active or recent mycoplasma (type of bacteria) infection
Ureaplasma Culture.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare practitioner suspects that your respiratory or other symptoms are caused by a mycoplasma infection; when a genital infection may be caused by mycoplasma or ureaplasma (a particular type of mycoplasma)
Ureaplasma Culture.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a throat swab, sputum sample, body fluid or tissue sample; occasionally, genital or urethral swab

Uric Acid.Why Get Tested?: To detect high levels of uric acid in the blood, which could be a sign of the condition gout, or to monitor uric acid levels when undergoing chemotherapy or radiation treatment; to detect high levels of uric acid in the urine in order to diagnose the cause of kidney stones and to monitor those with gout who are at risk of developing such stones
Uric Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have joint pain or other symptoms that your healthcare practitioner suspects may be due to gout; when you have had or are going to have certain chemotherapy or radiation therapies for cancer; when you have recurrent kidney stones; when you have gout or are otherwise at risk for kidney stone formation
Uric Acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in the arm or a 24-hour urine sample
Uric Acid.Test Preparation Needed?: None may be needed; however, some institutions recommend fasting. Follow any instructions you are given.

Urinalysis.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, help diagnose and/or monitor several diseases and conditions, such as kidney disorders or urinary tract infections (UTIs)
Urinalysis.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms, such as abdominal pain, back pain, frequent or painful urination; sometimes as part of a health examination, pregnancy check-up, hospital admission, or pre-surgical work-up
Urinalysis.Sample Required?: One to two ounces of urine—a sufficient sample is required for accurate results; sometimes you may be directed to collect a sample using a "clean-catch" technique: women should spread the labia of the vagina and clean from front to back; men should wipe the tip of the penis. Start to urinate, let some urine fall into the toilet, then collect one to two ounces of urine in the container provided, then void the rest into the toilet.

Urinary Cortisol.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose Cushing syndrome or primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease); to detect conditions affecting the pituitary or adrenal glands
Urinary Cortisol.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects excess or deficient cortisol production
Urinary Cortisol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a saliva sample may be used
Urinary Cortisol.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be required to rest before sample collection. For a salivary cortisol test, you may be instructed to refrain from eating, drinking, or brushing your teeth for a period of time (may be some time between 15 to 30 minutes) prior to the test. Follow any instructions you are given.

Urinary Stone Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the composition of a kidney stone, to help determine the cause of its formation and to guide treatment
Urinary Stone Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When a stone has passed through or been removed from your urinary tract
Urinary Stone Analysis.Sample Required?: A stone or stones filtered from your urine or surgically removed from your urinary tract by a health practitioner

Urine Albumin and Albumin/Creatinine Rat.Why Get Tested?: To detect early kidney disease in those with diabetes or other risk factors, such as high blood pressure (hypertension)
Urine Albumin and Albumin/Creatinine Rat.When To Get Tested?: Annually after a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes; annually 5 years after diagnosis of type 1 diabetes
Urine Albumin and Albumin/Creatinine Rat.Sample Required?: A random, timed, overnight, or 24-hour urine sample

Urine Albumin; Albumin-to-Creatinine Rat.Why Get Tested?: To detect early kidney disease in those with diabetes or other risk factors, such as high blood pressure (hypertension)
Urine Albumin; Albumin-to-Creatinine Rat.When To Get Tested?: Annually after a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes; annually 5 years after diagnosis of type 1 diabetes
Urine Albumin; Albumin-to-Creatinine Rat.Sample Required?: A random, timed, overnight, or 24-hour urine sample

Urine Analysis.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, help diagnose and/or monitor several diseases and conditions, such as kidney disorders or urinary tract infections (UTIs)
Urine Analysis.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms, such as abdominal pain, back pain, frequent or painful urination; sometimes as part of a health examination, pregnancy check-up, hospital admission, or pre-surgical work-up
Urine Analysis.Sample Required?: One to two ounces of urine—a sufficient sample is required for accurate results; sometimes you may be directed to collect a sample using a "clean-catch" technique: women should spread the labia of the vagina and clean from front to back; men should wipe the tip of the penis. Start to urinate, let some urine fall into the toilet, then collect one to two ounces of urine in the container provided, then void the rest into the toilet.

Urine C and S.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a urinary tract infection (UTI)
Urine C and S.When To Get Tested?: When you experience symptoms of a UTI, such as frequent and painful urination, and/or when a urinalysis indicates you may have a UTI
Urine C and S.Sample Required?: A mid-stream clean catch urine sample (women should spread the labia of the vagina and clean from front to back; men should wipe the tip of the penis; start to urinate, let some urine fall into the toilet, then collect one to two ounces of urine in the container provided, then void the rest into the toilet); sometimes a urine sample obtained via catheter
Urine C and S.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally none, but you may be instructed not to urinate for at least one hour before the test and/or to drink a glass of water 15-20 minutes before sample collection.

Urine Calcium.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's risk of recurring kidney stone formation; to help determine the underlying reason for developing a kidney stone; to determine if there is a family history of kidney stone disease; to help guide and monitor treatment
Urine Calcium.When To Get Tested?: When you have had kidney stones and a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your risk of developing additional kidney stones; when you have risk factors such as a family history of kidney stones, a single functional kidney, or a transplanted kidney
Urine Calcium.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine collection is required for this test. Frequently, two different 24-hour urine samples are collected and tested to determine whether elevated or decreased levels of a substance eliminated in the urine are temporary or persistent. Collection containers with preservative will be provided by your healthcare practitioner or the lab performing the testing.

Urine Citric Acid (Citrate).Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's risk of recurring kidney stone formation; to help determine the underlying reason for developing a kidney stone; to determine if there is a family history of kidney stone disease; to help guide and monitor treatment
Urine Citric Acid (Citrate).When To Get Tested?: When you have had kidney stones and a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your risk of developing additional kidney stones; when you have risk factors such as a family history of kidney stones, a single functional kidney, or a transplanted kidney
Urine Citric Acid (Citrate).Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine collection is required for this test. Frequently, two different 24-hour urine samples are collected and tested to determine whether elevated or decreased levels of a substance eliminated in the urine are temporary or persistent. Collection containers with preservative will be provided by your healthcare practitioner or the lab performing the testing.

Urine Copper.Why Get Tested?: To measure the amount of copper in the blood, urine, or liver tissue; to help diagnose and monitor Wilson disease; sometimes to identify copper deficiency or excess
Urine Copper.When To Get Tested?: When you have jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, behavioral changes, tremors, or other symptoms that a health practitioner thinks may be due to Wilson disease or, rarely, to copper deficiency or excess; at intervals when you are being treated for a copper-related condition
Urine Copper.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a liver biopsy sample

Urine Creatinine.Why Get Tested?: To evaluate the health of your kidneys; to help diagnose kidney disease; to monitor treatment for kidney disease
Urine Creatinine.When To Get Tested?: Routinely as part of a comprehensive or basic metabolic panel; when your have signs and symptoms that may be due to kidney disease or damage or when you have a condition that may affect your kidneys and/or be worsened by kidney dysfunction; at intervals to monitor treatment for kidney disease or kidney function while on certain medications
Urine Creatinine.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a 24-hour urine sample
Urine Creatinine.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast overnight or refrain from eating cooked meat; some studies have shown that eating cooked meat prior to testing can temporarily increase the level of creatinine.

Urine Culture.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a urinary tract infection (UTI)
Urine Culture.When To Get Tested?: When you experience symptoms of a UTI, such as frequent and painful urination, and/or when a urinalysis indicates you may have a UTI
Urine Culture.Sample Required?: A mid-stream clean catch urine sample (women should spread the labia of the vagina and clean from front to back; men should wipe the tip of the penis; start to urinate, let some urine fall into the toilet, then collect one to two ounces of urine in the container provided, then void the rest into the toilet); sometimes a urine sample obtained via catheter
Urine Culture.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally none, but you may be instructed not to urinate for at least one hour before the test and/or to drink a glass of water 15-20 minutes before sample collection.

Urine Culture and Sensitivity.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a urinary tract infection (UTI)
Urine Culture and Sensitivity.When To Get Tested?: When you experience symptoms of a UTI, such as frequent and painful urination, and/or when a urinalysis indicates you may have a UTI
Urine Culture and Sensitivity.Sample Required?: A mid-stream clean catch urine sample (women should spread the labia of the vagina and clean from front to back; men should wipe the tip of the penis; start to urinate, let some urine fall into the toilet, then collect one to two ounces of urine in the container provided, then void the rest into the toilet); sometimes a urine sample obtained via catheter
Urine Culture and Sensitivity.Test Preparation Needed?: Generally none, but you may be instructed not to urinate for at least one hour before the test and/or to drink a glass of water 15-20 minutes before sample collection.

Urine Drug Testing.Why Get Tested?: To screen for drug abuse, to monitor someone with a substance abuse problem, to monitor compliance with prescribed medications, or to detect and evaluate drug intoxication or overdose
Urine Drug Testing.When To Get Tested?: Sometimes required prior to the start of a new job or insurance policy; randomly for workplace drug testing or athletic drug testing programs; as mandated when court-ordered; as indicated when ordered by a health practitioner to monitor a known or suspected substance abuse patient; sometimes when you are pregnant, will be receiving an organ transplant, when you are prescribed pain medication, or when you have symptoms suggesting drug intoxication or overdose
Urine Drug Testing.Sample Required?: A random urine sample; sometimes a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; hair, saliva, or sweat
Urine Drug Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: Some prescription and over-the-counter drugs may give a positive screening result; prior to testing, indicate any medications that you have taken and/or for which you have prescriptions.

Urine Glucose.Why Get Tested?: To determine if your blood glucose level is within a healthy range; to screen for and diagnose diabetes and prediabetes and to monitor for high blood glucose (hyperglycemia) or low blood glucose (hypoglycemia); to check for glucose in your urine
Urine Glucose.When To Get Tested?:
Blood glucose: when you are older than 45 years or have risk factors for diabetes; when you have symptoms suggesting high or low blood glucose; during pregnancy; when you are diabetic, self-checks up to several times a day to monitor blood glucose levels
Urine glucose: usually as part of a urinalysis
Urine Glucose.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a drop of blood from a skin prick; sometimes a random urine sample is used. Some diabetics may use a continuous glucose monitor, which uses a small sensor wire inserted beneath the skin of the abdomen to measure blood glucose at frequent intervals and provides a result.
Urine Glucose.Test Preparation Needed?: In general, it is recommended that you fast (nothing to eat or drink except water) for at least 8 hours before having a blood glucose test. For people with diabetes, glucose levels are often checked both while fasting and after meals to provide the best control of diabetes. For random, timed, and post-meal glucose tests, follow your health practitioner's instructions.

Urine Homocysteine.Why Get Tested?: To help determine if you are deficient in vitamins B6, B9 (folate) or B12; to determine if you are at increased risk of heart attack or stroke; to monitor those who have heart disease; sometimes to help diagnose a rare inherited disorder called homocystinuria in newborns
Urine Homocysteine.When To Get Tested?: When your healthcare provider suspects that you have a vitamin B6, B12 or folate deficiency; when you have had a heart attack or stroke and do not have traditional risk factors, such as unhealthy lipid levels
Urine Homocysteine.Sample Required?: A blood sample taken by needle from a vein
Urine Homocysteine.Test Preparation Needed?: You may be instructed to fast for 10 to 12 hours prior to this test; only water is permitted.

Urine Metanephrines.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Urine Metanephrines.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of increased catecholamines release, such as sudden bursts (paroxysms) of high blood pressure (hypertension), severe headaches, rapid heart rate (palpitations), sweating, tremors and pallor; when hypertension does not respond to standard treatments; when the signs and symptoms occur in a relatively young person (younger than age 40) and when there is a family history of hypertension; when your healthcare provider suspects you may have a tumor that is releasing or may release excess catecholamines
Urine Metanephrines.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection.

Urine Metanephrines, Total and Fractiona.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or rule out a rare adrenal tumor called a pheochromocytoma or a rare extra-adrenal tumor called a paraganglioma; these tumors produce excess hormones called catecholamines, which are broken down to metanephrines.
Urine Metanephrines, Total and Fractiona.When To Get Tested?: When you have signs and symptoms of increased catecholamines release, such as sudden bursts (paroxysms) of high blood pressure (hypertension), severe headaches, rapid heart rate (palpitations), sweating, tremors and pallor; when hypertension does not respond to standard treatments; when the signs and symptoms occur in a relatively young person (younger than age 40) and when there is a family history of hypertension; when your healthcare provider suspects you may have a tumor that is releasing or may release excess catecholamines
Urine Metanephrines, Total and Fractiona.Test Preparation Needed?: These tests are affected by certain drugs, foods, and stresses. Inform your healthcare provider of any medications you are taking and follow any preparation instructions you are given before sample collection.

Urine Myoglobin.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether muscle has been injured; to help diagnose conditions associated with muscle damage; to detect high levels in the urine that can cause kidney damage after extensive muscle damage; sometimes to help determine if you have had a heart attack, although for heart attack detection, this test has been largely replaced by troponin.
Urine Myoglobin.When To Get Tested?: When you have muscle weakness, muscle aches, and/or dark urine and your healthcare provider suspects muscle damage; when there has been severe traumatic injury to skeletal muscle
Urine Myoglobin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a random urine sample

Urine Oxalate.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's risk of recurring kidney stone formation; to help determine the underlying reason for developing a kidney stone; to determine if there is a family history of kidney stone disease; to help guide and monitor treatment
Urine Oxalate.When To Get Tested?: When you have had kidney stones and a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your risk of developing additional kidney stones; when you have risk factors such as a family history of kidney stones, a single functional kidney, or a transplanted kidney
Urine Oxalate.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine collection is required for this test. Frequently, two different 24-hour urine samples are collected and tested to determine whether elevated or decreased levels of a substance eliminated in the urine are temporary or persistent. Collection containers with preservative will be provided by your healthcare practitioner or the lab performing the testing.

Urine Protein.Why Get Tested?: To screen for excess protein in the urine, to help evaluate and monitor kidney function, and to detect kidney damage
Urine Protein.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine physical, as a follow-up to a previous positive urine protein test, or when you have a disorder or disease that affects the kidney
Urine Protein.Sample Required?: A single urine sample collected at any time (random) or 24-hour urine sample; occasionally, a split 24-hour sample, with the night collection (11pm to 7am) separated from the day collection (7am to 11pm). Often, a blood sample may also be taken to measure your creatinine and serum protein levels, especially when a 24-hour urine has been ordered.

Urine Protein and Urine Protein to Creat.Why Get Tested?: To screen for excess protein in the urine, to help evaluate and monitor kidney function, and to detect kidney damage
Urine Protein and Urine Protein to Creat.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine physical, as a follow-up to a previous positive urine protein test, or when you have a disorder or disease that affects the kidney
Urine Protein and Urine Protein to Creat.Sample Required?: A single urine sample collected at any time (random) or 24-hour urine sample; occasionally, a split 24-hour sample, with the night collection (11pm to 7am) separated from the day collection (7am to 11pm). Often, a blood sample may also be taken to measure your creatinine and serum protein levels, especially when a 24-hour urine has been ordered.

Urine Protein Electrophoresis.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or monitor conditions that result in abnormal protein production or loss
Urine Protein Electrophoresis.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal result on a total protein or albumin blood test or have symptoms of diseases that are associated with abnormal protein production, such as multiple myeloma or multiple sclerosis
Urine Protein Electrophoresis.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a random or 24-hour urine sample; sometimes a sample of cerebrospinal fluid

Urine Protein to Creatinine Ratio.Why Get Tested?: To screen for excess protein in the urine, to help evaluate and monitor kidney function, and to detect kidney damage
Urine Protein to Creatinine Ratio.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine physical, as a follow-up to a previous positive urine protein test, or when you have a disorder or disease that affects the kidney
Urine Protein to Creatinine Ratio.Sample Required?: A single urine sample collected at any time (random) or 24-hour urine sample; occasionally, a split 24-hour sample, with the night collection (11pm to 7am) separated from the day collection (7am to 11pm). Often, a blood sample may also be taken to measure your creatinine and serum protein levels, especially when a 24-hour urine has been ordered.

Urine Supersaturation Profile.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's risk of recurring kidney stone formation; to help determine the underlying reason for developing a kidney stone; to determine if there is a family history of kidney stone disease; to help guide and monitor treatment
Urine Supersaturation Profile.When To Get Tested?: When you have had kidney stones and a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your risk of developing additional kidney stones; when you have risk factors such as a family history of kidney stones, a single functional kidney, or a transplanted kidney
Urine Supersaturation Profile.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine collection is required for this test. Frequently, two different 24-hour urine samples are collected and tested to determine whether elevated or decreased levels of a substance eliminated in the urine are temporary or persistent. Collection containers with preservative will be provided by your healthcare practitioner or the lab performing the testing.

Urine Test.Why Get Tested?: To screen for, help diagnose and/or monitor several diseases and conditions, such as kidney disorders or urinary tract infections (UTIs)
Urine Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms, such as abdominal pain, back pain, frequent or painful urination; sometimes as part of a health examination, pregnancy check-up, hospital admission, or pre-surgical work-up
Urine Test.Sample Required?: One to two ounces of urine—a sufficient sample is required for accurate results; sometimes you may be directed to collect a sample using a "clean-catch" technique: women should spread the labia of the vagina and clean from front to back; men should wipe the tip of the penis. Start to urinate, let some urine fall into the toilet, then collect one to two ounces of urine in the container provided, then void the rest into the toilet.

Urine Total Protein.Why Get Tested?: To screen for excess protein in the urine, to help evaluate and monitor kidney function, and to detect kidney damage
Urine Total Protein.When To Get Tested?: As part of a routine physical, as a follow-up to a previous positive urine protein test, or when you have a disorder or disease that affects the kidney
Urine Total Protein.Sample Required?: A single urine sample collected at any time (random) or 24-hour urine sample; occasionally, a split 24-hour sample, with the night collection (11pm to 7am) separated from the day collection (7am to 11pm). Often, a blood sample may also be taken to measure your creatinine and serum protein levels, especially when a 24-hour urine has been ordered.

Urine Uric Acid.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate a person's risk of recurring kidney stone formation; to help determine the underlying reason for developing a kidney stone; to determine if there is a family history of kidney stone disease; to help guide and monitor treatment
Urine Uric Acid.When To Get Tested?: When you have had kidney stones and a healthcare practitioner wants to evaluate your risk of developing additional kidney stones; when you have risk factors such as a family history of kidney stones, a single functional kidney, or a transplanted kidney
Urine Uric Acid.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine collection is required for this test. Frequently, two different 24-hour urine samples are collected and tested to determine whether elevated or decreased levels of a substance eliminated in the urine are temporary or persistent. Collection containers with preservative will be provided by your healthcare practitioner or the lab performing the testing.

Uroporphyrin.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose and sometimes to monitor porphyrias
Uroporphyrin.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that suggest a neurologic porphyria (e.g., abdominal pain, tingling or numbness in the hands or feet, muscular weakness and/or alterations in thought or mood) or a cutaneous porphyria (e.g., redness, blistering, or scarring of sun-exposed skin)
Uroporphyrin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm, a random or 24-hour urine sample, and/or a stool sample
Uroporphyrin.Test Preparation Needed?: If a neurologic porphyria is suspected, the sample should be collected during an acute attack.

Valproate.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of valproic acid in your blood; the purpose is to maintain a therapeutic level and monitor toxicity.
Valproate.When To Get Tested?: At regular intervals to monitor the drug's level or when a person shows signs of toxicity
Valproate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
Valproate.Test Preparation Needed?: No special test preparation is needed, but talk to your healthcare practitioner about the timing of sample collection. Since dosage timing varies and some formulations are time-released, collection specifics may vary. Often, the recommended time for sample collection is just before the next dose is received, when the drug level is at its lowest (trough level). This ensures that the minimum amount of drug to be effective is maintained in the blood.

Valproic Acid.Why Get Tested?: To determine the concentration of valproic acid in your blood; the purpose is to maintain a therapeutic level and monitor toxicity.
Valproic Acid.When To Get Tested?: At regular intervals to monitor the drug's level or when a person shows signs of toxicity
Valproic Acid.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein
Valproic Acid.Test Preparation Needed?: No special test preparation is needed, but talk to your healthcare practitioner about the timing of sample collection. Since dosage timing varies and some formulations are time-released, collection specifics may vary. Often, the recommended time for sample collection is just before the next dose is received, when the drug level is at its lowest (trough level). This ensures that the minimum amount of drug to be effective is maintained in the blood.

Vancomycin.Why Get Tested?: To measure and monitor the level of vancomycin in your blood
Vancomycin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Vancomycin.Test Preparation Needed?: None, but timing of the sample for testing is important; samples are typically collected just before the next dose (trough level). Follow any instructions provided.

Vanillylmandelic Acid (VMA).Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or rule out a neuroblastoma or other neuroendocrine tumor; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Vanillylmandelic Acid (VMA).When To Get Tested?: When your child has a lump in the abdomen (abdominal mass), bruising around the eyes, trouble walking, or bone pain; when you have symptoms of increased catecholamine release, such as persistent or periodic high blood pressure, severe headaches, rapid heart rate, and sweating; when you have been treated for a neuroendocrine tumor, such as neuroblastoma
Vanillylmandelic Acid (VMA).Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample is preferred; sometimes a random urine sample is acceptable.
Vanillylmandelic Acid (VMA).Test Preparation Needed?: This test is affected by caffeine, certain foods, certain drugs, and stresses. Inform your healthcare practitioner of any medications you are taking and follow any instructions you are given for things to avoid before sample collection.

Vanillylmandelic Acid, urine.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or rule out a neuroblastoma or other neuroendocrine tumor; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
Vanillylmandelic Acid, urine.When To Get Tested?: When your child has a lump in the abdomen (abdominal mass), bruising around the eyes, trouble walking, or bone pain; when you have symptoms of increased catecholamine release, such as persistent or periodic high blood pressure, severe headaches, rapid heart rate, and sweating; when you have been treated for a neuroendocrine tumor, such as neuroblastoma
Vanillylmandelic Acid, urine.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample is preferred; sometimes a random urine sample is acceptable.
Vanillylmandelic Acid, urine.Test Preparation Needed?: This test is affected by caffeine, certain foods, certain drugs, and stresses. Inform your healthcare practitioner of any medications you are taking and follow any instructions you are given for things to avoid before sample collection.

Varicella Zoster Virus.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose, as necessary, a current, recent, or past case of chickenpox or shingles; to determine whether you have developed immunity to the varicella zoster virus (VZV) or whether there is the potential for reactivating a VZV infection prior to receiving immunosuppressive drugs
Varicella Zoster Virus.When To Get Tested?: When you have atypical and/or severe symptoms and your healthcare practitioner wants to distinguish between a VZV infection and another cause; when a healthcare practitioner wants to check whether or not you are immune to VZV; sometimes prior to an organ transplant or when a child, pregnant woman, or a person with a weakened immune system has been exposed to someone with chickenpox
Varicella Zoster Virus.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for VZV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, a sample of fluid from a blister (vesicle), blood, cerebrospinal fluid, or other body fluid or tissue

Varicella Zoster Virus by Culture, PCR,.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose, as necessary, a current, recent, or past case of chickenpox or shingles; to determine whether you have developed immunity to the varicella zoster virus (VZV) or whether there is the potential for reactivating a VZV infection prior to receiving immunosuppressive drugs
Varicella Zoster Virus by Culture, PCR,.When To Get Tested?: When you have atypical and/or severe symptoms and your healthcare practitioner wants to distinguish between a VZV infection and another cause; when a healthcare practitioner wants to check whether or not you are immune to VZV; sometimes prior to an organ transplant or when a child, pregnant woman, or a person with a weakened immune system has been exposed to someone with chickenpox
Varicella Zoster Virus by Culture, PCR,.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for VZV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, a sample of fluid from a blister (vesicle), blood, cerebrospinal fluid, or other body fluid or tissue

Vasopressin.Why Get Tested?: To help detect, diagnose, and determine the cause of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) deficiency or excess; to investigate low blood sodium levels (hyponatremia); to distinguish between the two types of diabetes insipidus
Vasopressin.When To Get Tested?: When you have low blood sodium or have persistent thirst, frequent urination, and dehydration
Vasopressin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Vasopressin.Test Preparation Needed?: None needed for an ADH test; however, talk to your health care provider about required preparation when the ADH test is performed as part of a water deprivation ADH stimulation test or a water loading ADH suppression test.

VDRL.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
VDRL.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
VDRL.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Venereal Disease Research Laboratory.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose an infection with the bacterium Treponema pallidum, which causes syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease (STD)
Venereal Disease Research Laboratory.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of a syphilis infection; when you are at risk of being exposed to syphilis, such as when you have another STD or HIV infection, are a man who has sex with men, have a sexual partner diagnosed with syphilis, or have engaged in high-risk sexual activity; when you are pregnant
Venereal Disease Research Laboratory.Sample Required?: Most often, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes, a scraping from a chancre in the affected area; less commonly, cerebrospinal fluid taken via a spinal tap, depending on your clinical presentation

Very Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To help assess the risk of developing heart disease
Very Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?: As part of a lipid profile during a regular medical exam (at least once every 4-6 years for adults; for children, at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between the ages of 17 and 21); more frequently if you have risk factors for heart disease
Very Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a fingerstick
Very Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: Current standards recommend that testing be done when you are fasting. For 9 to 12 hours before the test, only water is permitted. In addition, alcohol should not be consumed for 24 hours just before the test. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

Viral Hepatitis A Antibody.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose the cause of acute hepatitis; as part of a viral hepatitis panel to identify the type of hepatitis virus causing an infection; sometimes to evaluate the need for the hepatitis A vaccine
Viral Hepatitis A Antibody.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of an acute hepatitis infection, such as jaundice, or when you may have been exposed to hepatitis A virus (HAV)
Viral Hepatitis A Antibody.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Viral Hepatitis C Antibody Screen; Viral.Why Get Tested?:
To screen for and diagnose a hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection and to monitor treatment of the infection
To learn more about hepatitis C, read the article on Viral Hepatitis.
Viral Hepatitis C Antibody Screen; Viral.When To Get Tested?:
For screening: when you have risk factors for HCV infection or were born between 1945 and 1965, per 2012 CDC recommendations
For diagnosis: when you may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus, such as through contact with infected blood, or have symptoms associated with liver disease
Viral Hepatitis C Antibody Screen; Viral.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Viral Hepatitis Panel.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose an infection with a hepatitis virus
Viral Hepatitis Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of acute hepatitis and a viral infection is suspected to be the cause; when you have been exposed to one or more of the three most common hepatitis viruses: hepatitis A, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C
Viral Hepatitis Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Vitamin A.Why Get Tested?: To detect vitamin A deficiency or toxicity
Vitamin A.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting a vitamin A deficiency or excess, or are at risk for a deficiency
Vitamin A.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Vitamin A.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is required and no alcohol should be consumed for 24 hours before sample collection.

Vitamin B complex.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and detect moderate to severe vitamin B deficiencies
Vitamin B complex.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that may be due to a B vitamin deficiency, are at risk for a deficiency, or have a condition associated with malabsorption
Vitamin B complex.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a random or 24-hour urine sample may also be collected.
Vitamin B complex.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is usually required for blood testing.

Vitamin B Testing.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and detect moderate to severe vitamin B deficiencies
Vitamin B Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms that may be due to a B vitamin deficiency, are at risk for a deficiency, or have a condition associated with malabsorption
Vitamin B Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; a random or 24-hour urine sample may also be collected.
Vitamin B Testing.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting is usually required for blood testing.

Vitamin B12 and Folate.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose one cause of anemia or neuropathy; to evaluate nutritional status in some people; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
Vitamin B12 and Folate.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal complete blood count (CBC) with a blood smear showing large red blood cells (macrocytosis) or abnormal (hypersegmented) neutrophils; when you have symptoms of anemia (weakness, tiredness, pale skin) and/or of neuropathy (tingling or itching sensations, eye twitching, memory loss, altered mental status); when you are being treated for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
Vitamin B12 and Folate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Vitamin B12 and Folate.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting for 6-8 hours before sample collection may be required. Certain medicines may affect the test results; your healthcare provider will advise you on which ones to stop taking.

Vitamin B12; Folate.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose one cause of anemia or neuropathy; to evaluate nutritional status in some people; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
Vitamin B12; Folate.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal complete blood count (CBC) with a blood smear showing large red blood cells (macrocytosis) or abnormal (hypersegmented) neutrophils; when you have symptoms of anemia (weakness, tiredness, pale skin) and/or of neuropathy (tingling or itching sensations, eye twitching, memory loss, altered mental status); when you are being treated for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
Vitamin B12; Folate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm
Vitamin B12; Folate.Test Preparation Needed?: Fasting for 6-8 hours before sample collection may be required. Certain medicines may affect the test results; your healthcare provider will advise you on which ones to stop taking.

Vitamin D Tests.Why Get Tested?: To determine if you have a vitamin D deficiency; if you are receiving vitamin D supplementation, to determine if it is adequate
Vitamin D Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have an abnormal calcium, phosphorus, and/or parathyroid hormone level; when you have evidence of bone disease or bone weakness; when you are at high risk of deficiency or a healthcare practitioner suspects that you might have a vitamin D deficiency; prior to starting drug treatment for osteoporosis; periodically to monitor treatment of vitamin D deficiency
Vitamin D Tests.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

VLDL.Why Get Tested?: To help assess the risk of developing heart disease
VLDL.When To Get Tested?: As part of a lipid profile during a regular medical exam (at least once every 4-6 years for adults; for children, at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between the ages of 17 and 21); more frequently if you have risk factors for heart disease
VLDL.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a fingerstick
VLDL.Test Preparation Needed?: Current standards recommend that testing be done when you are fasting. For 9 to 12 hours before the test, only water is permitted. In addition, alcohol should not be consumed for 24 hours just before the test. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

VLDL Cholesterol.Why Get Tested?: To help assess the risk of developing heart disease
VLDL Cholesterol.When To Get Tested?: As part of a lipid profile during a regular medical exam (at least once every 4-6 years for adults; for children, at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between the ages of 17 and 21); more frequently if you have risk factors for heart disease
VLDL Cholesterol.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a fingerstick
VLDL Cholesterol.Test Preparation Needed?: Current standards recommend that testing be done when you are fasting. For 9 to 12 hours before the test, only water is permitted. In addition, alcohol should not be consumed for 24 hours just before the test. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

VLDL-C.Why Get Tested?: To help assess the risk of developing heart disease
VLDL-C.When To Get Tested?: As part of a lipid profile during a regular medical exam (at least once every 4-6 years for adults; for children, at least once between the ages of 9 and 11 and again between the ages of 17 and 21); more frequently if you have risk factors for heart disease
VLDL-C.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or a fingerstick
VLDL-C.Test Preparation Needed?: Current standards recommend that testing be done when you are fasting. For 9 to 12 hours before the test, only water is permitted. In addition, alcohol should not be consumed for 24 hours just before the test. Your healthcare practitioner may decide that you may be tested without fasting. Follow any instructions you are given and tell the person drawing your blood whether or not you have fasted.

VMAU.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose or rule out a neuroblastoma or other neuroendocrine tumor; to monitor the effectiveness of treatment
VMAU.When To Get Tested?: When your child has a lump in the abdomen (abdominal mass), bruising around the eyes, trouble walking, or bone pain; when you have symptoms of increased catecholamine release, such as persistent or periodic high blood pressure, severe headaches, rapid heart rate, and sweating; when you have been treated for a neuroendocrine tumor, such as neuroblastoma
VMAU.Sample Required?: A 24-hour urine sample is preferred; sometimes a random urine sample is acceptable.
VMAU.Test Preparation Needed?: This test is affected by caffeine, certain foods, certain drugs, and stresses. Inform your healthcare practitioner of any medications you are taking and follow any instructions you are given for things to avoid before sample collection.

von Willebrand Factor.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of unexplained excessive or repeated episodes of bleeding, to diagnose von Willebrand disease (VWD), and to distinguish between different types of VWD
von Willebrand Factor.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal or family history of heavy, prolonged, and/or spontaneous bleeding; when your healthcare provider suspects that you may have a bleeding disorder
von Willebrand Factor.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

von Willebrand Factor Antigen and Activi.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of unexplained excessive or repeated episodes of bleeding, to diagnose von Willebrand disease (VWD), and to distinguish between different types of VWD
von Willebrand Factor Antigen and Activi.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal or family history of heavy, prolonged, and/or spontaneous bleeding; when your healthcare provider suspects that you may have a bleeding disorder
von Willebrand Factor Antigen and Activi.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

von Willebrand Panel.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of unexplained excessive or repeated episodes of bleeding, to diagnose von Willebrand disease (VWD), and to distinguish between different types of VWD
von Willebrand Panel.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal or family history of heavy, prolonged, and/or spontaneous bleeding; when your healthcare provider suspects that you may have a bleeding disorder
von Willebrand Panel.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

VWF:Ag.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of unexplained excessive or repeated episodes of bleeding, to diagnose von Willebrand disease (VWD), and to distinguish between different types of VWD
VWF:Ag.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal or family history of heavy, prolonged, and/or spontaneous bleeding; when your healthcare provider suspects that you may have a bleeding disorder
VWF:Ag.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

VWF:RCo.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of unexplained excessive or repeated episodes of bleeding, to diagnose von Willebrand disease (VWD), and to distinguish between different types of VWD
VWF:RCo.When To Get Tested?: When you have a personal or family history of heavy, prolonged, and/or spontaneous bleeding; when your healthcare provider suspects that you may have a bleeding disorder
VWF:RCo.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

VZV.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose, as necessary, a current, recent, or past case of chickenpox or shingles; to determine whether you have developed immunity to the varicella zoster virus (VZV) or whether there is the potential for reactivating a VZV infection prior to receiving immunosuppressive drugs
VZV.When To Get Tested?: When you have atypical and/or severe symptoms and your healthcare practitioner wants to distinguish between a VZV infection and another cause; when a healthcare practitioner wants to check whether or not you are immune to VZV; sometimes prior to an organ transplant or when a child, pregnant woman, or a person with a weakened immune system has been exposed to someone with chickenpox
VZV.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for VZV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, a sample of fluid from a blister (vesicle), blood, cerebrospinal fluid, or other body fluid or tissue

VZV Antibodies IgG and IgM.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose, as necessary, a current, recent, or past case of chickenpox or shingles; to determine whether you have developed immunity to the varicella zoster virus (VZV) or whether there is the potential for reactivating a VZV infection prior to receiving immunosuppressive drugs
VZV Antibodies IgG and IgM.When To Get Tested?: When you have atypical and/or severe symptoms and your healthcare practitioner wants to distinguish between a VZV infection and another cause; when a healthcare practitioner wants to check whether or not you are immune to VZV; sometimes prior to an organ transplant or when a child, pregnant woman, or a person with a weakened immune system has been exposed to someone with chickenpox
VZV Antibodies IgG and IgM.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm for VZV antibody testing; to detect the virus itself, a sample of fluid from a blister (vesicle), blood, cerebrospinal fluid, or other body fluid or tissue

Warfarin Sensitivity Genotyping.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have CYP2C9 and/or VKORC1 genetic variations and are likely to need lower, or less commonly, higher than average doses of the "blood-thinning" drug (anticoagulant) warfarin
Warfarin Sensitivity Genotyping.When To Get Tested?: A health practitioner might order this test prior to prescribing warfarin for you; a health practitioner may sometimes order it when you are being treated with warfarin and have had bleeding or clotting episodes or dosing difficulties
Warfarin Sensitivity Genotyping.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Warfarin Sensitivity Testing.Why Get Tested?: To determine whether you have CYP2C9 and/or VKORC1 genetic variations and are likely to need lower, or less commonly, higher than average doses of the "blood-thinning" drug (anticoagulant) warfarin
Warfarin Sensitivity Testing.When To Get Tested?: A health practitioner might order this test prior to prescribing warfarin for you; a health practitioner may sometimes order it when you are being treated with warfarin and have had bleeding or clotting episodes or dosing difficulties
Warfarin Sensitivity Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

WBC Count.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose a variety of conditions that can affect white blood cells (WBC) such as an infection, inflammation or a disease that affects the production or survival of WBCs; to monitor treatment of a blood disorder or to monitor therapy that is known to affect WBCs
WBC Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting WBCs such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you have a condition or are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs
WBC Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

WBC Count Differential.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of abnormal results on a white blood cell (WBC) count; to help diagnose and/or monitor an illness affecting your immune system, such as an infection or inflammatory condition, or cancers that affect your white blood cells, such as leukemia
WBC Count Differential.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when results of a CBC fall outside the reference range; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting white blood cells, such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs, such as chemotherapy
WBC Count Differential.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (infants)

West Nile Virus Testing.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose an infection caused by West Nile virus (WNV); to determine the cause of viral meningitis or encephalitis or febrile illness that occurs during the summer season; to detect the presence of WNV and to track its spread in the community and across the United States; to screen for WNV in donated units of blood, tissues, or organs
West Nile Virus Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting WNV such as headache, fever, stiff neck, and muscular weakness and have been exposed to mosquitos or when you have had a diagnosis of encephalitis and/or meningitis associated with the summer season
West Nile Virus Testing.Sample Required?: Cerebrospinal fluid collected from a spinal tap and/or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

West Nile Virus, IgM and IgG Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose an infection caused by West Nile virus (WNV); to determine the cause of viral meningitis or encephalitis or febrile illness that occurs during the summer season; to detect the presence of WNV and to track its spread in the community and across the United States; to screen for WNV in donated units of blood, tissues, or organs
West Nile Virus, IgM and IgG Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting WNV such as headache, fever, stiff neck, and muscular weakness and have been exposed to mosquitos or when you have had a diagnosis of encephalitis and/or meningitis associated with the summer season
West Nile Virus, IgM and IgG Antibodies.Sample Required?: Cerebrospinal fluid collected from a spinal tap and/or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Westergren Sedimentation Rate.Why Get Tested?: To detect the presence of inflammation caused by one or more conditions such as infections, tumors or autoimmune diseases; to help diagnose and monitor specific conditions such as temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis
