Westergren Sedimentation Rate.When To Get Tested?: When your health practitioner thinks that you might have a condition causing inflammation; when you have signs and symptoms associated with temporal arteritis, systemic vasculitis, polymyalgia rheumatica, or rheumatoid arthritis such as headaches, neck or shoulder pain, pelvic pain, anemia, poor appetite, unexplained weight loss, and joint stiffness
Westergren Sedimentation Rate.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Wet Prep.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose an infection with the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, which causes the sexually transmitted disease trichomoniasis
Wet Prep.When To Get Tested?: When a woman has symptoms of infection, such as a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, genital itching, and/or pain during urination, or when a man has genital itching or irritation, burning after urination or ejaculation, and/or a discharge from the penis
Wet Prep.Sample Required?: For men or women, the initial portion of urine stream (first-catch urine sample); or in women, a swab of fluid and cells from the vagina or cervix; or in men, a swab from the tube that carries urine from the bladder to outside the body (urethra).

White Blood Cell (WBC) Differential.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of abnormal results on a white blood cell (WBC) count; to help diagnose and/or monitor an illness affecting your immune system, such as an infection or inflammatory condition, or cancers that affect your white blood cells, such as leukemia
White Blood Cell (WBC) Differential.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when results of a CBC fall outside the reference range; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting white blood cells, such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs, such as chemotherapy
White Blood Cell (WBC) Differential.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (infants)

White Blood Cell Count.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose a variety of conditions that can affect white blood cells (WBC) such as an infection, inflammation or a disease that affects the production or survival of WBCs; to monitor treatment of a blood disorder or to monitor therapy that is known to affect WBCs
White Blood Cell Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting WBCs such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you have a condition or are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs
White Blood Cell Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

White Blood Cell Count (WBC).Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose a variety of conditions that can affect white blood cells (WBC) such as an infection, inflammation or a disease that affects the production or survival of WBCs; to monitor treatment of a blood disorder or to monitor therapy that is known to affect WBCs
White Blood Cell Count (WBC).When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting WBCs such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you have a condition or are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs
White Blood Cell Count (WBC).Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

White Blood Cell Differential.Why Get Tested?: To help determine the cause of abnormal results on a white blood cell (WBC) count; to help diagnose and/or monitor an illness affecting your immune system, such as an infection or inflammatory condition, or cancers that affect your white blood cells, such as leukemia
White Blood Cell Differential.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when results of a CBC fall outside the reference range; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting white blood cells, such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs, such as chemotherapy
White Blood Cell Differential.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (infants)

White Count.Why Get Tested?: To screen for or diagnose a variety of conditions that can affect white blood cells (WBC) such as an infection, inflammation or a disease that affects the production or survival of WBCs; to monitor treatment of a blood disorder or to monitor therapy that is known to affect WBCs
White Count.When To Get Tested?: As part of a complete blood count (CBC), when you have a routine health examination; when you have any number of signs and symptoms that may be related to a condition affecting WBCs such as infection, inflammation, or cancer; when you have a condition or are receiving treatment that is known to affect WBCs
White Count.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or by a fingerstick (children and adults) or heelstick (newborns)

Whooping Cough Tests.Why Get Tested?: To detect and diagnose a Bordetella pertussis infection, commonly known as whooping cough
Whooping Cough Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have persistent spasms or fits of coughing (paroxysms) that the healthcare practitioner suspects is due to pertussis (whooping cough); when you have symptoms of a cold and have been exposed to someone with pertussis
Whooping Cough Tests.Sample Required?: A nasopharyngeal (NP) swab or a nasal aspirate; occasionally, a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

WNV by NAAT.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose an infection caused by West Nile virus (WNV); to determine the cause of viral meningitis or encephalitis or febrile illness that occurs during the summer season; to detect the presence of WNV and to track its spread in the community and across the United States; to screen for WNV in donated units of blood, tissues, or organs
WNV by NAAT.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting WNV such as headache, fever, stiff neck, and muscular weakness and have been exposed to mosquitos or when you have had a diagnosis of encephalitis and/or meningitis associated with the summer season
WNV by NAAT.Sample Required?: Cerebrospinal fluid collected from a spinal tap and/or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

WNV Tests.Why Get Tested?: To help diagnose an infection caused by West Nile virus (WNV); to determine the cause of viral meningitis or encephalitis or febrile illness that occurs during the summer season; to detect the presence of WNV and to track its spread in the community and across the United States; to screen for WNV in donated units of blood, tissues, or organs
WNV Tests.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms suggesting WNV such as headache, fever, stiff neck, and muscular weakness and have been exposed to mosquitos or when you have had a diagnosis of encephalitis and/or meningitis associated with the summer season
WNV Tests.Sample Required?: Cerebrospinal fluid collected from a spinal tap and/or a blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Xa Inhibition.Why Get Tested?: To monitor standard, unfractionated heparin (UFH) therapy and sometimes to monitor low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) therapy
Xa Inhibition.When To Get Tested?: When you are being treated with UFH or LMWH and your healthcare provider wants to monitor the amount of heparin in your blood
Xa Inhibition.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

Xylose Absorption Test.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your ability to absorb carbohydrates and help determine the cause of malabsorption
Xylose Absorption Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
Xylose Absorption Test.Sample Required?: Timed blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm and timed urine collection
Xylose Absorption Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Fast for 8 hours and avoid foods high in pentose, such as jams, fruits, and pastries, for 24 hours prior to the test. Ask your healthcare provider if there are any changes to your medications that you should make.

Xylose Tolerance Test.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate your ability to absorb carbohydrates and help determine the cause of malabsorption
Xylose Tolerance Test.When To Get Tested?: When you have symptoms of malabsorption, such as persistent diarrhea and fatty stools
Xylose Tolerance Test.Sample Required?: Timed blood samples drawn from a vein in your arm and timed urine collection
Xylose Tolerance Test.Test Preparation Needed?: Fast for 8 hours and avoid foods high in pentose, such as jams, fruits, and pastries, for 24 hours prior to the test. Ask your healthcare provider if there are any changes to your medications that you should make.

Zika Antibody Test.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a Zika virus infection
Zika Antibody Test.When To Get Tested?: When you develop a fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis (pink eye) after traveling to an area where Zika virus is endemic or have symptoms and had sexual contact with someone who recently traveled from an area where Zika is present; if you are pregnant and have traveled to an area where Zika is active, regardless of symptoms; or when a baby is born with microcephaly (small head)
Zika Antibody Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container; less commonly cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or amniotic fluid

Zika PRNT.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a Zika virus infection
Zika PRNT.When To Get Tested?: When you develop a fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis (pink eye) after traveling to an area where Zika virus is endemic or have symptoms and had sexual contact with someone who recently traveled from an area where Zika is present; if you are pregnant and have traveled to an area where Zika is active, regardless of symptoms; or when a baby is born with microcephaly (small head)
Zika PRNT.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container; less commonly cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or amniotic fluid

Zika RT-PCR Test.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a Zika virus infection
Zika RT-PCR Test.When To Get Tested?: When you develop a fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis (pink eye) after traveling to an area where Zika virus is endemic or have symptoms and had sexual contact with someone who recently traveled from an area where Zika is present; if you are pregnant and have traveled to an area where Zika is active, regardless of symptoms; or when a baby is born with microcephaly (small head)
Zika RT-PCR Test.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container; less commonly cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or amniotic fluid

Zika Virus Testing.Why Get Tested?: To diagnose a Zika virus infection
Zika Virus Testing.When To Get Tested?: When you develop a fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis (pink eye) after traveling to an area where Zika virus is endemic or have symptoms and had sexual contact with someone who recently traveled from an area where Zika is present; if you are pregnant and have traveled to an area where Zika is active, regardless of symptoms; or when a baby is born with microcephaly (small head)
Zika Virus Testing.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm and/or a urine sample collected in a clean container; less commonly cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or amniotic fluid

Zinc Protoporphyrin.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and monitor chronic exposure to lead in adults; to detect iron deficiency in children
Zinc Protoporphyrin.When To Get Tested?: When you have been chronically exposed to lead, as part of a program to monitor lead exposure, and/or when your healthcare provider suspects lead poisoning; as part of a screening program for iron deficiency in children and adolescents
Zinc Protoporphyrin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

ZP.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and monitor chronic exposure to lead in adults; to detect iron deficiency in children
ZP.When To Get Tested?: When you have been chronically exposed to lead, as part of a program to monitor lead exposure, and/or when your healthcare provider suspects lead poisoning; as part of a screening program for iron deficiency in children and adolescents
ZP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

ZPP.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and monitor chronic exposure to lead in adults; to detect iron deficiency in children
ZPP.When To Get Tested?: When you have been chronically exposed to lead, as part of a program to monitor lead exposure, and/or when your healthcare provider suspects lead poisoning; as part of a screening program for iron deficiency in children and adolescents
ZPP.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

ZPP/Heme Ratio.Why Get Tested?: To screen for and monitor chronic exposure to lead in adults; to detect iron deficiency in children
ZPP/Heme Ratio.When To Get Tested?: When you have been chronically exposed to lead, as part of a program to monitor lead exposure, and/or when your healthcare provider suspects lead poisoning; as part of a screening program for iron deficiency in children and adolescents
ZPP/Heme Ratio.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm or from a fingerstick

β2-Glycoprotein 1 Antibodies.Why Get Tested?: To help investigate inappropriate blood clot formation (thrombotic episode or venous thromboembolism); to help determine the cause of recurrent miscarriage; as part of an evaluation for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
β2-Glycoprotein 1 Antibodies.When To Get Tested?: When you have had one or more unexplained blood clots in a vein or artery; when you have had recurrent miscarriages, especially in the second and third trimesters
β2-Glycoprotein 1 Antibodies.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm

β2-Microglobulin.Why Get Tested?: To help evaluate the severity and prognosis of certain cancers, including multiple myeloma and some lymphomas
β2-Microglobulin.When To Get Tested?: When you have been diagnosed with multiple myeloma or certain other cancers; sometimes to monitor disease activity and treatment
β2-Microglobulin.Sample Required?: A blood sample drawn from a vein in your arm; sometimes a 24-hour urine sample; rarely a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample
